Praefatio.	 Preface.
Postquam compleui uobis o Filii, librum hunc, qui est postremus scientiae in medicina cum complemento ipsius, et consecutus sum finem in eo, ex expositionibus eius, et ipsius declarationibus, uisum est mihi, ut compleam ipsum uobis cum hoc Tractatu qui est pars operationis, id est, chirurgiae cum manu.	 After I completed this book for you, my Sons, which is the last on the science of medicine with its complement, and having reached an end in it through expositions of its contents and its declarations, it seemed to me that I should complete it for you also with this Treatise, which is a part of operations, that is, surgery with hands.
Quoniam operatio cum manu prostrata est in regione nostra, et tempore nostro priuata omnino: donec fortasse periit scientia eius, et abscissum est uestigium eius: et non remanserunt ex ea, nisi descriptiones paruae in libris antiquorum, quas mutauerunt manus: et accidit eis error et haesitatio, donec clausae sunt intentiones eius, et elongata est uis ipsius: Visum est mihi, ut uiuificem eam cum ordinatione huius Tractatus in ea secundum uiam ex positionis, et declarationis, et abbreuiationis: et ut ueniam cum formis ferramentorum Cauterii, et reliquorum instrumentorum operis: cum fit ex declarationis additione, et ex properatione eius quod est necesse.	 Since the operation with hands is prostrate in our region and at our time, altogether lacking; until perhaps the knowledge of it has perished, and its trace has disappeared, except for some small descriptions in ancient books which have been altered by hand, and error and hesitation have occurred, until the intentions have been closed off, and the force of it has been weakened: It seemed to me that I should revive it with the arrangement of this Treatise in it according to the way from the positions, the declarations, and the abbreviations, and that I should come with forms of iron tools, and the rest of the instruments of work, through addition of declarations and proper use of what is necessary.
Caussa autem propter quam non inuenitur bonus artifex eius cum manu sua in hoc nostro tempore, est: quia ars medicinae est longa, et oportet auctorem eius exercitari ante illud in scientia anatomiae, quam narrauit Galenus, donec sciat iuuamenta membrorum, et ipsorum formas, et eorum coniunctionem, et separationem, et habeat cognitionem ossium, et neruorum, et lacertorum, et numerum ipsorum, et eorum egressionem, et uenarum pulsatilium, et quietarum, et locorum exitus earum.	 The reason why a skilled artist with his hand is not found in this present time, is because the art of medicine is long, and it is necessary for its author to exercise himself before that in the science of anatomy as Galen narrated, until he knows the remedies of members, their shapes, and their connections, and disconnections, and has knowledge of bones, nerves, muscles, their number, their exits, veins pulsating and quiet, and places of their exit.
Et propter illud dixit Hippocrates, quod nomen cum nomine est multum, et cum opere est paucum, et praecipue in arte manus.	 And for this reason, Hippocrates said that name with name is much, and with work it is little, and especially in the art of hands.
Nos uero iam diximus de illo in introitu huius libri.	 We have already said about him at the beginning of this book.
Quoniam qui non est sciens, quod diximus de anatomia, non euacuatur, quin iam cadat in errorem, quo interficiuntur homines: sicut ego uidi multos ex illis, qui formantur de hac scientia, et iactant se de ea absque scientia, et sine experimento.	Whoever is not knowing what we have said about anatomy, may already fall into error, in which people are killed: as I have seen many of those who are formed by this science and boast about it without knowledge, and without experiment.
Quod est, quia uidi medicum stolidum secuisse apostema scrophulosum in collo mulieris, et incidit quasdam arterias in collo: quare fluxit sanguis mulieris, donec cecidit mortua inter manus eius.	 I have seen a foolish physician cut an abscess on a woman's neck, and he accidentally cut some arteries in the neck: therefore, blood flowed from the woman until she fell dead at his hands.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui praesumpsit ut extraheret lapidem uiro, qui processerat in aetate, et lapis erat magnus.	 And I have seen another physician who presumed to draw out a stone from an old man, and the stone was large.
Peruenit ergo ad eum, et extraxit ipsum cum frusto uesicae.	 Therefore, he came to him, and drew it out with a piece of bladder.
Quare mortuus est uir in tertio die.	 Wherefore, the man died on the third day.
Et ego quidem iam uocatus fueram ad extrahendum ipsum: et uidi ex magnitudine lapidis, et dispositione infirmi, quod moriretur.	 And indeed I was already called to draw it out; and I saw from the size of the stone and the condition of the man that he would die.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui accipiebat stipem apud quendam Ducum terrae nostrae propter medicinam: et accidit eunucho nigro, qui erat apud ipsum, fractura in crure eius prope calcaneum: et properauit medicus cum ignorantia sua, et strinxit fracturam super uulnus cum puluinaribus, et astellis strictura forti, et non dimisit uulneri expirationem.	 And I have seen another physician who received a stick at the court of some Duke of our land for his medicine: and there was a black eunuch with him, who sustained a fracture in his leg near the heel; and the physician, with his ignorance, pressed the fracture over an open wound with awls, iron staples, and strong ties, and did not allow the wound to breathe.
Deinde absoluit eum secundum desyderia sua.	 Then he cured him according to his own devices.
Postea dimisit eum diebus aliquot, et praecepit ei, ne solueret ligamentum: et stetit sic donec apostematum est crus eius, et ipsius pes, et peruenit ad perditionem.	 Then he dismissed him for some days and commanded him not to loosen the bandage; and he stood thus until an abscess formed on his leg, and his foot, and it came to ruin.
Vocatus sum ergo ad eum: et properaui ad soluendum ligamentum: et consecuta est tranquillitas, et euasit a doloribus suis.	 I was therefore called to him; and I hastened to loosen the bandage; and peace came, and he was freed from his pains.
Verumtamen corruptio iam confirmata erat in membro: et non potui refraenare ipsam.	 However, corruption had already become fixed in the limb; and I could not restrain it.
Pon ergo cessauit corruptio perambulare in membro, donec periit.	 Translation: Place therefore let corruption walk through the member until it perishes.
Et uidi medicum alium, qui perforauit apostema cancerosum: et ulceratum est post dies, donec magnificata est malicia eius cum domino ipsius.	 And I saw another physician who perforated a cancerous apostema: and it was healed afterwards until the evilness of its magnitude with its lord was revealed.
Quod est, quia quando est cancer purus ex humore melancholico, tunc non oportet ut perueniatur ad eum cum ferro omnino, nisi sit in membro quod toleret, ut abscindatur totum eius.	 Because when it is a pure cancer from the humor of melancholy, then it is not necessary to approach it with iron entirely, unless it is in a member that can endure, so as to remove all of its extent.
Et propter illud o Filii, necesse est uobis, ut sciatis, quod operatio cum manu diuiditur in duas diuisiones: scilicet, operationem cui associatur salus: et operationem, cum qua est periculum in pluribus dispositionibus.	 And on account of this it is necessary for you to know that the operation is divided into two divisions: namely, an operation which brings salvation: and an operation with which there is danger in various dispositions.
Et ego iam excitaui in omni loco huius libri, in quo uenit operatio, in qua est terror et timor.	 And I have already awakened in all places of this book where the operation comes, where there is fear and dread.
Quare necesse est uobis, ut caueatis illud, et dimitatis ipsum: ut non inueniant stolidi uiam ad loquendum, et dehonestandum.	 Therefore it is necessary for you to beware of this and divide it so that fools do not find a way to speak and shameful things.
Accipite ergo mensuram cum sollicitudine et protectione, et infirmos uestros cum facilitate et firmitudine, et utimini uia meliore perducente gratia Dei ad salutem et successionem laudabilem: et dimittite aegritudines terribiles difficilis sanationis: et tollite animas uestras ab eo quod facit uos timere, ut ingrediatur super uos haesitatio in fide uestra et commodo uestro.	 Therefore take the measurement with care and protection, and treat your sick ones gently and firmly, and make use of a better way leading by the grace of God to salvation and praiseworthy succession: and leave behind terrible illnesses difficult to heal: and remove from you what makes you fear, so that hesitation enters upon you in faith and comfort.
Est enim magis remanens ad gloriam uestram, et sublimius in mundo isto, et postremo ad quantitates uestras.	 For it remains more to your glory, and higher in this world, and finally to your profits.
Galenus enim iam dixit in quibusdam suis admonitionibus.	 Galen has already said in some of his warnings.
Non medicetis aegritudinem malam: ne nominemini medici mali.	 Do not treat an evil sickness, lest you be called a bad physician.
Iam autem diuisi hunc Tractatum secundum tria Capitula. ¶	 Now however I have divided this Treatise into three Chapters. ¶
Capitulum primum.	 First Chapter.
De Cauterio cum igne, et Cauterio cum medicina acuta, capitulatum, et ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum, et ferramentis Cauterii: et omni quod necessarium est in operatione. ¶	 On the cautery with fire, and the cautery with sharp medicine, set out, arranged from head to foot, and forms of instruments, and ironwork of the cautery, and all that is necessary for the operation. ¶
Capitulum secundum.	 Chapter second.
De sectione et perforatione, phlebotomia et uentosis, et uulneribus: et extractione sagittarum, et similibus illius: et totum capitulatum, ordinatum formis instrumentorum. ¶	 On cutting and perforating, on venesection and cupping, and on wounds; and on the extraction of arrows, and similar matters; and an entire chapter arranged according to the forms of instruments. (paragraph break)
Capitulum tertium.	 Chapter third.
De restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus illius: capitulatum, ordinatum a capite usque ad pedes, et formis instrumentorum.	 On restoration and dislocation, on the treatment of twisting and similar matters; arranged from head to foot, and according to the forms of instruments.
Soli Deo Gloria.	 To God alone be the glory.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis.	 The Book of Surgery by Albucasis.
Pars I.	 Part I.
¶ De Iuuamento, et Nocumento Cauterii: et quibus complexionibus conueniat, et quo tempore: et si cum ferro, uel auro.	 On the benefits and harm of cautery; in what constitutions it is appropriate, and at what time; and whether with iron or gold. (paragraph break)
Caput I.	 Chapter I.
Sed Ante Quidem Quam rememorer operationis cum eo, oportet ut dicam qualitatem Iuuamentorum eius, et Nocumentorum ipsius: et in qua complexione exhibeatur.	 Before I remember the operation with him, it is necessary that I say the quality of his remedies and his harmful effects; and in what composition they are presented.
Dico ergo, quod sermo de qualitate iuuamenti Cauterii, et nocumenti eius, est sermo prolixus, et subtilis, scientia, et secretum occultum.	 I say therefore, that the discourse on the quality of the remedy of the Cautery, and its harmful effects, is a long, subtle, scientific, and hidden secret.
Etiam locuta fuit in eo multitudo sapientum, et dissenserunt in eo: et mihi quidem sufficit parum ex sermonibus eorum, timens prolongationem.	 Also there was a multitude of wise men who disagreed about it; and to me, at least, their many discourses are enough for me, fearing a prolonged debate.
Dico ergo, quod Cauterium confert uniuersaliter omni complexioni, quae est cum materia, et absque materia: excaeptis duabus complexionibus, quae sunt complexio calida absque materia, et complexio sicca absque materia.	 I say therefore, that the Cautery applies universally to every composition, which is with matter and without matter; except for two compositions, which are a hot composition without matter, and a dry composition without matter.
In complexione autem calida et sicca cum materia dissenserunt.	 In the hot and dry composition with matter they disagreed.
Quidam enim dixerunt, quod Cauterium iuuatiuum est in ea.	 Some indeed said that the Cautery is beneficial in this [hot and dry composition with matter].
Et dixerunt alii contrarium illius, scilicet quod Cauterium non est conueniens in aegritudine, quae est ex caliditate et siccitate: quoniam natura ignis est caliditas: et inconueniens est, ut sanetur ex agritudine calida et sicca, cum calido et sicco.	 And others said the opposite of this [that the Cautery is beneficial in hot and dry composition with matter], namely that the Cautery is not suitable for the sickness which is due to heat and dryness; because the nature of fire is heat; and it is inconvenient to heal a hot and dry disease, when heated by hot and dry.
Et dixit ille qui dicit contrarium illius: quod per Cauterium fit iuuamentum in omni aegritudine calida et sicca, quae accidit in corporibus hominum: quoniam quando tu comparas corpus hominis, et humiditates eius, ad complexionem ignis, inuenis corpus hominis frigidum.	 And he who says the opposite said that by Cautery is beneficial for any hot and dry sickness which happens in human bodies; because when you compare the body of a man and its humidity to the composition of fire, you find the body of a man cold.
Et ego quidem dico per sermonem eius: quia ex perimentum iam detexit mihi illud aliquotiens.	 And I myself say by his discourse; because he has often revealed that to me in experiment.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut ueniat super illud, nisi qui iam probatus est, et exercitatus in capitulo Cauterii exercitio ultimo, et cognouit diuersitatem complexionum hominum, et dispositionem aegritudinum in se ipsis, et caussas earum, et accidentia ipsarum, et spacium temporis earum.	 Nevertheless, it is not necessary for him to come back to this, unless he who has already been tested and experienced in the last exercise of the chapter on Cautery, and knows the diversity of human compositions, and the disposition of diseases in themselves, and their causes, and accidents thereof, and the space of time of those diseases.
Ex reliquis autem complexionibus non est super uos timor: et praecipue in aegritudinibus frigidis et humidis.	 From the remaining body compositions, there is no fear for you: and especially in cold and moist illnesses.
Iam enim conuenerunt omnes medici super eas: et non dissenserunt in iuuamento cum Cauterio in eis.	 For it has agreed all physicians on these: and they did not disagree in helping with cautery in them.
Et scitote filii, quod ex secreto curationis per Cauterium cum igne, et bonitate eius super Cauterium cum medicina comburente est: quoniam ignis est simplex, cuius actio non peruenit, nisi ad membrum quod cauterisatur: et non nocet membro alio coniuncto cum eo, nisi nocumento paruo.	 And know, sons, that from the secret of cure by cautery with fire, and its goodness over cautery with medicine burning, is that fire is simple, whose action does not reach, unless to the member which is being cauterized: and it does not harm another joint connected with it, unless a small damage.
Medicinae uero comburentis actio peruenit ad illud quod elongatur ex membris: et fortasse facit accidere in membro aegritudinem difficilis sanationis, et fortasse interficit.	 However, the action of medicine burning reaches to what is extended from members: and perhaps it causes illness difficult to heal in a member, and perhaps it kills.
Ignis autem propter subtilitatem suam et bonitatem substantiae suae, non facit illud, nisi superfluat.	 Fire, however, because of its subtlety and goodness of substance, does not do that unless it is excessive.
Iam uero innotuit nobis illud per experimentum, propter longitudinem seruitutis et studii cum arte, et stationem super ueritatem rerum: et propter illud excusor a longitudine sermonis.	 Now we have understood that through an experiment, because of the length of service and study with art, and position on truth of things: and because of that I excuse myself from the length of speech.
Et si non esset, quia non licet huic libro meo, afferrem uobis secretum occultum in igne, et qualitatem operationis eius in corporibus expulsionis suae, qua expellit aegritudines sermone philosophico demonstratiuo, qui acueretur a mentibus uestris.	 And if it was not forbidden to this book of mine, I would give you the secret hidden in fire, and the quality of its operation in bodies, by which it expels illnesses with a philosophical demonstrative speech, which would be understood by your minds.
Et scitote filii, quod ipsi dissentiunt in tempore, in quo conuenit fieri cauterium, et ponunt melius tempus ueris.	 And know, sons, that they themselves disagree on the time when cautery should be made, and put a better time for it with truth.
Et ego dico, quod cauterium conuenit in omni tempore: propterea, quod nocumentum accidens propter tempus submergitur in iuuamento, quod attrahitur cum cauterio.	 And I say that cautery is suitable in every time: therefore, because damage occurring due to the time is drowned in help, which is attracted with cautery.
Et praecipue si cauterium est propter dolores ex doloribus necessariis, fortibus, festinis, qui non tolerant tarditatem: propterea quod timetur ex eis, quod accidat malicia quae est maior, quam paruum nocumentum intrans propter tempus.	 And especially if cautery is for pains from necessary pains, strong, pressing, which cannot endure delay: therefore because it is feared that what may happen from them is greater than a small damage which occurs due to the time.
Et non cadat in mentibus uestris o filii illud, quod non extimant, nisi uulgus et stolidi medici, scilicet quod illi aegritudini quae sanatur per cauterium, non est reditio semper: et ponunt illud consequens, et res non est sicut putant: propterea quod cauterium non est, nisi loco medicinae, quae alterat complexionem, et exiccat humiditates quae sunt caussae, quare accidunt dolores.	And let not that thought enter your minds, O sons, that it is only the common people and foolish physicians who believe that there is not always a return for the sickness cured by cautery; and they assume this as a consequence, but the matter is not as they think: because cautery is not, except in place of medicine, which alters complexion, and extracts humidities which are the causes, wherefore pain arises.
Verumtamen cauterium superfluit super medicinam per uelocitatem ualetudinis suae, et uirtutem suae operationis, et uehementiam dominii sui: et possibile est, ut redeat aegritudo hora aliqua temporis secundum complexionem infirmi, et locationem aegritudinis suae, et uirtutem eius: et quod praeparatur in corpore eius ex aggregatione superfluitatum in eo: et quod peruenit ad ipsum in acquisitione sua ex cibis, et similibus illis ex caussis, nisi fit aegritudo, in qua administratur cauterium.	 However, cautery is superfluous over medicine due to the swiftness of its health, and the strength of its operation, and the power of its dominion: and it is possible that sickness returns at some hour according to the complexion of the sick, and the location of the sickness, and the virtue of the same: and what prepares in his body from an accumulation of superfluities within him: and what reaches him in acquiring it from foods, and similar things due to its causes, except for the sickness in which cautery is administered.
Aegritudo subtilis in membro paucarum superfluitatum, et humiditatum, sicut cauterium dentis, propter dolorem, et similia illi, possibile est enim, ut non redeat in eo ille dolor.	 A subtle sickness in a member with few superfluities and humidities, such as the cautery of a tooth, because of pain and similar things, it is possible that that pain does not return in him.
Sed illud fit in paucis.	 But this happens rarely.
At uero sermo uulgi iterum, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, est sermo rectus: non ad illud quod ipsi intendunt in illo: quoniam ipsi credunt, quod non est curatio quae conferat cum medicina, neque cum alio post occasum cauterii.	 However, the speech of the common people is again correct that cautery is the last medicine: not to what they intend in it: because they believe that there is no cure that confers with medicine, nor with anything after the fall of cautery.
Res autem est econtrario illius, et intentio, quod cauterium est postremum medicinae, non est, nisi quod quando nos administramus modos curationis in aliqua aegritudinum, et non conferunt illae medicinae: deinde administramus in fine rei cauterium, et confert: tunc inde cadit, quod cauterium est postremum mediciuae, non secundum intentionem quam intelligunt uulgus et multistolidorum medicorum.	 But the matter is contrary to theirs and their intention, that cautery is the last medicine, is not, except when we administer modes of cure for a sickness and they do not confer with the same medicine: then we administer cautery at the end of things, and it confers: thence it happens that cautery is the last medicine, not according to the intention which the common people and many foolish physicians understand.
Antiqui autem dixerunt, quod cauterium cum auro est melius, quam cauterium cum ferro: et non dixerunt illud, nisi propter aequalitatem auri, et sublimitatem substantiae suae: et dixerunt, quod non facit pus locus cauterii.	 The ancients said that a cautery with gold is better than a cautery with iron; and they did not say this, if not because of the equality of gold, and the loftiness of its substance; and they said, that it does not cause a place for pus at the site of the cauterization.
Verum non est illud absolute: quoniam ego iam probaui illud, et inueni, quod ipsum non facit illud in quibusdam corporibus absque aliis.	 That is not entirely true; because I have already proven it and found that it does not do this in certain bodies without others.
Et cauterium cum ipso est bonum, et melius quam cum ferro, sicut dixerunt.	 And a cautery with it (gold) is good, and better than with iron, as they said.
Verumtamen quando tu ignis cauterium in igne ex auro, non declaratur tibi, quando ignitur secundum quantitatem quam uis, propter rubedinem auri: et quando properat ad ipsum frigus, et si addis super ipsum ignitionem, liquescit in igne, et uertitur in laminas.	 However, when you put fire to the cautery from gold in fire, it is not shown to you, when it burns according to the quantity that you want, due to the redness of gold; and when it rushes towards it (the gold) coldness, and if you add more fire to it, it melts in the fire and turns into sheets.
Quare cadit artifex ex illo in occupationem: et propter illud fit Cauterium cum ferro apud nos uelocius et propinquius, ex rectitudine ad operationem.	 Therefore, the craftsman falls into this (mistake) due to it; and because of this, a cautery with iron is more quickly and closely made among us for the sake of the operation.
Et ego quidem iam ordinaui hoc Capitulum in Cauterio, secundum capitula: et ordinaui ea a capite usque ad pedes: ut alleuient quaerenti illud quod uult ex eo.	 And I myself have already arranged this Chapter (on cautery) in the Cautery, according to chapters; and I have arranged it from head to foot, so that those who are seeking (information on cautery) may find what they want from it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Caput in commissura coronali.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing a head at the coronal suture.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Confert hic cauterizatio ad dominium humiditatis et frigiditatis super cerebrum: quae duae sunt caussae sodae, et multitudinis fluxus humorum ex capite ad partes oculorum et aurium, et multitudinis somni, et doloris dentium, et doloris gutturis: et uniuersaliter omnis aegritudinis, quae accidit ex frigiditate, sicut paralisis, et sodae, epilepsiae, et apoplexiae, et similia illis ex aegritudinibus.	 Here is the cauterization for the dominion of humidity and coldness over the brain: these two are the causes of soda (seizures), and the flowing multitude of fluids from the head to the parts of the eyes and ears, and the multitude of sleep, and toothache, and throat pain; and universally all illness that happens due to coldness, such as paralysis, sodae, epilepsy, apoplexy, and similar illnesses.
Modus cauterizationis est, ut praecipias infirmo: ut euacuetur in primis cum medicina solutiua mundificante caput tribus noctibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod exigit uirtus infirmi, et eius aetas, et consuetudo eius.	 The method of cauterization is to instruct the sick person: first, that the head should be evacuated with a solution of medicine cleaning for three or four nights, depending on the strength of the sick person, their age, and their habit.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radi faciat caput suum cum nouacula.	 Then instruct him to shave his head with a razor.
Deinde fac eum sedere inter manus tuas quadratum, ita quod iam posuit manus suas super pectus suum.	 Then make him sit square between your hands so that he puts his hands on his chest.
Deinde pone radicem palmae tuae super radicem nasi sui inter oculos suos.	 Then put the root of your palm over the root of his nose between his eyes.
Vbicumque ergo peruenerit digitus tuus medius, signa locum illum cum incausto.	 Wherever your middle finger comes, mark that place with an uncauterized spot.
Deinde igni Cauterium Oliuare: cuius haec est forma.	 Then heat the cautery oil: this is its form.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum signatum cum incausto, descensione, qua constringatur manus tua paulatim, et tu reuolues ipsum.	 Then put it on the marked uncauterized spot, descending with your hand to tighten it gradually, and you turn it.
Deinde leua manum tuam uelociter, et aspicias locum.	 Then quickly withdraw your hand, and look at the place.
Quod si uides iam detegi ex osse quantitatem capitis alkiel, aut quantitatem zeuherbi, tunc eleua manum tuam.	 If you see that a piece of bone or quantity of pus has been discharged from the skull, then remove your hand.
Et si non, itera manum tuam ferro ipso, aut cum alio ab ipso si infrigidatur: donec uideantur ossa, quae dixi tibi.	 And if not, press your hand with the iron itself or with another tool, until you see the bones that I told you about.
Deinde sume aliquid ex sale, et solue illud in aqua, et imbibe in ipso cotum, et pone super locum: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then take something from salt, dissolve it in water and soak the cloth in it, and put it on that place; leave it for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, et dimitte illum super locum, donec destruatur eschara ignis.	 Then place on top of it a wet cloth in butter, and let it remain until the burn is consumed by the fire.
Deinde cura illud cum unguento tetrapharmacon, usquequo sanetur.	 Then treat it with the four-ingredient ointment until it heals.
Iam dixerunt, quod quanto uulnus plus remanet apertum, emittit pus: quare est melius et magis iuuatiuum.	 It is said that the larger an open wound remains, the more pus it discharges; therefore, it is better and more helpful.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum, ut cauterizetur cutis usque ad os: et teneatur Cauterium, donec aduratur quiddam spissitudinis ossis.	 And some of them said that the skin should be burned up to the bone; and the cautery should be held until it has heated something of the bone's thickness.
Deinde radatur post illud quod adustum est ex osse, deinde curetur.	 Then grind down what has been burned from the bone, then treat it.
Et dicunt alii, quod oportet ut cum cauterio perueniatur ad ultimum, donec imprimat in os impressionem for tem, ita quod cadat os, quod fit sicut forma kirate: aut instrumentum quod mulieres ponunt infuso alphabeti parui: et extimant, quod exspirantur ex hoc loco uapores capitis, et dimittatur uulnus apertum tempore longo.	 Others say that when the cautery reaches the bone, it should make an impression on the bone for as long as the bone falls off, so that it becomes like the shape of a scorch mark; or they use an instrument that women put in place of the small alphabet: and they believe that vapors from the head will escape from this place; and let the open wound remain for a long time.
Deinde curetur, donec consolidetur.	 Then treat it until it solidifies.
Mihi autem non uidentur hae duae species Cauterii omnino nisi in quibusdam hominibus secundum uiam timoris.	 But I do not see these two types of cautery at all except in some people according to the way of fear.
Et dimittere ipsum, apud me est melius cum salute ipsius.	 And let it be, in my opinion, it is better for his health.
Debilitatur enim caput ex solutione continuitatis ipsius naturalis: sicut testificati sumus in reliquis membris: et praecipue quando caput infirmi debile est natura: et species quidem Cauterii prima est magis salua et melior apud me, et ea utor: operare ergo cum ea in salute.	 For the head is weakened by the solution of its own continuity; as we have testified in other members: and especially when the head of a sick person is naturally weak: and the first species of cautery is safer and better in my opinion, and I use it: therefore operate with it for his health.
¶ De modo cauterizandi capitis in dolore totius capitis.	 On the method of cauterizing the head in pain of the whole head.
Caput III.	 Chapter 3.
Quando in toto Capite accidit dolor chronicus: et prolongatur illud in infirmo, et utitur hyeris, et cochiis, et caputpurgiis, et oleis, et empleumatis.	 When a chronic pain occurs throughout the head, and it persists in a weak person, and they use hyson (a type of tea), hot baths, bloodletting, massages with oil, and fomentation.
Et praecipue si iam cauterizatum est cauterio uno, quod narrauimus, et non confert ei aliquid ex illis: tunc considera.	 And particularly if it has already been cauterized with one cautery, as we have mentioned, and none of the above helps him: then consider.
Nam si caput infirmi est fortis creationis natura, et non est debile, et inuenit frigus uehemens: tunc cauteriza cum cauterio alio sub illo parum.	 If the head of a weak person is strong by nature and not frail, and it finds extreme cold: then cauterize it with another cautery, but sparingly.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio, do nec pertranseat cutis, et discooperiatur ex osse quantitas, quam narrauimus.	 Then cauterize it on all the horns of his head with another cautery, but be careful not to penetrate the skin, and remove only the quantity of bone that we have mentioned.
Et cauteriza ipsum cauterio uno in occipitio capitis sui, in loco qui nominatur uas: et est locus in quo ponitur uentosa: et eleua matum tuam in hoc, et non discooperias os.	 Cauterize it with one cautery on the occiput of his head, in the place which is called "was": and it is a place where pus collects: and clean out your medicine in this place, but do not remove bone.
Infirmus enim inuenit propter illud dolorem uehementem, et diuersum a dolore reliquorum cauteriorum capitis omnium.	 For the weak person finds relief from that intense pain, and it is different from the pain of all other cauteries on the head.
Et ego dicam hoc Cauterium in loco suo: et oportet quod sit cauterium, quo cauterizantur cornua capitis, et occiput eius subtilius cauterio, quo cauterizatur medium capitis.	 And I will say that this cautery is in its place: and it must be a cautery with which the horns of the head are cauterized, and the occiput more subtly with the cautery used for cauterizing the middle part of the head.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in hemicrania, tam cum medicina adustiua, quam cum ferro.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing a hemiplegia, both with burned medicine and with iron.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Quando accidit in parte capitis dolor et soda, aut extenditur dolor usque ad oculum, et euacuatur cum medicinis mundificantibus caput, et administratur reliqua curatio, quam dixi in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert illud totum: tunc cauterizatio in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterizatio cum medicina acuta comburente: aut cum ferro.	 When pain and swelling occurs on part of the head, or the pain extends to the eye, and the head is treated with cleaning medicines, and further treatment is administered as I have said in the divisions of diseases, but it does not work completely: then cauterization is used in this case according to two methods: either cauterization with a burning medicine, or with iron.
Cauterium autem cum medicina acuta comburente, est, ut accipias dentem unum allii, et excortices ipsum, et abscindas extremitates eius ex duobus lateribus.	 The cautery with burning medicine is to take one clove of garlic, peel it, and cut off the ends from both sides.
Deinde scinde locum doloris in tempore cum phlebotomo lato, donec fiat in eo locus sub cute, in quo dens capitur.	 Then cut the painful spot at the time with a broad lancet until there is a place under the skin where a tooth can be captured.
Intromitte ergo eum in ipso sub cute, donec occultetur: deinde stringe super ipsum cum puluillo constrictione decenti, et dimitte ipsum quantitate quindecim horarum deinde solue eum, et extrahe allium, et dimitteuulnus duobus diebus, aut tribus: postea pone super ipsum cotum submersum in butyro, donec locus efficiat pus: deinde cura ipsum cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Insert it (the tooth) into the same place under the skin until it is hidden; then press upon it with a suitable plaster and leave it for fifteen hours, then dissolve it and extract the garlic clove and let it be for two or three days; later, place it submerged in butter on the spot until pus forms; then treat the spot with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis fac illud cum quibusdam medicinis comburentibus, quas ego scripsi in tractatu duodecimo, de Medieinis adurentibus.	 And if you wish to do this with certain burning medicines, as I wrote in the twelfth treatise on Medications that Burn.
Cauterizatio uero eius cum ferro, est secundum hunc modum.	 But cauterization is performed in this manner (with iron).
Igni Cauterium, cuius forma haec est.	 The form of the hot cautery is as follows: a cylinder of iron about the size of a finger, covered with a sheath of leather, and on both
Et nominatur Clauilis: quoniam forma capitis eius est sicut forma claui, in quo est quiddam curuitatis, et in medio eius est quaedam eminentia parua.	 It is called a claw-like cautery because its head resembles the shape of a nail, having something sharp on it and in the middle there is a small projection.
Deinde pone ipsum super locum, et retine manum tuam: et tu reuolue ferrum paulatim cum uelocitate: et sit quantitas quae aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, sicut medietas eius.	 Then place it on the spot and hold your hand; and you rotate the iron slowly with speed; and the amount that is burned should be of the thickness of the skin, as the middle part of it.
Et eleua manum tuam, ut non aduratur arteria, quae est inferius, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And lift your hand so that an artery below is not burned and there is no bleeding.
Deinde imbibe cotum in aqua salis, et pone super locum, et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus: deinde pone cotum cum butyro: postea cura cum unguento usquequo sanetur.	 Then immerse the hot iron in water with salt and place it on the spot for three days; then immerse the hot iron in butter; later, treat the spot with ointment until it is healed.
Et si uis, cauteriza hanc hemicraniam cum extremitate cultellari secunda Cauterii.	 And if you wish, cauterize this hemicania (half headache) with the tip of the second cautery (small knife-like instrument).
Et caue ab incisione arteriae in hac hemicrania, non antiqua proprie.	 Be careful not to cut an artery during this half-headache, not by the ancient method.
¶ De modo cauteriezandi in hemicrania antiqua.	 On the method of cauterizing in the old half-headache.
Caput V.	 Head V.
Quando curas hemicraniam, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione praecedente, et quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio: et uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei quod diximus ex cauterio primo cum medicina, aut cum cauterio cum igne, tunc oportet ut ignias Cauterium cultellare, donec albificetur postquam signas super locum doloris cum linea, cuius longitudo sit medietas digiti, aut quasi illud: et depone manum tuam uice una, et stringe eam donec incidas arteriam, et peruenias usque ad os.	 When you treat a half-headache as we have said in the treatment that follows, and what we have said in the division of diseases, and it does not help: and you see from the disease that it is not enough for us what we have said with the first cautery with medicine, or with the cautery with fire, then it is necessary to use a cold cautery, until it whitens after marking the place of pain with a line, whose length is half a finger, or about this much: and put your hand instead, and tighten it until you cut an artery, and reach as far as the bone.
Verumtamen necesse est tibi, ut caueas a continuatione mandibulae, quae mouetur apud masticationem, ne aduratur latus, aut neruus qui mouet ipsam, unde accidat spasmus.	 However, it is necessary for you to be careful about the lower jaw area that moves during chewing, so as not to burn the side or the nerve that moves it, thus causing a spasm.
Et esto super custotiam, et cautelam de fluxu sanguinis arteriae, quae abscisa est.	 And take care and be careful about the flow of blood from the artery that was cut.
In abscisione enim eius est timor, et praecipue ei qui ignorat illud quod facit, et non est studiosus, nec expertus: et dimittit operationem cum eo in primis.	 For there is fear in its cutting, especially for those who do not know what they are doing and are not careful or experienced: and they abandon the operation first of all.
Et ego ueniam cum rememoratione regiminis fluxus sanguinis accidentis ex arteria secundum modum suum, et in loco suo huius libri.	 And I will come with a reminder about the management of the flow of blood that occurs from the cut artery according to its method and in its place in this book.
Quod si uides ex aegritudine, quod non sufficit ei hoc Cauterium, et uides corpus infirmi tolerans cauterium in medio capitis, sicut narrauimus, cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	 If you see from the disease that this cautery is not enough for him, and you see a weak body tolerating the cautery in the middle of the head as we have said, treat a wound until it heals.
Et si uis, administra Cauterium, quod diximus in capitulo extractionis arteriae cum Cauterio habente duos cultellos.	 And if you wish, administer the cautery that we have said in the chapter on the extraction of an artery with a cautery having two blades.
Est enim cauterizatio melior hac et magis conferens.	 Cauterization is indeed better in this way and more suitable.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Aurium.	 On the method of cauterizing ear pain.
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Quando accidit in Aure dolor a frigore, et curatur cum solutiuis, et reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione, et non remouetur dolor, tunc igni Cauterium: et est illud quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma est haec.	 When cold pain occurs in the ear and it is treated with solutions, and the rest of the treatment as we have said in the division, and the pain does not subside, then cautery by fire: and that is what is called a puncture, whose shape is as follows.
Deinde puncta cum eo post eius ignitionem in circumitu auris totius, sicut reuoluitur: aut in circumitu utriusque, si simul dolor est in utrisque.	 Then the puncture is made around the entire ear, as it is rotated: or around both sides if the pain is on both sides.
Et elonga te cum Cauterio a radice auris parumper, postquam signaueris loca cum encaustro: et sit cauterii quantitas decem punctorum in omni aure, et quasi illa.	 And elongate [the cautery] from the ear's root slightly after marking the spots with encaustum (beeswax): and let the amount of cautery be ten punctures on every ear, approximately.
Deinde cura loca, donec sanentur.	 Then heal the spots until they are healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tortura.	 In the manner of cauterizing in a strain (torture).
Caput VII.	 Chapter VII.
Tortura quae curatur cum cauterizatione, non est nisi ex speciebus, quae accidunt ex phlegmate, secundum quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum.	 A strain that is treated with cauterization, is not anything other than those types which occur due to phlegm, as we have said in the divisions of diseases.
Et deuita cauterizationem speciei, quae accidit ex exiccatione, et spasmo nerui.	 And avoid cauterizing species that occur due to exhaustion and muscle spasm.
Quando curas hanc speciem torturae cum hyeris, et caputpurgiis, et gargarismis, et non confert curatio tua, tunc oportet ut cauterizes infirmum tribus Cauteriis: uno apud radicem auris, et secundo parum inferius a timpore suo, et tertio apud coniunctionem duorum labiorum.	 When treating this species of strain with hyssop, mouth washings, and gargles, and the treatment does not help, then it is necessary to cauterize the weakened area with three cauteries: one at the root of the ear, and the second slightly lower than its own time (i.e., below the earlobe), and the third at the junction of the two lips (labia).
Et pone Cauterium tuum ex contrario partis infirmae.	 And place your cautery on the opposite side of the weakened area.
Quoniam mollificatio non accidit, nisi in parte quae apparet sana.	 Since softening does not occur unless in the healthy part.
Et forma cauterizationis est, ut cauterizes ipsum Cauterio in directo extremitatis auris superioris sub cornu capitis parum: et alio in timpore: cuius longitudo sit secundum longitudinem pollicis.	 And the shape of the cauterization is to cauterize with the cautery itself, along the tip of the upper part of the ear near the head slightly, and another at the earlobe; whose length should be according to the length of the thumb.
Et depone manum tuam cum cauterio, donec comburatur quantitas medietatis spissitudinis cutis.	 Place your hand with the cautery until it is burned to a depth of half the thickness of the skin.
Et haec est forma Cauterii, et est species ex cultellari, cuius forma praemissa est: uerumtamen non est subtilior ea parum, sicut uides: et oportet ut sit cultellus in eo superfluae grossitudinis parum.	 This is the form of Cautery, and it is made of a knife whose shape is as follows: however, it should not be too thin as you can see; it is necessary that the knife in it has little extra thickness.
Deinde cura loca, cum eo quod praecessit: donec sanetur.	 Then take care of the places with it until they heal.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Apoplexia antiqua.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization for apoplexy (ancient).
Caput VIII.	 Chapter 8.
QUando antiquatur Apoplexia, et curas eam cum eo quod diximus, et non confert medicatio tua, et infirmus non habet febrem, tunc cauteriza eum quatuor cauteriis super omne cornu capitis sui, et cauterio in medio capitis, sicut diximus, et cauterio in occipitio capitis, secundum quod praecessit: et modus cauterii sit secundum quod praecessit.	 When apoplexy occurs and your treatment does not help, nor does the patient have a fever, then cauterize him with four cauteries on every horn of his head, and a cautery in the middle of his head as previously stated, and a cautery in the back of his head according to what has been described; the method of cauterization should be as previously described.
Etiam cauterizatur cum Cauterio super os stomachi: et est magis ultimum.	 Additionally, it is cauterized with a Cautery on the mouth of the stomach; this is more the final procedure.
Deinde curetur, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then it will be treated with what has been described before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Obliuione.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization for oblivion (forgetfulness).
Caput IX.	 Chapter 9.
Oportet ut in potu dentur in primis infirmo hyerae magnae, et pillulae mundificantes cerebrum.	 It is necessary that in drink there are firstly large quantities of hyssop, and pills cleansing the brain.
Deinde rade caput infirmi totum, et pone super occipitium eius emplastrum de synapi descriptum in tractatu emplastrorum: et pone ipsum aliquotiens.	 Then scrape the head of the sick person entirely, and place upon his occiput ointment described in the treatise on ointments, and place it repeatedly.
Ipsum namque est modus Cauterii: et fac illud secundum ordinem eundem, quem dixi illic.	 For this is the method of cauterization: and do that according to the same order as I said there.
Si ergo sanatur per illud, bonum est.	 If therefore he is cured by it, it is good.
Si non: tunc fac ei cauteria tria in posteriori parte capitis sui, quae sint descendentia a superiori parte capitis usque ad inferiorem partem oculi: et pone inter omne cauterium grossitudinem digiti.	 If not: then do three cauterizations on the back part of his head, which are descending from the upper part of the head to the lower part of the eye: and place between every cauterization a thickness of a finger.
Deinde cura Cauterium, cum eo quod praecessit.	 Then take care of the cauterization, with that which preceded.
Si autem uis additionem, et infirmus est tolerans illud: tunc fac ei Cauterium in medio.	 If however you wish an addition, and the sick person can bear it: then do a cauterization in the middle.
Quod si uis additionem: tunc cauteriza ipsum super duo cornua.	 What if you wish an addition: then cauterize him above both horns.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: sitque Cauterium oliuare secundum formam, quae praemissa est.	 Then take care of him until he is cured: and let the cauterization be anointed according to the shape that was mentioned before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Paralisi, et mollificatione.	 [Chapter Title] On the method of cauterizing in paralysis, and softening.
Caput X.	 Chapter X.
Oportet ut procedas in mundificatione capitis cum hyeeris, et cum eo quod diximus.	 You should proceed with the cleansing (munda) of the head with hyson (hyeeris), and with what was said.
Deinde rade caput infirmi: postea cauteriza ipsum cauterio in medio capitis, et cauterio super omne cornu capitis, et cauterio super posterius ipsius, et tribus super spondiles colli.	 Then scrape the head of the sick person: afterwards cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head, and with a cautery over all the horns of the head, and with a cautery over behind it, and three over the vertebrae of the neck.
Si autem indiges in aegritudine mollificatione corporis pluribus illis, et infirmus est tolerans, et aegritudo est fortis: tunc cauteriza ipsum quatuor cauteriis super spondiles dorsi, et ultima cum cauterio, donec comburatur ex cute plurimum eius, et eleua manum tuam.	 If, however, you need for the softening (mollification) of the body to be done with more of these things, and the patient is weak and the disease is strong: then cauterize it with four cauteries over the vertebrae of the back, and the last one with a cautery, until the skin of most of it has been burned off, and wipe your hand.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur: et sic cauterium Oliuare.	 Then take care of him (the patient), until he is cured: thus cauterize with oil (Oliuare).
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Epilepsia.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in epilepsy.
Caput XI.	 Chapter XI.
Non Cauterizatur epilepticus, nisi ille cuius epilepsia est ex phlegmate.	 Epilepsy is not to be cauterized, unless that person's epilepsy is from phlegm.
Oportet ergo ut mundifices cerebrum eius in primis cum hyeris, et cum reliqua curatione quam diximus in diuisione: quando infirmus est magnus, aut est tolerans in accaeptione medicinarum.	 Therefore, it is necessary to cleanse the brain of that person first with hyson (hyeris), and with the treatment we mentioned earlier: when the patient is very sick, or weak in accepting medicine.
Si autem est puer, qui non tolerat medicinas, tunc administratur gargarisma, et masticationes mundificantes cerebrum, ante illud diebus multis cum bonificatione ciborum.	 If, however, the patient is a child who cannot tolerate medicine, then administer gargarisma, and cleansing mastication (masticationes) for the brain, before that for many days with good food.
Deinde rade caput eius, postea cauteriza ipsum Cauterio uno in medio capitis, secundum quod praecessit in modo: et cauterio alio in occipitio eius, et super omne cornu capitis sui cauterio.	 Then scrape the head of that person, afterwards cauterize it with a cautery in the middle of the head, as before (secundum quod praecessit in modo): and with another cautery on the back of his head, and over all the horns of his head with a cautery.
Quod si infirmus fuerit fortis, et fuerit tolerans, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauteriis, quae dixi in habente paralisim, et mollificationem corporis super spondiles colli, et spondiles dorsi: et sit Cauterium oliuare secundum modum qui praecessit.	 If the patient is strong and can tolerate it, then cauterize him with the cauteries that were mentioned in the presence of paralysis, and the softening (mollification) of the body on the vertebrae of the neck and back: and let the cautery be oiled (Cauterium oliuare) as before.
Si autem infirmus est puer, tunc pone cauterium subtile, secundum hunc modum.	 If a child is sick, then place a subtle cautery in this manner.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Melancholia.	 On the method of cauterizing in melancholy.
Caput XII.	 Book Twelfth.
Quando caussa melancholiae sunt humiditates corruptae, et phlegma grossum, tunc cauteriza ipsum Cauteriis, quae diximus in habente paralisim.	 When the cause of melancholy are corrupted humors and thick phlegm, then cauterize it with the Cauteries which we have mentioned in a person having paralysis.
Et si caussa melancholiae est superfluitas decliuis ad melancholiam, et est corpus infirmi humectum, tunc da ei in potu quod mundificet cerebrum eius, secundum quod praecessit in diuisione: deinde rade caput infirmi, et fac postea tortellam decenter factam ex lino, sicut circulum.	 And if the cause of melancholy is an excess of declivities to melancholy and the body of the sick person is moist, then give him to drink what purifies his brain, according to what was mentioned in the division: then shave the head of the sick person, and make afterwards a well-made plaster made from linen, just like a circle.
Deinde pone ipsam in medio capitis: et infirmus sedens quadratus teneatur ab omni parte.	 Then place it on the middle of the head: and the sick person sitting facing all directions should be held.
Deinde praesenta linimentum.	 Then bring a liniment.
Et est dignius ex butyro ouium antiquo.	 It is better from ancient sheep butter.
Et calefac ipsum super ignem calefactione temperata mensura, quam toleret digitus, quando intromittitur in ipsum.	 And heat it over a controlled fire temperature that the finger can bear when it is inserted into it.
Deinde euacua ipsum in medio capitis eius in circulo, et dimitte ipsum donec infrigidetur.	 Then evacuate it in the middle of his head in a circle, and leave it until it cools down.
Fac illud infirmo omni hebdomada semel, cum reliquo regimine eius bono, donec sanetur.	 Do this to the sick person once every week, with the rest of his good treatment regime, until he is cured.
Aut si uis, cauteriza ipsum faciendo puncta parua plurimum eius, praeter quod teneas manum cum cauterio: imo sit odorando.	 Or if you wish, cauterize it by making many small punctures in it, besides holding your hand with the cautery; it should be smelly.
Haec enim species cauterii humectat cerebrum cum qualitate.	 For this kind of cautery moistens the brain with a certain quality.
Deinde pone super ipsum cotum imbibitum in butyro, aut adipe gallinae.	 Then put over it a cloth soaked in butter or goose fat.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aqua descendente ad oculum.	 On the method of cauterizing in water descending to the eye.
Caput XIII.	 Book Thirteenth.
Quando declaratur tibi principium aquae in oculo per signa, quae dixi in diuisione, tunc incipe et pota infirmum, cum eo quod mundificet caput eius.	 When the beginning of water in the eye is declared to you by the signs I mentioned in division, then begin and wash the sick person, with it to clean his head.
Et custodi ipsum ab omnibus humiditatibus, et fac eum sedere in balneo, in ieiunio diebus aliquot.	 And keep him away from all moistness, and make him sit in a bath for several days while fasting.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut radat caput suum, et cauteriza ipsum in medio capitis sui.	 Then command him to shave his head, and brand himself in the middle of his head.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum super duo timpora duobus cauteriis, si est incaeptio descensus aquae in duobus oculis simul: aut ex latere uno, si est incaeptio aquae in oculo uno: et abscinde cum cauterio omnes uenas et arterias quae sunt sub cute: et sint cauteria in ea longa in latitudine timporum: et caue a fluxu sanguinis.	 Then brand him with two cauteries on both temples, if there is an obstruction of water descending in both eyes at once: or from one side, if there is an obstruction of water in one eye: and cut with the cautery all veins and arteries that are under the skin: and let the cauterizations be long in width equal to the temples: and avoid bleeding.
Quod si uides aliquid ex eo, tunc abscinde eum statim cum quacumque medicina est possibile: et ego ueniam cum sapientia, quae est in extractione arteriarum, et abscisione earum, et cautela a fluxu sanguinis.	 If you see something from him, then cut it off immediately with any medicine that is possible: and I will come with wisdom, which is in the extraction of arteries, and cutting them, and caution against bleeding.
Et quandoque cauterizatur in ceruice, sub duobus ossibus, duobus cauteriis ultime productis.	 And sometimes he should be branded on the neck, under two bones, with two cauteries that are pushed out to the utmost.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lachrymis antiquis.	 Chapter on the method of branding in tears (anciently).
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIV.
Quando lachrymae oculorum sunt antiquae, assiduae: et sunt super uenas, et arterias quae sunt in manifesto capitis exterius, uerificatur quod illud est ex superfluitatibus frigidis, phlegmaticis: tunc cauteriza cauterio eodem quod narraui in incaeptione aquae descendentis, cauterio in medio capitis, et duobus cauteriis super duo timpora, et duobus cauteriis in ceruice sub duobus ossibus.	 When the tears of the eyes are old and constant: and they are on veins and arteries that are manifest on the outside of the head, it is verified that this is from superfluidities cold, phlegmatic: then brand with the same cautery as I mentioned in the obstruction of water descending, branding in the middle of the head, and with two cauteries on both temples, and with two cauteries on the neck under two bones.
Et si indiges additione, tunc cauteriza ipsum in omni latere caute oculi, super extremitatem supercilii cum cauterio paruo.	 And if it is necessary to add, then brand him on all sides of the eye with caution, on the edge of the eyebrow with a small cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in foetore Nasi.	 Method for Cauterizing in Nasal Foul Smell.
Caput XV.	 Head Fifteenth.
Quando tu medicaris illud, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert medicatio: tunc propera, et da in potu infirmocochias tribus noctibus: deinde rade caput eius, et cauteriza ipsum cauterio medio, cum cauterio oliuari.	 When you treat it as we have said in division, and the medication does not work: then hurry up, and give infirmocochia for three nights; afterwards, shave its head, and cauterize it with a medium cautery, with an oil-filled cautery.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio clauili duobus cauteriis, super duo supercilia sub capillis parum.	 Then cauterize it with a pair of cauteries, two cauteries, on both eyebrows under the hair.
Et custodite ab arteria, ne incidas eam.	 And keep away from the artery, lest you cut it.
Et haec est forma cauterii Clauilis.	 And this is the form of the claw-shaped cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in mollificatione Palpebrae.	 Method for Cauterizing in Softening of the Eyelid.
Caput XVI.	 Head Sixteenth.
Quando mollificatur Palpebra oculi ab aegritudine, aut humiditate: tunc cauteriza Palpebram cauterio uno, cum hoc cauterio lunari.	 When the eyelid of an eye is softened by illness or moisture: then cauterize the eyelid with one cautery, with this lunar-shaped cautery.
Et si uis, cauteriza ipsum supra duo supercilia parum duobus cauteriis in omni parte: et elongentur a duobus timporibus: et sit longitudo omnis cauterii, secundum longitudines supercilii: et non ultimes manum tuam cum cauterio, imo secundum quantitatem quod aduritur tertia palpebrae.	 And if you wish, cauterize it over both eyebrows with two cauteries in all places; and they extend from the two temples: and let the length of the entire cautery be according to the length of the eyebrow: and do not go beyond the end with your hand, rather according to the amount that is burned by the third eyelash.
Et haec est forma cauterii secundum hunc modum cauterii lunaris.	 And this is the form of the cautery according to this method of lunar-shaped cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Palpebram cum pili inuersantur pungentes oculum.	 Method for Cauterizing the Eyelid when the hair turns inward and pricks the eye.
Caput XVII.	 Head Seventeenth.
Cauterium in eo est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum igne: aut cauterium cum medicina comburente.	 Cautery is in it according to two modes: either cautery with fire; or cautery with burning medicine.
In cauterio autem cum igne, praecipe infirmo ante illud, ut dimittat pilos suos, si est ex illis qui mundant eos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 In cauterio with fire, command the patient to shave his hairs beforehand if he is among those who clean them, until they are extended and evened out.
Si autem pungunt eum apud ortum suum: tunc constringe oculos eius cum uitta, ut non moueantur, donec nascantur.	 If however they prick him at its origin: then constrict his eyes with adhesive until they do not move until they grow (healing).
Cum ergo nascuntur et aequantur, tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo: deinde signa super Palpebram oculorum eius cum encaustro, signo quod sit secundum figuram folii myrti: et sit principium signi prope pilos.	 When they grow and are evened out, then place the head of the patient in your lap; afterwards mark on the eyelid of his eyes with encaustic (wax), mark what is second in shape to a myrtle leaf; let the beginning of the mark be near the hairs.
Deinde pone cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum.	 Then place a cotton soaked in egg white or slippery elm gum on the eye.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then heat the cautery, which has this shape (circular or spoon-shaped).
Deinde cauteriza super figuram, quam signasti paulatim in uicibus multis, donec comburatur superficies cutis, quae est sicut figura folii myrti, totam apparentem proprie.	 Then cauterize on the shape marked by you gradually at many spots, until the surface of the skin that is like a myrtle leaf, completely visible, is burned.
Et signum sanitatis operis tui est: ut si uideas Palpebram oculi iam contrahi, et pilos eleuari apud puncturam oculi.	 And the sign of your health work is: if you see that the eyelid of the eye already contracts, and hairs are rising at the prick on the eye.
Eleua ergo manum tuam tunc: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	 Then lift your hand at that time; and release him for three days.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur eschara.	 Then place on it a cotton with butter until the scab falls off.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with ointment until he is healed.
Quod si redeat aliquod ex pilis post horam, et mollificetur palpebra: tunc itera Cauterium super illum locum, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If some hair grows back after an hour and the eyelid becomes soft: then repeat the cautery on that place as you did at first.
Si autem pili sunt in inferiori: tunc cauteriza ipsam, donec eleuetur ad locum suum naturalem: et aequetur ut non pungant pili oculum.	 If however the hairs are on the lower part (eyelash area): then cauterize it until they rise to their own place and become even so that they do not prick the eye again.
¶ De modo cauterizandi cum medicina comburente in eodem casu.	 Method of cauterizing with burning medicine in the same case.
Caput XVIII.	 Head XVIII.
Est ut praecipias infirmo, ut dimittat pilos, donec prolongentur et aequentur.	 It is to be ordered for the sick one, that he lets go of hairs until they grow out and become equal.
Fac ex charta de panno formam folii myrti.	 Make from linen cloth the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Deinde accipe ex sapone cognito, et ex calce non imbibita ex unoquoque pondus uncia I aut quasi illud: deinde tere ea simul contritione bona, et fac illud cum festinatione, ut non infrigidetur.	 Then take from known soap and unabsorbed lime each a weight of ounce I or about that, then crush them together well with good grinding, and make it quickly so that it does not get cold.
Deinde ex pande ex eo super chartam quam fecisti sicut formam folii myrti, et pone ipsum super palpebram oculi unius, aut duorum.	 Then spread the paste on the cloth that you made in the shape of a myrtle leaf and place it over the eyelid of one or both eyes.
Et pone sub oculo cotum imbibitum in albumine oui: et caput infirmi sit in sinu tuo.	 And put under the eye, an egg yolk immersed in white of egg; and let the head of the sick one be in your lap.
Et pone digitum tuum indicem super medicinam, et preme ipsum parumper.	 And place your forefinger on the medicine and press it a little.
Et tu moueas ipsum quotiens sentit infirmus mordicationem medicinae: quoniam inuenit eius mordicatio sicut ignis.	 And you move it as often as the sick one feels pain from the medicine; because its pressure is like fire.
Dum ergo perseuerat hoc quod ipse inuenit mordicatio, tunc dimitte medicinam, et moue ipsam cum digito tuo.	 While this pressure, which he feels as pain, continues, then release the medicine and move it with your finger.
Cum ergo quiescit mordicatio, tunc remoue medicinam, et ablue oculum cum aqua.	 When the pain subsides, then remove the medicine and wash the eye with water.
Et considera tunc, si uides palpebram eleuari, sicut eleuatur apud contractionem cum igne, aut cum incisione, est bene: et si non, tunc itera super ipsam ex medicina super locum, in quo non imprimit medicina, et non denigrat, donec aequetur operatio tua, et contrahatur oculus.	 And then consider if the eyelid rises as it does when contracted with fire or incision, this is good; and if not, then repeat the application of the medicine on the place where the medicine does not press or blacken until your operation becomes equal and the eye contracts.
Deinde pone super ipsum Cotum cum butyro, donec eradicetur cutis adustionis.	 Then place over it the yolk of an egg with butter until the skin of the burn is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento diaphinicon, aut alio, donec sanetur.	 Then treat him with a diaphine ointment or another one until he is healed.
Et necesse est tibi apud operationem, ut custodias ultima custodia, ne in oculum cadat aliquid ex medicina.	 And it is necessary for you during the operation that you keep the last guard so that nothing from the medicine falls into the eye.
Quod si mollificatur palpebra post dies, et pugnat ex capillis aliquid in oculo, tunc itera medicinam super illum locum, qui mollificatur ex palpebra proprie, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If the eyelid becomes softened after days and something fights from hairs within the eye, then repeat the medicine on that place which becomes softened from the eyelid, as you did initially.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then cure it (the affected area) until it is healed.
Et haec est forma folii myrti.	 And this is the shape of a myrtle leaf.
Et scias, quod oculi hominum diuersificantur in magnitudine, et paruitate.	 And know that human eyes differ in size and smallness.
Ergo secundum illud sit consideratio tua: et non occultatur uia rectitudinis illi, cui est studium de hac arte.	 Therefore according to that (knowledge), let your consideration be: and the path of righteousness for this art should not be hidden from you.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Fistula lachrymali.	 Chapter on the method of cauterization in the lacrimal fistula.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter XIX.
Quando curas Fistulam, cum eo quod diximus in diuisionibus aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc, oportet ut cauterizes ipsam secundum hunc modum.	 When you treat the fistula (lacrimal duct), and your treatment does not help as mentioned in the divisions of diseases, then it is necessary that you cauterize it using this method.
Praecipe infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo, et teneat caput eius minister inter manus suas taliter, ut non moueatur, neque agitetur cum capite suo.	 Command the patient to place his head in your lap and hold his head with one of your hands so that it is not moved or shaken along with his head.
Deinde pone Cotum infusum in albugine oui, aut in mucilagine psilii super oculum eius: deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma est haec.	 Then place the cotton soaked in alcohol or slime of comfrey on his eye, then with a hot cautery whose shape is as follows.
Sit concauum, sicut forma cannae pennae uulturis ab extremitate una, cum qua fit Cauterium: et si uis sit penetrans usque ad extremitatem aliam, et si uis sit sursum sic tenta.	 Be concave like the shape of a goose feather quill from one end, with which the cautery is made: and if you want it to penetrate up to the other end, or if you want it to be extended upward, it should be thus shaped.
Verumtamen hoc concauum est melius ad opus tuum.	 Nevertheless, this concave shape is better for your purpose.
Deinde exprime fistulam, si est aperta, et extrahe ex ea saniem, et exicca ipsam: et si non est aperta, tunc aperi eam, et extrahe pus eius.	 Then open the fistula if it is open and remove the pus from it, and cut it (the affected area): and if it is not open, then open it and remove the pus.
Deinde pone tunc super eam Cauterium, quod fit ignitum ualde.	 Then place the hot cautery on it.
Et tene cum eo manum tuam parumper apud Cauterium ab oculo, ad partem nasi, ut non erret manus tua, aut inquietetur infirmus: et ponas Cauterium in adipe oculi, et corrumpas ipsum.	 And hold your hand a little away from the cautery near the eye, by the nose, so that your hand does not slip or shake, and place the cautery on the fat of the eye and burn it.
Si ergo peruenis in principio Cauterii tui usque ad os, erit bene.	 If therefore you arrive at the beginning of your cautery until the bone, it will be well.
Et si non: tunc itera Cauterium semel, aut bis, si indiges illo: et dimitte illud tribus diebus.	 And if not: then repeat the cautery once, or twice if necessary; and leave it for three days.
Deinde pone Cotum cum butyro, et cura ipsum cum unguento exiccatiuo, donec sanetur.	 Then place a cotton with butter, and care for it with an incisive ointment, until it is healed.
Quod si praeterierint ei quadraginta dies, et non sanatur: tunc pone super ipsum medicinam acutam corrosiuam, donec detegatur os: et rade ipsum secundum quod uenit in capitulo suo.	 What if it passes beyond forty days and is not healed: then place a sharp corrosive medicine on it until the bone appears; and shave it according to what comes in its chapter.
Et est modus alius Cauterii fistulae, quem quidam primi dixerunt.	 And there is another way of cautery for a fistula, which some of the first said.
Intende ad locum fistulae, et finde ipsum: deinde pone in ipsam fissuram camahan subtile, id est, Cannulam subtilem, cuius forma haec est.	 Direct yourself to the place of the fistula, and pierce it; then put in it a fine cannula, that is, a thin cannula, whose shape is this.
Et funde in ipsum quantitatem drachmae ex plumbo liquefacto, et tene manum tuam cum Canna retentione bona, et non moueatur infirmus omnino, ut non currat, uel perueniat plumbum liquefactum ad oculum eius.	 And pour into it a quantity of drachmas made from melted lead, and hold your hand with good retention on the cannula, and do not move at all, so that the melted lead does not run or reach its eye.
Et oportet ut ponas super oculum infirmi cotum infusum in albumine oui, aut in aqua.	 And it is necessary that you put a hot cotton on the eye of the weak person, either in egg white or in water.
Plumbum enim comburit locum fistulae, et sanat ipsam sanatione mirabili.	 For lead burns the place of the fistula and heals it with a marvelous healing.
Quod si sanatur fistula, cum eo quod diximus ex Cauterio, et curatione, est bonum.	 If the fistula is healed with what we said from cautery and cure, it is good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est administrare foramen nasi, et reducere fistulam ad cursum nasi, secundum quod ueniet in loco suo sibi proprio.	 And if not, then it is necessary to administer a nostril hole, and lead the fistula to the nasal passage, according to what comes in its own place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fissuris Labiorum.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing in fissures of the lips.
Caput XX.	 Chapter XX (20).
Multotiens accidunt in Labio fissurae, quae nominantur Pili, et praecipue in labiis puerorum.	 Multiple splits occur in the Lip, which are called Hairs, and especially in the lips of children.
Cum ergo tu curas has fissuras, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio, tunc igni cauterium paruum cultellare, secundum hanc formam.	 When you treat these splits, as we have said in the division of diseases, and the treatment does not help, then apply small cautery with a knife, according to this shape.
Et sit concauitas eius secundum subtilitatem cultelli.	 And let its depression be according to the subtlety of the knife.
Deinde pone ipsum ignitum festinanter in ipsis fissuris, donec perueniat cauterium ad profundum fissurarum.	 Then place it [the heated tool] quickly into these splits, until the cautery reaches the depth of the splits.
Deinde cura ipsum cum caeroto, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with pitch, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fistula Oris.	 [Title] The method of cauterization in the Fistula of the Mouth.
Caput XXI.	 Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit apostema in radice gingiuae, aut in palato, aut in radicibus dentium: deinde facit pus, et rumpitur: postea antiquatur, et currit pus, et fit fistula: deinde curas ipsam, et non confert in ea curatio, tunc oportet ut ignias cauterium secundum quantitatem, quod capiat in fistula.	 When an abscess occurs at the root of the gum, or in the palate, or in the roots of the teeth: then it produces pus and bursts; afterwards it becomes old, and pus runs, and a fistula is formed: then treat this fistula, and the treatment does not help in it, then it is necessary that you apply heat to the cautery according to its size, which can enter into the fistula.
Deinde intromitte ipsum ignitum in foramine fistulae, et tene manum tuam, donec perueniat ferrum ignitum ad profundum eius, et ultimum eius: fac illud semel, aut duabus uicibus.	 Then insert the heated tool into the opening of the fistula, and hold your hand; until the iron becomes hot to its depth and end; do this once or twice.
Deinde cura ipsum post illud, cum eo quod diximus de curatione usquequo curetur.	 Then treat it after that, as we have said about treatment, until it is treated.
Si ergo abscinditur sanies, et sanatur, erit bonum.	 If the pus is cut off and healed, it will be good.
Et si non, tunc necesse est detegere locum, et auferre os corrupum secundum quod ueniet in capite suo.	 And if not, then it is necessary to remove the corrupted bone according to what comes out of its head.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Gingiuis, et Dentibus mollificatis.	 [Title] The method of cauterization on softened gums and teeth.
Caput XXII.	 Chapter XXII.
Quando mollificatur gingiua propter humiditates, et mouentur dentes, et curas eam cum medicinis, et non confert: tunc pone caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 When the gum softens due to moistures and teeth move, and care of it with medicines does not help: then place the head of the sick in your bosom.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius forma ueniet post haec, ita ut ponas Cannulam super dentem: et intromitte in ea Cauterium ignitum festinanter: et tene manum tuam parumper, donec sentiat infirmus calorem ignis iam peruenisse ad radicem dentis.	 Then apply fire to the cautery, whose form will come later, in such a way that you place the Cannula on the tooth and introduce into it the heated cautery quickly: hold your hand for a moment, until the sick person feels the warmth of the fire has reached the root of the tooth.
Et eleua manum tuam: deinde itera Cauterium aliquotiens, secundum quod uis.	 Then remove your hand: then repeat the cautery several times as you wish.
Deinde impleat infirmus os suum aqua salis, et teneat ipsam hora una: et exspuat ipsam.	 Then let the sick person fill his mouth with water and salt, and hold it for an hour: then spit it out.
Dens enim motus firmatur, et gingiua mollificata stringitur, et siccatur humiditas corrupta.	 For the tooth moved hardens, and softened gums contract, and dryness sets in to corrupt moisture.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in dolore Dentium.	 Chapter on the method of cauterizing tooth pain.
Caput XXIII.	 Chapter XXIII.
Quando dolor dentis est propter frigiditatem, aut in ipso est frigus, aut uermis, et non confert curatio cum medicinis: tunc Cauterium in ipso est secundum duos modos: aut Cauterium cum butyro: aut cauterium cum igne.	 When the tooth pain is due to coldness or has coldness itself, or worms, and care with medicines does not help: then apply cautery in it according to two modes: either cautery with butter; or cautery with fire.
Cauterium autem eius cum butyro est, ut accipias butyrum uaccinum, et bullias ipsum in cochleari ferreo, aut in uenera.	 The cautery with butter is such that you receive fresh butter, and heat it in an iron cauldron or in a ewer.
Deinde accipe cotum, et inuolue ipsum super extremitatem tentae.	 Then take the bag and turn it over the end of the wound.
Deinde submerge ipsum in butyro bullito: et pone ipsum super dentem dolorosum festinanter, et tene ipsum donec infrigidet: deinde itera ipsum aliquotiens, donec perueniat uirtus ignis ad radicem dentis.	 Submerge it into boiling butter and place it quickly on the painful tooth and hold it until it cools; then repeat this process several times until the heat of the fire reaches the root of the tooth.
Et si uis, submerge lanam, aut cotum in butyro frigido, et pone ipsum super dentem dolentem: et pone super ipsum ferrum ignitum, donec perueniat ignis ad profundum concauitatis dentis.	 If desired, immerse wool or cloth in cold butter and place it on the painful tooth; then place a heated iron on it until the heat reaches the depth of the cavity of the tooth.
Cauterizatio autem eius cum igne est, ut intendas ad cannulam aeris, aut cannulam ferri.	 Cauterization with fire is to prepare a copper or iron tube (cannula).
Et sit in corpore eius quiddam grossitudinis, ut non perueniat acuitas ignis ad os infirmi.	 Let there be something bulky in the body so that the sharp heat does not reach the weak bone.
Deinde igni Cauterium, cuius forma ueniet: et pone ipsum super illum dentem: et tene manum tuam, donec infrigidetur Cauterium.	 Then apply fire to the cautery whose form will come; place it on the tooth and hold your hand until it cools.
Fac illud aliquotiens, nam dolor remouebitur, aut in illo eodem die, aut die alio.	 Repeat this several times, as pain will subside either on the same day or another day.
Et oportet in impressione illius Cauterii, ut impleat infirmus os suum buyro bono, et teneat ipsum hora una: deinde exspuat ipsum.	 It is necessary to fill the weakened bone with good butter and hold it for an hour; then spit it out.
Et haec est forma Cauterii.	 This is the form of the cautery.
Cauteriza cum quacumque extremitate uis secundum quod est possibile: et haec est forma Cannulae.	 Cauterize with whatever shape you desire, provided it is possible; and this is the form of the cannula (tube).
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Strophulis.	 Chapter on how to cauterize ulcers.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter 24.
Quando Strophulae sunt a phlegmate, et ab humiditatibus frigidis, et non sunt obedientes digestioni per mecicinas, et uis digestionem earum uelociter: tunc igni Cauterium concauum, cuius forma est haec.	 When worms are from phlegm, and from cold moistness, and do not obey digestion by medicines, and desire digestion quickly: then to a concave cautery, whose shape is this.
Habens duas extremitates apertas, ut egrediatur fumus apud Cauterium ab extremitate altera: et pone ipsum ignitum super ipsum apostema semel, et secundo, si indiges illo, donec perueniat ad profundum apostematis.	 Having two open extremities, so that the smoke may leave at the other end of the cautery: and place it heated above the ulcer once, and a second time, if necessary, until it reaches the depth of the ulcer.
Quod si apostema est paruum: tunc pone Cauterium secundum quantitatem apostematis.	 If the ulcer is small: then place the cautery according to the size of the ulcer.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super ipsum cotum infusum in butyro, donec remoueatur quod combussit ignis.	 Then let it be for three days, and place on it a cup full of butter heated, until what the fire has burned is removed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento dentis, donec sanetur forma cannulae.	 Then care for it with tooth ointment, until the canal heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in raucedine uocis, et constrictione anhelitus.	 On the mode of cauterizing in swelling of voice, and constriction of breathing.
Caput XXV.	 Chapter XXV.
Quando uincunt humiditates super cannale pulmonis, et praecipue quando illud est cum frigiditate complexionis, tunc oportet ut euacuetur infirmus in primis cum medicinis solutiuis.	 When moisture accumulates on the bronchial tube of the lung, and especially when it is accompanied by cold constitution, then it is necessary that the ill person first be evacuated with soluble medicines.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum in nocrati apud radicem gutturis in loce depresso: et caue, ne peruenias cum Cauterio ad guttur, neque in cute, nisi quiddam eius.	 Then cauterize it at the nose at the root of the throat in a hollow place: and be careful not to reach with the cautery at the throat, nor on the skin, unless something of that part is present.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum cauterio alio apud iuncturam colli in ultimo spondili eius ultimando: et sit Cauterium clauile secundum modum, qui praecessit.	 Then cauterize it with another cautery at the junction of the neck near the last vertebra of that joint: and let the cautery be small according to the manner which was mentioned earlier.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with what has been mentioned before, until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	 On the mode of cauterizing in diseases of the lungs and cough.
Caput XXVI.	 Chapter XXVI.
