Deinde pone in ignem cauteria oliuaria parua, et magna numero plura: et suffla super ea, donec fiant ignita ualde.	 Then place a small olive oil-coated cautery in the fire and many more of them; blow on it until they are lit very well.
Deinde accipe ex eis unum, aut paruum, aut magnum, secundum uulnus et locum, in quo disrupta est arteria, et depone cauterium super ipsam uenam, post quam tu remoues digitum tuum festinanter: et tene cauterium, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Then take one of them, small or large, depending on the wound and the location where the artery has been torn; place the cautery over the vein and then remove your finger quickly; hold the cautery until the blood is cut off.
Quod si expellatur cum eleuas digitum ab orificio arteriae, et extinguis cauterium, tunc accipe cauterium aliud festinanter, ex cauteriis quae in igne sunt praeparata.	 If it is expelled with the finger from the opening of an artery, and the cautery is extinguished, then take another cautery hastily, from those that are prepared in fire.
Non ergo cesses facere illud cum uno post aliud, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Therefore do not cease to do that (the procedure) one after the other, until the blood is cut off.
Et caue, ne comburas neruum qui est illic, et accidat super infirmum malicia alia.	 And beware lest you burn the nerve which is there, and another harm befalls the patient.
Et scias, quod quando ex arteria fluit sanguis, tunc non est possibile abscindere ipsum: praecipue quaudo arteria est magna, nisi cum uno quatuor modorum.	 And know that when blood flows from an artery, then it is not possible to cut it (the artery); especially because the artery is large, unless with one of four methods.
Aut cum cauterio, sicut diximus.	 Or with a cautery, as we have said.
Aut cum extractione, quando non est extracta.	 Or with extraction, when it has not been extracted.
Nam quando extrahitur, contrahuntur extremitates eius, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For when it (the artery) is drawn out, the ends are contracted, and the blood is cut off.
Aut ligetur cum filo ligatione forti.	 Or it is tied with a strong thread.
Aut ponantur super ipsum medicinae de proprietate, quarum est abscindere sanguinem, et stringatur cum puluinari constrictione decenti.	 Or medicines of the property for cutting off blood are placed upon it (the artery), and it is squeezed with a proper ligature.
Qui autem administrat abscisionem eius cum ligamento, et strictura cum panno, aut positione rerum comburentium, et similium, non confert ei penitus, nisi raro.	 Whoever administers the cutting off (of the artery) with a ligature and compression with a cloth, or placing of burning things and similar items, does not completely restore him (the patient), unless rarely.
Si autem accidat alicui illud, et non sit ei praesens medicus, neque medicina: tunc incipiat cum positione digiti indicis super orificium uenae ipsius, sicut narrauimus, et constrictione eius ualde, donec obsessus sit sanguis a superiori parte uulneris, et super arteriam.	 If that (the procedure) should happen to anyone and the physician is not present nor medicine: then let him begin with the position of the index finger over the opening of the vein itself, as we have said, and with very strong compression, until the blood is obstructed from the superior part of the wound, and on the artery.
Et digitus non remoueatur, desuper ipsum cum aqua frigida uehementis frigoris semper, donec congeletur sanguis, et ingrossetur, et abscindatur.	 And let the finger not be removed from above it (the artery) with cold water of violent coldness always, until the blood is frozen, thickened and cut off.
Et interim consideret in eo, quid indiget ex cauterio, aut ex medicina.	 And meanwhile let him consider in it (the wound) what requires a cautery or medicine.
¶ Partis Primae Finis.	 First Part's End.
Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars II.	 Book of Surgery by Albucasis Part II.
¶ De Incisione, Perforatione, et Phlebotomia in uulneribus, et his similibus.	 On Incision, Perforation, and Phlebotomy in Wounds, and Such Like Things.
Iam Diximus in Capitulo Primo, omnem aegritudinem in qua conueniens est cum igne cauterium et medicina comburente, et occasiones eius, ipsius caussas, et instrumenta eius, et formas cauteriorum.	 As we have said in the first chapter, every illness where cautery with fire and burning medicine is suitable, its occasions, causes, instruments, and forms of cauteries.
Et posui illic capitula a uertice usque ad pedem.	 And I set there chapters from the neck down to the feet.
Et ego procedam in hoc capitulo illa eadem uia: ut alleuietur super quaerentem quaesitum eius.	 And I shall proceed in this chapter along the same path, so that what is sought may be clarified for those who seek it.
Et antequam incipiam illud, oportet ut addiscatis o filii, quod in hoc capitulo est ex terrore illud quod est in capitulo primo de cauterizatione.	 And before I begin that (discussion), you sons must know what is in this chapter from the fear which was mentioned in the first chapter about cautery.
Et propter illud oportet, ut sit cautela in eo uehementior, quoniam in operatione quae est in hoc capitulo, multotiens cadit euacuatio cum sanguine, cum quo stat uita apud apertionem uenae, aut incisionem super apostema, aut apertionem exiturae, aut curationem uulneris, aut extractionem sagittae, aut incisionem super lapidem, et illis similia: ex quibus omnibus associatur tremor, et timor, et cadit in pluribus eorum mors.	 And for this reason it is necessary that there be a greater caution in this, because in the operation which is in this chapter, evacuation often falls with blood, with which life stands at the opening of a vein or incision on an abscess, or the opening of a wound, or treatment of wounds, or extraction of arrows, or incision on a stone, and such like: from all of which is associated tremor, fear, and death occurs in many cases.
Et ego moneo uos, ne cadat super uos illud in quo est haesitatio, nam quandoque cadunt ad uos in hac arte modi hominum cum modis infirmitatum.	 And I warn you that it does not happen to you what is hesitant, for sometimes men of this art fall into your hands like weak ones.
Ex eis enim est qui irascitur cum aegritudine sua, et est leuis apud eum mors: propter uehementiam eius quod inuenit ex infirmitate sua et longitudine eius maliciei.	 For there is one who gets angry with his illness, and death is easy for him because of the intensity he finds from weakness and the length of his wickedness.
Et cum aegritudine est ex timore quod significat mortem.	 And when it comes from fear, it signifies death.
Et ex eis est, qui dat tibicensum suum, et ditat te cum eo, sperans sanitatem, et aegritudo eius est perniciosa.	 And there is one who gives his guaranty and pays you along with it, hoping for health, but his illness is fatal.
Non ergo oportet ut consentiatis ei qui uenit ad uos ex eis, cuius modus est talis.	 Therefore, it is not appropriate that you agree with him who comes to you from those whose method is such.
Et sit cautela uestra uehementior, quam cupiditas et uestra rapacitas.	 Let your caution be more intense than your greed and rapacity.
Et non praesumatis super aliquid ex illo, nisi post scientiam certam, quae uerificat apud uos illud ad quod peruenit successio laudabilis.	 And do not presume about anything from it unless after certain knowledge which verifies at your place the successful outcome.
Et utimini in curatione omnium infirmorum uestrorum, prognosticatione et indicatione de eo ad quod conuenienter sit salus.	 And in treating all your sick people, make prognosis and indication concerning that which is appropriately healthy.
In illo namque est uobis adiutorium super acquisitionem famae et gloriae, et memoriae et laudis.	 For there is help for you in the acquisition of fame and glory, as well as memory and praise.
Inspiret uobis Deus o filii, intellectum suum, et non auferat uobis directionem et inspirationem: quoniam illud est in manu eius.	 May God inspire you, O sons, with His understanding, and may He not remove from you guidance and inspiration, for that is in His hand.
Et ego quidem ordinaui hoc Capitulum distinguendo per capitula, secundum quod praecessit in capitulo Cauterii, a ceruice usque ad pedes: ut alleuietur uobis quaesitum quod uultis ex eo, et quo indigetis.	 And I myself have arranged this chapter by dividing it into sections according to what preceded in the chapter on Cautery, from neck to feet: so that you may be relieved of what is sought from it and what you need.
¶ De curatione Aquae quae aggregatur in capitibus puerorum.	 Chapter on Treating Water That Gathers in Children's Heads.
Caput I.	 Section I.
Scias, quod haec infirmitas multotiens accidit pueris apud partum: aut quando stringit obstetrix caput pueri absque leuitate.	 Know that this weakness frequently occurs in children during childbirth: or when the midwife tightens the child's head without ease.
Et quandeque accidit etiam ex caussa occulta quae non scitur.	 And it sometimes happens due to an unknown cause which is not known.
Et ego quidem non uidi hanc aegritudinem in aliis quam in pueris: et ad omnem quem ex eis uidi properauit mors: propter illud ergo uisum est mihi dimittere operationem in ea.	 And indeed, I have not seen this illness in others than children; and death approached every one of them whom I saw from them; therefore it seemed to me that the operation should be avoided in it.
Et ego quidem uidi ex eis puerum, cuius caput impletum erat aqua, et caput magnificabatur in omni die, donec non poterat sedere super seipsum, propter magnitudinem capitis sui: et humiditas augmentata fuit, donec mortuus est.	 And indeed, I have seen a child whose head was full of water and his head grew great every day until he could not sit on himself due to the size of his head; and the moisture increased until he died.
Et haec quidem humiditas, aut aggregatur inter cutem et os: aut aggregatur sub osse super sifac.	 And this moisture, indeed, either collects between the skin and bone; or it collects under the bone above the brow ridge.
Et operatio in illo, si est humiditas inter cutem et os, et apostema est paruum, tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis fissura una in latitudine: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo nodi, donec currat humiditas.	 And the operation on it, if there is moisture between the skin and bone, and the abscess is small, then it is necessary to make a fissure in the middle of the head, one opening wide; and let the length of the fissure be like two knuckles, until the moisture runs out.
Et haec est forma spatumilis.	 And this is the form of trephining (spatumilis).
Si ergo humiditas est magis augmentata, et apostema est maius, tunc pone eas duas fissuras, secundum formam hanc.	 If therefore the moisture is more increased, and the abscess is larger, then place two fissures, according to this form (trephining).
Et si humiditas est sub osse, et signum eius est, quod uides commissuras capitis apertas ab omni parte: et aqua deprimitur quando comprimis eam manu tua ad interiora, et non occultatur tibi illud: tunc oportet ut findas in medio capitis tribus fissuris, secundum hunc modum.	 And if the moisture is under the bone, and there is a sign of it, which you see that the joints of the head are open everywhere; and water sinks when you press it with your hand to the inside, and it does not hide from you; then it is necessary to make three fissures in the middle of the head, according to this method.
Et post incisionem extrahe humiditatem totam.	 And after the incision, extract all the moisture.
Deinde stringe fissuras cum pannis et puluillis.	 Then tighten the fissures with bandages and lints.
Deinde embroca illud desuper cum uino et oleo usque ad diem quintum.	 Then pour oil and wine over it until the fifth day.
Deinde solue ligamentum, et cura uulnus cum tentis, et unguentis.	 Then cut the ligament, and care for the wound with sutures and ointments.
Et non dimittas stringere caput cum aequalitate.	 And do not let the head be bound equally.
Et ciba infirmum omni cibo sicco paucae humiditatis, usquequo confortetur membrum, et sanetur.	 Feed the sick man with dry food of little moisture until the limb recovers and heals.
Et modus alius incisionis est, ut consideres ubi apparet magnitudo apostematis, et collectio aquae.	 Another method of incision is to consider where the size of the abscess appears, and collection of water.
Quoniam quandoque est in occipitio plus, aut in sincipite, aut in dextra, aut in sinistra.	 Because sometimes it is more in the skull, or in the forehead, or on the right, or on the left.
Ascende ergo cum incisione ubi apparet tibi apostema et impletio aquae: et scinde illud secundum quod tibi possibile est.	 Therefore, with the incision, go where you see the abscess and filled water: and cut it as much as possible for you.
Et obserua, ne incidas arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis, et moriatur infirmus ex illo fluxu cum euacuatione humiditatis.	 And observe that you do not cut the artery and cause a blood flow, and let the sick man die from this flow along with the evacuation of moisture.
¶ De incisione Arteriarum quae sunt post aures.	 [Section heading] On incisions of arteries after the ears.
Caput II.	 Chapter II.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri ad oculos, aut ad pectus, et antiquatur illud, et non confert curatio medicinarum: tunc magis ultima curatio est in illo, incisio harum duarum arteriarum.	 When someone suffers from catarrhs on the eyes or chest and it becomes chronic and does not improve with medical treatment: then the final cure is more in him, incision of these two arteries.
Oportet ergo quando uis incidere eas, ut radat infirmus caput suum.	 Therefore, when one wishes to make an incision there (on the affected area), let him shave his head.
Deinde frica locum cum panno aspero, ut appareant arteriae.	 Then rub the place with a rough cloth, so that the arteries appear.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum, cum quolibet panno suo.	 Then let him tighten his neck with any of his cloths.
Deinde considera, ubi pulset uena.	 Then observe where the vein pulses.
Et loca utriusque sunt loca quae sunt post aures depressa: et raro occultatur, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 And these places are places that are depressed behind the ears: and they are rarely hidden except in some men.
Deinde signa cum encaustro super utraque: et incide utramque cum spatumili utrimque acuro, incisione perueniente ad os: et fiat illud per latitudinem capitis.	 Then mark both with pitch (or wax): and make an incision on both sides with a spatula or sharp tool, the incision reaching the bone: and let it be done along the width of the head.
Et si uis, intromitte spatumile sub arteria, et incide eam ad superiora cum incisione.	 And if one wishes, introduce the spatula under the artery, and make an incision upward with the incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quasi duo digiti iuncti.	 Let the length of the incision be like two fingers joined together.
Nam quando inciditur uena, egreditur sanguis egressione pulsatili, qui salit ad interiora saltu frequenti.	 For when an artery is cut, blood comes out with a pulsating flow, which leaps to the interior with frequent jumps.
Si autem arteria non apparet sensui, tunc oportet ut mensures ab aure quantitatem spacii trium digitorum.	 If, however, the artery does not appear to the senses, then it is necessary that measurements from the ear determine the size of three fingers' space.
Deinde signa cum encaustro, et finde usque ad os.	 Then mark both with pitch (or wax) and make an incision up to the bone.
Et illud quod oportet emittere ex sanguine, est VI uncia et fortasse emittis ex eo plus, aut minus.	 And what must be released from the blood is about 6 ounces, and you may possibly release more or less from it.
Totum illud secundum quantitatem quae apparet tibi ex uirute infirmi et repletione arteriae eius.	 All of this according to the quantity that appears to you from the strength of the disease and the filling of its artery.
Deinde considera ad uulnus.	 Then observe at the wound.
Tunc si remanet ad os ex sifac aliquid, tunc incide illud, ut non accidat apostema calidum: tunc stringe uulnus cum liciniis ex panno lini.	 Then if there remains any of the flesh at the bone, then cut it so that a hot abscess does not occur: then tighten the wound with linen rags.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then care for him with an ointment until he is healed.
¶ De extractione arteriarum, quae sunt in timporibus.	 On the extraction of arteries that are in the temples.
Caput III.	 Chapter III.
Quando accidit homini hemicranea antiqua, aut catarri acuti propter humiditates acrimoniales, et caliditate in lacertis timporum, aut soda antiqua, uehemens, et similia illis: et medicatur cum modis curationis medicinae, et non confert illud: tunc experti sumus in his aegritudinibus extractionem arteriarum ex timporibus, aut cauterizationem earum, sicut narrauimus.	 When an old hemiplegia or acute catarrh due to acidic humoral excess and heat in the neck muscles, or an old sclerosis, violent, and similar conditions occur in a man, and it is treated with methods of medication, but there is no improvement: then we have experience in dealing with such diseases by extracting arteries from the neck or cauterizing them, as we have said.
Et modus operationis in extractione earum, est, ut radat infirmus pilos qui sunt in timporibus, et intendat ad arteriam apparentem in timpore.	 The method of operation for extracting them (arteries) is as follows: shave the sick hairs that are on the neck, and stretch to the visible artery in the neck.
Ipsa namque ostenditur tibi ex pulsu suo, et raro occultatur nisi in paucis hominibus, aut uehementia frigoris.	 It is indeed evident to you by its pulse and rarely hidden except in a few men or in case of violent coldness.
Quod si occultatur tibi, tunc stringat infirmus caput suum cum quolibet panno suo: deinde frica locum cum panno aspero.	 If it is hidden to you, then let the sick person tighten his head with any cloth of his own and then rub the place with a rough cloth.
Aut uapora locum cum aqua calida, donec appareat tibi apparitione manifesta.	 Or apply heat to the place with warm water until it appears clearly to you.
Deinde accipe spatumile, quod paulo ante formaui.	 Then take the spatula that I have prepared earlier.
Deinde excoria cum eo cutem cum facilitate, donec peruenias ad arteriam.	 Then scrape the skin with it (the spatula) easily until you reach the artery.
Deinde proiice in eam uncinum, et extrahe eam ad superiora, donec extrahas eam ex cute, et facias eam euadere ex tunicis quae sunt sub ea ab omni parte.	 Then plunge a hook into it (the artery) and pull it upwards until you extract it from the skin, and make it escape from all sides from the layers beneath it.
Si autem arteria est subtilis: tunc inuolue eam cum extremitate uncini.	 If the artery is fine: then insert the tip of the hook into it.
Deinde incide ex ea partem secundum quantitatem qua elongentur extremitates eius, et contrahantur, et non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 Then cut off that portion according to its length where the ends are extended and contracted so as not to cause bleeding.
Nam si non inciditur, et si non abscinditur, non ascendit sanguis penitus.	 For if it is not cut and not separated, blood does not rise deep inside.
Deinde euacua ex sanguine ana VI unci, usque ad .III.	 Then evacuate the blood to six ounces up to three-quarters.
Quod si arteria est magna: tunc oportet ut liges eam in duobus locis ex filo duplo, forti, ex serico: aut ex chordis alhohod, ut non properet ad ipsam putrefactio ante consolidationem uulneris, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 If the artery is large: it must be tied in two places with strong double thread, silk or catgut, or with a twisted linen strip, so that decay does not occur near it before the wound heals and bleeding occurs.
Deinde incide superfluitatem, quae est inter duo ligamenta.	 Then cut the excess, which is between two ligaments.
Fac illud in illa hora, aut post horam aliam.	 Do this at that hour, or after another hour.
Et si uis, cauteriza eam cauterio usque ad os, cum cauterio cultellari: donec incidantur extremitates eius, et stabit loco eiusdem operis.	 And if you wish, cauterize it with a cautery up to the bone, with a small cautery: until its ends are cut and it remains in place for that same operation.
Et est melius opus, nisi si infirmus habet febrem, autest calefactae complexionis.	 It is better work unless if the patient has fever, or has a warm constitution.
Quoniam cauterium est ex eis, quae iuuant ad finiendas humiditates.	 Because the cautery is from those things that help to end moisture.
Ergo est melius iuuamentum.	 Therefore it is better treatment.
Et oportet post extractionem arteriarum, ut impleatur locus cotto antiquo: et ponantur super ipsum puluilli decenter facti.	 And after the removal of the artery, it is necessary that the place be filled with cooked clay from ancient times; and little balls made of clay should be placed on top of it.
Et post solutionem curetur cum medicinis siccis, quae faciunt nasci carnem, et cum liciniis, donec sanetur.	 And after the solution, it will be cleaned with dry medications that promote growth of flesh, and with linen cloths until it heals.
Quod si interim dum operaris accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, tunc propera ad abscindendum eum cum cauterio, aut ut impleas locum cum zegi: et stringe manum tuam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If during the operation bleeding occurs from the artery, then hasten to cut it with a cautery, or to fill the place with wax; and press your hand until the blood stops flowing.
Quod si nihil ex illis est tibi praesens, tunc pone super locum digitum tuum, donec congeletur sanguis.	 If nothing from these is present to you, then place your finger on the place until the blood freezes.
Et embroca locum cum aqua uehementis frigoris, donec quiescat acuitas, et stringatur secundum quod oportet.	 And pack the place with water of intense cold, until the pain subsides and it is tied as necessary.
Et ex eo quod est leuius et facilius extractione arteriae, est, ut cauterizes uenam cum hoc cauterio habente duos cultellos: sitque acuitas duorum cultellorum similis almagdatem.	 And because the vein is lighter and easier to remove, it is to be cauterized with this cautery having two small blades; and the sharpness of the two blades should resemble a lancet.
Verumtamen sunt multo minoris acuitatis, quam duo cultelli.	 Nevertheless, they are much less sharp than two knives.
Quoniam si sunt acutae, sicut duo cultelli, properat utrisque frigus: et non incidunt carnem cum uelocitate.	 Because if they are sharp like two knives, cold is needed for both of them; and they do not cut flesh with speed.
Cum ergo in eis est aliquantulum grossitudinis, tenetur in eis calor ignis, et abscinditur caro uelociter: cum hoc ergo opus est melius omni opere, et leuius, et facilius.	 Since there is a certain thickness in them, heat from fire must be held within them and the flesh is cut quickly; therefore this work is better than any other, and lighter, and easier.
Et sit spacium quod est inter duos cultellos quantitas grossitudinis digiti, postquam tu signas duo loca cum encaustro: et depone utrosque ignitos ualde, donec perueniant ad os, et incidant uenam in duobus locis: ut elongetur quod est inter extremitates eius.	 And let the space between two knives be the thickness of a finger, after you mark two places with hot iron; and place both heated ones until they reach the bone, and cut the vein in two places: so that what is between its ends can be removed.
Nam non consolidantur cum hoc cauterio penitus.	 They do not coagulate completely with this cautery.
Et haec est forma cauterii.	 And this is the form of the cautery.
¶ De cura cursus lachrymarum acutarum assiduarum ab oculis.	 Chapter on the care of sharp, frequent epiphora from the eyes.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Quando sunt lachrymae assiduae, et est cursus earum ex uenis, quae sunt super craneum capitis exterius: et non confert in eis aliquid curationis medicinae cum medicinis, et uides faciem infirmi iam rubere, et sentit in fronte sua deambulationem, sicut est deambulatio formicarum: et oculi eius sunt extenuati, humidi, ita quod iam corrosi sunt pili eorum cum corrosione: et calefactae sunt palpebrae eius ex acuitate lachrymarum: tunc antiqui indiguerunt in curatione earum hac operatione, et denominauerunt eam curationem, cum Ense.	 When the tears are frequent and the flow is from veins on the outside of the skull; and no medicine for their cure is applied to them with medicines; and you see the face of the sick already reddening, and he feels a wandering in his forehead like the wandering of ants; and his eyes are weakened, wet, so that the hairs of them have already been corroded by corrosion; and the eyelids have been heated by the acuity of the tears: then the ancients used this operation for their cure, and they named it treatment with the sword.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere pilos qui sunt in fronte sua.	 And it is to be ordered that the sick person should shave the hairs on his forehead.
Deinde incide in fronte tres fissuras aequedistantes secundum longitudinem frontis: et sit longitudo fissurae quasi duo digiti, et fissura una sit aequedistans longitudini nasi in medio frontis, et secunda secundum longitudinem parumper a motu lacertorum, et tertia a parte altera: et caue ab incisione arteriarum quae sunt in duobus lateribus: et elonga manum tuam a continuatione duarum mandibularum, et sit spacium omnis incisionis quantitas trium digitorum coniunctorum: et sit tibi frustum spongiae praeparatum, aut panni siccati multi, cum quibus exsicces sanguinem.	 Then make three cuts in the forehead, equal in length to the forehead; and let the length of the cut be about two fingers, and one cut should be in the middle of the forehead, and the second, a little below the movement of the arms, and the third on the opposite side: and avoid cutting the arteries that are on both sides; and extend your hand from the continuation of the lower jaws, and let the entire length of the cut be the size of three connected fingers: and prepare for yourself a piece of sponge or dry cloth with which to squeeze the blood.
Deinde intromitte spatumile duarum acutarum extremitatum, cuius mox sequens est forma.	 Then insert a double-ended probe (spatula) with sharp tips, which follows its shape immediately.
Ab incisione quae est a parte timporis, usque ad incisionem secundam: et excoria cum eo totam cutem, quae est inter duas incisiones, cum sifac, quod est super os.	 From the first incision that is on the side of the temple, until the second incision: and excise with it all the skin that is between the two incisions, along with the sifak (sinus frontalis) that is above the eye.
Deinde fac illud etiam ab incisione media usque ad incisionem secundam.	 Then do the same from the central incision until the second incision.
Deinde extrahe hoc spatumile, et intromitte in incisionem primam iterum instrumentum aliud, quod nominatur cultellare acutum, ab una parte lene, non acutum ab altera parte.	 Then extract this probe and insert into the first incision another tool called a sharp scalpel, blunt on one side but not on the other.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Et pone latus eius acutum uersus carnem annexam cum cute, et latus eius lene uersus os: et impelle ipsum, donec perueniat ad fissuram mediam: et abscinde cum eo omnia uasa, quae descendunt a capite ad oculos: praeter quod continuetur incisio usque ad illud quod apparet de cute.	 And position its sharp side towards the attached flesh with skin and its blunt side towards the bone; push it in until it reaches the midline, and cut with it all vessels that descend from the head to the eyes, except where the incision continues until it appears on the skin.
Deinde fac illud in fissura media usque ad fissuram aliam.	 Then do this along the midline up to another fissure (incision).
Et postquam currit ex sanguine quantitas aequalis, exprime loca ex frustis sanguinis coagulati.	 And when an equal amount of blood has flowed out, squeeze the places from the clotted blood fragments.
Deinde pone in omnem fissuram licinium ex cotto ueteri, et pone super eos puluillos imbibitos in uino, et oleo, aut aceto.	 Then put a linen cloth soaked in old oil (or wine or vinegar) into every incision and cover them with small pieces of wool soaked in water, oil, or vinegar.
Et uide ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 And be careful not to cause a hot abscess (infection).
Et in die tertia solue ligamentum, et administra infusionem multam cum aqua tepida.	 On the third day, loosen the bandage and administer a large infusion with warm water.
Deinde cura illud ex unguento basilicon, et reliquis quibus curantur uulnera: usquequo sanetur.	 Then treat it with basilicon ointment and the other ointments used to heal wounds until it heals.
¶ De cura lachrymarum acutarum et catarrorum ad oculos ex interioribus capitis.	 Chapter on the treatment of acute tears (eye discharge) and catarrhs of the eyes from within the skull.
Caput V.	 Chapter 5.
Quando accidunt alicui catarri acuti, acres, assidui: et uides oculos eius extenuatos, paruos, et iam debilitatus est aspectus eorum: et palpebrae ulceratae, et cadunt pili ex eis, et in profundo capitis est dolor acutus, laedens, et sternutatio consequens: tunc sume ex istis accidentibus, quod illae materiae, et catarri non ueniunt, nisi ex uenis multis.	 When someone experiences acute and intense catarrhs or tears that are persistent, you see their eyes weakened, small, and their appearance is already debilitated; and their eyelids are ulcerated, hairs fall out from them, and there is a sharp pain deep within the skull, which causes sneezing; then take action on these symptoms when this happens, because those substances and catarrhs do not come unless from many veins.
Et melior curatio in eis est haec.	 A better treatment for them is this.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo radere frontem suam.	 And it should be ordered that the sick person shave his forehead.
Deinde incide in eam fissuram unam in medio frontis, aut alterius parumper per latitudinem, et incipe cum fissura a timpore sinistro ad timpus dextrum: et sit incisio usque ad os: et elonga manum tuam a lacertis timporum, qui mouentur apud masticationem: donec quando detegitur os: et exsiccabis totum sanguinem cum spongia.	 Then make one incision in the middle of the forehead, or slightly to one side, and begin with the incision from the left temple to the right temple; let the incision go as far as the bone; and move your hand away from the temples which move during chewing, until the bone is exposed; then dry up all the blood with a sponge.
Tunc separa inter duo labia fissurae cum cotto ueteri, aut cum liciniis ex lino.	 Then separate the fissure between the two lips with a spatula or with flax from linen.
Deinde stringe desuper cum puluillis: et imbibe puluillos cum uino et oleo, ut non accidat apostema calidum.	 Then bind it above with thread; and dip the threads in wine and oil, so that no hot abscess occurs.
Et quando soluis illud, et uides quod apostema calidum iam imminuitur: tunc oportet ut frices os, donec incipiat in eo nasci caro.	 And when you release it, and see that the abscess is about to burst; then it is necessary to fracture the bone, until flesh begins to grow in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum regimine exiccatiuo quod facit nasci carnem: sicut si accipias ex farina tritici partes duas, et ex colophonia quatuor partes: et praepares ex eis emplastrum, et administretur ad natiuitatem carnis in istis uulneribus.	 Then treat the person with a drying regimen that makes flesh grow; as if you were to take two parts of wheat flour and four parts of colophony; and prepare a plaster from them, and administer it for the growth of flesh in these wounds.
¶ De cura eius quod cadit in Aurem.	 Chapter on the care of an ear wound.
Caput VI.	 Chapter 6.
Omne Quod in Aurem cadit, est una quatuor specierum: aut lapis mineralis, aut simile lapidi, sicut ferrum, et uitrum: aut est ex planta, sicut est cicer, et fabae: aut est res fluxibilis, sicut aqua, et acetum, et eis similia: aut aliquod animal.	 Everything that falls into the ear is one of four kinds: either a mineral stone, or something like a stone, such as iron and wood; or it is from a plant, such as chickpeas and beans; or it is fluid, such as water, vinegar, and similar substances; or it is some animal.
Quando ergo cadit in aurem lapis, aut genus lapidis ex eis quae non adduntur, neque crescunt in aure, expone Aurem soli: si ergo uides lapidem, tunc distilla in Aurem aliquid ex oleo uiolato, aut sisamino.	 When a stone or something like a stone falls into the ear, which does not grow in the ear, lay open the ear; if you see the stone, then pour some oil of roses or sesame into the ear.
Deinde administra extractionem eius, et fac sternutare cum condisi, et opila nares apud aduentum sternutationis, postquam tu ponis in circumitu auris frusta ex pannis, aut lana, et extendis aurem ad superiora.	 Then administer the extraction and make it cause sneezing with powder, and insert oil at the nostrils during sneezing; after you place in the ear's edge fragments from cloth or wool, and stretch the ear upward.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum hac cura.	 For many times, it goes out with this care.
Si autem non egreditur, tunc administra extractionem eius cum Gesti, id est, Pizigarolis subtilibus: cuius forma est haec.	 If it does not come out, then administer the extraction with Geppi, that is, finely-powdered pigeon droppings; whose shape is as follows.
Si ergo egreditur cum gesti, est bonum.	 If therefore it comes out with Geppi, it is good.
Et si non, tunc administra extractionem eius cum uncino caeco subtili paucae duplicationis.	 And if not, then administer the extraction with a finely-sharpened blind hook in small doses.
Si ergo non egreditur per illud, tunc fac cannulam ex aere, et intromitte extremitatem cannulae in foramen auris multum, et opila quod est in circumitu cannulae cum caera mollificata cum oleo, ut non sit uento uia nisi cannulae: deinde extrahe cum uento tuo attractione forti.	 If therefore it does not come out by that, then make a cannula of bronze and insert the end of the cannula into the ear's hole as much as possible; and insert what is in the circumference of the cannula with softened wax mixed with oil, so that there is no path for wind but the cannula; then draw it out with your strong attraction of wind.
Multotiens enim egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus.	 For many times, it comes out by what we have said.
Si autem non egreditur hoc modo: tunc accipe ex helkalimbat, aut ex uisco, id est, gluten praeparato, cum quo capiuntur aues, rem modicam: et pone ipsum in extremitate radii postquam tu inuoluis super eam cotum decenter positum: deinde intromitte ipsum in foramen auris cum facilitate, postquam tu exiccas aurem ab humiditate.	 If it does not come out by this method, then take from helkalimbat or from vinegar (that is, prepared gluten), a small amount; and place it at the end of the radius after you have placed a well-centered piece on top of it; then insert it into the ear's hole with ease, after you have removed the ear from humidity.
Si ergo non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc propera ad scindendum, antequam accidat apostema calidum, aut spasmus.	 If therefore it does not come out by all that we have said, then hurry to cut it before a hot abscess or spasm occurs.
Et modus fissurae est, ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis in cephalica: et extrahe ei ex sanguine secundum mensuram uirtutis eius.	 And the method of cutting is that a lancet is applied first to the head; and draw blood from it according to its power.
Deinde fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et conuerte aurem eius ad superiora, et finde fissuram paruam in radice auris apud adipem eius in loco depresso ipsi: et sit fissura lunaris figurae, donec peruenias ad lapidem: deinde aufer eum cum eo, quod est tibi possibile ex instrumentis.	 Then make the patient sit between your hands, and turn the ear upward, and make a small incision in the base of the ear near the fat in a depressed place; and let the incision be crescent-shaped until you reach the stone; then remove it with what is possible for you using instruments.
Deinde sue fissuram ab hora tua cum uelocitate, et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then, open your wound at your hour (time) with speed, and care for it until it heals.
Quod si res cadens in aurem est ex uno granorum, quae crescunt, et inflantur: tunc administra extractionem eius.	 If something falls into the ear from among the grains that grow and swell, then administer its removal (extraction).
Si autem non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc accipe spatumile tenue, subtile, secundum hanc formam.	 But if it does not obey your attempt to come out, then take a thin, fine pledget, shaped as such.
Et administra cum eo abscisionem illius speciei ex granis, quae cadunt in aurem, et non facias illud, quando tu cogitas, quod illud granum iam humectatum est per uaporem auris, donec ponis ipsum frusta multa: deinde extrahe ea cum uncinis, aut cum gesti subtili, aut cum suctione, sicut diximus, nam extractio eius alleuiatur.	 And administer with it the removal of that kind (species) of grain from those that fall into the ear and do not come out; and do not do this when you believe that the grain is already moistened by the moisture of the ear, until you place many fragments (pieces) thereon: then remove it with tweezers, or with a thin stick, or with suction, as we said, for its extraction will be facilitated.
In aqua autem quae ingreditur in aurem, oportet ut utatur infirmus sternutatione cum condisi in primis: et iam impleuit aurem suam cum aliquanto cotto ueteri: et est iacens super illam aurem, in qua est aqua.	 In water that enters the ear, it is necessary for the sick person to use sneezing with incision at first; and already his ear has been filled with some warm water; and there lies on top of it (the water) the ear.
Si ergo egreditur per illud, est bonum.	 If therefore it comes out through that (opening), it is good.
Et si non: tunc accipe lapides multos, secundum longitudinem digiti, tenues, lenes, et calefac eos cum igne parumper, et intromittat infirmus ex eis unum in foramen auris suae: et saliat super pedem suum unum ex illa parte, et percutiat cum lapide alio super lapidem qui est in aure.	 And if not: then take many small, soft stones (pebbles), and warm them slightly with fire; and the sick person shall insert one of these into the ear's opening; and let him spit on one foot from that side, and strike with another stone upon the stone that is in the ear.
Non ergo cesset facere illud cum lapide et lapide, donec egrediatur tota aqua.	 Therefore, he should not cease doing it with stone and stone until all the water comes out.
Et iam egreditur aqua ita, ut accipias ex parpyro, aut ex iunco unum, et intromittas extremitatem eius unam in aurem: et accendas extremitatem alteram cum igne, donec comburatur plurimum eius.	 And now the water comes out in such a way that you shall take one from parchment or reed and insert its end into the ear; and you shall light the other end with fire until it is burned much of it.
Deinde itera iuncum alium, et fac illud multotiens, donec egrediatur tota aqua: et extrahe ipsam cum cannula secundum quod praemissum est in lapide.	 Then take another reed and do this repeatedly until all the water comes out; and remove it with a syringe according to what was said about the stone.
In extractione autem animalis intrantis in eam, si est parui corporis, ut pulex, et ei simile, cura ipsum sicut dixi in diuisione.	 In the extraction of an animal entering into it [the wound], if it is small like a louse, and similar to it, care should be taken as I have said in division.
Sed si est corporis magni, quod appareat sensui: tunc administra extractionem eius cum gesti, et uncinis: et res eius est facilior omnibus, quae tenentur in aure.	 But if it is of a large body, which appears to the sense: then administer its extraction with forceps and tweezers; and its removal is easier for all who are required to pull it out from the ear.
In extractione autem uermis generati in aure, quando curas eum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et in tractatu distilationum, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut aspicias aurem in sole.	 In the extraction of a worm generated in the ear, when you care for it with what I have said in division, and in treatment of distillation, and your care does not help: then it is necessary that you look at the ear in sunlight.
Si ergo apparet illic aliquid ex uermibus, tunc extrahe illud cum gesti, aut cum uncinis subtilibus.	 If therefore something appears there [in the ear] of worms, then extract it with forceps, or with fine tweezers.
Si autem non apparet illic aliquid, tunc accipe cannulam, cuius haec est forma, stricta inferius, ampla superius: et intromitte extremitatem subtilem in aurem secundum quantitatem quod tolerat eam infirmus: deinde suge cum ea suctione forti.	 But if nothing appears there [in the ear], then take a cannula whose form is constricted below and wide above; and insert its fine end into the ear according to the quantity that the sick person can bear; then suck with strong suction.
Fac illud multotiens, donec egrediantur omnes uermes.	 Do this often until all worms come out.
Si autem non obediunt tibi ad exitum, tunc opila circumitum cannulae cum caera, sicut dixi in lapide.	 If they do not obey you for exiting, then surround the head of the worms with a cannula and beeswax, as I have said in stone [a chapter about treatment with ointments].
Quod si non egrediuntur cum eo quod diximus: tunc administra distillationes quas iam experti sunt antiqui in interfectione uermium: et inuenies illud in tractatu distillationum.	 If they do not come out with what I have said, then administer the distillations that were experienced by the ancients in killing worms; and you will find it in treatment of distillation.
Et sit effusio tua qua effundis olea et medicinas in aurem cum hoc instrumento, cuius forma depicta est hic.	 And let your flow be with oil and medicines into the ear with this tool, whose shape is depicted here.
Sicut uides fac ipsum ex argento, aut aere, inferius strictum, in quo sit foramen paruum, amplum superius.	 Make it [the instrument] of silver or brass, constricted below and wide above, with a small hole.
Sit ergo ut impellens quod est in concauitate cannulae, sit ex aere decenter factum.	 Let the pressing part which is on the concavity of the cannula be made of well-made brass.
Et si uis, accipe radium, et inuolue in extremitate eius cottum inuolutione decenti: deinde proiice oleum, aut succum, aut quod uis ex istis medicinis in cannulam: et ipsa sit in aure: deinde intromitte radium cum cotto desuper, et exprime ipsum manu tua compressione temperata, donec impellatur oleum in concauitate auditus, et sentiat ipsum infirmus interius: et illud quod infunditur in aurem, sit iam calefactum cum igne parumper: et caue ne sit res quae distillatur in eam frigida ualde: medicinae enim non tolerant illud.	 And if you wish, take the radish, and insert it into the ear opening with a suitable lining: then pour oil, or juice, or whatever medicine you prefer into the cannula; let it be in gold: then insert the radish with the cooked [substance] on top, and press it gently with your hand until the oil is driven into the hollow of the ear, and the sick person feels it inside: and whatever is poured into the ear, let it already be heated slightly with fire: and take care that no substance which distills very cold is put in it; for medicines do not tolerate that.
¶ De cura opilationis accidentis Auri.	 On the Care of Ear Blockage (Auris).
Caput VII.	 Chapter 7.
Quandoque egrediuntur quidam infantes ex uentribus matrum suarum non perforati.	 When some infants are born from the wombs of their mothers without perforated eardrums.
Et iam accidit etiam quibusdam hominibus opilatio in meatu Auris a uulnere, aut carne nata in ea.	 It also happens to some people that ear blockage occurs in the cavity of the Ear due to a wound or flesh born in it.
Et haec opilatio quandoque fit in profundo foraminis Auris, quam non consequitur uisus: et quandoque accidit ad exteriora foraminis parum, et consequitur eam uisus.	 And this blockage sometimes occurs deep within the Ear's cavity, which is not visible to the eye; and sometimes it happens near the outer part of the cavity, which can be seen by the eye.
Illa ergo quae accidit in profundo Auris, et quam non comprehendit aspectus, est in pluribus dispositionibus difficilis sanationis.	 Therefore, that which occurs deep within the Ear and is not apparent to the eye, is difficult to cure in many respects.
Et in illa quam consequitur uisus, oportet ut ponas Aurem infirmi in sole, et aspicias in ea: tunc si uides opilationem apparentem, aperi eam cum spatumili subtili, cuius forma est haec quae sequitur, sit extremitas eius in qua sit quaedam latitudo parua, cuius quaedam pars sit acuta: et reliquum spatumile sit duarum laterum lenium: ut non laedat aurem.	 And in that which can be seen by the eye, one must place the sick person's Ear on the sun and observe it; then if you see the blockage appearing, open it with a fine spatula whose shape is as follows: its end should have a small notch, part of which is sharp; and the rest of the spatula should be flat on both sides so as not to injure the Ear.
Si ergo opilatio est a carne nata in meatu auris: tunc tene eam cum uncino subtili, et incide eam cum facilitate uehementi, donec auferatur tota caro.	 If the blockage is due to flesh born in the Ear cavity: then hold it with a fine hook and cut it out gently but powerfully until all the flesh is removed.
Quod si opilatio est in profundo auris: tunc accipe radium subtilem, lenem, et calefac ipsum cum igne parumper: deinde mitte ipsum in meatum auris.	 If there is an opening in the deep part of the ear: then take subtle radium, leno, and heat it slightly with fire; afterward send it into the ear's flesh.
Si ergo senseris opilationem cum eo, quod inuenit infirmus cum grauitate auditus, conare apertionem eius cum facilitate: et caue, ne uulneres neruos auris.	 If you find that the patient is weakened by illness with hearing difficulties, try to open it (the ear) easily; and be careful not to injure the nerves of the ear.
Deinde pone in aurem licinium secundum quantitatem amplitudinis foraminis, quod inuoluisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud aliquot diebus, donec sis securus de consolidatione uulneris.	 Then place linen in the ear according to the size of the opening you made, wrapped in Egyptian ointment; do this for several days until you are sure that the wound has healed.
Aut accipe licinium, et infunde ipsum in aqua rosata, et pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, et utere ipso.	 Or take linen and soak it in rose water, sprinkle powdered alum over it, and use it (as a poultice).
Quod si uides aurem iam apostemari: tunc oportet ut extrahas licinium, et permittas ipsum cum licinio alio, quod inuolues in caeroto quod sit factum cum oleo rosato, donec sedetur apostema calidum: deinde cura ipsum usquequo sanetur.	 If you see that the ear is already suppurating: then it is necessary to remove the linen and allow it to be covered with another piece of linen, wrapped in a cerotto made with rose oil, until the warm suppuration settles; then take care of it until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis: tunc submerge spongiam, aut pannos in aqua frigida, et pone super eam aurem: et utere reliqua curatione, quae abscindit fluxum sanguinis praedicta in tractatu distillationum.	 If there is bleeding (occurring): then immerse sponges or cloths in cold water and place it on the ear; and use the rest of the treatment that removes the mentioned bleeding in the section on distillations.
¶ De cura Altheli palpebrarum.	 Chapter on Altheli's Treatment for Eyes (Eyelids)
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
Isti Althelil qui accidunt in Palpebris oculi, quandoque sunt humidi, et sunt sicci.	 These are the Althelils that occur in the eyelids, which are sometimes wet and are sometimes dry.
Oportet ergo ut teneas eos cum tenaliis: aut cum uncino, et incidas eos cum spatumili a radicibus suis.	 Therefore, you must hold them with forceps or tweezers: or with a hook, and cut them at their roots with a spatula.
Deinde pone super loca zegi tritum.	 Then place it over the place of the bite, grinded.
Si autem ex eis fluat sanguis, tunc cauteriza eos cum cauterio lenticulari subtili.	 If blood flows from them, then cauterize them with a thin lentil-shaped cautery.
Et cauterizare eos, est melius post incisionem.	 And it is better to cauterize them after the incision.
Multotiens enim redeunt quando remanet ex radicibus suis aliquid.	 They often return when something remains from their roots.
Et quando cauterizantur cum igne, comburuntur illae radices, et non redeunt.	 And when they are cauterized with fire, those roots are burned and do not return.
¶ De cura Grandinum palpebrarum oculi.	 Chapter on the care of the eyelids of the eye.
Caput IX.	 Chapter IX.
Multotiens accidit in palpebris aliquid quod assimilatur Crandini in fortitudine sua, et sua duricie, et propter illud nominatur Grando: et est aggregatio humiditatis grossae in palpebra superiore, et palpebra inferiore.	 It often happens in the eyelids that something similar to a crab occurs, which is hard and tough, and because of this it is called a crab; and it is an accumulation of thick moisture on the upper eyelid, and the lower eyelid.
Operatio ergo in eis est, ut consideres tunc, si est Grando procedens in eo, quod apparet de palpebra, et mouentur ad omnem partem, et res eius est facilis.	 Therefore, the procedure in them is to examine if there is a crab emerging from it, which appears on the eyelid, and they move around in all directions, and its substance is soft.
Finde ergo super eam fissura per latitudinem.	 Find a split on her (it) in width.
Deinde excoria eam ab omni parte cum facilitate, donec euadat.	 Then scrape it from all sides easily, until it comes out.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncino, et abscinde ipsam.	 Then hang it with a hook and cut off the pouch.
Si autem non praeparatur tibi abscisio eius, nisi postquam tu penetras palpebram cum incisione parumper, tunc nocet infirmo illud in aliquo.	 But if its removal is not prepared for you unless after you pierce the eyelid with a small cut, then it harms the weak in some way.
Quod si fissura est magna: tunc aggrega ipsam cum sutura: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 If the split is large: then bring it together with stitches: and take care of it until it heals.
Et si est parua, non superueniet tibi malum ex ea.	 And if it is small, no harm will come to you from it.
Vnguentum enim restaurat ipsam, et incarnat eam.	 Ointment indeed restores and fleshes it.
Et si grando est decliuis ad interiora auris uersus superficiem intrinsecam, tunc inuersa palpebram, et suspende grandinem cum uncino: praeter quod indigeas incisione, et preme eam ab omni parte.	 And if the sand is turned towards the inner parts of the ear with the surface facing inside, then turn the eyelid inward and hang the sand grain with a hook: besides requiring a cut, press it from all sides.
Quod si elongatur palpebra per incisionem, non nocet illud in aliquo.	 If the eyelid is stretched out by an incision, no harm will come to you from it.
Deinde ablue oculum post incisionem grandinis, cum aqua salsa: et cura locum cum eo quod incarnat, donec sanetur infirmus.	 Then wash the eye after the sand grain incision with salt water: and care for the place where it is until the weak heals.
¶ De cura Axirnath palpebrarum.	 Section on the Care of the Eyelids.
Caput X.	 Chapter X.
Axirnath est adeps qui generatur in tunicis palpebrae superioris: et plurimum quidem accidit illud pueris: et ipsum grauat oculos eorum, et accidunt eis catarri in matutinis, et non possunt intueri lumen solis, propterea, quod lachrymae properant ad eos, et propter illud uides eos discumbere super facies suas semper, et super eas dormiunt, et sunt palpebrae eorum sub superciliis humidae, quas iam cooperuit inflatio: et eminentia quidem Axirnath apparens est oculo, et quando tu premis locum cum digitis tuis, sentis Axirnath inter eos.	 The translation is: "Axirnath is a cyst that is generated in the upper eyelid's covering; and it most often occurs in children; and it weighs down their eyes, and they get cataracts in the mornings, and they cannot see the light of the sun, because tears flow towards them due to this, and therefore you see them always lying on their faces, and sleeping on them, and their eyelids are wet below the eyebrows, which have already been inflated; and the appearance of Axirnath is evident to the eye, and when you press the area with your fingers, you feel Axirnath among them.
Et modus operationis eius est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 The translation is: "The method of treatment for it is that the afflicted puts his head in your lap.
Deinde accipe pannum lini, et praepara in eo licinia, et fac ex illo licinio circulum secundum quantitatem quod continet Axirnath ab omni parte.	 The translation is: "Then take a piece of linen cloth, and prepare within it a linen square according to the size that contains Axirnath on all sides.
Deinde pone eum super eam, et preme cum digitis tuis ab omni parte, ut aggregetur Axirnath in medio circuli.	 The translation is: "Then place it on top of the square and press it with your fingers from all sides, so that Axirnath gathers in the middle of the circle.
Deinde finde in medio illius humiditatis cum spatumili incidente fissuras per latitudinem, et non sit fissura maior illa quae fit in phlebotomia in profundo.	 The translation is: "Then find in the middle of that moisture with a narrow incision made, and it should not be larger than the one made in phlebotomy in depth.
Aut oportet ut findas cutem totam, donec peruenias ad Axirnath in pluribus enim dispositionibus procedit Axirnath ex fissura secundum formam frusti pinguedinis albae.	 The translation is: "Or it is necessary that you find the entire skin, until you reach Axirnath, for in many positions Axirnath comes out of the incision in the shape of a white lump.
Extrahe ergo eam cum panno, quem infiltrasti inter digitos tuos ad exteriora: et tu reuoluis manum tuam ad dextram et sinistram, donec dispergatur: et caue, ne addas in fissura, ut non peruenias cum spatumili ad oculum, et laedas eum.	 The translation is: "So pull it out with the cloth that you have inserted between your fingers towards the outside; and you turn your hand to the right and left until it disperses; and be careful not to add in the incision, so that you do not reach the eye with the spatula and harm it.
Si autem non appareat tibi Axirnath in principio fissurae, tu addas in fissura parum cum facilitate, donec procedat Axirnath.	 The translation is: "If Axirnath does not appear to you at the beginning of the incision, you add a little more easily into the incision until it comes out.
Deinde extrahe eam, sicut diximus.	 Then extract it, as we said.
Deinde submerge pannos in aceto et aqua, et pone eos super locum, et stringe eum cum puluillis.	 Submerge the cloths in vinegar and water, and place them over the spot, then sew it with small threads.
Et ex hominibus sunt qui terunt salem, et ponunt ipsum in concauitate fissurae, ut liquefiat quod remansit ex illa humiditate.	 And among humans are those who crush salt, and place it into the hollow of the crack, so that it softens what remains from that moisture.
Deinde cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat in loco apostema calidum, tune cura ipsum cum emplastris sedatiuis, donec sanetur.	 If, however, a boil occurs at the spot, then care for it with soothing plasters until it heals.
¶ De modis Ataxmir oculi, id est, cum palpebra mollificatur oculi, unde fit ut rugetur sicut non debet.	 [Heading: Methods of Ataxmir for the Eye, that is, when the eyelid becomes soft and weeps as it should not.]
Caput XI.	 Chapter XI.
Quando nascuntur in palpebris oculi pili additi praeter cursum sub pilis naturalibus, et antiquantur: tunc ipsi nocent oculo, et faciunt accidere modos aegritudinum, sicut lachrymas assiduas, et mollificationem palpebrarum, et albuginem, donec fit illud caussa destructionis oculi.	 When hairs appear in the eyelids that are in addition to the natural hairs and turn white: then they harm the eye and cause illnesses such as constant tears, softening of the eyelids, and cloudiness, until it causes the destruction of the eye.
Et Ataxmir quidem oculi curatur secundum quatuor modos.	 And Ataxmir indeed is cured according to four methods.
Aut per cauterium cum igne.	 Or by cautery with fire.
Aut cum medicina acuta, secundum quod praemissum est in capitulo cauterii.	 Or with sharp medicine, as was mentioned in the chapter on cautery.
Aut curatur Ataxmir per incisionem et suturam.	 Or it is cured by incision and sewing (of the eyelid).\]   Aut curatur per emplastrum temperatum cum medicamento ad un
Aut per cannas, secundum quod ego dicam.	 or it is cured with a plaster made mildly warm with medicine as I will say. Or with reeds, as I shall tell you.
Oportet ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 You must place the head of the sick person on your chest.
Deinde conuerte palpebram oculi manu tua sinistra.	 Then turn the eyelid of the eye with your left hand. \]   Et si vis bene curare Ataxmir, debes postea accedere ad incisionem, secundum
Si ergo conuertitur, bonum est.	 Therefore, if it has been turned, that is good. If, however, you wish to cure the Ataxmir well, then afterwards approach inc
Et si non: intromitte acum in eam, in qua sit filum ab inferiori parte palpebrae, et fac penetrare acum cum filo desuper, et sit illud prope pilos ipsos, id est, prope marginem palpebrae, in quo nascuntur pili: et trahe filum ad superiora cum palpebra, et conuerte eam cum radio.	 And if not: insert a needle into it where the thread is on the underside of the eyelid, and make the needle penetrate with the thread above, near the hairs themselves, that is, near the edge of the eyelid, in which hairs grow: then pull the thread upward along with the eyelid, and turn it with a spatula.
Deinde finde in interiori parte palpebrae sub pilis additis cum spatumili incidente a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus.	 Then find, within the internal part of the eyelid, under hairs added with a spurting spout coming from the greater lacrimal until the lesser lacrimal.
Deinde extrahe filum, et pone sub palpebra puluillum paruum ex cotto, aut panno: deinde signa super palpebram cum encaustro, quod sit sicut figura folii myrti.	 Then draw out the thread, and place a small speck of dust from boiled egg or cloth underneath the eyelid; then mark the eyelid with wax in the shape of a myrtle leaf figure.
Verumtamen oportet, ut fit figura secundum quantitatem et eleuationem palpebrae: quoniam iam diuersificatur illud in hominibus.	 However, it is necessary that the figure be made according to the size and elevation of the eyelid; since it has been varied among humans for a long time.
Ex eis enim est, qui indiget ut incidatur ex palpebra quantitas magna, secundum quantitatem quae mollificatur a palpebra.	 From this [it is] one who needs to be cut from the eyelid in quantity large, according to the quantity which is softened by the eyelid.
Deinde cum spatumili finde super duas lineas quas signasti, et incipe a lachrymali maiore usque ad lachrymale minus, et sit fissura una prope pilos naturales, sicut est grossitudo radii.	 Then with the spurting spout find above two lines which you marked, and start from the greater lacrimal until the lesser lacrimal, and let there be one crack near the natural hairs, as the thickness of a radius.
Deinde intromitte uncinum in uno duorum angulorum cutis.	 Then insert the hook into one of the two angles of the skin.
Deinde excoria ipsam totam.	 Then scour it all.
Deinde aggrega cum sutura duo labia, cum acu et filo lana subtili: et absterge sanguinem, et fac adhaerere quod superfluit ex filis super duo supercilia, cum quibusdam rebus inuiscantibus, si uis facere illud: et si non, non cures.	 Then sew together the two eyelids with a suture using a fine needle and thread, remove the blood, and make any excess from the threads adhere to the eyebrows with some binding materials if you wish to do this; but if not, do not worry about it.
Deinde dimitte suturam et fila usque ad tres dies, aut quatuor: postea cura illud.	 Then release the stitches and threads for three or four days, then take care of it.
Et si uis, dimitte uulnus absque sutura, et cura ipsum cum eo, quod exsiccat et constringit.	 And if you wish, let the wound heal without stitches, and take care of it so that it dries and contracts.
Nam palpebra eleuatur apud sigillationem uulneris et aggregationem eius: sed futura est melior.	 For the eyelid will rise when pressing on the wound and sewing it; but it will be better later.
Hunc modum curandi Ataxmir docuerunt antiqui.	 This method of treating wounds was taught by the ancients (Ataxmir).
Verumtamen in eo est sollicitudo super infirmum, et est ex bona operatione, et non est in eo timor.	 However, in this there is concern for the sick one, and it is from a good operation, but there is no fear in it.
Et modus alius est in Ataxmir etiam: et est, ut signes super palpebram figuram, quae sit sicut figura folii myrti, sicut narrauimus.	 And another method is in Ataxmir also: and it is, that signs on the eyelid a figure, which is like the figure of a myrtle leaf, as we have told.
Deinde eleua palpebram cum tribus uncinis separatis, aut aggregatis, secundum formam hanc quae sequitur, deinde incide quod superfluit cum forficibus paruis, secundum hanc formam, cum aequalitate incisionis.	 Then pull the eyelid with three separated or gathered hooks, according to the following shape, then cut off what remains with small scissors, according to this shape, with equal cutting.
Si autem non est tibi possibile tenere uncinum, et non aequatur illud: tunc accipe acum in qua sit filum, et intromitte ipsum in medio figurae: et intromitte filum aliud prope lachrymale maius, et filum secundum prope lachrymale minus: et aggrega inter digitos tuos fila cum aequalitate.	 If it is not possible for you to hold the hook and it does not fit: then take a needle with thread, and insert it into the middle of the figure; and insert another thread near the greater tear duct, and another thread near the smaller tear duct; and gather threads equally between your fingers.
Deinde eleua manum tuam eleuatione aequali: et eleua cutem super quam est signatum cotum, sicut narrauimus.	 Then pull your hand with equal pulling; and pull the skin where it is marked by the cut, as we have told.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then gather together two lips of the wound with stitching; and care for it until it heals.
Si uero accidat apostema apud incisionem tuam, aut fissuram tuam: seda illud apostema cum caeroto, et his similibus, ex unguentis sedantibus.	 If however an abscess occurs at your incision or your wound crack: bandage it with wool and similar things from healing ointments.
Et quandoque accidit palpebrae etiam, ut conuertantur pili eius.	 And sometimes the eyelashes also turn over.
Oportet ergo ut utaris in ea quod diximus in incisione: sed sutura utrisque magis est artificialis.	 Therefore, it is necessary that you use what we have said in the incision; but suturing both is more artificial.
¶ De cura Ataxmir cum cannis.	 Chapter on the care of Ataxmir with teeth.
ET Est, ut conuertas palpebram, et scindas fissuram quae est deintus, secundum quod narraui.	 And it is to turn the eyelid and cut the crack that is inside, as I have told.
Deinde arte fac duas cannas, aut duo ligna subtilia: quarum longitudo sit secundum longitudinem palpebrae, et latitudo earum sit minor latitudine spatumilis: et tu iam incidisti in extremitatibus utriusque ab utrisque partibus ubi tenes fila.	 Then make two teeth or two thin sticks whose length is according to the length of the eyelid, and the width of them is less than the width of a fingertip; and you have already cut at both ends from both sides where you hold threads.
Deinde aggrega utramque cum subtilitate super illud quod superfluit ex palpebra oculi, et stringe duas cannas ab utrisque partibus strictura forti, et dimitte eam diebus aliquot.	 Then gather both together with thin material over what remains from the eyelid of the eye, and tie two teeth from both sides tightly with a strong stitch, and leave it for several days.
Cutis enim stricta morietur, et denigrabitur, et putrefiet, donec cadet per se.	 The tightened skin will die and become darkened and rot until it falls off by itself.
Si ergo tardatur, tunc incide eam cum forficibus.	 If delayed [in healing], then cut it with scissors.
Deinde cura eam, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it until it heals.
Cum ergo consolidatur, eleuatur palpebra: et non pungunt pili.	 When it has solidified, lift the eyelid and do not pluck the hairs.
Et haec est forma duarum cannarum, quas facies secundum hanc figuram, et quantitatem in longitudinem et latitudinem.	 And this is the form of two scissors, as you shall make according to this shape and measurement for length and width.
¶ De eleuatione pilorum pungentium in oculo cum acu.	 § On plucking painful hairs from the eye with a sharp instrument.
Caput XII.	 Chapter XII.
Operatio in illo est, ut accipias acum subtilem, et intromittas in eam filum ex serico subtile, lene.	 The operation is that you take a subtle point and insert a fine silk thread into it gently.
Deinde aggreges extremitates eius, et nodes utramque nodo subtili ualde: et sit longitudo filorum palmus unus.	 Then gather the ends of it and knot them both with a very subtle knot, and let the length of the threads be one palm [width].
Deinde compone in Alinxotati filum aliud subtile sub eo in breui, et noda extremitates eius si uis.	 Then combine another fine thread beneath it in a short distance, and knot its ends if you wish.
Deinde ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo, et sit prope solem ut declaretur operatio: quoniam est operatio subtilis, uel minuta.	 Then place the weak head of the patient on your lap and bring it close to the sun so that the operation may be clearly seen, because the operation is subtle or delicate.
Deinde intromitte acum cum alinxotati in radicem palpebrae, et fac eam penetrare in palpebram festinanter, donec extrahas eam desuper pilum naturalem.	 Then insert the fine point with the scissors into the root of the eyelash and make it penetrate the eyelid quickly until you pull out the natural hair from above.
Deinde trahe pilum usque supra alinxotati: et intromitte in alinxotati illum pilum: si est unus, aut duo, aut tres, non plures.	 Then draw the hair up to the scissors and insert the scissors into the hair; if it is one, or two, or three, do not take more than that.
Deinde trahe manum tuam cum eo, donec egrediatur pilus cum alinxotati in palpebra cum pilo naturali.	 Then draw your hand with it until the hair comes out of the eyelid along with the plucked hair.
Si autem trahatur alinxotati, et non egrediatur pilus cum ea: trahes alinxotati ad inferiora, cum filo quod tu composuisti in ea, donec egrediatur alinxotati ex foramine superiori, et uideas eam uisione oculi: tunc enim trahes alinxotati, et filum: et extrahe utraque, et claude oculum: et dimitte ipsum clausum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec adhaereat pilus loco suo, et nascatur super ipsum caro.	 If the scissors are pulled out without the hair coming out of the eyelid along with it: pull the scissors downwards with the thread that you have prepared in it until the scissors come out from the upper opening and are visible to the eye; then, when you pull the scissors and the thread, draw both of them out, close the eye and let the closed eye heal for two or three days until the hair adheres to its place and new flesh grows over it.
Quod si pilus est breuis, tunc aut associa ei pilum longum ex pilis naturalibus, et eleuatur cum eo: aut dimitte ipsum, donec elongetur post spacium, et tunc eleua ipsum.	 If the hair is short, then either bind a long hair from natural hairs with it and lift it up together; or leave it alone until it grows out a little, and then lift it up.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae accidit in palpebra superiori.	 On the care of Alzacter's condition that occurs in the upper eyelid.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter XIII.
Quando accidit oculo haec Alxatrati, nominatur Leporina.	 When this Alzacter's condition occurs in the eye, it is called Leporina.
Et haec Alxatrati est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	 And Alzacter's condition is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis ergo fit ex consolidatione uulneris, aut sectionis, aut cauterii, et similium illis.	 Therefore, the accidental form arises from the consolidation of a wound, a cut, a cautery, and similar things.
Et modus operationis in ea est, ut tu findas illam consolidationem, et ut separes labia eius, et ponas in eo quod est inter ea licinium ex lino, et liges eam, donec sanetur.	 And the method of operation is to open that consolidation and to separate its edges, and to place a piece of linen gauze in it, and bind it until it heals.
Et non oportet, ut utaris in curatione eius rebus quae exiccant et constringunt: nam si tu facis illud, redit Alxatrati deterior quam fuit: imo utere in ea rebus quae mollificant, sicut foenumgraecum: et embroca cum aqua, in qua cocta sit althea, semen lini: et unguento dyaquilon, quod liquefactum sit cum aliquo ex oleis: et inuolue cum eo licinium, et cura cum eo.	 And it is not necessary to use in the treatment of this condition things that dry and tighten, for if you do so, Alzacter's condition will become worse than it was; rather, use soft things such as flaxseed: and embrocation with water, in which althea has been boiled, linseed seed: and ointment of djaquilon, which has been made liquefied with some oil: and wrap it with linen, and treat it with it.
Et thesaurus curationis tuae est, ut coneris omni ingenio, ut non consolidetur, secundum formam quae fuit in primis.	 And your treasure of healing is to strive with all your skill so that it does not consolidate again in its original form.
Et haec quidem operatio quam diximus, non est nisi quaedam rectificatio Alxatrati, ut non redeat forma loci secundum quod fuit omnino.	 And this operation that we have mentioned is not other than a correction of Alzacter's condition, so that it does not return to its original form entirely.
¶ De cura Alxatrati quae fit in palpebra inferiori, et est rugatio uel contractio sursum ad dextrum et sinistrum.	 On the care of Alzacter's condition that occurs in the lower eyelid, and is a ridge or contraction upward towards the right and left.
Caput XIIII.	 Chapter XIV.
Haec Alxatrati quae fit inferius, est quae uere nominatur Alxatrati.	 This Alzacter's condition that occurs below is properly called Alzacter's condition.
Et est naturalis, et est accidentalis.	 And it is natural, and it is accidental.
Et accidentalis fit ex uulnere, aut fissura, aut cauterio, et illis similibus.	 From wound, or fracture, or cautery, and similar things it becomes accidental.
Et uia operationis in ea est, ut accipias acum, in qua sit filum duplum, et tingas eam in carnem, et facias eam penetrare a lachrymali sinistro usque ad lachrymale dextrum, donec perueniat filum in duabus extremitatibus carnis.	 The way of the operation in it is that you receive the needle, on which there should be a double thread, and you dye it in flesh, and you make it penetrate from the left tear duct to the right tear duct, until the thread reaches both ends of the flesh.
Deinde extende carnem ad superiora cum acu, et incide eam cum spatumili lato.	 Then stretch the flesh towards the upper part with a knife, and cut it with a broad lancet.
Si ergo redit figura palpebrae secundum quod oportet, est bonum.	 If then the figure of an eyelid returns as it should be, it is good.
Et si non, accipe radium, et pone ipsum in fissuram, et conuerte cum eo palpebram: et finde duas fissuras in latere interiore palpebrae, et sint extremitates duarum fissurarum ex duobus angulis incisionis, donec concurrant et fiat ex eis angulus: donec quando aggregantur fiat figura earum haec figura, et est litera lauda graeca.	 And if not, take radium, and place it in the fissure, and turn the eyelid with it; and make two fissures on the inner side of the eyelid, and let their extremities be from the two angles of the incision, until they converge and form an angle: until when they come together a figure is formed, and it is a Greek letter lambda.
Deinde aufer illam carnem per quantitatem, quod est latus eius acutum inferius, ab eo quod sequitur palpebram.	 Then remove that flesh to the extent of its sharp lower part, from what follows the eyelid.
Deinde aggrega partes separatas: sue eam cum filo lanae.	 Then join the separated parts; or sew it with a woolen thread.
Deinde cura eas cum eo quod diximus, de medicinis mollificantibus, et liciniis, donec sanentur.	 Then take care of them with what I said, with softening medicines and linen cloths, until they heal.
Et si Alxatrati accidat ex fissura, et sutura, aut cauterio: tunc oportet ut findas fissura plana sub pilis palpebrarum, etiam secundum quod praecessit.	 And if the Alxatratus happens from the fissure or stitching or cauterizing: then it is necessary to make a flat wound under the eyelashes, even as it was before.
Deinde separa inter duo labia cum licinio, secundum quod diximus.	 Then separate between two lips with linen cloth, as I said.
Et summa sermonis de cura Alxatrati, quando est desuper, aut inferius, est, ut currat in ea operatio, secundum quod praeparatur ex forma Alxatrati.	 The summary of the discussion on treating Alxatratus, whether it is above or below, is that the treatment should be performed according to the preparation for the form of Alxatrati.
Ipsa namque est multarum diuersitatum in forma: et artifex prudens praeparat ingenium cum quocunque modo est possibile ei, donec redire faciat figuram ad formam naturalem, aut prope eam, et ipsemet infirmus, secundum quod conuenit ei ex operatione et instrumentis in plurimis dispositionibus.	 For indeed it has many diverse forms; and the skillful craftsman prepares his talent with whatever means is possible for him, until he brings back the figure to its natural form or close to it, and himself who is ill, according to what suits him from the operation and instruments in various positions.
¶ De adhaerentia palpebrae oculi cum coniunctiua, aut cornea.	 Chapter on the adhesion of the eyelid with the conjunctiva or cornea.
Caput XV.	 Chapter XV.
Quandoque accidit haec consolidatio multis hominibus, ita ut consolidetur palpebra superior cum albedine oculi, et prohibeat ipsum ab operationibus suis naturalibus.	 Sometimes this consolidation happens to many people so that the upper eyelid becomes consolidated with the white of the eye, and prevents it from performing its natural functions.
Oportet ergo quod intromittas extremitatem radii sub palpebra, et eleues eam sursum: aut extendas eam cum uncino: deinde incide adhaerentiam cum spatumili subtili, quod non sit cum acuitate incisionis spatumilium, imo sit obtusum parumper: ut non inquietetur infirmus apud operationem, et remoueatur spatumile, et laedat oculum cum acuitate sua: et sit incisio tua quasi tu excories illam adhaerentiam cum facilitate, donec quando redit palpebra secundum formam suam naturalem, et sanetur adhaerentia tota.	 Therefore it is necessary that you insert the end of the radius under the eyelid and lift it up; or stretch it with a hook; then cut the adhesion with a thin spatula without sharpness of the spatula cuts, but rather bluntly somewhat; so that the weak one will not be disturbed during the operation and the spatula will be removed and not harm the eye with its sharpness; and your incision should be like you scrape off that adhesion with ease, until when the eyelid returns to its natural form, and the adhesion is healed completely.
Funde tunc in oculum aquam salsam, cum aqua ablue ipsum: aut distilla in ipsum ex sief facto, ex ziniar dissoluto cum aqua.	 Then pour salt water into the eye and wash it; or distill it onto him from sifon made of zinc dissolved with water.
Deinde separa inter palpebram et oculum cum licinio lini: et pone super oculum lanam infusam cum albugine oui: et post diem tertium utere sief, et cum solidatiuis, donec sanetur.	 Then separate between the eyelid and the eye with a linen cloth; and place wool soaked in egg white over the eye; and after three days use zinc ointment and with salves, until it is healed.
¶ De incisione ungulae et eminentiae carnis lachrymarum.	 Chapter on incision of nail and protrusion of skin around eyelashes.
Caput XVI.	 Chapter XVI.
Scias, quod ungula est secundum duos modos.	 Know that the nail is of two kinds.
Aut est neruosa: et est similis sifac duro, subtili.	 Or it is nervous: and is similar to horn, but delicate.
Aut est non neruosa, similis humiditati congelatae albae: quae quando tangit cam ferrum, aut conaris capere eam cum uncino, abscinditur, et non figitur in ea uncinus.	 It is not a nerve, similar to the consistency of frozen white moisture; when iron touches it or one tries to grasp it with a forceps, it is torn away and the forceps do not take hold in it.
Et utraeque species non incipiunt, nisi a lachrymali maiore, usquequo uadit paulatim, donec cooperit uisum, et prohibet lumen, et motum oculi.	 And neither of the kinds begins except from the greater tear duct, up until it gradually reaches the eye, until it fills the sight, and prevents light, and movement of the eye.
Et modus operandi in incisione eius est: ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 The method of operation in its incision is: that the sick person places his head in your lap.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et eleua palpebram manu tua.	 Then open his eyes, and lift the eyelid with your hand.
Deinde collige ungulam cum uncino paucae duplationis, et extende eam ad superiora.	 Then collect a few double-spaced claws with forceps and extend them upward.
Deinde accipe acum, et intromitte in eam pilum ex pilis equi, et bouis, aut uaccae: et sit filum forte, et duplica extremitatem acus parumper, et fige eam in medio ungulae: et penetra eam cum acu, et liga cum filo ungulam, et extende eam ad superiora: et excoria cum pilo latus ungulae quod sequitur pupillam, ac si tu serres eam cum pilo usque ad postreimnum eius.	 Then take a spear and insert a horse hair or ox or sheep hair into it, let it be a thread, and slightly double the end of the spear point, and fix it in the middle of the claw; penetrate it with the spear and tie it with the thread to the claw, and extend it upward; peel off the side of the claw following the pupil as if you were holding it with the hair up until the end of it.
Deinde incide residuum in radice lachrymalis cum spatumili subtili, aut cum forficibus paruis: et dimitte carnem lachrymalis naturalem, ut non accidat ex incisione eius cursus lachrymarum assiduus.	 Then cut the remainder at the root of the tear duct with a thin spatula or small forceps; let the natural tissue of the tear duct remain, so that no persistent flow of tears occurs due to its incision.
