Et quandoque extenditur ungula cum uncino solo: aut cum filo, sicut diximus.	 And sometimes the claw is extended with forceps alone; or with a thread, as we said.
Deinde excoriatur cum spatumili leni, cuius haec est forma.	 Then it is scraped with a soft spatula, which has this form.
Et caue, ne tangat spatumile tunicam corneam, et accidat in ea ruptura, et perforetur pupilla.	 And be careful that the soft spatula does not touch the corn layer and cause a break there, and pierce the pupil.
Deinde post incisionem, proice in oculum aliquid salis contriti, aut ex sief facto ex ziniar, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	 Then after the incision, throw something crushed salt or made from chalk into the eye and let it stay until another day.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur.	 Then take care of him with what is required, until he is healed.
Quod si ungula est non neruosa, et non potes intromittere in eam acum, neque figitur in ea uncinus, tunc multotiens curatur haec species ungulae cum medicinis, et sanatur sicut narraui in diuisione.	 If the nail is not sensitive and you cannot insert a probe into it nor apply a clamp to it, then repeatedly treat this kind of nail with medications, and it will heal as I have described in the division.
Quod si uis incidere eam, tunc aperi oculum infirmi, et accipe spatumile subtile, lene, debilis acuitatis, secundum hanc formam.	 If you wish to cut it, then open the sick person's eye and take a thin, soft, weakly sharp probe of this shape.
Et rade ungulam desuper rasione cum subtilitate.	 And shave the nail from above with delicacy.
Quod si uides quod ipsa rarificatur et confringitur, et imprimit in eam rasio, tunc distilla ex hora tua in oculum ex sief facto ex ziniar, aut ex sief rubeo, aut sale trito: et opila oculum usque ad diem alium.	 If you see that it becomes rarefied and crushed, and press a razor into it, then drip from your hour (urine) into the eye made from seif or from ziniar, or from red seif ground fine: and keep the eye closed until another day.
Deinde itera super ipsam operationem, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 Then repeat the operation on it until the entire thing is removed.
Nisi contrarium sit tibi in oculo apostema calidum: tunc enim dimitte ipsam, et cura apostema, donec sanetur.	 Unless a hot abscess appears in your eye, then leave it alone and treat the abscess until it is healed.
Deinde itera operationem super ipsam cum rasione, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat the operation on it with delicacy, until it is healed.
Eminentia autem carnis lachrymalis, si nocet in oculo nocumento magno, suspendatur cum uncino, et incide ex ea partem eius: et non ultimes incisionem, ut non accidat cursus lachrymarum.	 The growth of the flesh on the eyelash, if it causes great harm to the eye, is to be suspended with a clamp and cut off that part of it; not too deep so as not to disturb the flow of tears.
Deinde stilla in lachrymale sief rubeum, aut factum ex ziniari, donec sanetur.	 Then drip red seif or seif made from ziniar into the eye until it is healed.
¶ De incisione Alguardenic, et carne nata in oculo.	 Chapter on Incision of Albucasis and growth of flesh in the eye.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter 17.
Nascitur quandoque in quibusdam oculis hominum caro rubea composita, uel superposita, donec cooperit pupillam, aut appropinquat, aut stringit super palpebras, et fortasse conuertit palpebras ad exteriora: et assimilatur rosae balaustinae.	 Sometimes in the eyes of men there grows red flesh composed or laid on top, covering the pupil or approaching it, or pressing against the eyelids and perhaps turning the eyelids toward the outside; and it resembles a balustrade rose.
Et operatio in ea etiam est, ut ponat infirmus caput suum in sinu tuo.	 The operation in it is also to place the sick head in your armpit.
Deinde aperi oculos eius, et collige illam carnem totam cum uncinis conuenientibus ad illud: et tene illud cum forcipe uno, aut gesti.	 Then open his eyes and collect the entire flesh with suitable hooks to it; hold it with a single forceps or tweezers.
Deinde incide carnem in primis, donec finiatur totum eius cum incisorio.	 Then cut the flesh first, until you finish it all with a knife.
Et caue ab oculo, ut non laedas ipsum apud operationem: et sit incisio tua qua ipsam incidis, aut cum spatumili, quod narrauimus in incisione ungulae: aut cum forficibus paruis, cum quibus colligitur asebel, secundum quod ueniet forma eius post hoc capitulum.	 Take care not to touch the eye during the operation; make your cut be such that it is made as we have described in the incision of the nail, or with tweezers like those used for asbestos, according to the shape it will take after this chapter.
Cum ergo completur incisio tua, et remouetur tota alguardenici, tunc imple oculum ex sale contrito: aut distilla in eum puluerem rubeum, et similia illi ex medicinis corrosiuis: et pone super oculum deforis cottum cum albugine oui: ut securetur ab apostemate calido.	 When your incision is completed and the entire nail-root is removed, then fill the eye with salt solution; or drizzle into it red powder and similar substances from corrosive medicines; and place over the eye on the outside a cotton pad with egg white: to protect it from a hot infection.
Quod si remanet ex alguardenici aliquid, et dominatur tibi sanguis calidus, et times apostema calidum: tunc dimitte oculum, et cura ipsum cum eo quod sedat apostema.	 If some of the nail-root remains and hot blood prevails, and you fear a hot infection; then leave the eye alone, and treat it with what soothes an abscess.
Deinde itera super ipsum cum operatione, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat the procedure over it until it heals.
Et similiter fac cum carne addita quae accidit in oculo ex hac specie.	 And similarly do with any flesh that happens to be present in the eye of this kind.
Verumtamen oportet, ut alienes curationem omnis oculi debilis ex uia naturali, aut ex uia accidentali, operando cum ferro: et non intromittas manum tuam in aliqua harum operationum, donec uideas, quod illud membrum est tolerans illam operationem.	 Nevertheless, any weakening of the eye from a natural or accidental cause must be treated by cutting with iron; and do not insert your hand into any of these operations until you see that the member is able to withstand this treatment.
¶ De collectione Sebel ex oculo.	 Chapter on removing asbestos from the eye.
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter XVIII.
Sebel sunt uenae rubeae quae texuntur super oculum, et prohibent uisui operationem suam: et debilitant oculum cum longitudine dierum.	 Asbestos are veins of red color that cover the eye and impede vision; they weaken the eye day by day.
Necesse est ergo tibi in primis, ut consideres, si oculus in quo est Sebel, est fortis, et non est in eo aegritudo aliqua, praeter Sebel: tunc collige Sebel eius.	 Therefore, first you must consider if the eye in which asbestos is found is strong and there is no other illness except for asbestos; then collect the asbestos of it.
Et est, ut praecipias infirmo, ut ponat caput suum in sinu tuo.	 And it is that you command the sick one, that he places his head in your bosom.
Deinde suspende illas uenas cum uncino uno, aut duobus secundum prudentiam tuam: et sit uncinus subtilis duplationis, secundum hanc formam, aut sint duo uncini gradat in corpore uno, secundum hanc formam.	 Then suspend those veins with one or two needles according to your judgment: and let the needle be fine of double fold, according to this shape, or let there be two needles graduated in one body, according to this shape.
Deinde collige cum forficibus subtilibus illas uenas cum subtilitate, et absterge sanguinem hora post horam, donec uideas illas uenas remoueri ex oculo, et resoluuntur: et caue ne laedas oculum cum extremitatibus spatumilis.	 Then collect with fine forceps those veins and remove the blood by the hour, until you see the veins removed from the eye and resolved: and be careful not to hurt the eye with the tips of the forceps.
Et sit operatio tua in meridie coram sole, et sis firmus in operatione tua ualde: ut non incidas nisi illas uenas.	 And let your work be at noon before the sun, and be very firm in your work: so as not to cut except those veins.
Et cum tu expleueris, tunc distilla in oculum sief uiride, aut rubeum: ut sua acuitate corrodat quod remansit ex sebel.	 And when you have finished, then distill into the eye green or red: so that with its own acidity it burns what remains from the scalpel.
Si autem non est tibi possibile colligere illud totum in illa hora, tunc emplastra oculum cum eo, quod sedat dolorem oculi: et dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur dolor eius: et securetur ab apostemate calido: deinde itera super ipsum secundum modum eundem, donec sanetur.	 If it is not possible for you to collect all of it in that hour, then plaster the eye with that which soothes the pain of the eye: and leave it for some days until the pain subsides: and bind it with warm poultice: then again repeat over it according to the same method until it heals.
Et haec est forma forficis.	 And this is the form of the forceps.
¶ De reductione Arissati ad nasum.	 Chapter on reducing Arissatas (nasal polyps) to the nose.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter XIX.
Nominant medici Arissati Fistulam, quam curas cum cauterio, aut cum medicina acuta comburente, secundum quod praecessit eius narratio.	 The surgeon is called Arisatha, and he treats the Fistula, which he cures with a cautery or with a medicine burning sharply, according to his narrative that has gone before.
Et si non sanatur, tunc non est ingenium in ea: nisi ut findas super apostema apud natiuitatem eius, et extrahas totam humiditatem quae est in eo et pus, donec detegatur os.	 If it is not healed, then there is no skill in this case, except to open a boil at its birth and remove all the moisture that is in it and the pus, until the bone appears.
Cum ergo detegitur os, et uides in eo corruptionem, aut nigredinem, tunc rade ipsum cum instrumento, cuius forma est haec.	 When the bone is exposed, and you see in it corruption or blackness, then grind it with an instrument of this form.
Et nominatur Asperi capitis.	 And it is called Asperga for the head.
Fiat ex ferro indo, et sit caput eius rotundum sicut azir, quod sit punctatum punctatione limae, aut punctatione aliskilferi punctatione subtili: et pone ipsum super locum corruptum ossis.	 Make it from iron and round its head like a needle, pierced by the grinding of a file or a finely-pointed aliskilfer; place it on the corrupted bone.
Deinde reuolue ipsum inter digitos tuos, et tu preme manum tuam parumper, donec scias quod illa corruptio iam rasa est: et fac illud aliquotiens.	 Then turn it over between your fingers and press your hand a little, until you know that the corruption has been ground away; do this repeatedly.
Deinde restaura locum cum medicinis exiccatiuis stipticis.	 Then restore the place with very dry ointments.
Si ergo consolidatur locus, et nascitur in eo caro, et abscinditur cursus saniei: et remanet quadraginta diebus, et non renouatur, et non apostematur, et non accidit in eo accidens: tunc scias quia iam sanatus est.	 If the place consolidates and flesh grows in it, and the flow of pus is stopped; and forty days have passed, and it does not break open again, nor develop an abscess, nor does anything else happen in it; then you know that it has been healed.
Et si non, tunc non est in eo ingenium, nisi reducere fistulam ad foramen nasi, secundum hanc formam.	 If not, then there is no skill in this case, except to lead the fistula back to the nostril, according to this shape.
Et est, ut detegas ab osse secundo cum ferro, aut cum medicina acuta: et cum detectum est os, tunc accipe terebrum secundum hanc formam, sit extremitas ferrea, triangulata: et lignum eius sit pyramis extenuata usque ad extremitatem, sicut uides.	 And it is to be exposed from the second bone with iron or with a sharp medicine; when the bone has been exposed, then take a gimlet according to this shape, its tip being made of iron, triangular: and let the wood of it be a pyramid extended to the end, as you see.
Deinde pone illud super os ipsum: et sit illud prope lachrymale: et elonga manum tuam ab oculo parum.	 Then place it on the bone itself; let it be near the tear duct; and extend your hand slightly away from the eye.
Deinde reuolue manum tuam cum terebro, donec penetret os, et sentiat illud infirmus: per hoc quod inuenit uentum exire ex eo, quando tenet manum suam super nasum suum.	 Then turn your hand with the lancet until it penetrates the bone and feels it weak; by this you will find wind coming out of it when you hold your hand over his nose.
Ergo tunc restaura locum cum medicinis stipticis exiccantibus, sicut docui te.	 Then restore the place with medicines that dry (or stop bleeding), as I have taught you.
Cum ergo nascitur caro, et induratur locus: tunc materia quae effundebatur ad exteriora, redit ad nasum: est ergo leuius illud super infirmum.	 When the flesh grows and the place hardens, then what was flowing out to the outside returns to the nose; therefore it is lighter above the weak one.
¶ De reductione eminentiae Oculi.	 [Section Title] Reduction of an Eyeball Protrusion.
Caput XX.	 Chapter 20.
Quando eminet Oculus cum totalitate sua, et non accidit in uisu nocumentum, neque diminutio: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum: deinde phlebotomes eum: postea ponas uentosas in ceruice absque scarificatione, sed cum suctione.	 When the eye protrudes entirely and no harm or reduction occurs while looking at it: then it is necessary to loosen the patient; next, phlebotomy should be performed on him; afterwards, place cupping glasses in the neck without incision, but with suction.
Deinde pone super Oculum linimentum quod fit ex acacia, et aloe, et olibano, et sarcocolla.	 Then place a liniment on the eye which is made from acacia, aloe, myrrh, and colophony.
Deinde stringe Oculum desuper super emplastrum cum puluillis multis.	 Then bind the eye above with plaster and many small stones.
Et modus puluillorum est: ut accipias pannos lenes, multos, et duplicetur omnis pannus ex eis super quatuor: fac ex eis multos: deinde pone eos unum super alium, secundum quantitatem qua indiget Oculus: deinde stringe super ipsos cum panno duro strictura forti.	 And the method of the small stones is: take soft cloths, many, and cut all the cloth from them into four parts; make many from these; then place one on top of another according to the quantity that the eye requires; then bind them strongly with a stiff cloth.
Et itera uentosas cum suctione sine scarificatione.	 And repeat cupping glasses with suction without incision.
Deinde aufer uentosas, et dimitte oculum strictum die et nocte.	 Then remove the cupping glasses, and release the bound eye day and night.
Si autem ligamentum iterum mollificatur, tunc oportet ut stringatur multum: deinde aufer ligamentum post diem et noctem, sicut diximus.	 If the binding again becomes soft, then it is necessary to bind it very tightly; then remove the binding after a day and night, as previously stated.
Si ergo uides oculum iam redisse uuae tunicae, est bonum: et si non, tunc itera emplastrum, et puluillos, et stricturam, et uentosas, donec sanetur.	 If you see the eye has returned to its original position, that is good; and if not, then repeat the plaster, the small stones, the binding, and the cupping glasses until it heals.
¶ De incisionie Vuae tunicae.	 Chapter on the incision of the eyelid.
Caput XXI.	 Chapter XXI.
Quando accidit disruptio in tunica Vuea, deinde eminet et procedit extra palpebras sicut granum Vuae, et foedatur forma hominis propter illud, et uis incidere illud: tunc operatio in eo est, secundum quod narro: et est, ut intromittas acum in radice Vuae ab inferiori ad superiorem partem.	 When a rupture occurs in the tunica Vuea, it then protrudes and proceeds outside the eyelids like a grain of Vuae, and fouls the human form because of this; and there is desire to cut it: then surgery on it is necessary, as I have told; and it is to introduce a point into the root of Vuae from below to the upper part.
Deinde intromitte acum aliam in qua sit filum duplum a parte lachrymalis, et fac eam penetrare: et dimitte acum primam secundum dispositionem suam.	 Then insert another point with a double thread from the lacrimal side, and make it penetrate; and release the first point according to its position.
Deinde incide locum fili dupli, et liga cum eo partem Vuae in circumitu acus: et stringe eam multum.	 Then cut the place of the double thread, and tie a piece of Vuae around it with the point; and tighten it strongly.
Deinde extrahe acum, et pone super oculum lanam infusam in albugine oui: et dimitte eum, donec cadat filum cum Vua.	 Then remove the point, and place wet wool on the eye's white; and leave it until the thread falls with the Vua.
Deinde cura oculum cum eo, quod confortat ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	 Then care for the eye so that it is comforted, until the wound heals.
Et quandoque stringitur Vua ab omni parte cum circulo ex panno, donec addat oculus eminentiam magnam.	 And sometimes the Vua is tightened from all sides with a ring made of cloth, until the eye protrudes greatly.
Deinde perforetur cum spatumili subtili, quod perueniat ad profundum oculi, et currat humiditas albuginea, et descendat oculus, et ingrediatur statim: deinde stringe eum, donec sanetur.	 Then it is pierced with a fine spatula that reaches the depth of the eye, and moistens the white of the eye, and the eye sinks, and immediately enters; then tighten it until it heals.
¶ De curatione Alcomnati.	 [Title] On the cure of Alcomnat.
Caput XXII.	 Chapter XXII.
Haec Aegritudo quae nominatur Alcomnati, non, est nisi sanies, quae aggregatur in oculo, similis aquae descendenti, et non est ipsa.	 This disease called Alcomnat is not other than pus that accumulates in the eye, similar to descending water, and it is not itself.
Et modus operandi in ea est, ut facias sedere infirmum super sedem praeparatum, uel directum.	 And the method of operation in this case is that you make the sick person sit on a prepared chair or straight-backed one.
Deinde accipe caput eius manibus tuis a partibus duabus, et moue ipsum, donec uideas saniem peruenire ad inferiora oculis tuis.	 Then take hold of his head with your hands from both sides and move him until you see the pus reach the lower parts of your eyes.
Deinde figatur, et non descendat, et absoluatur lumen: et uideat infirmus res sicut uidebat: et si non descendit inferius, scias quia est aqua.	 Then it is shaped, and does not fall down, and the vision is cleared; and the sick person sees as he saw before: and if it does not fall lower, know that it is water.
Si autem non praeparatur descensus saniei cum eo quod diximus, tunc fac sedere infirmum inter manus tuas.	 If however the descent of pus is not prepared as we said, then make the patient sit between your hands.
Deinde accipe spatumile subtile, et finde cum eo supra panniculum corneum parumper apud continuationem coniunctiuae cum tunica cornea in corona, donec egrediatur sanies.	 Then take a thin probe and pierce it through the cornified panniculus continuous with the cornea at the junction with the tunica cornea in the corona, until the pus is expelled.
Cum ergo egreditur, tunc distilla in oculum aquam calidam in qua miscuisti mel: aut aquam in qua iam bullisti foenumgraecum et mel: deinde curetur cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 When it comes out, then pour warm water into which you have mixed honey over it; or hot water in which you have already boiled fennel and honey; then treat it with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
¶ De cura aquae, quae descendit in oculo, uel cataracta.	 Chapter on the care of water that falls into the eye, or cataract.
Caput XXIII.	 Chapter XXIII.
Iam Diximus species aquae in diuisione, et quae conuenit ad perforandum sermone declarante et exponente, tunc accipe illud idem secundum sanitatem.	 We have already said the type of water in division and which is suitable for perforation in speech declaring and explaining it, then take the same according to its health.
Tunc ergo oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas quadratum, oppositum lumini, prope solem: et liga oculum eius sanum, et stringe eum ualde: deinde palpebram oculi eius manu tua dextra, si oculus in quo est aqua, est oculus sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	 Then it is necessary that you make the patient sit with your hands facing each other, opposite to the eye, near the sun; and tie the healthy eye, and squeeze it very tightly; then close the eyelid of the affected eye with your right hand, if the water is in the left eye; or with your left hand, if the water is in the right eye.
Deinde accipe manu tua dextra almagda, si oculus est sinister: aut manu tua sinistra, si oculus est dexter.	 Then take your right hand with a large spoon, if the eye is the left; or your left hand with a large spoon, if the eye is the right.
Deinde pone extremitatem almagda prope coronam per grossitudinem radii in ipsa albedine oculi apparente lachrymalis minoris: deinde impelle almagda cum uirtute: et tu reuoluis cum eo manum tuam, donec penetret in albuginem oculi: et sentias, quod almagda iam peruenit ad rem uacuam.	 Then place the almadga near the corona proximate to the apparent lachrymal of the smaller eye-socket; then push the almadga with force, and you will roll your hand together with it, until it penetrates into the white part of the eye; and you will feel that the almadga has reached the empty space.
Et oportet, ut sit mensura itineris almagda ad profundum, mensura spacii quod est a pupilla usque ad finem nigredinis: et est corona oculi.	 And it is necessary that there be a measure for the journey of the almadga to the depth, a measure of the space from the pupil to the end of the blackness; and this is the corona of the eye.
Uidebis enim ea in ipsa pupilla uisione oculi, propter claritatem tunicae corneae.	 For indeed you will see it in the pupil of the eye itself, due to the clarity of the cornea coating.
Deinde pone almagda usque ad locum in quo est aqua.	 Then place the almadga up until where there is water.
Deinde preme ipsum inferius uice una post aliam.	 Then press it downward once after another.
Si ergo descendit aqua statim, tunc infirmus uidet illud super quod aperit uisum suum statim, et almagda in oculo suo.	 If therefore the water descends immediately, then the sick person sees immediately whatever opens his vision, and the almadga in his eye.
Deinde quiescas paululum.	 Then rest for a little while.
Si ergo descendat aqua, tunc depone eam secundo, praeter quod egrediatur almagda.	 If therefore the water descends, then put it down in the second place, beyond which the almadga emerges.
Quando ergo figitur, et non ascendit: tunc extrahe almagda cum facilitate: et tu reuoluis manum tuam paulatim.	 When it is clogged and does not rise, then extract the almadga with ease; and you roll your hand slowly.
Deinde dissolue in aqua aliquid ex sale claro gemmae: et ablue cum eo oculum deintus.	 Then dissolve something from salt in water of the gemma, and wash the eye with it.
Deinde pone extra oculum totum stuppam, aut lanam infusam oleo rosato, et albugine oui: et liga cum eo oculum sanum.	 Then place over the entire eye all wool soaked in rose oil or linen and the white part of the eye; and bind it with a clean bandage.
Nos autem, et illi qui sunt nostri temporis, ponimus super eum ciminum tritum cum albumine oui.	 We and those who are in our time place over him camphor powder with the white part of the eye.
Quod si non obedit tibi almagda ad introitum in oculum propter duriciem suam, quoniam ex hominibus est, cuius oculus est durus ualde: tunc oportet ut accipias spatumile, quod nominatur Alberid, cuius haec est forma.	 If the almadga does not obey you in entering the eye due to its hardness, since it is from a man whose eye is very hard; then it is necessary that you take Spatholea (Alberid), whose form is as follows:
Pefora ergo cum eo ipsam coniunctiuam tantum, et non ultimes manum tuam in foramine: et non est nisi ut facias uiam ad almagda locum subtilem.	 Perforate only the connecting tissue and not the final joint; and it is not to be done except to make a passage to a subtle place.
Deinde intromitte almagda, secundum quod diximus.	 Then introduce almagda, as we have said.
Et apud complementum operis tui, praeparetur infirmo dormitorium decenter factum, in quo dormiat super dorsum suum in domo tenebrosa: et prohibeatur ab omnibus motibus, et a tussi: et pone cibum eius illud quo lenitur natura eius: et non moueat caput suum dextra, neque sinistra omnino.	 Prepare for your procedure a well-made bed for the sick person in which he may sleep on his back in a dark room; and keep him free from movement, coughing; and put food for him that soothes his nature; and do not let him turn his head to either side at all.
Et sit ligamentum secundum dispositionem suam usque ad diem tertium.	 And let the ligament remain according to its position until the third day.
Deinde solue illud in illa domo tenebrosa, et experire uisum eius: et fac eum uidere res.	 Then dissolve that in the dark room and test his sight; and make him see things.
Deinde reduc ligamentum usque ad diem septimum.	 Then bring back the ligament until the seventh day.
Et non oportet ut faciat illud in hora curationis, aut post incisionem statim: imo oportet, ut alienes illud: propterea quod aqua ascendit uelociter per aspectum uehementem.	 It should not be done during the hour of cure or immediately after cutting; rather it should be done by others because water rises quickly through a vehement heat.
Si autem accidit apostema calidum: tunc oportet ut soluas oculum ante septimum: et rectifica illud cum eo quod sedat apostema, donec sedatur: tunc absolue ipsius uisum, et pone super faciem eius orale quo regatur uisus eius sub eo diebus aliquot, ipso existente in illa domo tenebrosa.	 If, however, an abscess occurs that is hot: then it is necessary to dissolve the eye before the seventh day; and rectify that with what calms the abscess until it is calm; then remove his sight from him and place on his mouth orally whatever regulates his sight during several days, while he remains in that dark room.
Deinde egrediatur a domo gradatim, et conuersetur in casis suis.	 Then leave the house gradually and change into your clothes.
Et scias, quod in zaltea non excusatur discipulus a uisione aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super operationem.	 And know that a student is not allowed to be absent from view often; then he dares at the operation.
Et iam quidem peruenit ad nos quidam ex illis qui sunt de Alayrach, qui dixit, quod factum fuit in Alayrach magdan perforatum, quo sugitur aqua.	 Now someone from those of Alayrach has arrived who said that a large perforation was made in Alayrach where water flows out.
Verum ergo non uidi aliquem in terra uostra, qui fecerit illud: neque legi illud in aliquo ex libris antiquorum: et est possibile, ut sit illud nouum.	 Therefore I have not seen anyone in your country who has done that; nor have I read it in any old books; and it is possible that it is new.
Et istae sunt formae specierum ex magda, ut stet super ea qui ea ignorat.	 These are the shapes and appearances from the hand, so that they may stand upon him who knows them not.
Fiant ex aere proprie: et sint extremitates eorum cum hac eadem subtilitate triangulatae, et extremitas acuta.	 Make from bronze: and let their extremities have the same subtle triangular shape, and the extremity be sharp.
Formae magda.	 Great forms.
¶ De cura Carnis natae in naso.	 Treatment for the born flesh in the nose.
Caput XXIIII.	 Chapter XXIV.
Quandoque nascuntur in naso Carnes diuersae additae, ex quibus est aliquid quod assimilatur scorpioni multorum pedum: et ex ea est caro cancerosa, lapidea, fusci coloris: et ex ea est quae est caro lenis, non fusci coloris.	 Sometimes in the nose are born diverse fleshes added, of which there is something similar to the many-footed scorpion; and from it there is a cancerous flesh, stony, dark colored; and from it there is one that is soft flesh, not dark colored.
In ea ergo quae ex istis carnibus est lenis, non fraudulenta, neque cancerosa, oportet ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas oppositum soli, et aperi nares eius, et proiice uncinum in illas carnes: deinde trahe eas ad exteriora, et incide quod comprehendisti ex eis cum spatumili subtili acuto a parte una, donec scias quod caro tota iam ablata est.	 In the one that is among these fleshes soft, not fraudulent, nor cancerous, you must make the sick man sit facing the sun, and open his nostrils, and thrust the hook into those fleshes; then draw them out to the exterior, and cut what you have grasped with a subtle spoon-like instrument sharp at one side, until you know that all the flesh is removed.
Quod si remaneret aliquid ex ea cuius abscisio non est possibilis: tunc rade illud cum uno instrumentorum subtilium cum facilitate, donec non remaneat ex eo aliquid.	 If anything remains from that one whose removal is not possible; then shave it with a subtle instrument with ease until nothing remains from it.
Si autem sanguis tibi dominatur, aut accidat apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei per id quod oportet: aut est ex apostematibus malignis, tunc propera cauterizando eum, donec abscindatur sanguis, et auferantur omnes carnes.	 If blood dominates you, or a hot boil occurs; then oppose it with the necessary remedy; or if it is among the malignant boils, then hurry to cauterize him, until the blood is removed and all fleshes are removed.
Deinde proiiciatur in nasum post incisionem acetum, et aqua, aut uinum.	 Then vinegar, or water, or wine is thrown into the nose after the incision.
Si autem aperitur nasus, et procedat ex eo humiditas usque ad palatum, tunc scias quia iam sanus est.	 If the nostril opens and moisture proceeds to the palate, then you know that he is well.
Si uero non penetrat humiditas, secundum quod oportet, tunc scias quod intra ipsum est caro nata in superioribus ossibus naris, ad quae non peruenit cum incisione instrumentum.	 If moisture does not penetrate as it should, then you know that there is born flesh within the upper nasal bones, to which the instrument did not reach with the incision.
Tunc ergo oportet, ut intromittas filum lini cui sit quaedam grossitudo, et noda in eo nodos multos: et pone inter omnem nodum quantitatem digiti, aut minus: et ingeniet infirmus, ut mittat extremitatem unam fili in nasum cum radio, aut cum quo possibile est ei postquam fecerit ipsum simile azer: et trahat odoratum suum, donec perueniat usque ad caassum, et egrediatur super guttur suum.	 Then it is necessary that you insert a thread of linen with some thickness and many knots; and place between every knot an amount equal to a digit or less; and make the sick one send out one end of the thread into his nose with a probe, or as he can do after he has done this, similar to the aze; and pull the scented substance until it reaches the cavity, and exit on his throat.
Et multotiens quidem faciunt simile huic Attomi pueri in scholis: et est res facilis ei, qui uult.	 And indeed many times boys do this which is similar to that of Attomus in schools; and it is easy for him who desires it.
Deinde pone duas extremitates fili, extremitatem unam quae egreditur super nasum, et alteram quae remansit in naso.	 Then place two ends of the thread, one which exits on the nose and the other that remains in the nose.
Deinde ac ministra serraturam carnis cum nodis qui sunt in filo.	 Then as a servant, sew together the flesh with knots that are in the thread.
Fac illud donec scias quod carnes iam sunt cum nodis fili.	 Do this until you know that the flesh is now with the knots of the thread.
Deinde extrahe filum: et pone in nasum post abstersionem sanguinis licinium quod imbibisti in unguento aegyptio: fac illud tribus diebus, aut plus, donec unguentum corrodat totum quod remansit ex carnibus.	 Then pull out the thread; and put linen in the nose after bloodletting which you have soaked in Egyptian ointment; do this for three days or more, until the ointment has completely corroded what remains of the flesh.
Deinde pone in fine rei in nasum cannulam de plumbo, diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 Then at the end, put a tube of lead into the nose for some days until it heals.
Si autem indiget curatione quae exiccet, utere illa.	 If however there is need for treatment to dry it, use that.
Ad caputpurgium faciendum, cum quo distillantur olea, et aliae medicinae in nasum, fac illud ex argento, aut aere: quod sit simile lampadi paruae, apertum sicut conchula: et meatus eius similiter.	 For the purge to be made with oil and other medications into the nose, make it of silver or copper; it should be like a small lamp, open as a shell and its opening similarly.
Et si uis fac cannulam clausam, sicut canna.	 And if you wish to make a closed tube, like a tube.
Et conchula instrumenti ad caputpurgium faciendum, sit plena, detecta: cui sit manubrium in postremo eius, cum quo teneas ipsam, quando calefacis in ea oleum, aut quod uis ex succis, et rebus fluxibilibus.	 And the shell instrument for the purge should be full, pierced; to which there should be a handle at the end of it, with which you hold it when heating oil or what you wish from juices and flowable things in it.
Et haec est forma instrumenti.	 And this is the form of the instrument.
¶ De cura Thelul nasi.	 On the treatment of nasal ulcers.
Caput XXV.	 Chapter XXV.
Multotiens nascitur in extremitate nasi Thelul, et magnificatur, et augmentatur cum diebus, donec foedus fit aspectus eius.	 Many times is born at the end of the nose, Thelul, and it swells, and grows larger with days, until its appearance becomes foul.
Et propter illud oportet, ut in cidas illud in principio apparitionis eius, et eradices totum eius.	 And because of that, it is necessary to cut it at the beginning of its appearance and to remove all of it.
Deinde pone super locum, aut cauterium, aut medicinam comburentem quae stat loco eius.	 Then place on the spot either cautery or medicine burning in its place.
Si ergo tardatur incisio eius, donec magnificetur, tunc considera, si est lapideum, durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro: quoniam apostema est cancerosum.	 If the cutting of it is delayed until it swells, then consider if it is hard, stone-like, dark colored, and with few senses; then do not touch it with iron because it is a cancerous boil.
Multotiens enim uidi, qui incidit hmoni apostema, et accidit ex eo malicia magna super illum qui ipsum habebat.	 For often I have seen that one cuts a boil, and great evil comes upon him who has it.
Et si apostema est lenis tactus, non fusci coloris, et uides quod incisio possibilis est in toto eius, tunc euacua infirmum, et incide ipsum sine timore, absque pauore: et cura locum cum eo quod exiccat et constringit, donec sanetur.	 And if the boil is soft and not dark colored, and you see that it can be cut completely, then evacuate the weak, and cut it without fear, without dread; and take care of the place where it was with the remedy to draw it out and constrict it until it heals.
¶ De sutura nasi, et labii, et auris.	 Section on the stitching of the nose, and lip, and ear.
Caput XXVI.	 Chapter 26.
Scias Quia quando accidit solutio continuitatis in una harum cartilaginum, parum confert in ea operatio, nisi in quibusdam hominibus.	 Know that when there is loosening of continuity in one of these cartilages, the operation does not help much unless in certain men.
Oportet ergo quando accidit alicui aliquid ex illo, ut consideres, si est uulnus recens cum sanguine suo: et tunc aggrega duolabia uulneris cum sutura: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Therefore, when something happens to anyone from it, you should consider if it is a recent wound with its blood; and then gather together two strips of the wound with suture; then take care of it until it heals.
Et si solutionis continuitatis labia iam separata sunt, et facta est unaquaeque pars sana: tunc oportet ut excories omnem partem a cute sua apparente, donec sanguinetur.	 And if the loosening of continuity of the lip has already separated and each part is healthy; then it is necessary to remove all the edge from its visible skin until it bleeds.
Deinde aggrega duo labia cum sutura, et stringe ea, et pulueriza super ipsum sanguinem draconis, et olibanum trita: et pone supra pulueres frustum emplastri diafinicon, et alicuius alterius ex emplastris consolidatiuis: et dimitte ipsum ligatum duobus diebus, aut tribus.	 Then gather together the two lips with suture and bind them; then sprinkle over it the powder of dragon's blood and pulverized olibanum; and put on top of the powders a piece of an emollient plaster and any other consolidating plaster; and let it be bound for two or three days.
Deinde solue ipsum, et permuta medicinam: et dimitte ipsum, donec abscindantur fila per se.	 Then dissolve it (the suture), and change the medicine: and let it be until the threads are separated by themselves.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with ointment, until it is healed.
Modus autem suturae est, ut aggreges solutionem continuitatis, aut cum acubus, sicut narrauimus in sutura uentris: aut aggrega solutionem cum filo, sicut feci te scire.	 The method of suturing is to gather the solution of continuity with needles, as we have said in abdominal sutures: or gather the solution with thread, as I have told you.
¶ De extractione nodorum labiorum.	 Chapter on the removal of neck nodes.
Caput XXVII.	 Chapter 27.
Multis Quidem hominibus accidunt plaerumque in interioribus labiorum suorum apostemata dura similia granis herbi: et quaedam eorum minora, et maiora.	 Many men occur, and often in the inner parts of their own lips, hard ulcers similar to grains of grain: and some of them smaller, and others larger.
Ergo oportet ut conuertas labium, et findas super omnem nodum eius, et suspendas ipsum cum uncino, et incidas ipsum ab omni parte.	 Therefore, it is necessary that you turn the lip, and cut on top of every node of it, and hang it up with a hook, and cut it from all sides.
Deinde impleas locum post incisionem zegi trito, donec abscindatur sanguis.	 Then you shall fill the place after the cut with lime until the blood is separated.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto, et curetur locus cum eo, in quo est stipticitas, usquequo sanentur uulnera.	 Then it is scraped with vinegar, and the place where there is hardening is rubbed with it, until the wounds heal.
¶ De incisione carnis natae super gingiuam.	 Chapter on the incision of the flesh of a newborn on the gums.
Caput XXVIII.	 Chapter XXVIII.
Multotiens nascitur super gingiuam caro addiat, quam antiqui nominant abuluss.	 Often flesh grows over the gum, which the ancients called abscesses.
Oportet ergo ut suspendas eam cum uncino: aut teneas eam cum forcipibus, et incidas eam apud radicem suam, et dimittas saniem currere, aut sanguinem.	 Therefore it is necessary to hang it up with a hook or hold it with forceps and cut it at the root, and let the pus run out, or blood.
Deinde pone super locum zegi tritum, aut alios pulueres stipticos, exiccatiuos.	 Then put on top of the place lime or other healing powders, drying.
Quod si redit illa caro post curationem, nam multotiens redit, tunc incide eam secundo, et cauteriza ipsam: ipsa namque non redit post cauterium.	 If that flesh returns after treatment, which often happens, then cut it again the second time and cauterize it; for it does not return after cauterization.
¶ De rasione Dentium cum ferro.	 Chapter on filing of teeth with iron.
Caput XXIX.	 Chapter XXIX.
Quandoque aggregantur in superficiebus Dentium ab interiori et extetiori parte, et inter gingiuas cortices asperi, turpes, et quandoque denigrantur, et citrini fiunt, et uirides, donec peruenit ex illo corruptio ad gingiuam, et foedi fiunt dentes per illud.	 When the teeth accumulate on their surfaces from inside and outside, and between the gums rough, dirty, and sometimes they turn yellowish or greenish, until corruption reaches the gum and the teeth become foul through it.
Oportet ergo ut facias sedere infirmum inter manus tuas, et caput eius in sinu tuo, et rade molam et dentem, in quo apparent tibi cortices, et res similis arenae: donec non remaneat ex eis aliquid, et similiter fac de nigredine, et uiriditate, et citrinitate, et aliis donec mundentur.	 Therefore it is necessary that you make the sick person sit between your hands, and put his head in your lap, and file the pulp and tooth, where the gums appear, and it is like sand; until there remains nothing of them, and similarly do for yellowish, greenish, blackish, and others, until they are cleaned.
Si ergo auferatur quod in eis est a principio rasionis, bonum est: et si non, tunc itera super eos rasionem die alio, secundo, et tertio, donec ad ultimum perueniat studium in eo quod uis.	 If therefore that which is in them at the beginning of reason is removed, it is good: and if not, then apply reason to them on another day, second, and third, until finally study reaches what you desire.
Et scias, quod dens indiget rasoriis diuersarum formarum, multarum figurarum: secundum quod praeparatur operationi tuae: proptera, quod rasorium quo raditur dens ab inferiori parte, est aliud a rasorio quo raditur inter dentes, secundum formas alias.	 And know that the tooth requires variously shaped razors of many shapes; according to which it is prepared for your operation: therefore, because the razor with which the tooth is scraped from below is different from the razor with which it is scraped between the teeth, according to other forms.
Et istae formae rasoriorum sint apud te praeparatae, quas uides.	 These forms of the razors should be prepared by you, which you see.
¶ De extractione doloris Dentium.	 Chapter on the extraction of tooth pain.
Caput XXX.	 Chapter XXX.
Oportet ut cures Dentem a dolore suo cum omni ingenio, et tardes in eradicatione eius.	 It is necessary that you cure Tooth from its pain with all your skill, and be not hasty in its extraction.
Non est enim quod uicem eius suppleat quando eradicatur: quoniam est substantia sublimis: donec quando non est excusatio de eradicatione eius, tunc oportet quando cogitur infirmus eradicare ipsum, ut firmetur, et certificetur apud te dens dolens.	 There is not another to take its place when it is extracted: because it is a substance that rises high: until there is no excuse for its extraction, then if one who is sick must extract it, it should be made firm, and the tooth in pain should be certified by you.
Multotiens enim decipit infirmum dolor, et putat quia est in dente saha et eradicat ipsum: deinde non recedit dolor, donec eradicetur dens infirmus.	 Often pain deceives the sick man and believes that there is worm in tooth and extracts it himself: then the pain does not subside until the diseased tooth is extracted.
Nos enim iam uidimus illud ex operatione phlebotomatorum.	 We have already seen that from phlebotomy. (referring to bloodletting)
Cum ergo certificatur apud te dens dolens ipsemet, tunc oportet ut scarifices in circumitu dentis cum spatumili, in quo sit quiddam uirtutis, donec soluatur gingiua ab omni parte: deinde moue ipsum digitis tuis, aut cum forcipibus subtilibus in primis paulatim, donec concutias ipsum.	 When the tooth in pain is certified by you, then it is necessary that you make an incision around the tooth with a spatula containing something of virtue, until the gums are loosened on all sides: then move it with your fingers or with delicate forceps first slowly, until you shake it.
Deinde loca tunc in eo forcipes magnos locatione bona, et caput infirmi inter genua tua: quod iam bene tenuisti, ita quod non moueatur: deinde trahe dentem secundum rectitudinem, ut non frangas ipsum.	 Then place the large forceps in that place with a good grip, and hold the head of the sick one between your knees: for what you have well held, so that it does not move: then pull the tooth according to its straight line, so as not to break it.
Si ergo non egreditur, tunc accipe aliquod illorum instrumentorum, et intromitte ipsum sub eo ab omni parte cum facilitate, et conare motionem eius, sicut fecisti in primis.	 If it does not come out then take one of those instruments and introduce it below it from all sides with ease, and try to move it as you did at first.
Si autem dens est perforatus, aut corrosus: tunc oportet ut impleas illud foramen panno: et stringas ipsum cum extremitate radii subtilis, ut non frangatur in hora constrictionis tuae super ipsum cum forcipibus.	 If the tooth is perforated or worn away then it is necessary that you fill that hole with a cloth and tie it with the end of a delicate radius so as not to break it during your constriction above it with the forceps.
Et oportet, ut exquisite agas cum scarificatione in circumitu gingiuae ab omni parte multum.	 And you must be careful when making an incision around the gums from all sides a lot.
Et custodi fortitudinem tuam, ut non frangas ipsum, et remaneat pars eius, et redeat super infirmum ex ea malicia quae sit maior dolore eius primo.	 And guard your strength so as not to break it and a part remains of it and returns to the sick one from that mischief which is greater than its initial pain.
Et caue, ne facias illud quod ignorantes faciunt phlebotomatores in festinatione sua, et audacia ipsorum super eradicationem eius, praeter quod administrent illud quod narrauimus.	 And beware, lest you do what ignorant phlebotomists do in haste, and because of their arrogance in excision, except for what we have mentioned.
Multotiens enim faciunt euenire super homines infirmitates magnas, quarum difficiliores sunt ut frangantur, et remaneant radices eius omnes, aut quaedam earum: aut ut extrahant ipsum cum quibusdam ossibus mandibulae: sicut testificati sumus multotiens illud.	 For many times they bring on great afflictions in men, which are difficult to break, and the roots of it remain all or some: or that they extract it with certain jaw bones: as we have often testified this.
Deinde colluatur post eradicationem eius cum uino, aut cum aceto et sale.	 Then it is to be anointed after excision with wine, or with vinegar and salt.
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis ex locis (multotiens enim accidit) tunc tere aliquid ex zegi, et imple cum eo locum: et si non, cauteriza ipsum si non confert tibi zegi.	 If bleeding should occur from the places (for it often happens), then rub something from beeswax and fill the place with it: and if not, cauterize it if you do not have beeswax.
Formae forcipum subtilium quibus mouetur dens in primis, sint longarum extremitatum, breuis manubrii, grossi, ut non duplicentur quando cum eis premitur super dentem: sint sicut uides grossorum manubriorum, donec quando stringis cum eis, non dent seipsas, neque duplicentur: breuium extremitatum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut ex faled decenter facti, directarum extremitatum: et in eorum extremitatibus sint dentes, quorum quidam ingrediantur in quosdam, et stringant constrictione decenti, forti.	 The handles of fine forceps with which the molar is moved should be long at the ends, short at the grip, thick, so that they do not split when pressed upon the tooth: as you see, those of the thick handles, until when you tighten them, they do not slip and do not split: the tips should be short and made of hard iron or well-made copper, pointed tips: and in their tips there should be teeth, some of which enter into some and hold tight with a decent constriction, strong.
Et quandoque fiunt extremitates sicut forma oris auis quae nominatur ciconia, et sunt fortis constrictionis.	 And sometimes the tips are like the shape of a bird's beak, which is called a ciconia, and they are strong in constriction.
¶ De eradicatione Dentium, et extractione ossium mandibularum fractorum.	 Chapter on Extraction of Teeth and Removal of Fractured Jaw Bones.
Caput XXXI.	 Chapter 31.
Quando remanet apud eradicationem Dentis qui frangitur aliquid, tunc oportet ut ponas super locum cotum cum butyro die uno, aut duobus diebus, donec mollificetur locus: deinde intromitte ad ipsum algasti, aut forcipes: quorum extremitates assimilantur ori auis quae nominatur ciconia.	 When something remains after the extraction of a tooth that is breaking, then you should place hot cotton over it for one or two days until the place softens: then insert algaster or forceps, whose tips are similar to the beak of a bird called ciconia.
Forma autem haec est forcipum.	 This form is forceps.
Sint extremitates eorum factae sicut lima deintus: aut sicut aliskilfegi.	 The ends of them (forceps) are made like a plane's edge, or as an aliskilfeghi (a type of forceps).
Si ergo non obedit tibi ad exitum cum istis forcipibus, tunc oportet, ut caues super radicem, et detegas carnem totam, et intromittas instrumentum quod nominatur Palanca parua, cuius forma est haec.	 If therefore it (a part of the body) does not come out with these forceps, then it is necessary that you be careful on the root and expose the whole flesh and introduce an instrument which is called a small Palanca, whose form is this.
Sit breuis extremitatis, grossae parumper: et non sit imbibitum, ut non frangatur.	 Let the end (of the forceps) be short, thick somewhat less: and let it not be filled with liquid, so that it may not break.
Si ergo egreditur radix per illud, est bonum: et si non, iuuare oportet cum istis instrumentis aliis quorum formae sunt istae.	 If therefore the root comes out through this (instrument), it is good: and if not, it is necessary to aid with these other instruments whose forms are these.
Forma primi triangulatae extremitatis, in qua est quaedam grossitudo.	 The form of the first triangular end, in which there is some thickness.
Forma triangulatae extremitatis subtilis.	 The form of the subtle triangular end.
Etiam iuuatur cum hoc instrumento habente duos ramos, cuius haec est forma.	 Also it (the operation) is aided by this instrument having two branches, whose form is this.
Et cum aliis instrumentis et ferramentis quae praecesserunt in rasione dentium.	 And with other instruments and tools which have been mentioned in the ratio of teeth.
Etiam sit iuuamentum cum hoc instrumento quod assimilatur uncino magno, huius formae, triangulatae extremitatis tortae, in qua est quiddam grossitudinis, ut non frangatur: et sit non imbibitum.	 Also aid with this instrument similar to a large nail, whose form is the triangular twisted end with some thickness, so that it may not break: and let it not be filled with liquid.
Et scias, quod instrumenta dentium sunt multa: et similiter reliqua instrumenta non computantur, et artifex prudens, subtilis in arte sua inuenit per se ipsum instrumentum, secundum quod significant ei operatio et aegritudines ipsae.	 And know that the instruments for teeth are many: and similarly other instruments are not accounted, and a skillful artist, subtle in his art, finds for himself an instrument according to what is signified by the operation and the illness itself.
Quoniam ex agritudinibus sunt ad quas non dixerunt antiqui instrumentum, propter diuersitatem specierum earum.	 Because from illnesses there are those for which the ancients did not find an instrument, due to the diversity of their forms.
Si autem frangatur os ex mandibula, aut ex aliis ossibus oris, aut putrefit: tunc perscrutare super ipsum in loco suo cum eo quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis et forcipibus quae dixi in extractione radicum, et iuuare cum gesti, cuius forma est haec.	 If however the bone breaks from the jaw, or from other bones of the face, or it rots: then to investigate on it (the tooth) itself in its place with that which suits it from among instruments and forceps which I have said for extraction of roots, and aid with gesti whose form is this.
Sit in eo quiddam grossitudinis paulatim, ut stringatur, uel teneatur cum eo os, et non fugiat et uadat, donec egrediatur os: et restaura locum cum medicinis conuenientibus ad illud.	Place something of some thickness in it [the wound], gradually so that a bone can be held or tied to it, and it does not escape and move away, until the bone comes out: and restore the place with appropriate medications for it.
Si autem in osse est putredo parua, tunc rade ipsum a putredine sua, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 If there is a small rottenness in the bone, then shave it off from its rot, and treat it until it heals.
De serratura Dentium eminentium super alios.	 On the setting of protruding teeth above others.
Caput XXXII.	 Chapter XXXII.
Quando Dentes eminent non secundum cursum suum naturalem, foeda fit per illud forma: et praecipue quando accidit illud in mulieribus, et puellis, scilicet uenalibus.	 When teeth protrude not according to their natural course, an ugly shape arises from it; and this occurs particularly when it happens in women and girls, that is, in those who menstruate.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	 Therefore you should consider.
Nam si dens est natus post dentem alium, et non locatur, uel est possibilis eius serratura, neque limatura ipsius: tunc eradica ipsum: et si est annexus cum dente alio, tunc incide ipsum cum isto instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	 For if a tooth is born after another tooth and does not settle or can be set, or its removal or trimming is not possible; then uproot it: and if it is attached to another tooth, then cut it with this tool whose form is as follows.
Est simile rostro paruo, et fit ex ferro indo, acutae extremitatis ualde.	 It resembles a small beak and is made from iron with a very sharp tip.
Et sit incisio tua qua ipsum incidis in diebus multis, et propter duriciem dentis, et ut non commoueatur alius ex dentibus.	 And your cut should be such that you make the incision over many days and because of the hardness of the tooth so that another tooth is not disturbed.
Si autem est eminens expositus limaturae suae: tunc lima ipsum cum lima ex indo, cuius forma est haec.	 If it is protruding and exposed to trimming; then trim it with a file made of iron whose form is as follows.
Sit totum ex indo, et manubrium eius minutorum punctorum ualdae, sicut lima cum qua fiunt acus: cum quo limetur dens paulatim in diebus multis cum facilitate, ut non commoueatur dens, et cadat: deinde leni ipsum, in fine rade ipsum cum quibusdam rasoriis.	 It should be made entirely of iron and the handle small with numerous sharp points like a file used to make a needle; with which you can trim the tooth gradually over many days with ease, so that another tooth is not disturbed and it falls out: then smooth it gently, in the end shave it off with certain rasps.
Quod si est dens, ex quo frangatur pars, et laedit linguam: tunc oportet ut limes eum etiam, donec auferatur asperitas illius fractionis, et aequetur: et applanetur, et non laedat linguam, neque corrumpat sermonem.	 If it is a tooth that breaks off and injures the tongue; then it should be filed down until the roughness of the break is removed and leveled: and smoothed, so as not to injure the tongue nor corrupt speech.
¶ De retatione Dentium cum filis auri.	 On the twisting of teeth with threads of gold.
Caput XXXIII.	 Quid autem de extractione dentes in quibus
Quando accidit Dentibus anterioribus concussio et commotio a percussione, aut casu: et non potest infirmus stringere super illud quod comedit ut non cadat: et curasti eos cum medicinis stipticis, et non ualuit curatio: tunc ingenium in eis est, ut stringantur cum filo auri: quoniam argentum fit uiride, et putrefit post dies: sed aurum nunquam mutatur.	 In the case of teeth that have been struck or jolted due to blow or accident and the patient cannot hold what he eats without it falling out; and treatment with medicinal poultices has failed; then it is appropriate for them to be threaded with a gold wire, because silver turns green and rots after days, but gold never changes.
Et sit filum medium in subtilitate et grossicie secundum quantitatem quod capiat inter Dentes.	 And the thread should be of medium thickness and coarseness according to its quantity that it may fit between the teeth.
Et forma quidem retationis est, ut accipias filum, et intromittas duplum eius inter duos dentes sanos: deinde texeas cum duabus extremitatibus fili inter dentes motos, siue unus sit, aut plures, donec peruenias cum tela usque ad dentem sanum alterius partis.	 The shape of the twisting is that you take the thread and insert its double between two healthy teeth; then wind it with its two ends between the moving teeth, whether one or more, until you reach the healthy tooth on the other side with the needle.
Deinde itera texturam usque ad partem a qua incaepisti: et stringe manum tuam cum subtilitate et sapientia, donec non remoueatur prorsus: et sit constrictio tua qua stringis filum, apud radices dentium, ut non euadat.	 Then wind again to the part from where you started; and hold your hand with delicacy and wisdom until it is completely removed; and your pressure when threading the wire should be at the roots of the teeth so that it does not escape.
Deinde incide extremitates fili superfluentes cum forficibus: et aggrega utrumque, et conuerte eas cum gesti: et occulta ipsas inter dentem sanum et dentem motum, ut non laedat linguam: deinde dimittatur ita strictum dum remanet.	 Then cut the excess ends of the thread with scissors; and join both, and turn them towards each other; and hide these under the healthy tooth and the moving tooth so as not to hurt the tongue; then release it when tightly fastened.
Si autem soluitur, aut inciditur, stringe eos cum filo alio, et stabit cum eo taliter tempore toto.	 If it loosens or breaks, thread them with another wire and it will remain in place for the whole time.
Et haec est forma Dentium, et figura retationis duorum dentium sanorum, et duorum dentium motorum, sicut uides.	 And this is the form of teeth and the shape of twisting two healthy teeth and two moving teeth, as you see.
Et quandoque fit, ut redeat dens unus, aut duo post casum urriusque in locis suis, et retentur sicut narrauimus, et remaneant: et non facit illud nisi artifex, prudens, et expertus.	 Sometimes a tooth or teeth return to their place after an accident, and are held as we have said, and remain; this is not done unless by an experienced craftsman who is both wise and skilled.
Et quandoque aptatur aliquod ex ossibus uaccinis: et fit ex eo sicut forma dentis, et ponitur in loco, ex quo munitur dens et stringitur, sicut diximus: et remanet, et seruitur cum eo tempore longo.	 And sometimes a bone from a cow is made suitable: and it is formed like a tooth and placed where the tooth is protected and tightened, as we have said; and it remains and serves for a long time.
¶ De incisione ligamenti quod accidit sub lingua, et prohibet loquelam.	 On the cutting of the ligament that occurs under the tongue, and prevents speech.
Caput XXXIIII.	 Chapter XXXIIII.
Quandoque ligamentum hoc quod accidit sub lingua, est aut naturale, cum quo nascitur homo, aut accidentale, a uulnere quod iam consolidatum est.	 Sometimes this ligament that occurs under the tongue is natural, with which a man is born, or accidental, from a healed wound.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi in capite eius in sinu tuo, et eleua linguam eius: deinde incide illud ligamentum neruosum per latitudinem, donec soluatur lingua a retentione sua.	 The operation in this is to open the weak mouth of the patient in your chest, and lift the tongue; then cut that nerve ligament across its width until the tongue is released from its holding.
Quod si in eo fuerit quiddam duriciei et nodationis, et fuerit illud ex consolidatione uulneris: tunc proiice in illud uncinum, et finde illud per latitudinem, donec incidas ligamentum, et soluatur nodatio.	 If there is something hard and knotty in it, and it is from the consolidation of a wound; then thrust a hook into it and pierce it across its width until you cut the ligament, and the knot is released.
Et caue, ne sit fissura in profundo carnis, et incidas arteriam illic, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And be careful that there is no opening in deep flesh, and do not cut an artery there and let blood flow.
Deinde colluatur in uestigio incisionis cum aqua rosata, aut cum aceto, aut aqua frigida.	 Then it is washed with rose water or vinegar or cold water.
Deinde pone sub lingua licinium ex lino, quod teneat infirmus in omni nocte: ut non consolidetur secundo.	 Then place a flannel of linen under the tongue for the patient to hold at all night so that it does not harden again.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc pone super locum zegi tritum.	 If blood flows out, then place onion paste over the place.
Si uero uincit te sanguis, tunc cauteriza locum cum cauterio lentiginoso, quod conuenit ad illud: deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 If the blood resists you, then cauterize the place with a flat cautery that is suitable for it; then care for it yourself until it heals.
¶ De extractione Ranulae quae fit sub lingua.	 On the removal of ranula that occurs under the tongue.
Caput XXXV.	 Chapter XXXV.
Quandoque accidit sub lingua apostema quod assimilatur Ranae paruae, prohibens linguam ab operatione sua naturali: et fortasse magnificatur adeo, donec implet os.	 Sometimes a boil occurs under the tongue that resembles a small frog, preventing the tongue from performing its natural function; and perhaps it swells so much that it fills the bone.
Et operatio in eo est, ut aperias os infirmi coram sole: et considera apostema.	 The operation in him is, to open the weak bone in the sun's presence: and examine the boil.
Si ergo uides ipsum fusci coloris, aut nigri, durum, cui non inuenit infirmus sensum: tunc non tangas ipsum, quoniam est cancer.	 If you see him of dark or black color, hard, which does not have a weak sensation, then do not touch it because it is cancer.
Et si est decliue ad albedinem, in quo est humiditas, tunc proiice in ipsum uncinum, et incide ipsum cum spatumili subtili, et libera ipsum ab omni parte.	 And if it is hollowed out towards whiteness, in which there is wetness, then throw a hook into it and cut it with a delicate spatula and free it from all sides.
Quod si uincit te sanguis in hora tuae operationis, tunc pone super ipsum zegi tritum, donec abscindatur sanguis: deinde redi ad operationem tuam, donec extrahas ipsum cum complemento eius.	 What if blood presses you during your operation hour, then place upon it a piece of zinc until the blood is separated; afterwards return to your operation until you draw it out with its entirety.
Deinde colluatur cum aceto et sale: et cura ipsum reliqua curatione conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	 Then cleanse it with vinegar and salt; care for the rest of the treatment as suitable to that until it is healed.
¶ De curatione apostematis duarum Amigdalarum.	 § On the cure of two boils, the Molar teeth.
Caput XXXVI.	 Chapter XXXVI.
Quandoque accidunt inter guttur godad, id est, glandulae, quae similantur algodad, quae accidunt deforis: et nominantur duae Amigdalae: quas quando curas cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non sanantur, tunc considera.	 When sometimes they happen near the throat, that is, the glands which resemble the goiters, which appear outside; and they are called the two Molar teeth: when you treat them as we said above in division, and they do not heal, then examine.
Si ergo est apostema durum, fusci coloris, pauci sensus: tunc non tangas ipsum cum ferro.	 If it is a hard boil of dark color with few sensations, then do not touch it with iron.
Et si est rubei coloris, et radix eius est grossa: tunc non tangas ipsum etiam cum ferro, timens fluxum sanguinis, imo dimitte ipsum, donec maturetur.	 And if it is of red color and the root is thick: then do not touch it even with iron, fearing blood flow; rather let it be until it matures.
Et tunc aut perforabis ipsum: aut rumpetur per se.	 And then either you will pierce it or it bursts by itself.
Et si est albi coloris, rotundum, et est radix eius subtilis: tunc oportet ipsum incidi.	 And if it is of white color, round and the root is subtle: then it should be cut.
Et operatio in ipso est, ut consideres ante operationem suam, si quieuit apostema eius calidum quiete completum, aut imminuitur quadam diminutione: tunc ergo fac sedere infirmum coram sole, et caput eius sit in sinu tuo: et aperi os eius, et accipiat seruiens inter manus suas, et premat linguam eius inferius cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma.	 The operation on it is, to examine it before the operation itself, if the boil has stopped being hot and quieted completely or has decreased slightly: then let the patient sit in the sun with his head in your lap; open his mouth, and take a servant between your hands and press his tongue downwards with an instrument of this shape.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere, quod sit subtile sicut cultellus.	 Make it from silver, or brass, that it may be as delicate as a scalpel.
Cum ergo premis cum eo linguam, et ostenditur tibi apostema, et cadit super ipsum uisus tuus: tunc accipe uncinum, et fige ipsum in amigdalam, et extrahe eam ad exteriora quantum potes, praeter quod trahas cum ea aliquid ex tunicis.	 When therefore you press with it your tongue, and the boil is shown to you, and it falls upon the same (boil), then take a hook, and fix it in the boil, and pull it out as far as possible, except that you pull something along with it from the tunics.
Deinde incide eam cum instrumento, cuius haec est forma quae sequitur.	 Then cut it (the abscess) with the instrument which has the following shape:
Assimilatur forficibus: uerumtamen extremitates eius sint curuatae, ita quod orificium cuiusque earum est in directo alterius acute: unde cura ut sit ex ferro indo, aut alfuled imbibitum.	 The forceps are to be made similar: however, the tips of it should be curved, so that the opening of each of them is directly opposite the other's sharp point: therefore, care should be taken that it is made of iron or brass coated with lead.
Si autem non est praesens hoc instrumentum, tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili, cuius haec est forma.	 If this instrument is not present, then cut it with a pair of scissors having such shape.
Sit acutum a parte una, non acutum a parte altera.	 Let one part be sharp, not the other.
Et postquam incidis amigdalam unam, incide alteram secundum hanc eandem speciem incisionis.	 And after cutting one almond, cut the other according to the same shape of the incision.
Deinde post incisionem gargarizet infirmus cum aqua frigida, aut cum aceto et aqua.	 Then, after the incision, the sick person shall rinse with cold water, or with vinegar and water.
Si autem accidat ei fluxus sanguinis, gargarizet cum aqua in qua bulliti sunt cortices granatorum: aut folia myrti, et similia illis ex stipticis, donec abscindatur fluxus sanguinis: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 If bleeding occurs, rinse with water in which the peels of pomegranates have been boiled; or leaves of myrtle, and similar things from willow bark, until the bleeding stops; then take care of him until he is healed.
Et quandoque nascuntur in gutture apostemata alia, praeter amigdalas duas.	 And sometimes boils other than almonds may occur in the throat.
Incide ergo ea secundum quod dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum aequaliter.	 Therefore, cut them as I said for the incision of the two almonds equally.
Et ego quidem iam medicatus fui mulierem ex apostemate, quod natum erat inter guttur eius, quod trahebat ad fuscedinem, pauci sensus, quod iam fere clauserat guttur: et mulier respirabat a meatu stricto, et iam prohibuerat ei comestionem, et potum aquae: et iam peruenerat ad mortem, si remansisset uno die, aut duobus diebus.	 And I myself have been cured of a woman who had a boil that was born in her throat, which dragged her to asphyxia, with few senses, which almost closed her throat; and the woman breathed through a narrow mouth, and she had already prohibited food for herself, and drink of water: and it was about to reach death, if it had remained one or two days.
Et apostema tantum ascenderat, quod emiserat duos ramos, donec exierant super duo foramina nasi.	 The boil had risen only so much that it discharged two branches, until they came out through the two nostrils.
Properaui ergo festinanter, et fixi in unum eorum uncinum.	 I approached quickly and fastened one of them with a hook.
Deinde traxi ipsum, et tracta ex eo est portio magna.	 Then I pulled it, and a large piece came out.
Deinde abscidi eam, ubi comprehendi ex foramine nasi.	 Then I cut it where it was seized from the nostril.
Deinde feci illud ei quod processit ex foramine nasi altero.	 Then I made that which came out through the other nostril hole.
Deinde aperui os eius, et pressi linguam eius: et postea fixi uncinum in ipsum apostema: deinde abscidi ex eo partem eius, et non cucurrit ex eo nisi sanguis paucus: absolutum est ergo guttur mulieris, et incepit statim bibere aquam, deinde accepit ex cibo.	 Then I opened his mouth and pressed his tongue; then I fastened a hook on the boil; then I cut off part of it, but nothing else ran out except a little blood; therefore, the woman's throat was healed, and she began to drink water immediately, then ate food.
Non ergo cessaui incidere ex illo apostemate multotiens tempore longo: et apostema succedebat loco eius quod incidebam, donec prolongatum est nimis et cum ea illud.	 I did not stop cutting from the boil for a long time; and the boil grew in place of what I was cutting until it became too prolonged and with her, [it seems that] I have made it worse.
Ingeniaui ergo, et cauterizaui apostema inter guttur.	 I made an incision and burnt the boil at her throat.
Stetit ergo ab additione: deinde ambulaui a parte, et non sciui quid fecit Deus cum ea post me.	 Therefore it stopped growing; then I went away from there, but I did not know what God did with her after me.
¶ De incisione apostematis uuulae.	 [Section on the incision of a boil in the throat.]
Caput XXXVII.	 Chapter XXXVII.
Quando descendit catarrus ad uuulam, et apostematur, et est long: tunc ipsa nominatur perpendicularis: et si est in inferiori parte grossa, rotunda, tunc ipsa nominatur uua.	 When the catarrh descends to the throat and becomes a boil that is long; then it is called perpendicular; and if it is thick and round in the lower part, then it is called uva.
Quando curatur cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: et uides quod apostema calidum quieuit ab ea, et est subtilis: tunc oportet ut incidas eam.	 When it is treated with what I have said in the division, and there is no improvement; and you see that the boil has become warm and thin; then it should be cut.
Et quae ex ea est aggregata rotunda, et non est ei longitudo, et est sanguinea, aut fusci coloris, aut nigri, et non est ei sensus: tunc oportet ut deuites incisionem eius.	 And what has gathered around it is round and not long, and it is red, dark or black, and there is no sensation; then it should be cut off.
In ea enim est timor super infirmum.	 For there is fear over the sick person.
Oportet ergo quando uides eam secundum modum quem dixi ex albedine, et longitudine sua, ut facias sedere infirmum coram sole: et premas linguam eius cum instrumento, cuius praecessit narratio: deinde fige uncinum in uuam, et trahe eam inferius: et incide eam cum uno duorum instrumentorum quae dixi in incisione duarum amigdalarum.	 Therefore, when you see it according to the manner I have said from whiteness and length, let the sick person sit facing the sun; then press his tongue with the instrument whose description has preceded; then fasten a hook in the boil, and pull it downwards; and cut it with one of the two instruments that I mentioned in the incision of two tonsils.
Et oportet ut non incidas ex ea, nisi illud quod additur super naturalem terminum sine additione.	 It is necessary that you not cut from it, unless what is added exceeds the natural limit without addition.
Nam si tu incidis ex ea plus, laedes uocem et sermonem.	 If you cut more from it, you harm the voice and discourse.
Deinde post incisionem utere eo quod narrauimus in incisione duarum amigdalarum: et cura eam, donec sanetur.	 Then, after the incision, use what we have said concerning the incision of two tonsils and take care of it until it heals.
Si autem terretur infirmus ab incisione: tunc oportet ut utaris ingenio in cauterizatione eius absque timore et pauore.	 If the sick person is afraid of the incision, then it is necessary to use skill in cauterizing it without fear and cowardice.
Et modus cauterii in ea non est, nisi cum aqua acuta: et est, ut ponas caput infirmi in sinu tuo.	 The method of cauterization is not anything but with sharp water and it is, to place the head of the sick person in your lap.
Deinde preme linguam eius cum instrumento quod diximus.	 Then press the tongue with the tool that we have said.
Deinde accipe ex aqua quam dixi tibi in capitulo cauterizandi, et confice cum ea calcem non extinctam, et pone eam non spissam, neque subtilem, et imple ex ea concauitatem huius instrumenti, cuius haec est forma.	 Then take water from the water that I have told you in the chapter on cauterization and melt with it an unquenched lump of chalk and do not make it thick or thin, but fill the hollow of this tool with it, whose shape is as follows:
Sit extremitati eius in qua ponitur medicina concauitas, sicut concauitas cochlearis radii.	 Let the concavity at its end where the medicine is placed be concave like a conch shell's radius.
Et pone instrumentum cum medicina super uuulam ipsam: et infirmus sit iacens super latus suum, ut currat saliua ex ore eius ex intrinseca medicina, ut non descendat ex ea ad guttur ipsius aliquid, et laedat ipsum.	 Place the tool with the medicine on the wound itself: let the sick person lie on his side so that the saliva from his mouth runs out through the internal medicine, so that something does not descend from it to his throat and harm him.
Deinde tene manum tuam cum medicina.	 Then hold your hand with the medicine.
Et tu ex primas eam super uuulam quantitate medietatis horae, donec uideas eam iam denigratam, et sedatam mordicationem medicinae.	 Then you apply it to the wound for the first time with a quantity of half an hour, until you see it darkened and the pain of the medicine subsided.
Et si uis ut accipias cotum, et inuoluas ipsum super extremitatem radii, et infundas cotum cum medicina, et intromittas radium cum coto in cannulam desuper, donec adhaereat cotum super uuulam.	 And if you want to take a piece of cotton and wrap it around the end of the radius, and pour the cotton with the medicine over it, and insert the radius into the canal above it until the cotton sticks to the wound.
Fac illud multotiens, donec consequaris quod uis de cauterizatione uuae.	 Do this repeatedly until you achieve what you want from the cauterization of the vein.
Deinde dimitte eam: ipsa namque arescit et cadit post tres dies, aut quatuor.	 Then let it go: indeed it dries up and falls off after three or four days.
Quod si indiges ut iteres medicinam, itera ipsam: et post cauterizationem absterge in circumitu uuae cum coto imbibito in butyro, et mundifica cum eo quod est in circumitu eius ex medicina: et colluatur cum aqua frigida.	 If you need to apply medicine again, apply it again: and after cauterization, wipe around the area with a cloth soaked in butter and clean it with that which is in the surrounding area from the medicine: and pour cold water over it.
Et curetur extrinsecus cum embrocis, et deintus cum gargarismis, donec sanetur.	 It shall be treated externally with plasters and internally with poultices until healed.
Haec ergo species curationis est salubrior incisione et longinquior a timore.	 Therefore this method of treatment is healthier than surgery and less to be feared.
Et quandoque curatur uuula etiam cum eo quod est subtilius quam cauterium et incisio: curatur enim cum suffumigatione, secundum hunc modum.	 And sometimes the ulcer is treated with a method that is more subtle than cauterization and surgery: it is treated with fumigation, according to this method.
Sume calamentum, et hyssopum, et origanum, et rutam, et sseah, et chamomillam, et abrotanum, et similia eis ex herbis: et aggrega ea omnia, aut quaedam eorum in olla, et submergantur cum aceto, et bulliant: et olla sit lutata cum luto decenter: et sit in medio ollae foramen, super quod componatur instrumentum concauum secundum hunc modum.	 Take calamus, hyssop, origanum, ruta, sassafras, chamomile, abrotanum and similar herbs: mix all of them or some of them in a pot, and submerge them with vinegar, and boil them: the pot should be coated with clay properly: there should be a hole in the middle of the pot, over which an instrument concave according to this method is placed.
Fiat ex argento, aut aere: et intromittatur extremitas, in qua est granatum, in os infirmi, donec ascendat uapor ad uuulam super cannulam, donec obscuretur uuula multum.	 Make it from silver or bronze: and insert the end, where there is a grain, into the sick man's nostril, until the vapor reaches the ulcer through the tube, until the ulcer is covered with a lot.
Deinde itera super ipsam multotiens, donec arescat.	 Then apply it many times over it until it dries up.
Et caue, ne facias hanc curationem in principio aduentus apostematis.	 And beware not to perform this treatment at the beginning of the abscess's arrival.
Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	 Usually pus is added to the abscess: and it should not be done unless at the time of the abscess's decline towards heat.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	 If this instrument is not available to you, then take a cannula and make a layer of ox horn at its end so that the sick man's bone is not burned: because the ox hide prevents the vapor from burning the bone: and this is a good treatment with safety.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	 On the extraction of thorns and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	 Item, si quid in gutture positum inveniri sit,
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	 Also, if anything found in the throat is bone or fish spine, or something else...
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	 Therefore, whatever appears visible from among them [bones or fish spine], that must be extracted after you press the tongue with an instrument near the sun, and when it is made clear to you that it is in the throat...
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	 And whatever is not visible and hidden in the throat, you should make a gentle vomit before the food is digested in the stomach...
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	 Perhaps it will come out attached through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	 Or the sick person swallows a piece of nutmeg or radish root, or a piece of dry bread crumb; or he may take a soft piece of sponge dried and bind it, then swallow it...
