Ergo necesse est ei qui rogatur in curatione eius, ut faciat iacere infirmum super dorsum suum, et incidat totam cutem quae mollificata est super cutem naturalem.	 Therefore, it is necessary for the one who is asked to treat him, that he makes the sick person lie down on his back, and cuts through the entire softened skin over the natural skin.
Deinde aggreget duo labia cum sutura: et si uis, sue in primis superfluitatem cutis mollificatae tribus suturis, aut quatuor, et firma suturam.	 Then gather the two lips together with stitching: and if you wish, or first of all remove the excess softened skin with three or four stitches, and a firm stitch.
Deinde incide inter sututuras.	 Then cut between the stitches.
Deinde cura curatione reliquorum uulnerum, usquequo sanetur, et cadant fila.	 Then take care of the treatment of the remaining wounds until they heal and the threads fall out.
¶ De Castratione.	 [Section Title: Castration]
Caput LXIX.	 Chapter LXIX.
Scias, quod Castratio in lege nostra excommunicata est: et propter illud liceret mihi, ut non rememorarer eius in libro meo isto: et non est necessaria rememoratio eius, nisi propter duos modos.	 Know that castration is excommunicated in our law: and therefore it would be permissible for me not to remember it in my book: and its remembrance is not necessary, unless because of two methods.
Quorum unus est, ut sit illud in scientia medici quando interrogatur de ea: et ut sciat curationem eius cui accidit.	 One reason is that it should be in the knowledge of a physician when he is asked about it: and so that he may know the cure for him to whom it happens.
Et modus alter est, quod nos multotiens indigemus castratione quorundam animalium, propter iuuamenta nostra per illud, sicut arietum, hyrcorum, et gattorum, et similium ex animalibus.	 And the other reason is that we often need castration of some animals for our benefit through it, such as rams, gazelles, and cats, and similar ones among animals.
Dico ergo, quod Castratio fit secundum duos modos.	 Therefore I say that castration is done according to two methods.
Aut per attritionem.	 Or by attrition.
Aut per fissuram, et sectionem.	 Or by a cut and section.
In illa autem quae fit per attritionem, uia operationis est: quod nos faciamus sedere animal in aqua calida, donec mollificentur testiculi eius, et leniantur, et pendeant: deinde attere eos manu tua, donec resoluantur et non appareant sub tactu.	 In that which is done by attrition, the method of operation is this: we make the animal sit in warm water until his testicles become softened and relaxed, and hang down: then rub them with your hand until they dissolve and are not noticeable under touch.
In castratione autem per fissuram et sectionem, oportet ut teneas animal, et premas cutem testiculorum eius cum manu sinistra.	 In castration by cut and section, it is necessary that you hold the animal and press the skin of his testicles with your left hand.
Deinde liga suspensorium, et seca super omne ouum sectione una, donec quando procedunt duo oua: tunc incide ea postquam excoriaueris utrumque, et non dimittas super ea ex sifaket aliquid praeter sifac subtile, quod est super uasa.	 Then tie the suspensorium, and cut through everything with one cut until when two eggs come out: then cut each after you have scoured it, and do not leave anything on them except sifak for the subtle part that is over the vessels.
Et iste modus castrationis est melior eo qui fit per attritonem: quoniam attritio fortasse relinquit aliquid ex testiculis, quare desiderat animal coitum.	 And this method of castration is better than that by attrition because attrition may leave something from the testicles, which makes the animal desire copulation.
Deinde cura uulnus, donec sanetur.	 Then heal the wound until it heals.
¶ De cura Hermafroditae duorum modorum.	 [Section Title] On the care of hermaphrodites in two methods.
Caput LXX.	 Chapter 70.
Hermafrodita ex uiris est secundum duos modos.	 Hermaphroditus is from men according to two modes.
Vnus eorum est, quia apparet in eo quod sequitur spacium, aut in cute testiculorum, in eo quod est inter duos testiculos, figura quasi uulua mulieris, in qua sunt pili: et quandoque currit urina ex eo quod est in cute testiculorum.	 One of them is that there appears in it the space following (?), or in the skin of the testicles, in what is between two testicles, a figure like that of a female womb, in which hairs are present: and sometimes urine flows out of that which is in the skin of the testicles.
In mulieribus autem est species una, et est uulua mulieris super pectinem sicut testiculi uiri parui omnino, eminentes ad exteriora: quorum unus est sicut priapus uiri, et duo sicut duo testiculi.	 In women there is one species, and it is a female womb above the comb (?), like the small testicles of a man, protruding to the exterior: one of them is like the prick of a man, and two like two testicles.
Et curatio trium specierum, duarum ex uiris, et speciei unius ex mulieribus, est: quia oportet ut incidas carnes additas, donec effugiat impressio earum.	 And the treatment of three species, two from men, and one from women, is: because it is necessary to cut the flesh added, until the impression escapes.
Deinde cura eas curatione reliquorum uulnerum.	 Then treat them with the treatment of other wounds.
In specie autem secunda uirorum, ex qua egreditur urina, quae est in cute testiculorum, non est operatio, neque est eius curatio omnino.	 In the second species of men, from which urine flows out (?), which is in the skin of the testicles, there is no operation, nor any treatment at all.
¶ De incisione Tentiginis, et carnis eminentis in uuluis mulierum.	 Chapter on the incision of tentigo and protruding flesh in women's ulcers.
Caput LXXI.	 Chapter LXXI.
Tentigo fortasse additur super rem naturalem, donec foedatur et turpis fit aspectus eius: et quandoque magnificatur in quibusdam mulieribus adeo, donec expanditur sicut in uiris, et peruenit usque ad coitum.	 A tentigo may be added on a natural matter, until it becomes filthy and ugly to look at; and sometimes it is magnified in certain women so much that it expands like in men, and reaches the point of intercourse.
Oportet ergo ut teneas superfluitatem Tentiginis manu, aut cum uncino, et incidas: et non ultimes in incisione, praecipue in profundo radicis: ut non accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 Therefore, it is necessary to hold the excess of tentigo with the hand or with a hook, and to cut; and not at the end of the cutting, especially in the deep roots, so that there is no bleeding.
Deinde cura ipsam curatione uulnerum, donec sanetur.	 Then treat it with the treatment of wounds, until it heals.
Caro autem orta, est caro quae nascitur in orificio matricis, donec impleat ipsum: et fortasse egreditur ad exteriora secundum similitudinem caudae: et propter illud quidam primi nominant aegritudinem caudatam.	 The flesh that arises is the flesh that is born in the opening of the womb, until it fills itself; and perhaps it comes out to the outside like a tail, and because of this some people call the illness 'tailless'.
Oportet ergo ut incidamus eam sicut incidimus Tentiginem, et curemus eam, donec sanetur.	 Therefore, we should cut it as we would cut a tumor, and heal it until it is healed.
¶ De cura Alratica, quae est uulua mulieris non perforata.	 On the treatment of an unperforated female breast lump.
Caput LXXII.	 Chapter LXXII.
Alratica est, ut sit uulua mulieris non perforata, aut sit foramen paruum.	 The vagina should be whole, not perforated, or have a small hole.
Et est aut naturalis, aut accidentalis.	 It is either natural or accidental.
Accidentalis est ex aegritudine quae praecessit: et ipsa quidem fit aut ex carne nata addita, aut sifach subtili, aut spisso: et fit aut in profundo matricis, aut in lateribus eius, aut in superiore ipsius, aut inferiori eius: et prohibet a coitu et impregnatione, et partu, et fortasse prohibet menstrua.	 The accidental [condition] is that which precedes the illness; it itself arises either from added flesh, or thin tissue, or fat; and it occurs either in the depth of the womb, or in its sides, or on its surface, either upper or lower; and it prohibits coitus and conception, and parturition, and possibly menstruation.
Et cognitio illius fit per aspectum obstetricis, si opilatio est apparens propinqua.	 And the knowledge of this [condition] is obtained through the examination by an obstetrician, if the membrane rupture is nearby apparent.
Si autem non est apparens, tunc quaere eam digitis tuis, aut cum radio.	 If it is not visible, then seek it with your fingers, or with a rod.
Si autem opilatio est ex sifach subtili, et est propinqua duobus labiis: tunc propera, et disrumpe ipsam.	 If the membrane rupture is from thin tissue and is near to two lips, then expel it, and tear it apart.
Et est, ut ponas super duo labia puluillos.	 And place a piece of wool on top of the two lips.
Deinde pone indices tuos duarum manuum simul, et mulier sit super dorsum suum expansis cruribus suis.	 Then place your fingers of both hands simultaneously, and let the woman lie down on her back with her legs spread open.
Deinde extende duo labia cum fortitudine, donec disrumpatur sifach subtile, et aperiatur opilatio.	 Then stretch the two lips forcefully, until the thin tissue is torn apart and the membrane rupture is opened.
Deinde accipe lanam, et imbibe eam in oleo, et pone ipsam super locum: et coeat mulier omni die, ut non consolidetur locus uice alia.	 Then take linen, and soak it in oil, and place it on the spot; let the woman anoint this place every day to prevent the area from hardening with a scab.
Si autem sifach est grossum, spissum: tunc oportet ut seces ipsum cum spatumili lato simili folio myrti.	 If the thin tissue is thick and fatty, then it must be cut with a broad sharp-edged leaf of myrtle.
Si autem opilatio est ex carne nata, tunc suspende eam cum uncinis, et incide eam: et sint tecum medicinae quae fluxum sedant sanguinis absque mordicatione, sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus aggregatum cum albugine oui.	 If the membrane rupture is from born flesh, then suspend it with hooks and cut it; have medicines with you which stop bleeding without causing pain, such as acacia, dragon's blood, and pitch mixed with sheep's milk fat.
Deinde administra cannulam ex plumbo amplam, ut non consolidetur uulnus uelociter, teneat eam diebus aliquot: et administra licinium ex lino sicco, deinde curetur reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then administer a wide cannula made of lead to prevent the wound from hardening quickly; hold it for some days; then administer dried flaxseed, and then treat the rest with the usual treatment until it heals.
Et quandoque nasciur in matrice natiuitas carnium aliarum: oportet ergo ut incidantur secundum hunc modum: dum non est apostema cancerosum apostemati enim canceroso quod est in matrice, non fiat contrarietas cum ferro omnino.	 And sometimes is born in the matrix a birth of fleshes of another kind: it is therefore necessary that they are cut according to this manner: while it is not an apostema cancerous, for an apostema cancerous which is in the matrix, there should be no opposition with iron altogether.
¶ De cura hemorroidarum, Athehelil, et Bothor rubeae in uuluis mulierum.	 About the care of hemorrhoids, Athehelil and Bothor regarding red ones in women's veins.
Caput LXXIII.	 Chapter LXXIII.
Hemorroides quidem sunt apertio orificiorum uenarum, donec currit ex eis sanguis multus assidue.	 Hemorrhoids indeed are an opening of veins' orifices, until much blood continuously flows out from them.
Cum ergo antiquantur hemorroides, fiunt thelil: et iam dixi in diuisione species earum, et signa ipsarum: et dicam hic quae ex eis recipiunt curationem, et quae non.	 When hemorrhoids become chronic, they become thrombosed: and I have already said about their species and signs in the division of them; and here I will say what among them receives treatment, and what does not.
Dico ergo, quod hemorroides quae sunt in orificio matricis, et non apparent sensui: tunc non est ei curatio cum ferro.	 Therefore, I say that hemorrhoids which are in the opening of the matrix and do not appear to the senses, then there is no treatment with iron for them.
Quae autem ex eis sunt in orificio matricis super quas cadit sensus, sunt quae curantur.	 But those among them which are on the opening of the matrix above which sensation falls, are those that can be treated.
Oportet ergo ut intromittas mulierem in domum frigidam.	 It is therefore necessary to introduce a woman into a cold house.
Deinde extende athehelil cum forficibus, aut cum panno aspero, et incide eas ex radicibus suis.	 Then extend Athehelil with forceps or with rough cloth, and cut them from their roots.
Deinde pulueriza super eas apud fluxum sanguinis ex uno puluerum incisiuorum absque mordificatione: sicut acacia, et sanguis draconis, et thus, et similia eis.	 Then sprinkle powder over them near the flow of blood from one of the incisions without biting: such as ashes of incense, dragon's blood, thistle, and similar ones.
Deinde impellat pedes eius ad parietem hora una.	 Then push his feet to the wall at hour one.
Postea depone eam in aquam frigidam.	 Afterwards place her in cold water.
Quod si perseuerat fluxus sanguinis: tunc fac eam sedere in decoctione sumach, et corticum granatorum, et gallarum, et similium.	 If the flow of blood persists: then make her sit in a decoction of sumach, and bark of pomegranates, and gallnuts, and similar ones.
Deinde accipe farinam hordei, et confice eam cum melle et aceto, et fac emplastrum cum eo super dorsum eius.	 Then take barley flour, and knead it with honey and vinegar, and make a plaster with it over his back.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis cum eo, bonum est: et si non, fac adhaerere dorso uentosas, et mammillis, absque scarificatione.	 If blood is cut with it, good; and if not, make adhesive ointments (to stick) to the back (wound) of blisters, and nipples, without incision.
Deinde accipe lanam, et submerge in succo tarathit, aut succo arnoglossae, aut succo ramorum alaulat, id est, aglanter, uino pontico, et fac adhaerere loeo.	 Then take wool and immerse it in the juice of tarathith, or the juice of arnoglosso, or the juice of branches of alaulat (aglanter), that is, fig tree leaves, Pontic wine, and make it sticky with beeswax.
Cum ergo quiescit apostema, tunc cura locum cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 When the abscess remains quiet, then take care of the place with ointments until it heals.
Albarth uero rubeum est simile capitibus alhaasse, et est asperi aspectus.	 Albath is red and resembles al-hassa heads, and has a rough appearance.
Oportet ergo ut incidas quod apparet ex eo, secundum quod dixi in thelil aequaliter: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Therefore it is necessary to cut what appears from it (the Albath), as I said earlier on the thighs equally; and take care of it until it heals.
¶ De perforatione Exiturae quae accidit in matrice.	 Chapter on Perforation of the Exitura that occurs in the womb (uterus).
Caput LXXIIII.	 Chapter LXXIV.
Accidunt in matrice species multae apostematum, sicut cancer, et apostema lapideum, et ulcera, et adubelati, et alekilati, id est, herpes, aestiomemus, et fistulae, et hemorroides, et ragadiae, et thelil, et apostema calidum.	 In the womb (uterus) many kinds of abscesses occur, such as cancer, stone-like abscesses, sores, adubelas, alekilas (herpes), fistulas, hemorrhoids, ragadias, thelils, and hot abscesses.
Et ego quidem iam dixi omnes has aegritudines et species earum, et signa ipsarum, et earum curationes in diuisione: necesse est ut dicam in hoc tractatu apostema calidum quod accidit in matrice, quando est ex apostematibus quae colligunt saniem, et uis scire qualiter fit eius apertio cum ferro.	And indeed I have already said all these diseases and their forms, and the signs of them, and their cures, divided; it is necessary that I say in this treatise about the hot abscess that occurs in the matrix, when it is one of the abscesses which collect pus, and you wish to know how its opening with iron is made.
Oportet ergo ut consideres.	 Therefore, consider.
Tunc si dolor apostematis in incaeptione sua est acutus cum percussione sua, et flamma, et febre: et uides ipsum rubere: si cadit super ipsum sensus, tunc non properes cum perforatione eius: et cura ipsum cum eo eo quod iuuat super maturationem, donec quando quiescat acuitas accidentium.	 If the pain of the abscess at its beginning is sharp with striking and flame, and fever; and you see it redden upon it; if pressure is applied to it, then do not perforate it; and treat it in that way which helps for maturation, until when quietness comes to the acuteness of the afflictions.
Tunc oportet ut facias sedere mulierem super sedem quae labeat duo sedilia, et reclinetur, uel appodietur super dorsum suum, et aggreget pedes suos ad partem inferiorem uentris: et sint coxae eius expansae, et ponat brachia sua sub genibus suis, et liget utraque ligamento conueniente ad illud.	 Then it is necessary that you make the woman sit on a chair with two armrests, and she reclines or lies on her back, and places her feet at the lower part of the belly; and let her hips be spread, and she puts her arms under her thighs, and ties both with a bandage fitting to it.
Deinde sedeat obstetrix a latere dextro, et administra instrumentum quo aperitur orificium matricis.	 Then the midwife sits on the right side, and administers the tool for opening the womb's opening.
Cuius forma uenit in eis quae sunt post.	 Its form comes to those who have passed.
Et oportet quando uis administrare hoc instrumentum, ut figas cum Radio profundum matricis mulieris: ut non sit illud quod ingreditur ex instrumento plus, quam profundum matricis, et laedat infirmam.	 And it is necessary when you wish to administer this tool, that you perforate with the point of a deep probe the womb of the woman, so that what enters from the tool is not deeper than the womb, and does not harm the weak.
Si autem fuerit instrumentum magis quam profundum, tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos super tecturam profundi matricis: ut prohibeatur introitus instrumenti totius in profundum matricis: et oportet ut ponat uertiginem, quae currit in instrumento, ex latere superiore: et ut teneat instrumentum, et ut reuoluat minister uertiginem, donec aperiatur profundum matricis.	 If the tool is too deep, then it is necessary that you place powder on top of the deep part of the womb; to prevent the entry of the whole tool into the depth of the womb; and it is necessary that you place a weight, which runs in the tool, on the upper side; and that you hold the tool, and turn the weight, until the deep part of the womb is opened.
Cum ergo apparet Exitura, et tangitur manu, et est lenis et mollis: tunc oportet ut seces ipsam apud caput suum cum spatumili lato.	 When it appears to be excised and is touched with the hand and it is soft and yielding, then it is necessary to cut off that [thing] near its head with a broad lance.
Cum ergo euacuatur sanies, tunc oportet ut ponas in uulnus licinium submersum in oleo rosaceo: aut oleo uiridi, in quo sit quaedam stipticitas: et pone licinium, et extrahe sectionem in profundo matricis.	 When the pus is drained, then it is necessary to place a linen cloth soaked in rose oil or green oil that contains some resin on the wound: and lay the linen cloth, and draw out the incision deeply into the matrix.
Et pone exterius super matricem, et super pectinem lanam mundam submersam in aqua, in qua bullitae sunt maluae.	 Place [something] externally on the matrix and on the bone a clean wool cloth soaked in water in which wormwood has been boiled.
Deinde curetur post duos dies cum unguento quod conuenit ad illud, donec sanetur.	 Then it shall be treated two days later with an ointment suitable for that, until it heals.
Et quandoque abluitur matrix et uulnus, ita quod clisterizatur cum aqua et melle: deinde cum aqua in qua bullita est radix lilii, aut aristolochia longa: deinde redeat ad unguentum.	 And sometimes the matrix and wound is washed so that it is cleansed with water and honey: then with water in which the root of the lily or Aristolochia longa has been boiled: then return to the ointment.
Quod si uulnus absconditum fuerit interius in matrice, tunc oportet ut prohibearis ex curatione eius cum ferro, imo cura ipsum cum eo quod diximus in diuisione.	 If the wound is hidden inside the matrix, then it is necessary to prohibit its treatment with iron: instead, treat it as I have said in the division [section].
¶ Doctrinae Obstetricum, qualiter medicentur embriones uiui, secundum figuram non naturalem egressi.	 Chapter on obstetrics, how to treat living fetuses that have left their normal position.
Caput Lxxu.	 Chapter LXXXVI (86).
Necesse est Obstetrici, ut cognoscat in primis figuram partus naturalis.	 It is necessary for the obstetrician to know first the shape of a natural delivery.
Ex signis ergo eius est, quod quando uides mulierem comprimi ad inferiora, et desiderat odorare aerem, et alleuiatur super eam quod super ipsam est de partu, et festinat exitus embrionis: tunc scias quod iste partus est secundum figuram naturalem, et est exitus eius super caput suum, et secundina cum eo: aut suspensa, uel pendens ex umbilico.	 Therefore, the signs of this [delivery] are as follows: when you see a woman pressing downward and desiring to smell air, and you apply pressure on her in the place of delivery, and she hastens the exit of the fetus: then know that this delivery is in its natural form, and it is an exit over the head of the fetus, and the second one with it: or suspended, or hanging from the navel.
Cum ergo uides haec signa, tunc oportet ut comprimatur uenter eius, ut descendat embrio uelociter.	 When you see these signs, then it is necessary to press on her abdomen so that the fetus descends quickly.
Nam quando descendit super caput suum, descendit secundina cum eo, et mundatur ex illis superfluitatibus mundificatione bona.	 When it [the surgical instrument] descends upon his head, it [the secondary one] also descends with it, and it should be purified from those superfluities by good cleansing.
Qui autem est praeter hunc partum, est innaturalis, illaudabilis.	 However, that which is beyond this parturition, is unnatural, inadmissible.
Quoniam quandoque egreditur foetus super pedes suos, et egreditur corpus eius ante caput ipsius, et pedes eius, et manus eius una, aut pes eius unus: aut egreditur caput eius et manus eius: aut egreditur uentrinus: et fortasse conuertitur super collum suum, et similia ex figuris illaudabilibus.	 For sometimes the fetus emerges with its feet first, and its body emerges before its head, and its feet, and one of its hands; or it emerges with its head and one hand; or it emerges with the umbilical cord, and perhaps it turns on its neck, and similar unadmissible figures.
Necesse est ergo Obstetrici, ut sit prudens, subtilis in istis rebus omnibus, et caueat sibi ab errore et decaeptione: et ego sum ostendens omnem figuram ex eis, et qualiter est ingenium in ea, et significetur per illud, et stetur super ipsum.	 Therefore, it is necessary for the obstetrician to be prudent, subtle in these matters, and to avoid error and deception; and I am showing all the figures from these, and how to understand them, and they are indicated by that, and they stand upon him.
Quando egreditur foetus super caput suum egressione sua naturali, et uehemens fit illud super mulierem, et difficilis fit ei partus, et uides uirtutem eius iam debilitatam: tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, aut mulieres teneant eam: et uapora uuluam eius cum foenugraeco decocto, et cum oleis humidis.	 When the fetus emerges with its head in its natural passage and it becomes difficult for him on the woman, and labor is strong, and you see his strength already weakened; then let her sit on a chair or women hold her; and let her drink warm water with fennel cooked in it, and with moist oils.
Deinde intromittat Obstetrix inter digitos suos Spatumile paruum, et findat cum eo secundinam, et secet eam ungue suo, donec currat quod est in ea ex humiditate: et preme uentrem mulieris, donec descendat foetus.	 Then the obstetrician introduces a small spatula-like instrument between his fingers, and he finds with it the secondary one, and cuts it with his nail until what is in her from moisture runs out; and presses the woman's womb, until the fetus descends.
Si autem non descendit, tunc oportet ut clisterizetur mulier ex mucillagine foenugraeci, cum oleo sisamino.	 If it does not descend, then she must be cleansed with fennel mucilage, with oil of sesame.
Deinde praecipe ei post clistere, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi, et tene os eius et nasum ipsius hora una.	 Then command her after cleansing to be pressed; and make her sneeze with snuff, and hold her mouth and nose for an hour.
Foetus enim egredietur statim.	 The fetus shall immediately exit.
Quod si egrediantur duae manus foetus in primis, iunc oportet ut reducas eas cum facilitate paulatim.	 If two hands come out first from the fetus, then it is necessary to draw them back gently.
Si autem non obedit in introitu, tunc pone mulierem super sedem, et eleua pedes eius sursum: deinde concute sedem super terram: et mulier teneatur, ut non cadat apud concussionem.	 If it does not obey in entering (the birth canal), then place the woman on a chair, and lift her feet up; then strike the chair upon the ground; and hold the woman so that she does not fall during the shock.
Si ergo non egrediuntur manus, et moritur foetus: tunc incide eas, et extrahe residuum foetus: et liga manum eius cum panno, et extrahe ipsum cum aequalitate: nam ipse egredietur.	 If the hands do not come out and the fetus dies, then cut them (the hands) off and take out the remaining fetus; bind its hand with cloth and take it out equally, for it will come out by itself.
¶ Exitus embrionis super pedes suo.	 The emergence of the embryo is on his feet.
Quando egreditur foetus super pedes suos, tunc oportet ut impellat eos sursum: deinde conuertat foetum paulatim: postea aequet ipsum.	 When the fetus emerges on his feet, then you should push them up; then turn the fetus gradually; afterwards straighten it equally.
Deinde accipiat unum pedum eius, et extendat eum paulatim.	 Then take one of its feet and stretch it gradually.
Cum ergo egrediuntur usque ad coxas, tunc praecipe ei, ut comprimatur, et fac eam sternutare cum condisi: egredietur enim, si Deus uoluerit.	 When they (the legs) emerge up to the hips, then command him (the woman) to push and make her sneeze with a pinch; for it will come out if God wills.
Et si non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc reduc foetum paulatim, donec ponas eum secundum figuram naturalem.	 And if it does not come out as we have said, then push the fetus back gently until you position it according to its natural form.
Nam ipse egredietur tunc egressu facili.	 For then it will come out easily with an easy delivery.
Quod si prohibeatur cum eo toto quod narrauimus: tunc accipe ex mucillagine alteae, et oleo sisamino, et gummi soluto: et percute totum in mortario percussione bona: deinde line cum eo uuluam mulieris, et inferius uentris eius.	 If it is forbidden as we have said (to perform the procedure), then take from althea mucilage, sesame oil and dissolved gum; grind it well in a mortar with good pounding; then anoint the woman's womb and below her belly with it.
Deinde fac eam sedere in aqua tepida, donec consequatur hypocundria.	 Then make her sit in warm water until she feels relief (from pain).
Cum ergo uides quod iam calefacta sunt inferiora eius, tunc fac ei sief de myrrha: et suppone ipsum.	 When you see that the lower parts of hers have become warm, then give her something made from myrrh and make her lie down.
Quando ergo tenet sief hora una, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	 When then it holds an hour, then make her sit on a chair.
Deinde fac eam sternutare: et stringe ipsius os et nasum: et preme inferiorem partem uentris compressione facili.	 Then make her sneeze: and bind her mouth and nose: and press the lower part of her abdomen with easy pressure.
Nam foeus egredietur statim.	 For feces will come out immediately.
¶ Exitus foetus super genua et manus.	 Delivery over knees and hands.
Quando egreditur secundum hanc formam, tunc ingeniet in intromittendo manus suas paulatim.	 When it exits in this manner, then insert your hand gradually.
Deinde resupinetur mulier super collum suum, et pendeant pedes eius ad inferiora: et ipsa sit iacens super lectum, et complicet manus suas.	 Then the woman lies on her back, and let her feet hang downwards; and she lies down on the bed, and clasps her hands.
Deinde preme supra uentrem eius paulatim.	 Then press gently over her abdomen.
Deinde extrahe quod est sub pedibus eius ex puluinaribus, donec sit praeparata in inferiori parte.	 Then take out what is under her feet from the pouches until it is prepared below.
Quod si non egreditur foetus, tunc accipe pedes eius, et moue eos motu uehementi.	 If the fetus does not come out, then take hold of her feet and move them with great movement.
Deinde preme quod est supra hypocundria paulatim, donec ascendat foetus ad superiora.	 Then press gently what is above the pubis until the fetus rises to higher parts.
Deinde intromittat manus suas, et aequet foetum paulatim: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimatur, donec egrediatur foetus.	 Then insert your hand and press the fetus gradually; and tell the woman to hold her breath until the fetus is delivered.
¶ Exitus foetus latitudinaliter pendens ex manibus.	 Delivery of the fetus, hanging down broadly from the hands.
Ingenietur in reductione manus eius.	 Insert your hand in reducing her hand.
Si autem non potest reducere eam, tunc eleua mulierem, et fac eam ambulare.	 If it cannot be reduced, then lift the woman and make her walk.
Si uero ambulare non potest, tunc fac eam iacere super lectum: et concute crura eius concussione uehementi.	 If she cannot walk, then let her lie down on the bed; and strike her legs with strong blows.
Deinde administra linimentum quod praeparasti ex mucillaginibus.	 Then administer the ointment you have prepared from mucilages.
Quod si accipit eam partus, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem.	 If she receives her delivery, then make her sit on a chair.
Deinde stude in reductione manus, et aequa foetum secundum figuram naturalem: et fac sternutare mulierem, et praecipe ei, ut comprimat se, donec egrediatur.	 Then strive to reduce the hand, and press the fetus according to its natural shape; and make her sneeze, and tell her to hold her breath until it is delivered.
¶ Exitus foetus super collum suum, expansis manibus, et est facies eius ad dorsum matris suae.	 Delivery of the fetus on its back, with spread hands, and its face to the mother's back.
Oportet ut teneat Obstetrix manum foetus, deinde reuoluat eum paulatim, et aequet eum cum facilitate.	 The obstetrician must hold the fetus and then turn it gradually with ease.
Cum ergo aequatur, tunc pone super uuluam eius quod narrauimus ex oleo et mucillaginibus.	 When it is evened [turned], then place upon its mouth as we have said from oil and mucilages.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut moueatur paulatim.	 Then command him to move slowly.
Cum ergo feceris illud, tunc fac eam sedere super sedem, et praecipe ei ut inclinetur ad latus dextrum.	 When you have done that, then make her sit on a chair, and command her to lean towards the right side.
Deinde praecipe ei, ut comprimatur: et fac eam sternutare cum condisi.	 Then command him to compress [the baby] and make her sneeze with powder.
¶ Exitus foetus praeparati super latus.	 The delivery of the fetus is prepared on the left side.
Quando descendit ad orificium matricis secundum hunc modum cum secundina, tunc scinde secundinam cum ungue tuo, donec euacuetur ex humiditate.	 When it descends to the mother's womb in this manner with the second membrane, then cut the second membrane with your nail until it is expelled by moisture.
Si ergo suspenditur super faciem foetus, et collum eius, tunc incide eam ex umbilico: ut non retineatur, et moriatur.	 If the fetus hangs over the face and its neck, then cut it from the navel so that it is not retained and dies.
Deinde impelle foetum ad interiora, donec ponas eam secundum quod oportet: et praecipe mulieri, ut comprimat se aliquotiens: ipse enim egredietur exitu leui.	 Then push the fetus towards the interior until you place her as necessary; and command the woman to compress herself several times; for it will come out easily with an exit.
¶ Exitus Geminorum, aut foetuum multorum.	 Delivery of twins or many fetuses.
Scias, quod Gemini multotiens nascuntur: et quandoque nascuntur tres, et quatuor.	 You should know that twins are often born; and sometimes three or four are born.
Verumtamen illud extraneum est, et raro contingit.	 However, this is an exception and rarely occurs.
Quinque uero est res extra naturam, et non uiuunt penitus: et continet eos, quamuis multiplicentur, secundina una: et separantur per sifach, distinguens inter eos ligatum in umbilico cuiusque eorum.	 But five is beyond nature and do not live completely; and it contains them, although they are multiplying, by a single second membrane; and they are separated by the siphac, distinguishing the tied one at each of their navels.
Et quandoque egrediuntur sicut egreditur foetus unus exitu naturali, facili: et egrediuntur exitu illaudabili, sicut narrauimus.	 And sometimes they come out like a single fetus through the natural and easy exit, and they come out through an unnatural exit as we have said.
Quod si difficiles fuerint quidam eorum apud partum, et perueniunt ad illud quod diximus ex figuris innaturalibus, tunc cura eos sicut narrauimus: et sit ob stetrix subtilis, et faciat quod facit cum facilitate et tarditate, et ingenietur secundum omnem figuram cum eo quod praeparatur ei ex ingenio ducente ad salutem.	 If some of them are difficult during childbirth and reach what we have said in the unnatural figures, then care for them as we have said: and let the midwife be subtle, and do what she does with ease and slowness, and invent every figure according to the one that is being prepared for him to save.
¶ Rememoratio eius quod formatur in matrice ex embrionibus, et abortiuntur.	 Recall that which forms in the womb from embryos, and they abort.
Quandoque formatur in matrice unus, et duo, et tres, et quatuor, et quinque, et sex, et septem, et plures decem: et iam uerificatum est apud me, quod mulier abortiendo emisit septem, et alia quindecim, omnes formatos.	 Sometimes one, two, three, four, five, six, seven and more than ten are formed in the womb: and it is already proven with me that a woman has expelled seven and another fifteen, all of them being formed.
Quod factum est mensuratione gloriosi sapientis.	 What was done by the measurement of the glorious wise man.
Hoc ergo totum oportet ut sit in scientia Obstetricis.	 Therefore, this entire matter should be in the knowledge of Obstetrics.
Fortasse enim perueniet ad eam simile illius: opponat ergo ei cum illo quod oportet	 Perhaps it may reach a similar one; therefore, confront it with that which is necessary.
¶ De extractione foetus mortui.	 On the extraction of the dead fetus.
Caput LXXVI.	 Chapter LXXVI.
Quando curas foetum mortuum cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex medicatione, et non egreditur, et cogeris uti operatione cum manu, tunc oportet ut consideres.	 When you care for a dead fetus as I said in the division from medication, and it does not come out, and you will have to operate with your hand, then it is necessary that you consider.
Si ergo mulier est sanae uirtutis, et non est cum aliquo ex accidentibus, ex quibus timetur super eam perditio: tunc oportet ut resupinetur mulier super lectum, super dorsum suum, et sit caput eius inclinatum inferius, et crura eius eleuata: et ministra teneat eam a duabus partibus, aut ligetur ad lectum, ut non extrahatur corpus eius apud extractionem foetus.	 If the woman is of good health and not with any accident from which it is feared for her loss: then it is necessary that the woman lies on the bed, on her back, and let her head be inclined downwards, and her legs lifted up; and the attendant holds her from both sides or tied to the bed, so that her body does not come out during the extraction of the fetus.
Deinde humecta os matricis ex oleis humidis cum mucillagine alteae, et foenugraeci, et seminis lini.	 Then moisten the cervix of the womb with moist oils such as olive oil, almond oil, fenugreek and linseed.
Deinde inungat Obstetrix manum suam cum istis oleis et mucillaginibus: deinde intromittat eam in matricem cum facilitate.	 Then the obstetrician wets his hand with these oils and mucilages; then he introduces it into the womb easily.
Deinde quaerat cum ea locum in quo figat uncinos ex foetu, et loca conuenientia ad illud.	 Then he seeks a place where he can insert hooks on the fetus, and places that are suitable for it.
Considera ergo tunc, si foetus est praeparatus ut descendat super caput suum: tunc fige uncinos in oculos eius, aut in collo eius, aut in ore eius, aut in palato ipsius, aut sub barba eius, aut in furcula ipsius, aut in locis propinquis costis, et sub hypocundriis.	 Therefore, consider then if the fetus is ready to descend upon its head; then insert hooks into its eyes, neck, mouth, palate itself, under its beard, in its collarbone, near the ribs, and below the hypochondriac regions.
Si autem descensus est super pedes eius, tunc in pectine, et costis eius mediis.	 If it is a descent (affecting) his feet, then make an incision in his breastbone and in the middle of his ribs.
Et oportet, ut teneat uncinum cum manu dextra: et ponat curuitatem eius in eo quod est inter digitos sinistrae manus: et intromittat cum manu cum facilitate, et figat uncinum in aliquo illorum locorum quae diximus, donec perueniat ad rem uacuam.	 And it is necessary that he holds a hook with his right hand; and places his wound on that which is between the fingers of his left hand; and introduces (his hand) with ease, and strikes the hook in one of those places which we have mentioned, until he reaches an empty space.
Deinde figat in oppositione eius uncinum alium, aut tertium, si indiges: ut sit contractio aequalis, et non declinet ad partem.	 Then strike the hook another or third (time), if necessary; so that the constriction may be equal and not deviate to one side.
Deinde extendatur extensione aequali, et non sit extensio secundum rectitudinem tantum, imo moueatur ad omnem partem, ut alleuietur exitus eius: sicut fit cum dente apud eradicationem eius.	 Then it is extended with an equal extension, and not an extension only in a straight line, but rather moved to all sides, so that the opening may be relieved; as it is done with a tooth during its extraction.
Et oportet in eo quod est inter illud, ut mollificetur extensio.	 And it is necessary that in that place, the extension may be softened.
Quod si retineatur ex eo pars, tunc oportet ut inungat Obstetrix quosdam digitos cum oleo, et intromittat eos ex parte, ut reuoluat cum eis quod retinetur.	 If a part is held back from it (the wound), then it is necessary that the midwife joins some fingers with oil and introduces them from that side to turn what is held back.
Si ergo egreditur pars foetus, tunc permutentur uncini ad locum alium qui sit altior: fac hoc donec egrediatur foetus totus.	 If therefore a part of the fetus comes out, then hooks are changed to another higher place; do this until the entire fetus comes out.
Si ergo egreditur manus ante alia, et non est possibile reducere eam, propter coartationem eius: tunc oportet, ut inuoluatur super eam pannus.	 If therefore a hand comes out before the other and it is not possible to return it because of its bending; then it is necessary that a cloth be wound over it.
Deinde extrahe eam donec quando egreditur tota, incide eam aut in iunctura plantae, aut in cubito: et ita oportet ut facias in manu altera, et in duobus pedibus.	 Then extract it (the hand) until when the entire one comes out; cut it at the joint of the ankle or elbow; and thus it is necessary that you do this in both hands and feet.
Si autem caput foetus est magnum, aut accidit ei coartatio in exitu, aut est in capite eius aqua aggregata: tunc oportet ut intromittat inter digitos Spatumile spinosum, et findat cum eo caput, et extrahat aquam: aut disrumpat ipsum cum instrumento quod nominatur Almisdac: cuius forma uenit cum formis reliquorum instrumentorum in capitulo quod est post hoc.	 If the head of the fetus is large, or there is bending at its exit, or water has collected on it; then it is necessary that a pointed spatula be introduced between the fingers and pierce the head, and extract the water; or break it with an instrument called Almisdac, whose shape comes with the shapes of the other instruments in the chapter following this.
Similiter faciat si foetus est magni capitis natura, tunc oportet ut seces algengematu: aut extrahas ipsum cum misdach, sicut diximus.	 Similarly, perform [the procedure] if the fetus is large-headed by nature, then it is necessary to cut the hairs off [the fetus]; or pull it out with forceps, as we have said.
Deinde attrahas ossa cum forcipibus.	 Then pull out the bones with forceps.
Quod si egrediatur caput, et coartetur apud furculam: tunc findatur, donec effundatur humiditas quae est in pectore.	 If the head comes out and is stuck at the neck, then it is to be split until the moisture that is in the chest is released.
Si autem non complicatur, neque obedit ad exitum: tunc incide caput frustatim, secundum quod possibile est tibi.	 If it does not twist nor yield for an exit, then cut the head intermittently, as you are able.
Quod si inferius uentris est apostematum, aut est in eo hydropisis: tunc oportet ut perfores ipsum, donec currat humiditas ex eo.	 If there is an abscess below the womb or it contains water (hydrops), then pierce it through until the moisture runs out from it.
Si uero foetus est super pedes suos, tunc attractio eius est facilis, et directio eius ad os matricis est leuis.	 If the fetus is large-footed, then its extraction is easy and its direction towards the bone of the womb is light.
Si autem coartatur apud uentrem, aut pectus: tunc oportet ut extrahas ipsum cum panno quem inuoluisti super manum tuam: et findat uentrem, aut pectus, donec currat quod est in eis.	 If it is stuck in the belly or chest, then pull it out with a cloth that you have wrapped over your hand; and split the belly or chest until what is inside runs out from them.
Si autem auferuntur reliqua membra, et redit caput: tunc intromittat Obstetrix manum sinistram.	 If other members are torn away and the head returns, then the midwife should insert her left hand.
Si ergo os matricis est apertum, tunc intromittat manum in profundum matricis, et quaerat cum ea caput, et attrahat ipsum cum digitis usque ad os matricis: deinde intromittat in eo uncinum unum, aut uncinos duos, et attrahat ipsum cum eo.	 If the bone of the womb is open, then insert your hand deep into the womb and search for the head with it, and pull it out with your fingers up to the bone of the womb; then insert a hook or hooks in it and pull it out with them.
Quod si os matricis coartatur, propter apostema calidum quod accidit ei: tunc non oportet ut laboretur super ipsum, imo oportet tunc administrare effusionem rerum humidarum, pinguium: et administra emplastra: et sedeat in aquis quae mollificant et humectant.	 If the bone of the womb is stuck due to a hot abscess that has happened to it, then it should not be pressed upon it, but rather administer warm liquids and oil; and apply poultices; and sit in waters that soften and moisturize.
Quod si foetus est super latus suum, tunc possibile est ut aequetur: tunc administretur quod diximus in foetu uiuo.	 If the fetus is on its side, then it can be turned; then administer what was said for a living fetus.
Quod si non est possibile illud, tunc incidatur frustatim, et extrahatur.	 If it is not possible to do that, then it should be cut piecemeal and extracted.
Et oportet ut non dimittas aliquid ex secundina intus omnino.	 And it is necessary that you do not leave anything inside the seconda at all.
Cum ergo compleueris operationem tuam, tunc administra quod diximus in apostematibus calidis quae accidunt in matricibus.	 Therefore, when you have completed your operation, then administer what we said regarding warm cauteries that occur in the wombs (uteri).
Quod si accidat fluxus sanguinis, tunc descendat in aquis stipticis, et administra reliquam curationem.	 If there is a flow of blood, then it goes down in warm water and administer the remaining treatment.
Et ego quidem iam uidi mulierem, in cuius uentre mortuus erat foetus: deinde impregnata est super ipsum uice alia, postea mortuus est foetus alius etiam.	 I myself have seen a woman whose womb contained a dead fetus; then she became pregnant again with another one, and yet another stillborn fetus was found in her.
Accidit ergo ei post tempus longum apostema in umbilico suo, et inflatum est, donec apertum est: et coepit emittere pus.	 After a long period of time, she developed an aposteme in the navel, which became swollen until it burst open and began to emit pus.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius, et medicatus sum ei tempore longo: et non consolidatum est uulnus.	 Therefore I was summoned for her treatment, and I treated her for a long time; but the wound did not heal.
Posui ergo super ipsum ex quibusdam emplastris fortis attractionis: et exiuit ex loco os.	 So I put on it some strong adhesive plasters; and the bone came out of the place.
Deinde praeterierunt ei dies aliquot, et exiuit os aliud.	 Then after a few days, another bone came out.
Miratus sum ergo inde, cum in uentre non sit os.	 Therefore I was amazed when there was no bone in the womb.
Cogitaui ergo, quia erant ex ossibus foetus mortui.	 Therefore, you thought that the dead fetuses were bones.
Inquisiui ergo uulnus, et extraxi ossa multa, muliere existente in melioribus dispositionibus suis: et iam uixit taliter tempore longo, et mittit ex loco pus parum.	 I asked about the wound and extracted many bones from her, while she was in good health; and she lived for a long time in this condition, and emitted little pus.
Et ego non firmaui hic hoc extraneum, nisi quoniam in eo est scientia, et adiutorium ad illud, quod administrat medicus artifex cum manu ex curatione.	 And I did not bind this foreign body here, except that it contains knowledge and help for what the skilled physician administers when healing with his hand.
¶ De formis Instrumentorum necessariorum in extractione foetus.	 Section on the shapes of necessary instruments for extracting a fetus.
Caput LXXVII.	 Chapter LXXVII.
Hic inferius est forma Strictorii, quo aequantur libri, cui aequaliter sunt duae uertigines in duabus extremitatibus duorum lignorum.	 Here is the form of the Stricture Instrument, by which books are leveled; it has two equal spirals at each end of two pieces of wood.
Verumtamen haec Vertigo oportet ut sit subtilior strictorio: et ut fiat, aut ex ebano, aut ex ligno bussi.	 Nevertheless, this Spiral should be finer than the Stricture Instrument; and for this purpose, it may be made of ivory or boxwood.
Et sit latitudo omnis ligni quasi duo digiti: et margo cuiusque amborum est quasi digitus unus, et longitudo cuiusque eorum est palmus et medietas: et in medio duorum lignorum sunt duo additamenta ex genere eiusdem ligni, quae iam firmata sunt in utrisque, quorum longitudo est medietas palmi et plus parum: et latitudo utriusque est quasi duo digiti, aut plus parum.	 And the width of all the wood should be about two fingers; and the edge of each of both is like one finger, and the length of each of them is a palm and half; and in the middle of two pieces of wood there are two additions made of the same kind of wood which have already been hardened on either side, whose length is half a palm and less; and the width of each of them is about two fingers or less.
Et ista duo additamenta intromittuntur in os matricis, ut aperiatur cum eis quando tu reuoluis duas Vertigines.	 And these two additions are inserted into the mouth of the matrix, to open it when you turn the two spirals.
Forma Vertiginis qua aperitur matrix.	 The form of the Spiral that opens the Matrix.
Forma alia ad simile illius, subtilior, et leuior.	 Another form similar to it but finer and lighter.
Fiat ex ligno ebani, aut bussi, secundum similitudinem forcipum.	 It should be made of ivory or boxwood, according to the resemblance of forceps.
Verumtamen in extremitate eius sint duo additamenta, sicut uides hic supra: et longitudo omnis additamenti ex eis est quasi palmus: et latitudo utriusque est, duo digiti.	 Nevertheless, at its end there should be two additions as you see here above; and the length of all the additions is like a palm; and the width of each of them is about two fingers.
Cum ergo uis aperire matricem cum eo, tunc fac sedere mulierem super lectum, pendentibus pedibus eius, aperto quod est inter crura eius.	 When you wish to open the matrix with it, then have the woman sit on a bed, her legs being hanging down, and that which is between her thighs be opened.
Deinde intromitte ista duo additamenta coniuncta in matricem: et tu es tenens extremitatem instrumenti inferius inter coxas eius.	 Then insert these two connected additions into the matrix; and you hold the end of the instrument lower between her thighs.
Deinde aperi manum tuam cum instrumento, sicut facis cum forficibus, aequaliter secundum quantitatem quam uis ex apertione oris matricis, donec faciat Obstetrix quod uult.	 Then open your hand with the instrument as you do with forceps, equally according to the amount you wish for the opening of the mouth of the matrix, until the midwife does what she wants.
Forma Vertiginis alterius quam dixerunt antiqui Forma Impellentis quo impellitur foetus.	 Form of Dizziness Different Than That Which the Ancients Called Impetigo Fetus (Impulsive Presentation of the Fetus)
Forma Almisdac, qua conteritur caput magnum: et assimilatur forcipi, cui sunt dentes in extremitate, sicut uides.	 The form which breaks the large head: and it resembles a pair of forceps, having teeth at the end, as you see.
Et quandoque fit oblungum, sicut forcipes secundum hanc formam, sicut uides, cui sunt dentes sicut dentes serrae, quo inciditur et conteritur.	 And sometimes it becomes wedge-shaped, as a pair of forceps according to this form, as you see, having teeth like the teeth of a saw, with which it is cut and crushed.
Forma Almisdac quo conteritur caput paruum.	 The form which crushes the small head.
Forma Vncini habentis spinam unam.	 The form of the scissors having one spine.
Forma Vncini habentis spinas duas.	 The form of the scissors having two spines.
Forma forcipis cui sunt dentes serrae, cum quo conteritur caput foetus.	 The form of the forceps with saw-like teeth, with which the fetal head is crushed.
Forma Spatumilis habentis duas extremitates ad abscindendum caput.	 The form of the spatula having two ends for cutting off the head.
Forma duorum Spatumilium etiam latorum.	 The form of two broad spatulas also.
Ista instrumenta omnia exercentur, et quanto plus multiplicantur species eorum, et praeparata sunt apud artificem, est uelocior ad operationem suam, et altior apud homines, propter quantitatem suam.	 All these instruments are used, and the more they multiply in variety, the more prepared they are by the craftsman, is quicker for its operation, and higher among men, because of their quantity.
Non ergo despicies ex eis instrumentum, quin sit apud te praeparatum.	 Therefore do not despise one of these instruments, as if it were not prepared for you.
Inexcusabilis est enim necessitas eorum.	 For the necessity of them is inexcusable (inexorable).
¶ De extractione Secundinae.	 Chapter on Second Extraction.
Caput LXXVIII.	 Chapter 78.
Quando retinetur Secundina apud partum, tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmae, ut retineat anhelitum suum.	 When the second is retained at birth, then it must be commanded to retain its breath.
Deinde fac eam sternutare cum condisi: et stringe manum tuam super os eius, et nares ipsius.	 Then make her sneeze with powder: and press your hand on her mouth, and her own nostrils.
Si ergo egreditur per hoc, bonum est.	 If therefore it exits through this, it is good.
Si non: tunc accipe ollam, et perfora in coopertorio foramen: et pone in ea herbas aperientes os matricis, sicut calamentum, rutam, et anetum, et camomillam, et sseham, et cassiam ligneam, et centauream: accipe omnes istas herbas, aut quasdam earum, et submerge eas cum aqua, et pone eas super ignem.	 If not: then take the pot and pierce a hole in the covering; and place inside it herbs that open the cervix, such as calaminthe, root of ruta, anise, camomile, wood of senna, centaury, and linear cassia; take all these herbs or some of them, submerge them with water, and place them over fire.
Deinde pone embulam arundinis super foramen coopertorii ollae, et extremitatem aliam in os matricis: et teneat eam donec perueniat uapor ad concauitatem matricis.	 Then place the infusion of rushes on the hole of the covering pot and another end into the cervix; hold it until the vapor reaches the concavity of the uterus.
Deinde fac eam sternutare, sicut diximus.	 Then make her sneeze, as we have said.
Secundina enim egredietur cum facilitate.	 For second birth it will exit easily.
Si autem remaneat post hanc curationem, et non egrediatur: tunc praecipe Obstetrici, ut submergat manum suam in oleo sisamino, aut mucillagine alteae.	 If it remains after this treatment and does not exit: then order the midwife to submerge her hand in sesame oil or mallow gum.
Deinde intromittat in uuluam, et quaerat cum ea Secundinam.	 Then insert into the vagina and search for the second child.
Cum ergo inuenerit eam, tunc accipiat eam, et extendat ipsam paulatim.	 When she finds it, then take it and gradually stretch it out.
Si autem fuerit annexa in profundo matricis, tunc intromittat manum, secundum quod narrauimus, donec quando inuenerit Secundinam, et extrahat eam paulatim secundum rectitudinem, ut non cadat matrix apud attractionem uehementem: imo oportet, ut permutetur cum facilitate ad latera dextra et sinistra: deinde addatur in quantitatem attractionis.	 If it is attached deep in the uterus, then insert the hand as we have said until she finds the second child and extracts it gradually in a straight manner so that the matrix does not fall due to violent attraction; rather, it should be moved with ease to the right and left; then add more according to the strength of the attraction.
Ipsa enim obedit tunc, et seruatur, et euadit ab adhaerentia.	 It will obey then, and be saved, and exit from attachment.
Quod si os matricis est coartatum, sicut nos iam narrauimus: cura eam cum sternutatione, et ex medicatione ollae cum herbis.	 If the cervix is constricted, as we have already said: treat it with sneezing and medicine from the pot with herbs.
Si autem non egreditur cum omnibus quae narrauimus, tunc caue ne fatigeris super eam in iteratione extractionis.	 If it does not exit with all that we have said, then beware not to tire her in the repetition of extraction.
Verum oportet, ut quod egreditur ad os matricis ex ea, liges ad coxam mulieris.	 It is necessary that what comes out from the matrix bone should be tied to the woman's hip.
Deinde clisteriza eam cum unguento tetrapharmacon.	 Then, enema her with the four-ingredient ointment.
Ipsum enim putrefaciet eam post dies, et dissoluetur, et egredietur.	 For it will corrupt and dissolve her after days, and will come out.
Verumtamen quando putrefit, eleuatur ex ea odor malus ad stomachum et caput, et laedit illud infirmam.	 However, when it corrupts, raise a bad smell from her to the stomach and head, and injure that which is already weak.
Oportet ergo ut administrentur suffumigationes conuenientes ad illud.	 Therefore, it is necessary that appropriate fumigations be administered for this purpose.
Quidam autem antiquorum iam experti sunt suffumigationem nasturtii, et ficuum siccarum.	 Some of the ancients have already experimented with a fumigation of nasturtium and figs dried in the sun.
Forma instrumenti quo suffumigatur mulier apud retentionem Secundinae et menstruorum.	 The shape of the instrument with which to fumigate the woman during the retention of the Second Stage and periods.
Fiat ex uitro simile alcama, aut ex zere: et ponatur extremitas ampla super ignem: et suffumigatio sit posita super prunas: teneat eam, donec consumatur illa suffumigatio: et itera aliam.	 Make it similar to an alcamea vessel or a jar: and place the wide end over the fire: fumigation should be placed on plums: hold her while that fumigation is consumed: and repeat another one.
¶ De curatione Ani non perforati.	 Chapter on the treatment of an unperforated anus.
Caput LXXIX.	 Chapter LXXIX.
Nascuntur multi puerorum, et Ani eorum sunt non perforati, quos iam opilauit sifac subtile.	 Many boys are born, and the anuses of these babies are not perforated, which have already been opened by a sharp forceps.
Oportet ergo, ut obstetrix perforet illud sifac digito suo: et si non, perforet ipsum cum Spatumili acuto: et caueat lacertum, ne tangat eum.	 Therefore, the midwife must pierce it with her finger; and if she cannot, she must pierce it with a sharp spatula; and be careful not to touch the muscle.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam infusam in uino et oleo.	 Place upon it a cloth soaked in wine and oil.
Deinde cura ipsum cum ungentis, donec sanetur.	 Then take care of it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem times quod opiletur, tunc pone in foramine cannulam de plumbo diebus multis, et auferatur quando puer uult egerere.	 If one fears that it is obstructed, then put a lead tube into the opening and leave it for many days; and when the child wants to come out, it will be removed.
Et iam accidit opilatio Ani etiam ex consolidatione uulneris, aut apostematis.	 And now, obliteration of the anus also occurs due to healing of a wound or an abscess.
Oportet ergo ut secetur illa consolidatio, deinde curetur cum eo quod diximus ex curatione et plumbo.	 Therefore, that consolidation must be cut off; then it should be treated as we have said before with the remedy and lead.
¶ De curatione Fistularum quae accidunt in inferiori parte.	 Chapter on the treatment of fistulas occurring in the lower part.
Caput LXXX.	 Chapter 80.
Fistulae quae accidunt in inferiori, sunt Nodatio, et Grossitudo quae accidunt prope anum deforis: aut in spacio unius partium: et est Fistula una, aut plures.	 Fistulas that occur in the lower part are nodosity and swelling that occur near the anus outside; or in the space of one part; and it is a fistula or multiple fistulas.
Cum ergo antiquatur illa Nodatio, aperitur, et currit ex ea humiditas aquosa alba, aut pus subtile.	 When therefore that old knot is opened, watery white moistness or subtle pus flows out from it.
Et quandoque sunt ex istis Fistulis penetrantes.	 And at times these are penetrating fistulas.
Ergo penetrantes cognoscuntur per illud quod egreditur ex egestione, et uentositate, quando utitur infirmus egestione: et fortasse egreditur ex eis uermis.	 Therefore they are recognized by what comes out during discharge, and by wind when the sick person uses discharge; perhaps a worm comes out of them.
Et sunt ex eis Fistulae quando sunt in spacio penetrantes usque ad uesicam, et usque ad meatum uirgae.	 There are fistulas among these when they penetrate the space to the bladder and to the bowel of the penis.
Et sunt ex eis penetrantes usque ad iuncturam coxae, et usque ad nodum caudae.	 There are also penetrating ones that reach as far as the hip joint and the node of the tail.
Ex eo autem quo cognoscitur Fistula penetrans usque ad anum, etiam a non penetrante, est, ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum: et intromittas tentam subtilem in Fistulam ex aere, aut ferro: quando non est tortuositas.	 From that which a penetrating fistula is recognized to the anus, it is also known from a fistula not penetrating, that you insert your index finger into the anus and insert a probe thin in the fistula made of metal or iron, without twisting, if there is no tortuosity.
Quod si in ea est tortuositas, tunc intromitte in eam tentam ex plumbo subtilem, aut pilum ex pilis equarum, donec sentias tentam, aut pilum in digito tuo.	 If there is twisting [in the fistula], then insert a thin probe of lead or horsehair into it until you feel the probe or the hair on your finger.
Quod si non sentis ipsam penitus, neque procedit ex foramine aliquid ex egestione, neque uentositas, neque uermis sicut dixi: tunc scias, quia est non penetrans: propera ergo ad curationem.	 If you do not feel it to the bottom and nothing comes out from discharge or wind or worm as I said; then you will know that it is not penetrating, so approach for treatment.
Et quando Fistula est penetrans usque ad uesicam, aut ad meatum urinae: tunc significatio eius est exitus urinae ex ea, et prohibitio eius ab hoc ut consolidetur locus cum medicinis.	 And when a fistula is penetrating to the bladder or urethra; its sign is the outflow of urine from it and its prohibition from this, that the location be consolidated with medicines.
Si uero est penetrans usque ad iuncturam coxae, aut ad os coxae: tunc signum eius est, quod perueniat tenta usque illuc, si non est in ea tortuositas usque ad os: et inuentio doloris in circumitu partis, et quod egreditur pus ex ea semper: et quod non ualeat in ea medicatio, neque consolidatur cum unguento.	 If it is penetrating to the hip joint or the hip bone; its sign is that a probe reaches up to there if there is no twisting up to the bone; and pain in the surrounding area, and that pus always comes out from it; and that medicine cannot be effective in it, nor does it consolidate with an ointment.
Et in istis Fistulis omnibus penetrantibus non est curatio omnino: et curatio earum est labor et uanitas ei, ex stultis medicis, super quem formatur.	 In these all penetrating fistulas there is no cure at all: and their cure is labor and futility to him, upon whom they are formed, from foolish physicians.
In illa autem quae non est penetrans, et non antiqua, speratur sanatio cum serro: secundum quod ego narro tibi, et ego iam probaui: et est, ut iaceat infirmus inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et eleua crura eius usque supra coxas ipsius, et coxae eius sint inclinatae ad uentrem ipsius.	 In that which is not penetrating and not old, healing is hoped for with the lancet: according to what I tell you, and I have already proven it: and there lies the sick one between your hands upon his back: and rub his legs up to his hips, and let his hips be inclined toward his own belly.
Deinde intromittetentam plumbi, aut aeris, si est in Fistula tortuositas, donec scias ubi peruenit tenta.	 Then introduce the lead or copper, if there is a winding in the fistula, until you know where the probe reaches.
Si autem sentit eam infirmus circa anum, tunc oportet ut intromittas digitum tuum indicem in anum.	 If the sick one feels it near the anus, then it is necessary that your index finger be introduced into the anus.
Si ergo sentis in digito tuo tentam iam penetrasse per seipsam detectam, praeter quod sentias inter digitum tuum, et inter ipsum sifac, aut carnem: tunc ergo scias certe, quia est penetrans: non ergo labores in ea, quoniam non est eius sanatio, sicut diximus.	 If you therefore feel the probe penetrate by itself, which is detected on your finger and between your finger and the fistula or flesh: then you certainly know that it is penetrating; so do not labor in it, because there is no cure for it, as we have said.
Dixerunt tamen, quia sanatur in quibusdam hominibus caro, et ex medicatione qua ei speratur iuuamentum, est, ut ignias cauterium subtile secundum amplitudinem Fistulae, sicut praecessit, et intromittas ipsum ignitum in Fistulam, donec perueniat circa anum.	 They say that flesh heals in some men, and the remedy by which they hope for help is to burn cauterization as thin as the width of the fistula, as before, and to introduce the burning into the fistula until it reaches near the anus.
Deinde itera illud bis, aut ter, donec scias, quia iam adustae sunt omnes illae carnes additae filtratae, quae sunt similes cannulae pennae auis.	 Then do this twice or thrice until you know that all those added fatty tissues filtered, which are like the quills of a bird's feather, have been burnt.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, donec egrediantur illae carnes, quae adustae sunt: deinde cura illud cum unguentis generantibus carnem et consolidantibus.	 Then care for it with linen cloths in butter until those burnt fats come out: then care for it with ointments generating and consolidating flesh.
Si ergo sanatur, bonum est.	 If therefore it heals, it is good.
Et si non, tunc non sanatur cum alia curatione unquam.	 And if not, then it is never cured with any other treatment.
Et si egreditur tenta, et non peruenerit usque ad digitum tuum, qui est in ano, et est inter ipsum et tentam uelamen spissum ex carne, aut sifac: et uides Fistulam in eo quod sequitur superficiem cutis, tunc seca cutem ab initio Fistulae, et tu uadis secando cum tenta quod est in fistula, donec perueniat secatio ubi peruenit tentae extremitas, et liberatur tenta et cadit.	 If it (the tumor) escapes and does not reach your finger which is inside the anus, and there is a thick layer of flesh or scrotum between it and the tumor, or if you see a fistula on what follows the surface of the skin, then cut the skin from the beginning of the fistula, and you go cutting with the tumor that is in the fistula until you reach the point where the extension of the scrotum ends, and the scrotum is released and falls off.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas, quae assimilantur cannulae pennae auis, ut non remaneat ex eis aliquid.	 Then clean those tissues which resemble the feathers of a bird's quill, so that nothing remains from them.
Si autem uincit te sanguis, et soluit inter te et inter operationem tuam ut seces illas carnes: tunc melius quod fit, et uelocioris iuuamenti, cauterizare eam cum igne, aut cum medicina acuta.	 If blood prevails and breaks through between you and your operation, so that those tissues escape, then it is better and more speedy relief to cauterize it with fire or with a sharp medicine.
Quoniam cauterium cum igne aggregat habitudines bonas, adustionem illarum carnium additarum, et abscisionem sanguinis, et exiccationem humiditatum.	 Because the cautery with fire produces good results by applying heat to those tissues, charring of those added tissues, stopping bleeding, and drying out moisture.
Deinde cura illud cum liciniis inuolutis in butyro, aut caulibus tritis, donec locus emittat pus, et egrediantur illae carnes adustae in pus.	 Then treat it with linens wrapped in butter or cooked leeks until the place emits pus, and those burnt tissues come out into the pus.
Deinde cura tunc uulnus cum unguentis consolidatiuis, generantibus carnem duram: et sunt medicinae in quibus sunt stipticitas et exiccatio.	 Then treat the wound with strengthening ointments that produce hard flesh; there are medicines containing styptics and drying agents.
Nam quando restaurantur, tunc iam sanatur: et non times iterationem.	 For when it is restored, then it is cured; do not fear repetition.
Si autem Fistula iam peruenit usque ad profundum ani, et elongatur a superfluitate corporis: tunc intromitte digitum tuum in anum, et inquire cum eo.	 If the fistula has already reached deep into the anus and is stretched out by the body's excess: then insert your finger into the anus, and examine it with it.
Si ergo sentis tentam, et inter te, et inter eam est uelamen ex sifac, aut carne, et est propinqua penetrationi: tunc non est operatio in illo, nisi secundum uiam fiduciae et spei.	 If you feel a tumor, and there is a layer of scrotum or flesh between it and yourself, which is close to penetrating: then there is no operation on that unless it is according to the path of trust and hope.
Quod est, quia administratur in eo unus trium modorum: aut ut cauterizes ipsam, sicut diximus: aut seces eam, donec consequaris concauitatem eius, ut sit possibile tibi intromittere licinia, et curationem ex proximo.	 That is, because it is administered in him one of the three modes: either to cauterize it itself, as we said; or to excise it, until you reach its concavity, so that it is possible for you to insert a linen, and cure it from nearby.
Et non procedas multum cum sectione, ut non incidas lacertum continentem anum, et accidat super infirmum exitus egestionis absque uoluntate.	 And do not proceed too much with the excision, lest you cut into the flesh containing the anus, and it happen by accident an unfortunate outcome of excretion without will.
Deinde cura illud cum eo quod diximus.	 Then cure that with what I said.
Fortasse enim sanabitur: aut elonges ipsum uelamen, et mundes ipsum postquam secas ipsum usque prope anum, sicut diximus, aut cum tenta, aut cum instrumento alio acutae extremitatis.	 For perhaps it will heal: or lengthen the same membrane and cleanse it after you have cut it up to near the anus, as we said, either with a probe or with another sharp tool.
Deinde mundifica illas carnes filtratas quae sunt in sectione, usque ubi potes cum perscrutatione.	 Then clean those fleshes filtered which are in the excision, as far as you can with examination.
Deinde conare restaurationem uulneris totius cum sectione, et orificio superiore ubi consolidatur: et remanet Fistula aperta in interiore parte anus, et erit leuius super infirmum.	 Then strive for the healing of the whole wound with excision and superior opening where it heals; and the fistula remains open at the interior part of the anus, and it will be easier on the patient.
Et quandoque suitur Fistula secundum hunc modum: et est, quando intromittis tentam in Fistulam: et est in latere ani circa superficiem corporis cum cute et margine ani: tunc accipe tentam perforatae extremitatis, quae est sicut acus aleskef, id est, praeparantium coria, secundum hanc formam.	 And sometimes the fistula is drained in this manner: and it is when you insert a probe into the fistula; and it is on the side of the anus near the surface of the body with skin and margin of the anus; then take the probe perforated at its end, which is like the awl (aleskef), that is, prepared with calfskin, in this form.
Et intromitte in eam filum inuolutum ex quinque filis, et circiter ea.	 And insert into it a thread wound around five strands and around thereabouts.
Deinde intromitte tentam cum filo in Fistulam, donec consequatur concauitatem eius.	 Then insert the probe with a thread into the fistula until you reach its concavity.
Si ergo est penetrans in margine ani interius prope, tunc extrahe filum ex illo foramine: ita ut intromittas digitum tuum in anum, et extrahas extremitatem fili, et aggreges duas extremitates simul: et stringe utramque, et dimitte illud die uno, aut duobus diebus: et quanto plus incidit filum in carne, stringe ipsum bene, donec incidantur illae carnes quae sunt inter duas extremitates fili, et cadant: deinde cura uulnus, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	 If it penetrates into the margin of the anus internally, then pull out the thread from that opening; so that you can insert your finger into the anus and pull out the end of the thread, and bring together its two ends; and tie each one and let it remain for one or two days; and the more the thread cuts into the flesh, the better tie it, until the fleshes between the two ends of the thread fall off and drop away; then cure the wound, until it heals and is cured.
Si autem orificium Fistulae non est penetrans: tunc fac ipsum penetrare quocunque modo praeparatur tibi, nisi sit in profundo multum.	 If, however, the opening of the Fistula is not penetrating: then make it penetrate by any means prepared for you, unless it is in great depth.
Non enim inest tibi, ut facias illud propter lacertum, ut non incidas ipsum.	 For you, there is no need to do that (make an incision) so as not to cut the muscle itself.
Deinde fac cum ea sicut diximus, donec sanetur.	 Then do it as we said, until it is healed.
Forma Spatumilis spinosi quo finditur Fistula, cuius curuitas est acuta ualde, et pars altera est non acuta, ut non incidat illud quod non est necesse, sicut uides.	 Make the spatula for the spiny fistula, whose sharpness is very acute on one side and not acute on the other so as not to cut what is unnecessary, as you can see.
¶ De sutura Hemorroidarum, ex quibus currit sanguis ex incisione earum: et cura fissurarum.	 On sewing hemorrhoids from which blood runs after being cut; and on the treatment of fissures (fissure in ano).
Caput LXXXI.	 Chapter LXXXI.
Sunt Hemorroides secundum duos modos.	 There are hemorrhoids according to two modes.
Aut enim sunt intra anum, similes uesicis carbonum, uel prunarum: aut quasi ipsae sint grana uuae.	 Either they are inside the anus, similar to coal lumps or prunes; or like grains of wheat themselves.
Et ex eis sunt paruae, et magnae: et sanguis currit ex eis semper, et est una, et sunt multae.	 And from these there are small ones and large ones; blood always runs from them, and there is one, and there are many.
Et sunt extra anum, et in extremitatibus eius.	 And they are outside the anus, and at its extremities.
Verumtamen istae quae sunt extra anum, sunt secundum plurimum paucae humiditatis, ex quibus currit aqua citrina, aut parum sanguinis cursu assiduo: et sunt secundum colorem corporis.	 However, those which are outside the anus, are for the most part few in moisture, from which runs either lemon water or a little blood with constant flow; and they are according to the color of the body.
Et curatio eius quae est intra anum, est, ut praecipias infirmo ut assellet: et exprimatur, donec egrediatur anus, et appareant athelil tibi.	 And the treatment of those which are inside the anus is to order the patient to sit on hot water, and it is expressed until it appears outside the anus and appears to you as athelia.
Propterea ergo et suspende cum uncinis: aut tene eos cum ungue tuo.	 Therefore, also hang them with hooks; or hold them with your nail.
Deinde incide eos apud radices suas.	 Then cut them at their roots.
Si autem non retinentur in eis uncini, propter humiditatem eorum et ipsorum mollificationem: tunc cape eos cum panno aspero, aut cum coto ex diploide lanea, et extrahe eos cum digitis tuis.	 If they are not held by hooks due to their moisture and their own softening: then take them with a rough cloth or a glove made of double wool and remove them with your fingers.
Deinde incide eos, et pulueriza super eos post incisionem quosdam pulueres calidos, ut stent eis loco cauterii.	 Then cut them (the vessels), and sprinkle some warm powders over them after the incision for them to remain in place of the cautery.
Aut cauteriza eos secundum quod praecessit in capitulo cauterizandi.	 Either cauterize them according to what preceded in the chapter on cauterization.
Deinde cura eos cum reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	 Then take care of them with the rest of the treatment until they heal.
Quod si non obedit anus egressioni, tunc clisteriza infirmum clisteri in quo sit mordicatio parua, ut lauetur cum eo quod est in ano, et obediat egressioni uelociter, quando exprimit se infirmus.	 If the anus does not obey to evacuation, then enema should be administered with a slight purgative, so that the sick person is cleansed with what is in the anus, and the evacuation is quick when the sick person releases it.
Si autem athelil sunt extrinseci ab ano, tunc res eorum est leuis, facilis: et est ut capias eos cum ungue tuo, aut capias eos cum uncino, et incidas eos.	 If the faeces are outside the anus, then their condition is light and easy; it is good to grasp them with your nail or to grasp them with a tweezers, and cut them.
Deinde cura eos cum eo quod diximus, donec sanentur.	 Then take care of them with what I said before, until they heal.
Et qui abhorret incisionem cum ferro, tunc oportet ut administres suturam eorum secundum hunc modum.	 And if the wound resists cutting with an iron, then it is necessary to apply suture to them in this way.
Accipe filum inuolutum, et intromitte ipsum in acum.	 Take a thread rolled up and insert it into the point.
Deinde extrahe athelil ad superiora, et fac ipsum penetrare cum acu in radice eius ex parte altera: et inuolue duas extremitates fili, in inferiori parte acus, et sint latitudinaliter: et stringe athelil strictura forti.	 Then pull the faeces towards the top and make it penetrate with the point on its root from the other side; and wind up the ends of the thread around the point and let them be broad; and tie the faeces tightly with a strong knot.
Deinde noda filum, et extrahe acum.	 Then tie the thread, and pull out the point.
Fac illud cum omnibus athelil, et dimitte ex eis unum: nec suas ipsum, ut currat ex eo superfluitas sanguinis.	 Do this with all faeces and leave one; do not leave yourself, so that excess of blood flows out from it.
Deinde pone super anum pannum infusum in oleo rosato, aut caeroto, et pone ipsum super anum: et praecipe infirmo, ut quiescat.	 Then place a cloth soaked in rose oil or pitch over the anus and place it on the anus; and order the sick person to rest.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, donec cadat.	 Then let him be until he falls asleep.
Cum ergo cadunt athelil, cura eos cum unguentis, et reliqua curatione, donec sanentur.	 When the faeces fall, take care of them with ointments and the rest of the treatment until they heal.
¶ De cura Fissurarum.	 On treating fissures (or cuts).
Multotiens enim accidunt ex exiccatione stercoris, et constrictione naturae.	 For they often happen due to the removal of feces and constriction of nature.
Cum ergo antiquantur, et non ualet in eis medicina: tunc oportet ut radas cum puncta Spatumilis, aut cum ungue tuo, donec fiant humidae, et auferatur ab eis cortex superior qui prohibet eas a consolidatione.	 When they have become chronic and medicine is not effective on them: then it is necessary that you shave with a spatula or with your nail until they become moist, and the superficial layer which prevents their healing should be removed.
Deinde cura eas, donec consolidentur secundum quod oportet.	 Then care for them until they heal as required.
Si autem non consolidantur: tunc itera eas cum rasione uehementiori quam prima, donec sanguinentur multum, et excorientur deinde cura eas, donec sanentur.	 If they do not heal: then treat them more forcefully than the first time, until they bleed much, and after that care for them until they are healed.
¶ De curatione Almirmar inuersorum, et non inuersorum: et Athelil siccorum, et Formicae.	 On treating an anus that is not right (or abnormal), and one that is normal: and about ulcers (Athelil) and scabies (Formicae).
Caput LXXXII.	 Chapter LXXXII.
Scias quod Almirmar non est nisi nodus rotundus secundum colorem corporis, similis capiti claui: et fit in toto corpore, praecipue in inferioribus partibus pedum, et digitis: et accidit ex eis dolor apud ambulationem.	 Know that Almirmar is only a round swelling similar to the head of a nail, colored like the body, and it occurs throughout the body, particularly in the lower parts of the feet and fingers; and pain occurs during walking from it.
