Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	 Form of a small, fine, bent razor.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	 Form of a razor for cutting bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	 Also the form of a large razor.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	 This resembles a drill and its tip is similar to a saw: it is used at many places due to the reason of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	 The form of a razor that fits for the purpose of cutting through bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	 Its tip is triangular and its angles are sharp.
Fit ex Indi.	 It comes from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	 And likewise it is necessary that all those things which I have said be made of razors, and chisels, and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	 Section on the incising of extremities, and serration (cutting) of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	 Chapter LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	 Extremities become rotten either due to external causes or internal causes.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	 Since you have treated the corruption with medication and it does not help, and you see that the corruption is spreading in a limb that nothing seems to affect: then it is necessary that you incise (cut) the limb up until where the corruption ends, so that the weakened part may escape death or the greater evil which is a defect of the limb.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	 And the sign for this is that the limb darkens (becomes black) until it seems to be dead; or the heat has burned it, or it becomes rotten after turning black: until the rot is cut through up until where it follows the limb and creeps throughout the entire body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	 Therefore when you make the incision and likewise if the cause of the corruption is from the sting of certain venomous creatures such as marine scorpions, weasels, hedgehogs, and similar animals.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	 If therefore corruption or injury is at the extremity of a finger, then cut off the finger and do not leave space for corruption to spread, until it reaches the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	 And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut it off from the root of the wrist, and do not leave space for corruption to spread, until it reaches the arm's bone.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	 And if it invades it (the bone), then cut off the arm at the elbow joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	 If however corruption passes beyond (the arm) and you see it about the elbow: then there is the death of a weak man.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	 And over that (the dead arm), administration of remedy is its amount of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	 And similarly do with the foot, when corruption invades a toe, then cut it off at one of the joints: and if it reaches the heel of the foot, then cut off the entire foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	 And if it ascends to the knee, then cut off the leg at the joint of the knee.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	 If corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no skill in it except to let it go and abandon the weak man to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	 And the method of cutting a member or sewing it is that you tighten the tendon below where you wish to cut, and tighten another tendon above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	 And stretch one of the tendons downwards, and stretch another tendon upwards towards the top.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	 And you separate the flesh that is between two tendons with a broad knife until all the flesh is exposed.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	 Then it is cut or sewn up.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	 And it is necessary that you place a linen cloth over all parts and not let the knife touch any healthy part; and an additional injury occurs to the weak man, and a hot abscess.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	 If however internal bleeding occurs while you are working on it, then quickly cauterize the place; or put some absorbing powders over it to stop the blood flow.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	 Then return to your treatment until it is completed.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable ligament and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	 And I tell you what happened to a man on his foot, the same thing happening to him as I told you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	 This is what happened to him, because his foot turned black due to a burn similar to fire burning it; the decay started with his toe and eventually spread throughout the entire foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	 Therefore, the man cut himself off from himself when he saw the decay spreading through his limb with great pain and burns; he cut himself at the joint, and healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	 And after a long time passed, the same decay occurred in the tip of his thumb on his own hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	 Therefore, he came to me and I tried to regain the loss with the remedy that I placed on his hand after cleansing his body; however, the loss did not stop, instead it spread to another finger, until decay started affecting his entire hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	 Therefore he called for me to cut off his hand; but I refused, hoping to cure the loss; and I also feared death for him during the cutting of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	 Because the man was above his loss.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	 And since he had given up on me, he returned to his own land; and then he came back to me because he was afraid of dying and cut off his entire hand; and he healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	 And I did not bring this narrative except as an aid for that which falls under the genus of this illness; and to show what is signified by it, and according to how it should be done.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	 [Title] On caring for bladder stones and the quality of enema with medications.
Caput XC.	 Head 90.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	 When a boil occurs in some fleshy parts and the space of the boil extends until it makes collection of pus: then it bursts or is perforated and what is in it comes out as pus, and there remains an empty place like a vessel: and the skin that is above it has become thin like a cloth that has already been softened: and it does not reach the final corruption nor presses on bone, nerve, or ligament: it deserves to be called Sinus: and it is not called Fistula: however, if the space of it extends until corruption presses into one of these parts, then it is called Fistula, or ulcer.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	 And the care of this [fistula or sinus] is that you cut the entire skin as it is rolled up: and especially when it has become thin like a cloth: and trust that it will not adhere to the place because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	 If you hope that the skin will adhere and the ultimate corruption does not follow from this: and if there is a thickness in the skin due to flesh, then treat it with Clisterium: and it is to be considered as a sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	 Then if it is large and the pus that is emitted from it has a foul odor: then clisterize it with a medicine from Egypt, which is vinegar, oil, and zinziber, parts receiving equal amounts, mixed together in a vessel: and boil it over fire, until the medicine turns red: and let it become thick like honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	 Then take from it whatever is necessary for you: and dissolve it with water and honey, and clisterize the sinus with it: and tie up its opening, and let the medicine remain in it for two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	 Then remove it by pressing: do this for days until the sinus is purified and the foul smell is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	 And at times, one cleanses with water and ashes when this medicine is not present to you; and it is to be known that you receive the ashes of vinewood or ashes from holm oaks; and you throw water upon it.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	 Then wash her, and cleanse with it until you are confident that the sinus is already cleaned.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	 If the patient cannot bear Egyptian medicine or water and ashes, then cleanse him with water and honey, to which something from crushed wine lees has already been added.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	 Or cleanse him with honey and wine mixed together, because the property of honey is to purify and cleanse; and wine makes the sinus adhere, especially when there is an excess of stiffness and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	 When you do that several times and are confident that the corruption of the sinus has been removed, then cleanse him with it which causes flesh to grow in it.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	 And it is to be known that you receive from the plaster diaphanicon; and you dissolve it with rose oil and stiptic wine; or cleanse him with certain medicines and other unguents whose properties I have written about in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	 If the opening of the sinus is narrow and cannot take a cannula for cleansing; then expand it slightly with iron; or place linen wound around an Egyptian ointment or basilicon ointment inside it until it expands.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	 And similarly, if the opening is also wide, then bring together the edges with a suture; and allow the quantity of cleansing solution to enter it without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	 And similarly, if the opening from which pus flows is elevated above; then cut it in a lower place within it so that the pus runs out below; because pus when obstructed in the depth of the sinus prevents flesh from growing in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	 If it is not possible for you to cut the bladder lower than you wish: then try, so that you prepare the member with a preparation by which pus runs out from it easily according to your preparation.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	 Try not to retain anything from pus within it: and take the consolidating medicines that are placed upon the sign, suitable for what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	 Spread them over a linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	 And let the cloth be of such quantity that there may be communication throughout the bladder.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	 Then cut with scissors directly into the bladder opening, larger than the bladder opening by a little bit.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	 Then spread ointments gently over another cloth, according to the size of the opening: and place it on top, at a distance from the bladder opening, in order to promote the outflow of pus from it: and do not remove the large cloth unless after several days, one by one.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	 He who is on top of the bladder opening, he is the one you remove at every hour, so that what collects in it from pus may come out: and know that, whether what flows out from it is much or little, digested or undigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	 And with this, again consider the place of the bladder itself, whether its master feels pain there or not, and whether there is an abscess there or not.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	 When your medicine is thus applied and you see the material that flows out from the bladder opening, then know that the bladder has already adhered or approaches adhesion: then dissolve it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you dissolve the wound, then change the cloth, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	 If pus flows out from the bladder after a long time with a subtle smell, then do not despair of its adhesion, for healing is approaching, since there are some people who slow down the regeneration of flesh in their wounds, and there are those who act contrary to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If however it comes out from the Sinus for many days as a putrid boil, then you shall know that the sinus is not adhered.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	 If the adhering sinus delays and its matter prolongs, then you shall add humid medicines with dry properties to it, as the doctors do; but they should be medicines that are moist in substance and dry in power, like dyafinicon ointment, when superfluous addition is added to it from zegi.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	 And from the last [part] that is treated, it is that you shall receive dyafinicon ointment, and let it be dissolved with rose oil, and rub over it aged wine equal in substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	 Then mix it with that and use it.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	 And now make one similar to this action, when you do not have dyafinicon ointment at hand, honey; when you boil it until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	 Or take myrrh, aloes, and olibanum; grind the whole thing and powder it over honey while it is on fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	 Then lay a cloth over it and bind it to the sinus; and anoint with the honey you boiled until thickened, and powder its shape, and place it over the cloth and bind it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	 And sometimes administered to him is long aristolochia, and the roots of celestial lily, and it is lily; and wheat flour, and knotgrass.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	 Use them singly or combined, grind them and sift the powder; and sprinkle it over the honey I told you about, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	 If the matter of the sinus prolongs and does not heal with this treatment, then you shall know that there is corruption in its depth; or it has already made an impression on the bones or hard members or ligaments; then treat it with fistula cure, as mentioned before.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	 On the treatment of Panaritis and a worn nail, and the incision of a finger, and a section.
Caput XCI.	 De Curatione Ulceris et Erysipelatis,
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	 Aposteme which occurs under the nail of the thumb or big toe of the hand or foot; perhaps it also arises in other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	 When the matter of this (Panaritis) is prolonged and neglected, it becomes an aposteme that is treated with heat; it may rot and discharge pus until it corrodes the root of the nail; perhaps it rots completely, and the corruption reaches the bone, so that there is a foul smell; and the end of the finger becomes wide and darkens.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	 When you treat it (the affected part), and your treatment does not improve it: then it is necessary to cut with the iron the entire excess that remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	 Cauterize the wound after that.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	 For cautery is very beneficial.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	 If the bone is healthy and the nail also is healthy, and the hollow additions of the nail already press the flesh towards the inside and begin to pierce it and harm it: then it is necessary that you place subtle radium under the corner of the nail which pierces the flesh, and push it up: and cut the flesh easily, and place on top of what remains of the flesh from medicines burning, corrosive ones, until all of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then heal it with ointments, until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	 If the corruption already presses on the bone, then it is necessary to cut that bone and extract it; for a corrupted bone never heals while it remains in there.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	 If you see corrosion and corruption advancing on the finger, then cut it at one joint, according to what was previously mentioned about its memory (anatomy).
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then heal it, until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 If there is wear or injury of the nail, and a violent pain occurs in it: then it is necessary to use leeches first.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	 Then cut the nail with a sharp spatula cut crosswise from above to below.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	 And keep, so that the cut does not reach the flesh which is under the nail, for you will cause a very violent pain to occur above it, and it will be a cause for the growth of additional flesh in that place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	 Then heal the place with what soothes the pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	 A finger which is born in some human hands, perhaps it is entirely fleshy; and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail in it: and some of them are born at the joint of the root, or its birthplace is in some joints of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	 He who is born in certain knots of the finger, is not moved; and he who is born near the junction of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	 The flesh that grows from them is easily divided.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	 It should be cut at its root with a broad spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	 But the treatment of one born at the junction of the root is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	 Therefore, refrain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	 However, in the one born on the finger at the end of the knots, then it is necessary to cut its flesh with a round incision up to the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	 Then saw the bone with one of those saws suitable for that.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	 The consolidation that happens between the fingers occurs frequently either from human birth, that is, being born with it, or from a wound consolidation, or burning by fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	 Therefore, it is necessary to cut the consolidated part until the fingers return to their natural shape.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	 Then place a cloth or linen soaked in rose oil between them to prevent them from consolidating quickly and separate them; or place a thin lead plate between them until the location is healed as needed.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	 And similarly, if consolidation happens with some fingers at the palm, then cut the consolidated part as needed and conform to the shape of the member.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	 Chapter on the defect in incisions.
Caput XCII.	 Chapter CXII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	 The veins are twisted, thick, full of melancholic excesses that occur in various parts of the body; and most frequently they occur in the legs, especially those who travel and work hard, and those who carry heavy loads.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	 It is necessary that you administer the lancing of the body from black choler several times by a strong lancing.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	 Then, phlebotomy (bloodletting) of the patient's basilic vein.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	 The treatment (of these things) with iron (lancet), is according to two methods.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	 One method is to score it (the affected area) and to draw out black blood.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	 And another method is to elevate the Vein and extract it entirely.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	 The incision of this [vein] is according to this method.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	 Irrigate the leg first with much hot water until the thick, foul blood dissolves.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	 Then bind the weak leg from the upper part of the hip of that [leg], up to the lower part of the thigh with a bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	 Then cut the vein at one, or two, or three wide sections.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	 Then lift (eleua), that is, draw blood from the lower part of the leg towards the upper part, and it should first be done by the leech for the weak [patient].
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	 Then cut the nail with what is below it (down to its base): until the quantity of blood that you see is sufficient, and what strength the weak [patient] can bear.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	 Then bind (it), and command him to abstain from foods that cause black bile; and repeat the evacuation and leeching when the veins are full, for it may harm the weak [patient].
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	 The lifting (eleuatio) of this [vein] is according to this method.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	 Scrape the weak leg if there are many hairs in it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	 Then immerse it [the leg] in a bath, or irrigate it in the leg with hot water until it turns red and the veins swell; or exercise it with strong movements if there is no bath present for him, until the limb becomes warm.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	 Then make an incision along the direction of the vein in length: or at the end [of the vein] near the knee, or at the lower part of it near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	 Then open the skin with the scalpel and scrape off the vein from all sides until it is felt: and at its appearance, it will turn from red to blackish-blue.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	 When it comes from the skin, it appears white as if it were a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	 Then insert the Radium under it until it is raised and comes out of the skin; suspend it with a blind hook, soft.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	 Then cut another section near that section with three fingers.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	 Then peel the skin from above the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	 Then lift it up with the radii as you did before, and suspend it with another hook as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	 Then cut another section or several sections if necessary for that one.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	 Then peel it and cut the last section at the heel.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	 Then extract from the section above that one.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	 Do this until you extract it from the upper or highest section, or all sections until it comes out completely; then cut it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	 If it does not obey you to be extracted and lifted; then insert a lancet with a strong thread twice, tie it and extract it yourself or insert the radii under it and turn your hand over all parts until it comes out.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	 And be careful not to cut it.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	 For if it is cut, it will become very difficult for you to lift it up and it may enter into the wound from that causing harm.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	 When you have extracted it completely; then place a linen cloth soaked in wine and rose oil or olive oil over the wound site and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	 If the vein is contracted having a winding with coiling to parts and it is not as we said according to the straightness; then you should make an incision over all its winding parts and the sites of its coiling.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	 Then suspend it with hooks until you lift it up completely; and be careful at your incision site not to cut the vein or wound; for it will become very difficult for you to lift or extract it.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	 Preserve therefore your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	 The method by which a vine is healed (or treated).
Forma Vncini caeci.	 The shape of the blind man's (catheter) cup.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 It is not narrow like other catheters nor has a sharp tip that would injure the vein; rather it is rounded and flexible because if it were too fine, it would pierce the vein with its fineness; on the contrary, it should have excess roundness, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	 On the extraction of a leg vein.
Caput XCIII.	 Chapter XCIII.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	 This vein is generated in the legs of warm lands, such as Alizegi and Arabia, and in dry, warm lands of little softness, that is, where no plant or tree grows.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	 And perhaps it is also generated in other parts of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	 And indeed its generation is from the putrefaction that occurs under the skin, such as happens within snake and ascaris worms, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	 And a sign of the beginning of this vein's occurrence is a violent inflammation in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	 Then the area is blistered.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	 Then the vein begins to come out from that blistered area, as if it were a root of a plant or an animal. This is followed by a series of further instructions on how to safely extract the vein, including using hot irons and cauterizing the surrounding tissue. The translation ends
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	 When its end appears, then wrap a piece of lead weighing one keil dram around it, up to two and a half drams; and let the suspended lead hang from the leg. This is part of instructions on how to safely extract the vein by wrapping it with lead to prevent it from collapsing or breaking during the extraction process.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	 Whenever something comes out of it towards the exterior, wrap it in lead and tie it up. This instruction is likely meant to prevent infection during the extraction process by keeping the vein covered and contained. The translation ends here.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	 If it extends too much, then cut off that part and turn up the remaining part.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	 Do not cut it at the root before it has emerged completely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	 Because if you cut it, it contracts and enters into the flesh; it causes an abscess to appear, and pus at the site, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	 Therefore, it should be treated gently and drawn out slowly until it has emerged entirely from its end, and nothing is left in the body from it: and this vein emerges from some humans that is as long as five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	 And now it has come to me, because it has emerged from a man of twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	 If it is cut during your treatment time: then insert a ray into its opening and pierce it with a long hole along with the body until everything that is in it from matter has been evacuated; and administer the rotting of the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	 Then cure it with treatment for abscesses.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	 This vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself; and holes occur in it, and a branch comes out from every hole.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	 Therefore, take care of it as we said in the division, and with what was mentioned earlier.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	 Section on worms generated under the skin, and this is called Bouina's disease.
Caput XCIIII.	 Chapter XCIII.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	 This disease is called Bouina's disease in a certain land among us; because it often occurs in cows, and there is a small worm that is born between the skin and flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	 And it travels through the body, moving up and down; and it is detected by the senses during walking of a limb to another, until it bursts anywhere that it bursts on the skin, and comes out.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	 And its generation is from the corruption of certain humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	 As it happens with worms and snakes, that is, earthworms and roundworms in the abdomen.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	 And feared from its malignancy.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	 Because when it moves in the body and is raised to the head and reaches the place: then perhaps it opens there, and goes out, and destroys the eye; and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	 Therefore, in order to cure it and remove it, this is not done except during its movement, and the perception of it by the senses.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	 Therefore, one should tighten what is above it and what is below it with a strong ligature.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut above it and remove it.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	 If it penetrates into the flesh, and you do not find it: then place a cautery over the spot with fire until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	 And what is feared more, is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	 If, however, you see it already having reached the head near the eye, then tighten under it with a good ligature above the eyebrow.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	 Then cut above it and remove it.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	 And the sick person should use cleanliness of his body, with medicines dissolving corrupting bad humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	 And let him avoid foods that cause corruption.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	 Chapter on the incision for the disease of Nakir.
Caput XCV.	 Chapter XCV.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	 This disease is called in our land Nakir; it is a pain that occurs in certain members, and then changes from member to member.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And I myself have seen this, as I am telling you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	 I was called to a sick woman in certain villages.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	 And she extended her arm, and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the arm.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	 And when an hour had passed, I saw a swelling move with a rod, as a worm moves, quickly ascending to the man's shoulder: it was like living silver running from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	 Therefore, pain left that place and was fixed in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	 After an hour it ran through the rest of the body until it reached another arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	 Then he told me that it was rotating throughout its entire body, as I had seen.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	 Therefore, I was amazed at the swiftness of the change from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	 And indeed, before that, I had never seen this sickness appear to my eyes in such a way.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	 However, I saw many who found the pain change from limb to limb; and I did not see it with my own eyes as I did in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	 And I do not think that it was anything other than the fact that she was from those who are dry of body vessels; hence, this appears to indicate a windiness changed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	 And it is necessary that it does not appear in those who are sweet-smelling and moist bodies of concealed veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	 Therefore, when you wish to cure it and the patient feels that pain; then if it is apparent to you, as we said, then press on it quickly and below it; cut above it until that windiness pressed out; and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	 If however you do not see it with your eyes; then cure it by expelling the body and that which expels windiness; and crush them with foul pills and pills of myrrh and similar substances.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	 Chapter on Extraction of Arrows.
Caput XCVI.	 Head LXVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	 Arrows are differentiated according to their types and the places where they fall on the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	 However, the diversity of ears is as follows: because among them are those with large tips and small ones; and concave ones, and those without openings.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	 And among them are those with three corners.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	 And among them are those with tongues (projectile points).
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	 And among them are those with stars (points with multiple prongs).
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	 But those which fall on the limbs, are according to two types.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	 Or the limbs are hollow, like the brain, heart, liver, lung, kidneys, intestines, bladder, and similar organs.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	 When therefore it falls in one of these members, and signs of death appear to you, which I tell you afterwards, then it is necessary that you devote extraction of that arrow from them, for death follows it in whom it is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	 And when these signs do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden deep within the member, then extract it, and take care of the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	 From the signs of the brain when an arrow falls into it and penetrates a bone, and exits above the brain, are: since sudden headaches occur from this, and blindness, and dizziness, and redness in the eyes, and swelling, and redness of the tongue, and spasms, and confusion of intellect, and vomiting of cholera.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	 And perhaps blood comes out from the nose, or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	 And perhaps speech is cut off, and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	 And moisture comes out from the wound's place, white like plaster.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	 And it comes out of it resembling a meaty fluid.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	 If therefore these signs appear to you, then refrain from treatment, and extract the arrow if it does not come out by itself.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	 The signs of the arrow when it falls on the heart are: that it is close to the left nipple, and one feels as if it were fixed in a hard object, not in an empty one.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	 And perhaps the arrow's movement is similar to a pulse movement, and black blood runs from the wound.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	 And it follows that coldness of the limbs, and cold sweat, and fainting occur.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	 Know therefore, that death is descending without doubt.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	 And the sign of an arrow wounding the lung is the exit of foamy blood from the wound, and the vessels that follow the neck are to be cut off, and the color of the sick is to be changed.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	 And it exhales a large, deep breath and seeks attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	 If an arrow falls into the lung, which is in the chest; then it is near to small ribs: and a great panting with intense pain, with sigh, occurs; and all limbs of shoulders move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	 And if an arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something undigested comes out through the wound from food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	 And if an arrow falls into the abdomen and pierces it: something of feces comes out through the wound, or pus, or an intestine that is already ruptured.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	 Therefore there is no hope for his cure, nor for the removal of the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 If an arrow falls into the bladder and passes urine: and something passes out from it to the outside, and the pain is stronger upon the sick; then you know that it is fatal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	 Remaining members, such as the face, neck, throat, spatula, aid, dorsal spine, fork, hip, leg, and similar limbs are saved according to several arrangements: when the arrow does not hit an artery or a nerve; and the arrow is not venomous.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	 And I tell you what I have seen of these arrows, to indicate to you by that on your cure.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	 That is, because a man had an arrow fall into his eye socket near the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	 Therefore I removed it myself from the other side, under the cheek of his ear; and he was cured, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	 I also removed another arrow from a Jew that had fallen on his eye under the lower eyelid; and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not get hold of it except for its small end, with which it adhered to its wood; and the arrow was large among arrows of Turkish bows, with soft iron, in which there are no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	 The Jew has been healed, and no accidental evil has happened to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	 And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	 The arrow was Arabic, and it belonged to those with ears [i.e., humans].
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	 So I cut through him on top of two windpipes; and by now he was drowned within his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	 I was sharpened with that [instrument], until I extracted it; and the Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	 I extracted another arrow from a man who had fallen into his abdomen; and we thought he would die because of it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	 After thirty days had passed and nothing changed in his condition, I made an incision over the arrow; I sharpened myself upon it and extracted it; and he was healed, and no accidental evil happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	 And I saw a man who had an arrow lodged in his back, and the wound was healed over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	 After seven years it came out [of the body] from the root of his hipbone.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	 I saw a woman who had an arrow lodged in her abdomen, and the wound was healed over it; but the arrow remained within her, and nothing changed in her condition or caused her any harm in her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	 I saw another man who had an arrow lodged in his face; the wound healed over it, and there was little pain for him; and similar things happened to many others.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	 I extracted an arrow from a nobleman of the King who had fallen into the middle of his nose and had already deviated slightly towards the right; but the entire arrow was hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	 I was called to treat him after the fall of the arrow for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	 I found therefore a wound of an arrow very tightly closed.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	 I probed it with delicate tweezers and did not feel it: and himself he found a puncture and pain on his right side of the ear.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	 I hoped therefore that it was this puncture from the tip of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	 I applied a plaster to the place with a drawing ointment having an attracting and dissolving property, trusting that the spot would open and show me the sign of the arrow so that I might cut above it: and it did not happen at the place where it should have happened, showing that the arrow had passed through.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	 I stayed with the plaster over him for many days: and it did not happen as expected, and the wound hardened in the meantime: and he remained weak from the extraction of it for a space of many days, until he felt the arrow one day within his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	 And he told me that.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	 I placed over the wound medicine that was sharp and corrosive for many days until it opened: and when I probed it with delicate tweezers, I felt the fine tip of the arrow sticking to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	 Then I added to the opening of the wound with this sharp medicine until the tip of the arrow appeared clearly to us: and it passed me with that space of time about four months.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	 Then when the wound had swollen and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it, and move it, it did not obey to come out: then I did not stop probing, and devising on it with means of ingenuity, until I began one day with correctly made forceps according to the form that they will take at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	 Then I healed the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	 And physicians indeed judge, that the nasal cartilage does not restore.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	 I therefore restored it, and the wound healed, and the patient recovered with complete health; nothing at all harmed him.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	 And I tell you the quality of extraction of some arrows: that you may place that rule and meaning on what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	 Because the parts and distinctions of this art are not comprehended with the narrative; nor does that book contain it, and a wise craftsman compares little with much; and with what is present, concerning what is absent; and finds a new operation, and a new instrument in the descent of foreign matters of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	 Therefore I say that arrows do not exit from the members to which they are fixed, unless according to two modes.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	 Or by attraction from the place from whence it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	 Or in reverse direction of another part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	 And that which goes out from whence it entered is an arrow proceeding into a soft place; and it is attracted and exits.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	 If it does not obey for an exit from the hour at which it falls: then it is necessary that you leave it for some days, until the flesh which is around it rots away; and the attraction of it will cease, and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	 And similarly if it strikes a bone, and does not obey you for an exit, then leave it also for some days; and move it with attraction and motion every day until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	 If it does not obey you for an exit after days, then it is necessary that you bore around the arrow in the bone on every side with a subtle chisel until the arrows swell.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	 Then attract it and draw out the arrow.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	 If the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head, and it has already advanced into one of the ventricles of the brain, and some of the symptoms which I said appear weak: then refrain from attracting the arrow, and leave it until it is balanced in its existence for days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	 If an arrow reaches the sifach (shinbone), then it does not prolong death.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	 If the arrow is not fixed except within the body of a bone but does not reach the shinbone and it remains weak for some days without any other incident happening, then skill is used in attracting the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	 If it is fixed firmly and does not obey you when trying to attract it, then apply the iron gouge around the arrow as I have told you; afterwards take care of the wound until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	 If the arrow is already hidden within the body and concealed from sensation, then search for it with a probe.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	 If you feel it (the arrow), then attract it using certain instruments suitable for the task.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	 If you cannot reach the arrow due to the constriction of the wound and the length of the arrow being deep; and there is no bone, nerve, or vein in that area: then pierce it (the arrow) and wait for the wound to expand so that it becomes possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	 If there are ears that hold the arrow fast on all sides: then free the fixed flesh from them by any means you can; and if you cannot lift the flesh due to a fracture of the ears or twisting of them, wait until it breaks out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	 And when you administer the extraction of the arrow in any location, then use the twisting of your hand with pliers for all parts; until it breaks out: and with great subtlety to avoid breaking the arrow, making its attraction difficult and the extraction itself.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	 If you cannot reach it (the arrow) for an hour: then leave it for some days until the things around it rot away.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	 Then probe it again; for the wound will close itself, but if it causes blood flow contrary to you: then administer what I have said in its treatment in its chapter; and protect your strength from cutting a vein, nerve, or tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	 And administer your art in every way possible to the removal of an arrow: and let it be with ease, calmness, slowness or firmness as I told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	 And it is necessary that when you pull out the arrow, it should be weakened according to the form (shape) by which it was lodged inside (the wound).
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	 Because it is more helpful (for the patient's recovery).
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	 If however, that is not possible for you, then administer what is possible according to shapes (arrowheads or arrows of different types).
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	 The arrow that comes out from the opposite side of the other part or has already proceeded outwards, or makes a hump at the end of the arrow by a sensation on the upper part of the skin nearby, and you see it protruding: therefore, cut above it, and let the incision be according to the quantity that forceps can grasp in it.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	 Then pull it out: for it becomes easy to come out by itself.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	 If however it is retained in the bone, then turn your hand according to its roundness, until the arrow presses against the bone and widens itself: then pull it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	 And if it does not (come out): let it be for some days; then try again until it comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	 If the shaft of the arrow is in it (the wound), then push it out with the shaft.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	 If however the shaft has fallen out, and you wish to administer a push: then insert an instrument with a hollow (concave) end into it so that it enters the concavity of the arrowhead; then push it out with the same (instrument).
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	 If however the arrow is concave, then push it out with the instrument inserted into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	 For the arrow will be loosened by that (method).
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	 If the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to excavate all the flesh in which the poison is, if that is possible for you.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	 Then care for her as is fitting until that point.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	 If an arrow is falling into the chest, or into the belly, or into the bladder, or into the side: and it is near by what you touch with the probe, and it can be cut through it: then cut through it, and be careful not to cut a vein, or a nerve, and pull it out.
Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	 Then suture the wound, if you see it, and care for it until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	 And this is the shape of the forceps with which arrows are pulled out.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	 The ends should be shaped like a bird's beak, made of iron: when they grasp the arrow, they do not let go of it.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	 And they are made in many shapes: large, small, and medium-sized, according to the size of the arrow, and its thinness, and the width of the wound, and its narrowness.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	 The shape of the impeller is concave.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	 And the shape of the impeller is deaf.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	 This is a deaf end like a radius, so that its entrance into the concave arrowhead is relieved, and it is driven with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	 The end of the concave impeller is concave like a bird's feather: so that the entry of the arrow into it is relieved and its thrust.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	 Chapter on venous bleeding.
Caput XCVII.	 Chapter XCVII.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	 Veins for bleeding, whose custom has run in the body, are thirty.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	 In the head there are sixteen: two pulsating veins that are behind the ears, called two herbs; and two arteries, appearing in two temples; and two veins which are in the two tear ducts of both eyes, called "Aspicientes"; and a prepared vein in the middle of the forehead; and a vein at the end of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	 And two jugular veins, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	 And two veins that are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	 And two veins that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	 And these are the veins called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	 And two veins that are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	 However, the veins that are bled in arms are five in every arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	 One of them is Cephalic and it is from the forest side; and the common people call it vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	 And Fusca.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	 And it is the middle vein, and it is composed of a branch of the basilica, and a branch of the cephalica; and they call it the vein of the body in common speech.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	 And Basilica, and it is placed on the domestic side; and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	 And the common people call it the vein of the belly.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	 And [it is] the arm vein, and it is placed on the fork: and this is where phlebotomy is performed, and this is that which appears above the thumb by a manifest protrusion.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	 And the little Saviour: and it is the vein which is between the anular and the cube [bone]: and there are to it two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	 And in the leg and in the foot, there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	 One of them is that which is under the bend of the thumb from the side of the little finger.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	 And the second is the saphenous vein: and its place is at the heel from the domestic side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 And the vein of Nessus: and its place is at the heel from the side of the forest.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	 And in another leg, there are three veins similar to these.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	 Chapter on phlebotomy of two veins after the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	 The phlebotomy of two veins which are after the ears, is helpful for old catarrhs, and hemiheadache, and scrofulas, and old sores on the head.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	 And the quality of [the procedure] is according to what I have said [before].
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	 And it is, that the head of the sick person should be shaved: and the nape of his head should be rubbed in the place of two veins with a rough cloth rubbing good.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	 Then the sick person should tighten his neck with a bandage until the two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	 And their places are behind the ears, in two depressed places of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	 So seek them with your finger, and where you feel their pulsations under your finger, mark that place with the branding iron.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	 Then take a phlebotomy knife, and this is called the Incisor.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	 Then insert it under the vein into the flesh, until the phlebotomist reaches the bone.
