Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	 Then, extend your hand with the vein and skin towards above, and cut the vein with an incision that includes the skin.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	 And let the length of the incision be the size of two joined fingers, or about that: and let out as much blood as you want.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	 Then, tie it with sutures and release it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	 And now, the excision and cauterization of these (vessels) begins at the start of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	 Chapter on Phlebotomy of Two Arteries in Time(s).
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	 The phlebotomy of the two arteries which are in two times is helpful for an old hemigraine: and for a painful sciatica, and for a constant headache: and for the flow of superfluous fluids that are sharp towards the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	 And the quality of phlebotomy (phlebotomizing) them is as I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	 Let the sick person tighten his neck much until two veins appear clearly to the sense through visible manifestation: and let the pulsation of them be shown under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	 Then, (make) signs with the cauterizing iron.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	 Then, extend the skin above the vein towards above with your index finger and insert the lancet from below: and extend the vein towards above.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 Then, cut it as you did with two other veins: and let out blood according to your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	 Then, loosen the constriction of the sick person, and place your finger on the vein at the hour position.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	 Then, place a linen cloth over it and sutures: and tie it tightly above with strong constriction: and release it until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	 And now, the reminder of them, and their excision, and their extraction begins at the start of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	 On phlebotomy of the front vein after phlebotomy in the head.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	 Remedy for phlebotomy of the front vein is after phlebotomy in the head, for old facial diseases: and for migraine, and redness: and for foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	 And the quality of its phlebotomy is as I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	 Tie the sick man's neck with a bandage until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	 Then take the instrument called "Fossorium".
Cuius haec est forma.	 This is its form: [Description of the shape and structure of the Fossorium follows].
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	 Place the prominent tip at the end of the Fossorium on the vein and strike it with a peck or with another tool in that manner, and let the blood flow according to the amount you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	 Then dissolve the wound of the sick man and tie it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	 And sometimes it opens with a wide phlebotomy.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	 However, the phlebotomist should not be sharp-pointed as the other phlebotomists, rather it should be wide-mouthed.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	 And the phlebotomy should be made across [the vein], since the bone is nearby; and perhaps the phlebotomist will break it when it is sharp.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	 On phlebotomy of the veins in the two tear ducts.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	 Remedy for the two veins that are in the two tear ducts of both eyes is for an eye with a scab or redness: and for swelling in the eye, and facial diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	 And the quality of its phlebotomy is that the sick man ties his neck with a bandage.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	 Then phlebotomize them [the veins]: and you stand over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	 And let phlebotomy be performed across [the vein], to a length less than usual, when phlebotomising little, incise slightly wider, for there is no flesh in that place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	 If one who phlebotomises is subtle at the end [of the vein], perhaps it will be broken.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	 Then make run out as much blood as it is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	 And place a bandage over them, and tie them up at night, and loosen them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	 [Section on nasal vein phlebotomy]
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	 The veins of the nose are phlebotomized to treat acute fever, and severe swelling, and diseases of the face, such as hemigraine and redness that occurs on the face; especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	 And the quality of its phlebotomy is that it tightens a weak neck [of a person].
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	 Then hold the nose of that person with your left hand, and take a subtle, long lancet; and place it in the middle of the nasal cavity, between that which separates the nose according to its correct alignment.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	 Because the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	 And it is necessary that your hand be at the end with the lancet slightly; and make out as much blood as it is necessary for you.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	 Then tie it up at night.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	 For it recovers quickly itself.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	 [Section on phlebotomy of the veins in the back (of the head)]
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	 The phlebotomy of the two veins in the back (of the head) has two beneficial effects: it helps to constrict coughing and the beginning of leprosy, and diseases of melancholy, and impetigo, and bad ulcers, and those that are corroding, i.e., herpetic sores or eruptions.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	 The quality of phlebotomy is that it binds the sick person under each neck with a ligature; and the craftsman should stand over the head of the sick, and the sick person should be sitting on a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	 Then phlebotomy vein to the length of phlebotomy wide a little shorter.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	 Then draw out an appropriate amount of blood, or according to what you see is necessary for that purpose.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	 Then do the same with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	 Then release the ligature and bind two veins together tightly: so that the sick person does not faint.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	 And let it be until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	 A wound heals.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	 Chapter on the veins of Albucasis.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	 The veins of Algeberich are helpful for phlebotomy because they contribute to alcohol in the mouth and corruption of gums, and ulcers, and fissures in lips, and ulcers, even those that are in the nose and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	 The quality of phlebotomy is that you should have the sick person sit before you: and bind his neck with a bandage.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	 Then roll back his lip and look at two veins; one of which is on the right side of the lip, and the second on its left side: and the demonstration of each is evident through their blueness.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	 And it is true that around them are small veins, black.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	 Therefore cut both with an incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	 If there is doubt about you and you do not know which of them it is: then direct your attention to the larger incision, and that will be clearer.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	 And do the same with two veins that are in the upper lip; and it is most common to use this procedure: and cut the two veins in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	 On phlebotomy: vein under the tongue after cephalic phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	 For the two veins that are under the tongue, phlebotomy is beneficial: it is because cephalic phlebotomy is for conditions in the throat and sickness of the windpipe, and sicknesses of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	 And the quality of phlebotomizing them is that the sick person should be seated in front of you with his hand on the sun: and loosen his tongue, and look under the tongue on one side for a vein, and on the other side for another vein: and the color of both declines towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	 Therefore, phlebotomize each one: and be careful not to injure your hand while phlebotomizing them.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	 For under it are the arteries, and possibly there may be a flow of blood from these arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	 On three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	 The three veins that are phlebotomized in the elbow, these are the ones for whose phlebotomy there is a custom among all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	 And phlebotomy of them is done according to two modes.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	 Or pricking with a broad phlebotome made of myrtle: or letting it open to the subtle point of decline: or cutting with a sharp phlebotome, and this is called Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	 Thus, Alnesil is that which fits for cutting.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	 And from these there are wide and thin forms according to the width and tightness of the veins. The shape of the phlebotome made of myrtle should be wide, as you can see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	 And it fits for opening veins that are hollow, full, proceeding, appearing, thick, and those that contain thick, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	 And this phlebotome is of smaller width and more subtle in cutting.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	 It is appropriate for phlebotomy of subtle veins that contain delicate lemon-yellow blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	 Book on Phlebotomy.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	 Phlebotomy of the basilica is helpful for one of these three veins' phlebotomy.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	 Because it drains blood from ailments that are under the throat and neck, following the chest and abdomen; therefore, the phlebotomist should be careful with it, since an artery is beneath it.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	 If, however, the phlebotomist makes a mistake and adds in the puncture, he will cut the artery, and there will be blood flow.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	 Therefore, the phlebotomist should not puncture it; rather, it should be cut by Alnesil.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	 If the basilica does not appear with a manifest appearance, then it is necessary that you exchange it for another or seek one of its branches; or you replace it with the vein of the arm, the phlebotomist.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	 It is itself obvious and cut it when Anesil the phlebotomist does so, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	 If, however, you wish to perform phlebotomy on this same one, then it is necessary before the tightening of the arm, that you touch the place, until you recognize the pulsed place.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	 Then mark the place with a sign using hot wax, afterwards the arm; and cut the vein with a concave incision, the phlebotomist Alnesil, as we have said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	 And be careful that the puncture does not fall into the space from the location of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	 And when you see, as you tighten the bandage, an inflammation at the place that you have marked with hot wax; then that inflammation is inflation of the artery; therefore, avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	 If you see blood rise during phlebotomy, like the urine of a boy, and it is thin, red: then you will know that it is from the blood of an artery.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	 Then draw back and place your finger over the spot at a distance, then remove your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	 If the blood is cut off (for it is often cut off), then bind the arm and let it be; let the weak one avoid moving it; and there should be fear of it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	 And do not move it for a few days until it heals.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	 But if the blood does not flow off and binds you, and there is no medicine present at your moment, then cut the artery, if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	 For its ends contract, and the blood flows off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	 Or take the bark of a fig tree, cut it and take one half, bind it over the place where the vein is constricted with a string and bandages until another day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	 Then if the blood flows off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	 And if it does not: then care for it with the remembrance of that place from where powder is removed to cause blood flow, and removal of the blood from that vein is not difficult in many positions due to the small size of the wound and the possibility of binding from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	 Chapter on Phlebotomy of the Blue Vein.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	 The phlebotomy of the Blue Vein is helpful because it draws blood from the upper part of the head and the lower body; therefore, since it is composed of a branch of Basilica and a branch of Cephalica, as we have said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	 And it is fitting for the phlebotomist that it should be feared from its phlebotomy, because under it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	 If a nerve is struck during phlebotomy puncture, and it causes fainting, the healing process becomes difficult, and perhaps it may not heal completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	 And this nerve appears to sensation often.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	 If it is concealed in some individuals and is subtle and not evident: then you must place your lancet where that vein is, along with a small incision and avoid the nerve with all your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	 If the vein is between two nerves, then find the vein along its length.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	 Chapter on the Vein of the Head.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	 The assistance of phlebotomy for the Vein of the Head is because it draws blood from the head and contributes to eye ailments.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	 And it is proper in this vein that if you wish, the lancet should be anointed with olive oil or myrtle oil before pricking, because it is safer than all the veins, since it is not near an artery nor a nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	 However, it is suitable for you in phlebotomy that you avoid the head and arm only, and seek a more comfortable location: and it does no harm if it is not found at the first prick, but you may return to it several times with the lancet.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	 However, perhaps an abscess may form in some individuals when it is not pricked at the first prick, but it does no harm to that abscess in any case.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	 Chapter on the Usefulness of Phlebotomy and the Cautions Observed in It.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	 The nature and accidents of phlebotomy, which you must consider for its correction.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	 First of all, you should know that phlebotomy is not administered except in the conservation of health and its persistence, and with caution to avoid illnesses.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	 And it shall be done venesection on one of the three veins that are on the elbow, namely, Cephalica, Fusca, and Basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	 And it shall be done venesection at the beginning of Spring after fasting, in truth, and summer; in autumn, and winter after eating, when signs of fullness appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	 Venesection shall be done on the first or third day, after three hours have passed from the previous day.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	 Venesection which is administered in diseases does not have a specific hour; but when the need and appropriateness for it arises, it can be done at night or day, and at any hour, and at any time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	 It is not necessary to perform venesection on boys until they reach fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	 Venesection shall not be performed on pregnant women except from the fourth month up to the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	 Venesection shall not be performed on the elderly who have already passed sixty years.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	 When someone wants to perform venesection for any reason, it is necessary to clean the intestines before venesection with a soft enema, if there is much fecal matter retained in them; so that during venesection, the veins are not attracted by putrid waste from the intestines harmful to the main organs.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	 Venesection shall not be performed on the patient who is intoxicated, that is, suffering from sickness of satiety or nausea; nor on one drunk or vomiting due to drunkenness until it has passed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	 Venesection shall not be performed on a patient with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	 It should be avoided to perform venesection again after a colic attack, vomiting, diarrhea, multiplication of coitus, labor, exercise, sleeplessness, fasting, or anything that dissolves the strength from the body or an animal.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	 Then consider in fineness of humors before that, if blood is thick with foods and drinks, and medications: if it is possible for him to do that.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	 Then enter the bath, unless it is forbidden by something: or exercise in some way, so that blood may be made more subtle.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	 And place phlebotomy on his chest, on the third day, as we have said: and endeavor that his chest is evacuated of all evils that day: such as pain, anger, fear: and of all bodily ailments, such as labor, punishment, excess, and similar things.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	 And let him have present the things that are used in custom among men from their fragrance, and scent, and joy, and similar things, according to the quantity possible for him.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	 Then let the phlebotomist sit on a stool higher than the stool for phlebotomy: afterwards he will draw out his arm and rub it with his hand two or three times.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	 Then bind the ligature with a cord, and wind it around twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	 And let the ligature be moderated, because if the ligature is unequal or excessive in the ligature, then it prevents the flow of blood: or in softening, it also prevents the flow of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	 Then after tying, it is necessary that the person being bled rub his hands together until the veins swell and are felt.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	 Then the phlebotomist cleans the puncture point with a little oil, an old one properly.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	 Then he shall place his index finger of the left hand on that vein at the place where he wants to make a puncture, slightly: so that the vein does not escape and the blow is not wasted.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	 Because it is from the vein as you find it, similar to a fleeing cord, during phlebotomy; and from these there is what is full of windiness; and when you place the phlebotomy instrument upon it, it contracts under the phlebotomy instrument, and deceives the phlebotomator, and the phlebotomist does not open the vein; and if he opens it, it is tightened: therefore, for this reason, the phlebotomator should be firm, and careful in all these matters.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	 Draw or incise the phlebotomy instrument away from the vein.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	 If the vein is opened by one cut, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	 And if not, then make another cut a little below or above the same place with haste; but if it is not possible to make another incision.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	 If it cannot be made another incision or the weak person faints, then leave him for a day, or two days; and do not tighten the bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	 Perhaps the abscess will attract heat.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	 Do not enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	 Then make another incision if necessary.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	 If the opening is small or blood runs subtly, then be afraid that not enough blood will come out; then make another incision in the same hole according to the straight line, and add a little more in the procedure.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	 And do this quickly before the abscess is removed, for the place of the abscess is in many people during small operations.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	 If you see that the abscess has already been removed, then do not go over it at all, for it does not cleanse anything in your hands.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	 And put something of olive oil over it, because it eases the flow of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	 And it is better in this place than olive oil itself and other oils.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	 And similarly administer oil faeces in every phlebotomy of yours, where phlebotomies veins are against the prohibition of blood circulation; and they do this by Tyriac Albaharik, and sagzenea, when it is placed over one of them.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	 Blood is made subtle and dissolved, when it is thick.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	 If it happens in the place of phlebotomy a large abscess, for it often happens, especially to those who are not phlebotomists except at that time, or there is a small opening of vein; then hasten and put over the place a sponge soaked in water and salt, heated slightly; and tighten it for an hour, because it dissolves.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	 And it is necessary that you do this after the blood leaves from that vein itself, when its completion, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	 If something remains in the place after several days of blackness or greenness, it does not hurt it; and if you wish, put over it something of aloe, or myrrh dissolved; or something from mint juice, that is, camphor or similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	 Often abscesses and protuberances happen at the phlebotomy of the Basilica.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	 Put then your hand over it; if you find softness under the pressure of your hand on it, then that protuberance is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	 Be careful to put over it something from what I said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	 For perhaps blood from an artery flows out of it.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	 But make a plaster to it with what is there for the swelling, so that the place becomes hardened.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	 Then care for it with the rest of the treatment, until it heals.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	 And it is necessary that you draw blood from every man according to the amount of its virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	 And what appears due to a color prevailing over blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	 If the blood is black, then let it come out until it turns red; similarly, if you see it thick, let it go until it becomes subtle; and similarly, if it is sharp, let it be removed until its sharpness disappears.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	 It is necessary for him who is full, strong and in need of bloodletting with one vein to be amplified, and the bloodletter should be on the side; and it should be contrary for him who is weak.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	 It is necessary that it be drawn from the veins and that there be a narrow opening; and it is better that which is administered in bloodletting through the vein be a cross-section rather than a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	 This method of bloodletting is safe from the flow of blood and from the cutting of nerves; and it is more praiseworthy and safer than bloodletting through breadth and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	 And to whom this is accustomed to come upon bloodletting syncope, it is necessary that he eat before bloodletting with a little bread soaked in water of muscatel grapes or dried if heated; and draw out from his blood in three veins, or four.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	 And if it is of cold constitution, then let him take before bloodletting bread soaked in syrup of honey or scented honey with spices or aromatic syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	 If syncope occurs during bloodletting and the cause is the outflow of blood, then it is necessary that he drink meat water and subtle aromatic syrup; and use aromatics with algae and let his chest be wrapped with it; and use the rest that we said in division in the chapter on syncope through evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	 Whoever wishes to amputate his arm and let out blood in the second [stage]: it is necessary for him whose phlebotomy is for evacuation of much, and the strength of whose phlebotomy is weak, to let out blood gradually by the quantity of strength in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	 Whoever wants to amputate his arm and let out blood in the second [stage], and it is his body (i.e., he is doing it voluntarily): then he should do that after seven or nine hours from his first phlebotomy.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	 Whoever wants to draw blood from his body towards the opposite part that it flows to: it is necessary for him that it be let out on the second day or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	 In whose body there is much blood already heated and sharpened, and causes a fever to come on: it is necessary for the blood to be let out in a single instance, and a large quantity drawn: and the opening should be widened until there occurs fainting: after you have observed all the conditions of phlebotomy: and so that you place your hand upon his pulse near the flow of blood, so that death does not occur from the fainting.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	 For often it happens when the phlebotomist is unaware, and falls through carelessness.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	 And it is not necessary when you wish to amputate the arm and let out blood in the second [stage], if the opening of the vein is already closed, and the exit of blood becomes difficult, that you press on it violently and the area around it be quickly extended.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	 For this is very bad indeed, rather let it alone until the second [stage of] phlebotomy.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	 Or remove with the sharpness of the phlebotomy that which has coagulated from blood in the vein opening, and place something dissolved salt in water on top of it.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	 Place something made from turiyakh alfarokh or sagzena on top of it, and apply gentle pressure until the blood comes out.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	 If the vein has already been cut, then leave it alone, and do not cover it, until the boil settles down.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	 If it is necessary to let blood for any reason and there is no excuse, then either perform venesection at that location or in another vein in the other arm.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	 The arm should be bled at the location of Fuscus and Basilicus, since they are not found and are concealed because they are composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	 The manner of venesection is as follows: the weak person should insert his hand into hot water until it turns red and the vein becomes visible.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	 Then, a bandage with moderate constriction should be tied above it.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	 Then the venesection is to be done obliquely gradually, neither horizontally nor vertically; and let the incision be wide, and let your venesection be made over the joint of the hand a little.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	 If the outflow of blood is forbidden, then immerse your hand in hot water and let the blood flow into the water until you meet your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	 But if it is during the summer days, then you are excused from immersing your hand in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	 Above all, the flow of blood into hot water is recommended during wintertime.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	 The venesection of this vein is healthier than all other veins because it is not a pulsating vein and there is no nerve under it.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	 Venesection of the Saluatella in the right hand is beneficial for liver diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	 The manner of venesection is to tie a ligature around the thumb with a bandage or your hand, after you immerse it in hot water until the vein swells and becomes very sensitive.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	 Then make an incision across the vein (phlebotomy).
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	 And if you cut it completely, it will not harm her in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	 And keep, lest you amputate your hand while performing phlebotomy.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	 For under that (skin) are the nerves of the fingers exposed from the flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	 Then return your hand to hot water and let the blood flow there.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	 For if you do not return your hand to hot water, the blood coagulates in the vein opening and it stops flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	 Since you will draw as much blood as needed, then place oil and salt on the vein to prevent it from coagulating quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	 And similarly, it is necessary that you do this with each constricted vein.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	 However, the remedy for this phlebotomy is from the left hand, because it alleviates diseases of the spleen; and similarly do this for his phlebotomy as you did for the second one equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	 The remedy for the saphenous vein phlebotomy is for diseases that are in the lower part of the body such as female diseases (menstrual problems), kidney diseases, old sores on hips and legs, and similar diseases.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	 And the quality of this phlebotomy is that an invalid should immerse his foot in hot water and make friction on it until the veins are full; then tie above the ankle with a bandage.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	 The location of the vein is near the heel, visible towards the thumb; and it branches out from there into multiple veins on the face of the foot.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	 Therefore, perform the phlebotomy on a larger branch of it or near the heel in its cluster; because it is better and safer.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	 If a phlebotomist performs it on the face of the foot, then be careful not to injure the nerves that are beneath the surface of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	 Place your phlebotomy instrument across it, as if you wish to cut through it; let the phlebotomist be Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	 If the flow of blood is forbidden, then immerse his foot in warm water; and let the blood flow out into it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	 If the vein of the phlebotomist strays in the first try, then he should repeat with the phlebotomy at a slightly higher location; for that spot is safe, and you need not fear harm from it, as long as you are careful around the nerves, as we have said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	 And similarly with the saphenous vein of the other foot.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	 The location of the sciatic vein is, as we have said, near the calcaneum on the side of the forest [of the foot].
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	 And the remedy for this phlebotomy is to alleviate pain in the ankle, when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	 And the quality of this phlebotomy is that an unwell person should enter the bath and hasten; then bind his leg from the side of the ankle to above the calcaneum with a thin, long plaster; for it does not appear except for that reason.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	 When it appears, then perform the phlebotomy as your skill allows, either with a cut or across; and it is better to make an incision or to sever [the vein] with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	 For that spot is safer, and the vein is hidden very deeply in many people.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	 If you do not find it and it does not appear at all to the senses; then perform a phlebotomy on one of its branches, and that which appears on the back of the foot and turns towards the ear; be careful around the nerves, and let as much blood flow out as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	 Then loosen the stricture, and place skin over the site of phlebotomy, and tie the site.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	 Swiftly it heals.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	 On Ventosection and its Quality of Use.
Caput XCVIII.	 Chapter CXVIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	 They are made from horns, copper, and glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	 Ventosection is indeed performed in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	 With incision and bloodletting; and the other is ventosection without incision.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	 And this ventosection which is without incision, is performed in two ways.
Aut enim est cum igne.	 Or it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	 Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	 And the places of ventosection which are administered with incision and bloodletting are fourteen on the body.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	 One of them is Ventosection of Alnocrates, and it is the last on the head; Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck; ventosections of Alhagdahim, and they are two plates on the neck from both sides at once; ventosections of the brain, and it is under the jaw in the lower part of the mouth; ventosections of two spatulas; ventosection of Alachosos above the tail end; ventosections of two foci, and they are in the middle of two arms; ventosections of two legs; ventosections of two knees.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	 And ventosection does not draw blood from small veins scattered in the flesh, and therefore its virtue does not fall out of them, as is the case with phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	 It is not necessary that ventosection be administered either with fire or without it in any disease caused by congestion until the entire body is evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	 If necessity arises for ventosection due to disease or habit, it is administered at any hour during the beginning of the month, at its end, and in the middle, and at any time whatsoever.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	 That is, because there is one of men who, when multiplied within him the blood, until it needs drawing out through ventilation, finds in his head a swelling and sores.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	 And there is one of them who finds repletion and redness on his face, his head, and his neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	 And there is one of them who finds itching on his face and forehead, and darkness and dullness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	 And there is one of them who scratches the place of his ventilation.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	 And there is one of them whose laughter is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	 And there is one of them who finds the taste of blood in his mouth: or the tongue is spitted out and the blood is spat out.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	 And there is one of them whose sleep is multiplied.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	 And there is one of them who sees in his sleep blood and redness, and the dead, and wounds, and things similar to those.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	 When we therefore see something of these, and properly if it is in the third month: we command then ventilation to be made, after two or three hours have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	 The remedy for ventilation of the neck is: because it brings about heaviness in the head, and what is expelled goes to the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	 But it should be that this is after the evacuation of the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	 And this ventilation is in place of a cephalic phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	 And it should not be used by one who is of cold temperament, or in whom there is catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	 Because it brings him great harm.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	 And for that reason it should not be used by the elderly, and in whose head there are cold diseases.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	 But he who does this frequently generates forgetfulness over him.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	 And therefore, you should instruct the Anesthetist to place his hand momentarily towards the lower part when letting go, fearing from forgetfulness due to generation.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	 Anesthesia or Alkehel, is in place of phlebotomy Fusca, and phlebotomy Basilica, and because of this it causes sneezing, constriction of breath, breathlessness of instruments, cough, and filling.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	 It is necessary that the anesthetist Alkehel should be pushed momentarily, because if it is placed lower, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	 But anesthesia alhagdahim causes headaches, attacks, migraines, and perforation; and it is in place of phlebotomy Basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	 And you should instruct the anesthetist not to press his hand during scarification; so as not to cut the artery and cause bleeding.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	 But anesthesia below the chin causes alcohol in the mouth, decay of the gums, and similar ailments that are in the mouth; and it is instead of phlebotomy aleherich, which are on the two lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	 But anesthesia with spatulas causes toothache, which occurs from pressing and heating.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	 But anesthesia of the internal parts of two kidneys causes help for phlebotomy of three veins, Basilica, Fusca, and Cephalica; because it attracts blood from all those small veins that are in the flesh; and these small veins draw blood from larger veins until the attraction reaches to veins three.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	 And you should instruct the anesthetist not to proceed too far during scarification; because the area is exposed with flesh, and under it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	 The ventosa that inflates over the alchausos is beneficial for hemorrhoids of the anus and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	 And it is necessary to advise the Ventosator that the ventosa should be large and made of air: since the place requires strong suction and perhaps fine ventoses may break; and let it be cut with a deep incision.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	 The ventoses of the legs diminish by a manifest reduction: since they draw blood from the whole body and they contribute to ancient pains in kidneys, womb, and bladder; they provoke menstruation, and contribute to bloating and dropsy; and they are in place of phlebotomy of two saphenous veins and alhorcobeni.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	 However, they weaken the body much, and cause fainting in many men.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	 And the help of the ventoses for alhorcobeni is near the help of the ventoses of the two legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	 The quality of the positioning of the ventoses is that you should place the ventosa first in an empty place and perform a moderate suction; and do not prolong the position of the ventoses, but place them quickly and remove them quickly, so that the humors come to the place at equal speed: and do not stop repeating this and continuing until you see the place already redden and inflame, and the redness appears to be blood; then scarify, and repeat suction slowly.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	 Then consider in the arrangement of bodies.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	 For if a man is of soft flesh and few pores, it is necessary to scarify him only once, not more, so that the place does not become ulcerated.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	 And advise the Ventosator to expand the scarification and make it shallow; and moderate the suction in ease, speed, and gentle motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	 If there is a swelling in the blood, then it is necessary to lance it twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	 In the first instance, an opening is made for the subtlety of the blood and its thinning; in the second instance, a thorough examination is made for the extraction of the thickened blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	 If the blood is very impure, then lancing should be done a third time: to achieve the final result.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	 And finally, when we wish to extract blood gradually or in small amounts, a single lancing is sufficient for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	 If we wish to make multiple extractions of the blood, we should perform multiple lancings.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	 And if we measure that the blood is thick, then it is necessary to perform a deep lancing; and the depth of the lancing, equal to the end, is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	 [Paragraph] What should be administered from the oils when in the position of the Ventosas (Venetians), and what one should avoid with the Ventosando.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	 In the case where the skin is thick, hard, dark, and its pores are constricted, it should be anointed with the Ventosas places using open, soothing, resolving oils: if it is during the summer season, as alkali oil, or olive oil, or oil from sweet almonds, or cucumber seed oil.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	 And if it is in winter time, then use oil of narcissus, or oil of lily, or oil of chamomile, or sulphur: and similar things.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	 If there is excessive fat that is cold, then use oil of amaracus, or oil of balm of Gilead, or oil of almond, or oil of dittany: and similar things.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	 If there is a windy discharge of large pores, soft flesh: then it should be prohibited from using oil, and the places of the windings should be washed with rose water, or cold water, or salt water, or water of squash, or water of purslane: and similar things.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	 But for him whose blood is abundant with moisture, wash the windings with vinegar, or water of myrtle, and sumac: and similar things.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	 For him whose excesses are thick, wash the windings with old wine, or sage water, or anise decoction, or chamomile: and similar things.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	 And it should be careful not to wash the windings in a bath, or in the foot of a bath, but rather it should be administered after leaving the bath for an hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	 And it is not good if anyone sleeps after washing.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	 What should be used to control the windy discharge, or the blood-letter before washing?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	 And after that, it should be considered first: if the patient is windy or blood-let, and his acuity and inflammation are choleric: then it should be given cooling things, such as grapes juice: also a bladder with vinegar and lettuce, and roasted onions, and yolk: and similar things.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	 Place his food before the chickens, and cook the mutton pieces, and set prepared food with herbs: and similar things for them.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	 If it is a cold complexion, let him drink syrup made from honey, or from almiua, or ale made from seeds; and let him drink moderately strong wine, which is between old and new; and let it be prescribed that he should eat sparingly.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	 Place his food before the chickens and dogs; and let him have small birds, that is, little birds; and let the pigeon chicks be crushed.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	 It is necessary that the drink on the day of venesection and bloodletting should be more than food; and it must be given in certain men at hours tyriaca or alfaroch, or a medicine made from musk (muscata), or ale of elderberry (alesselithe) before venesection; and before or after: to strengthen the main limbs, and to make the blood subtile.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	 And it is not necessary that they should drink it in a hot drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	 Chapter on venesection without scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	 Venesections without scarification are those which are applied on the liver, spleen, foot-affliction, and on the abdomen, umbilicus, places of kidneys, and on the ankle; because these limbs cannot endure scarification upon them.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	 And by these there is no search for anything, except that it draws blood from one limb to another; as we place the venesection on the breasts in the affliction of nosebleed.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	 And we use them to dissolve the venosity of an unwanted cold in a limb; as we place the venesection on the abdomen and umbilicus.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	 For it makes the limb rarefied, warms it up, and removes pain for this reason; because it has dissolved that venosity.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	 Also, it is placed on the kidney when there occurs an ulceration or stone in them.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	 By virtue of its attracting power, perhaps it opens the ulcer, or expels the stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	 Similarly, when it is placed on the liver and spleen for the treatment of windiness in both cases.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	 These are administered empty with a mere incision only.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	 And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	 And sometimes they are administered with warm water in cases of pleurisy: this is to fill the Ventosa and make it large, only with warm water, or water in which certain suitable herbs have been boiled.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	 Form of the Ventosa administered with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.	 The diameter of its opening should be two fingers apart, as we have made it; and the depth should be half the size of a palm; and on its side there should be a small hole, according to the quantity that enters into it with an awl; it should be made of copper, tin, leather, or linen, equal thickness, cleansed; so as not to harm the body during its placement upon it; and in its middle there should be a crossbar transverse from copper or iron, where the candle is placed with fire.
Et iam fit haec uentosa magna, maior ea quam narrauimus, et parum minor illa, secundum aegritudines et aetatem eius qui utitur.	 And now it becomes this swollen one large, greater than we said before, and yet not much smaller than that (swelling), according to the illnesses and age of the one who uses it.
Ventosae enim puerorum, et extenuatorum sunt aliae, quam uentosae uirorum, et grossorum corporum.	 Swellings in children are different from swellings in men, and those of larger bodies.
Qualitas autem ponendi hanc uentosam cum igne super membrum, est, ut accendas licinium cum igne ex lino decenter, aut candelam paruam ex caera: et pone eam super medium uirgae transuersae quae est in medio uentosae: ut sit accensus ignis circiter inferiorem partem uentosae, ut non comburatur corpus infirmi.	 The quality of placing this swollen one with fire on a limb is to ignite linen with fire from flax or a small candle from wax: and place it on the middle of the crossbar which is in the middle of the swelling: so that the fire may be kindled below the swelling, not to burn the body of the weak one.
Deinde ponatur super membrum: et digitus sit super foramen quod dixi, donec quando tenemus uentosam: dum indigemus, auferamus digitum, et egredietur uapor super illud foramen, et soluetur uentosa statim.	 Then it is to be placed on a limb, and the finger shall be on the hole which I said, as long as we hold the swelling: when we need it, we remove the finger, and the vapor comes out through that hole, and the swelling is immediately relieved.
Deinde igni licinium secundum modum suum, et itera eam, si indiges illa.	 Then linen with fire according to its manner, and repeat it if you need it.
In Ventosa autem quae administratur in aegritudine pleuresis cum aqua, non est uirga transuersa, neque foramen: et non administratur, nisi quia impletur aqua, et ponitur super membrum tantum.	 In the swelling administered for the illness of pleurisy with water, there is no crossbar nor hole: it is not administered unless it is filled with water and placed on a limb only.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its form.
Et haec Ventosa quanto plus est magna, ut capiat aquam multam, est melior.	 And this swelling, the larger it is, so as to hold more water, is better.
¶ De suspensione Sanguisugarum.	 Chapter on Suspension of Sanguisugums.
Caput XCIX.	 Chapter XCIX (99).
Sanguisugae non administrantur in pluribus, nisi in quibus membris non est possibilis positio uentosarum, propter paruitatem eorum, sicut labium, et gingiua, et eis similia.	 Sanguisugae are not administered in many places except where the position of swellings is not possible due to their smallness, such as the lips, gums, and similar parts.
Aut in membro denudato a carne, sicut digitus, et nasus, et eis similia.	 Or in a bare member, such as fingers or nose, and similar parts.
Et qualitas utendi eis est: ut ueneris ex Sanguisugis quae sunt in aquis dulcibus, mundis a putredinibus.	 And the quality of using them is that you come from Sanguisugis which are in sweet waters, clean from putrefaction.
Deinde dimittantur die et nocte in aqua dulci, donec famelicae sint, et non remaneat in uentre earum aliquid.	 Then they should be let for day and night in sweet water until they are hungry, and nothing remains in their stomachs.
Deinde euacuetur corpus in primis cum phlebotomia, et cum uentosis.	 The body is first evacuated with venesection, and with emetics.
Deinde absterge membrum infirmi, donec rubeat.	 Then the sick limb should be washed until it turns red.
Postea ponantur super ipsum.	 They are then placed on top of it.
Cum ergo implentur, et cadunt, et est possibilis suctio loci cum uentosa, tunc est magis ultimum in iuuamento: et si non, tunc ablue locum cum aceto.	 When they are filled and fall, and it is possible to suck the place with a syringe, then it is more helpful; if not, then clean the place with vinegar.
Deinde cum aqua multa, et fricetur, et exprimatur.	 Then it should be washed with much water, rubbed, and squeezed out.
Quod si prolongatur cursus sanguinis post casum Sanguisugarum, et est illud resudando: tunc infunde pannum lini in aqua frigida, et pone ipsum desuper, donec abscindatur resudatio.	 If the course of blood is prolonged after bleeding from leeches, and it becomes draining; then soak a linen cloth in cold water, place it on top, until the drainage stops.
Quod si multiplicatur sanguis, tunc pulueriza super ipsum zegi tritum, aut gallas, et similia eis ex stipticis: donec abscindatur sanguis.	 If there is an increase in blood, then sprinkle on it powdered alum, gall nuts, and similar things from the poppy; until the bleeding stops.
Aut ponantur super locum medietates fabarum excorticatarum: et dimittantur, donec adhaereant fabae in loco, nam sanguis abscinditur.	 Or pieces of stripped beans can be placed on the place; and they are left until the beans stick to the place, for the blood is stopped.
Et oportet si necessaria est iteratio Sanguisugarum, quando est possibile, mutare eas.	 And it is necessary that if leeches need to be repeated, when possible, to change them.
Si autem prohibentur Sanguisugae a suspensione, tunc abstergatur locus cum sanguine recenti.	 If leeches are forbidden from being hung up, then clean the place with fresh blood.
Aut fige acum in locis, donec egrediatur aliquid ex sanguine.	 Or stick a needle into the places until something comes out of the blood.
Deinde ponantur, nam ipsae quando sentiunt aliquid ex sanguine, adhaerent statim.	 Then they are placed, for when they feel something from the blood, they will stick immediately.
Quando ergo uis ut cadant, pulueriza super eas aliquid ex aloe trito, aut salem, aut cinerem: et cadent statim.	 When you want them to fall, sprinkle something from powdered aloes, salt, or ashes over them; and they will fall immediately.
¶ Partis Secundae Finis.	 § End of the Second Part.
¶ Liber Chirurgici Albucasis Pars III.	 § Book of Surgery by Albucasis, Third Part.
¶ Sermo uniuersalis de restauratione, et dislocatione, et curatione torsionis, et similibus.	 § Discourse on the restoration, displacement, and treatment of twisting, and similar things.
Caput I.	 Title I.
Hoc Capitulum etiam multotiens est necessarium in arte Medicinae, et est restauratio fracturae, et dislocationis accidentium in ossibus.	 This chapter is also often necessary in the art of Medicine, and it is the restoration of a fracture, and dislocation of accidents in bones.
Scitote o Filii, quia iactant se de hoc Capitulo stolidi medicorum et uulgi, et qui non inspexerunt unquam antiquorum librum, neque legerunt ex eo literam.
