Know ye, O sons, that many foolish doctors and the ignorant boast of this chapter, and those who have never examined an ancient book nor read from it a letter.
Et propter hanc caussam fit, quod iste modus ex scientiis in terra nostra est priuatus.	 And for this reason it happens that this method is lacking among the skilled [people] in our land.
Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	 And I have not encountered it [the method] at all in good form, and I have not obtained it from it anything except what I obtained due to the length of reading ancient books and diligence over understanding them, until I extracted that knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	 Then I adhered by experience and diligent study throughout my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	 Now I have described to you from that [method] in this chapter all that my knowledge contains: and beyond what my experience has exceeded, after I have abbreviated it for you, and have freed it from the occupation of abbreviation, and have abbreviated it at the point of abbreviation, and have shown it at the point of declination: and I have formed many shapes from the forms of the instruments that are used in it, since it is by addition of declination, as I did in the two preceding chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	 In summary, and collections concerning the existence of bone fractures, from those whose preliminary [examination] is necessary before we begin the recovery of fractured limbs, and various ones, if of each one separately.
Caput II.	 Title II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	 It is necessary that we say in the prologue of this chapter the main points, and chapters, to which understanding is first required of the craftsman at his station over their truth: namely that you, and those ready for it, know or learn this noble art, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	 I say therefore, that when a fracture, dislocation, twist or fall occurs to someone, then it is necessary, firstly, to hurry towards bleeding him and loosening him, or both at the same time: unless something forbids it, such as weakness of strength; or it happens to a child or an old weak person; or it is a time of intense heat or extreme cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	 Then let him be content with his food, cold vegetables, beans and heads; and forbid wine, heavy meats, and being filled with any food or anything that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	 Until he is safe from a hot fever and does not fear the outflow of matter to the limb; then let the sick one return first to his usual regimen with which his custom was accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	 When the fractured bone begins to heal, then it is necessary that the sick one eat nourishing foods in large quantities, thick, heavy, in which there is viscosity; such as food made from cooked wheat with water, rice, heads and feet, entrails of cows, eggs, fresh fish, strong wine, and similar things.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	 And with this regimen, the healing of the fracture is done more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	 And know that broken bones, when they are in men who are in the first old age and decrepit, it is not possible for them to be joined and consolidated according to their nature always, because of the drying of their limbs; and the bones which are from these are consolidated and united at the end of gentleness, like the bones of small children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 Nevertheless, nature connects something similar to glue around the broken bone from all sides, in which there is thickness, with which it adheres and tightens it until they are consolidated against each other, and tied together until it comes to the end of strength and firmness, as it was at first, until it does not forbid it something because of its operations; and because of this cause, it is necessary that you put the food of the sick in heavy foods, with thickness and viscosity, as we have said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	And know that the types of fractures are diverse, according to the differences of the limbs; since a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the head bone; and a fracture of the chest bone is different from a fracture of the backbone; and similarly all other members are different from each other; and I come with the reminder of all types of fractures exposed in their respective chapters distinct from one another.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	 The species of fractures themselves are also diverse.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	 Since a fracture occurs curved, except when stars appear in it.
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	 And sometimes a fracture occurs along the length of the bone; and there are its splinters, that is, stars, and additions proceeding from them, as are found in a pen when it is sharpened for writing with a knife.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	 And not proceeding; and there is a fracture with wound and rupture at the head; and there is a small fissure fracture.
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	 And to each type there is a skill or specific tool for its restoration, according to which its memory will come, distinguished in their respective places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	 And from that which is known about a bone fracture, it is its crookedness and prominence; its appearance to the senses; and its sound when you press it with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	 When therefore no crookedness appears in the place, nor does a sound occur to your touch when you press the bone with movement, nor does it cause great pain; then there is no fracture at that place, indeed it may be a crookedness or small fissure; therefore it is not necessary to move it with the hand and complete compression, but rather place medicines over it, whose memory comes after the time appropriate for the place; then a bandage is tightened with a fine string.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	 And know that when the place is bent and divided, except for what happens in it as satagiae, nevertheless remove all parts from their comparison: then it is necessary for you to begin from your hour for its correction, equating it before hot ulcer occurs.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	 If a hot ulcer occurs, then let it be for some days until the ulcer subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	 Then equal it according to whatever method is possible with gentleness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	 And know that the restoration of it and its equating is easier than bones, where satagia occurs.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	 Then tighten it, according to what comes to your recollection of it.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	 If satagia occurs in a bone, then extension of this broken member is necessary from two parts, if it is the hand or foot: or with your hand, if the member is small: or with two ropes, or with a rope and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	 And let your position be that in which you place the member over an equal place, according to its natural shape, until when the parts of the broken member extend: then try to make those additions with all skill and according to whatever method you can in their places: and take care according to your strength, so that pain does not occur to the weak due to your operation or injury: and try according to your strength to apply one of two bones with its partner, according to the best forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	 It is necessary at that time for you to test and touch it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	 If therefore you see something different there, correct it and equalize it according to the quantity of your strength.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	 And avoid a violent extension and a strong compression, as many foolish people do.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	 For often they cause a hot ulcer or constriction in the member through their operation, as we have already seen from their operations many times.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	 Then attach after the incision, and proper surgical procedure, and the compression of that member, and peace, and calmness: and warn the sick person about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	 And let him be careful not to move it during the hour of his watch, and sleep, at its revolution, and agitation, and at its discharge, and all movements during the last strength of his power.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	 And let him be careful that the position of the member is not one that follows pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	 This is because when he feels pain or injury in the position of the member, then it is necessary that he moves himself to another position from which he does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	 And be careful that his position is equal and straight: so that no curvature occurs in the member when it heals.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	 And the quality of the compression for a broken member is as I have said.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	 Know that fractured members differ according to their size, and their magnitude, and their shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	 Those that are small, such as the arm, finger, club, and similar to them, then it is necessary for there to be a soft, subtle wrapping of cloth.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	 But those that are large, such as the thigh and leg, it is necessary for there to be a wide, firm wrapping of cloth.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	 Because a broad bandage connects a large member and compresses it from every side with equal compression so that no spot is left bare.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	 Then after your evacuation, place the suitable linen on it from the incision, on a soft cushion above the fracture site.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	 Then begin to wrap the bandage over the fracture site three or four times, according to how deserving the member is: and compress your hand slightly with the bandage.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	 Then go with him to the upper part from the place of the break, and tie less than your previous binding, which you bound the broken place with.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	 Then draw out a little further from the place of the break, and soften the binding slowly until you take a large amount from a healthy place.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	 Then take another plaster, and apply it again to the broken place with bandages.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	 Then go downwards with the bandage towards the lower part from the break.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	 And let your work be in binding and softening of the bandage, and in the manner as I said in the first bandaging above.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	 Then place between the bandages pieces of soft flax or cloth, equal to the curvature of the break if there is any curvature in it; and if not, do not put anything in it.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	 Then apply another plaster over it.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	 Then place stars evenly spaced immediately above these bandages, if there is no swelling or hot abscess in that place.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	 But if there is swelling or an abscess there, then place that which sits on the abscess and remove the swelling; and let it be for several days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	 Then bind those stars over it.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	 And let the stars be made from the middle parts of thick reeds, shaved and skillfully formed; or let them be made of wood from which cribra are made, which are made from pine, yew, palm tree branches or calingi; and let the width of each star be according to this form and this same shape.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	 However, the star that is placed over the trace should be a little larger and wider than the other stars; and the length of the star should be according to what is allowed by the member in terms of size and smallness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	 Then bind over the Star with another ointment, according to the first binding.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	 Then bind firmly with threads, as we have said concerning binding; and it should be that your binding is stronger over the place of the break, and the farther it is from the break, the less the binding should be.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	 The threads must be of moderate thickness and fineness, and made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	 Since if the threads are thick, as I have seen in the operation of fools placing their own twisted cords of rough linen, it is a great error; since the binding falls off with them beyond quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	 And thin threads again do not suit; because you will not achieve with them through the binding what you want.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	 It is not necessary that there be less than a finger's breadth between one star and another.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	 If the sick person is hurt by the extremities of the stars after binding in healthy places: then place under them soft wool or camlet, until nothing is hurt from that.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	 But when there is a break with a wound, and rupture occurs in the skin, I will come back to it with its own discussion in the second chapter.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	 And know that not every broken member needs to be bound with stars from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	 That is because when a member is large, it is not necessary to place stars on top of it unless after five days, or seven, or more, according to your safety from the occurrence of cold abscess.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	 And this is the method of plasters that the ancients used, which are placed on a break and displacement.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	 The common method of plaster, restoring a break, suitable for many constitutions, especially women and children; since it is from that which heat does not overcome nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	 And it is that you receive from mill-dust, and it is the marrow of flour which hangs on the walls of the mill near the movement of the millstone: and you shall make it as such, except that sieves it with egg white: and place its mixture not thick, nor subtle.
Deinde utere eo.	 Then use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	 Another method of plaster, for the healing of a fracture, dislocation and twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	 Take almess, laudanum, acacia, enula and mugath: and macerate all with ten parts of myrrh, five parts of both aloes and twenty parts of alethil. All should be crushed and sifted, and mixed with water of alethil, or with egg white if the plaster is applied to a weak person who is heated.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	 Then use this plaster.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	 For it is a good composition, it quickly heals broken bones and helps many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	 Another method of plaster, which also helps for fractures and twisting.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	 Take mugath, mess, white alteae, all with ten parts of myrrh, five parts of both aloes and six parts of acacia, a pound of Armenian bolus twenty times, all should be crushed and sifted, and made with water or egg white: and administer them.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	 Another method of plaster for joining bones and those separated from their places: it soothes the pain that occurs to them, and the separation of a bone, and a fracture.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	 Wool juice is taken, and it is immersed in vinegar and boiled oil: and it is placed on the place.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	 And indeed, this plaster does not have the virtue of healing, but it is good for the soothing of a hot boil: and it expels pains properly.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	 Method for applying a plaster, which restores a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	 Take leaves of the fig tree that is deaf and leaves of wild parsnip: grind all of them, and make a plaster from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	 Method for a speedy application of a plaster for the restoration of a broken bone, and when you want to dissolve the remnants of an abscess.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	 Take equal parts of the root of althea, chamomile, marigold flowers, herb flour, all in one part: grind all of them, and make a decoction with wine if the member is not heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	 If it is heated, then make it with coriander water or with water and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	 Another method for a stronger plaster in the resolution, stronger than the first, when a hard abscess occurs during the restoration of a member.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	 Take equal parts of the root of althea, flax seeds, boxwood, licorice root, sampsucke, marigold flowers, chamomile, all in one part: grind all of them and make a decoction with willow water or sweet water or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	 Apply it according to the heat of the member and the calmness of its warmth.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	 Hippocrates himself did not say in his book that anything should be placed on a broken member during its restoration except a preparation made from wax and oil; nothing else. And he said it should be of a medium between thickness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	 Galenus, however, thought that things should be placed on a broken member during its restoration which have the heating property, such as myrrh and aloe and frankincense, and similar things from those mentioned before.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	 Method for a plaster that promotes injury and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	 Make a paste of equal parts of ground chickpea, human hair or goose feather, and althea (marshmallow root), along with salt: grind and sift it; then make an ointment from this mixture.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	 The amount required to make the bandage remain in place is such that if there is no pain or itching, nor does the bone move from its place, then do not dissolve it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	 If itchiness, distressing pain, or swelling occurs at the site, then hasten and dissolve it within an hour, remove the ointment from there; take a soft cloth or seawater sponge, moistened; immerse it in warm water and wash the area until the itch subsides and the pain is alleviated.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	 Then let the limb rest for an hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	 Then place on it (the limb) wool soaked in vinegar and oil, or rose oil; tie it over it at night until you are free from the danger of hot infection, and let the swelling of the limb subside and the pain be alleviated.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	 Then repeat the same process for a delicate binding and a small amount of ointment; do not bind it tightly with your first bandage or with a delicate one until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	 If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling and all other symptoms have been completely removed, and you require an ointment and binding, then repeat the same procedure as before equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	 If nothing of what was mentioned happens to the limb, then do not dissolve it before three days, or four, or five, or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	 And when it is permitted after twenty days according to the appearance of the dissolution of the limb, as we have said, until the fracture adheres and the coagulation of the flesh near it; add also more binding in your bandage than your first one completely; and also increase the intake of food for the sick person, as much as the memory of the previous advice suggests.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	 If you see that the place of fracture is already drying out and shrinking too much: then you will know that nourishment is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	 Therefore, anoint the area with warm oil and water at every spot where you dissolve it, and let it be for all three days, and apply a little softening agent to relax it slightly.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	 By this procedure, nourishment flows to the member, and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	 What foolish restorers do instead of restoring the fractured member by what is proper, when they do not restore it first as required, and restore it according to its curvature, is an error in their procedure, and there is great fear: and if it were correct, the ancients would have said so in their books, and they would have operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	 And I have not seen any trace of theirs whatsoever in that matter, and it is better not to do that.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	 Chapter on the making of a fracture in the head.
Caput III.	 Chapter III.
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	 Types of fractures are diverse, and their shapes are numerous; causes of the same are distinguished.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	 For the fracture that occurs from a blow with a sword: the blow removes the bone completely until it reaches the siphac, which is below the bone, just as an ax cuts through wood: and for this reason, the species of fracture is called Axial.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	 Or the sword cuts something of the bone and cuts its face, but does not penetrate through to the end of it: and this type of fracture is called Kalan, that is, Absolute Lever.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	 And a wound from two types of fractures, either great or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	 And the fracture that is crushing or grinding: and its cause is a blow with a stone or falling on a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	 This fracture is also penetrating, which is approaching the padding that is under bone: or it is on the face of the bone: and this wound belongs to these two kinds of fractures, whether small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	 This fracture is hidden within the bone in the subtlety of hair: and it is a small crack, for which reason this type of fracture is named Capillary Fracture.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	 Among these [types of fractures] is a fracture that occurs due to an accident or being struck by a stone, and these cause the bone layer to enter into the interior, forming a hollow: as it happens with the crucibles of metal, when they are struck and a part of them enters into the interior.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	 This is most often found in the moist bones of the head, such as those of children.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	 All these kinds of fractures are set separately, and I will return with the explanation of this [entire matter] in its proper place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	 We know all these kinds of fractures through examination of it, and investigation of them with probes, and removal of the corrupted flesh that is over them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	 The Capillary type is known through this: that it is revealed on the bone, scraped, and lined up on top of it with pitch: for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	 In the treatment of a fracture, first consider the condition of the patient: then if you see signs from his condition that indicate fearfulness, such as vomiting cholera, extension, loss of intellect, loss of voice, fainting, acute fever, eye problems, redness of eyes and similar signs in many other conditions, without a doubt it will not heal: and if you see the patient's conditions are not terrifying to you, and hope for recovery: then begin its treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	 If a wounded person comes to you in the first instance and is wounded: and it happens during winter days, then it is necessary that you study bone excision before the fourteenth day according to every arrangement.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	 If it is during the summer days, then it is necessary that you hurry to remove the bone before the seventh day, before it becomes rotten under the bone from the tissue, and such accidents occur as we have mentioned.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	 If the bone fracture has already reached the tissue touching the brain and is accompanied by pieces and pulling: then it is necessary that you cut the broken and smoothed parts according to what I have told you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	 It is necessary that you shave the head of the wounded person and scrape over the bone as much as possible for you, according to the shape of the wound and what is light over the weak.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	 If it happens to you during the scraping of the bone a flow of blood or a hot abscess: then put what is necessary against it.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	 And it is necessary that you fill the place with soaked cloths in wine and rose oil, and let the wound rest until the abscess settles, and be secure from blood flow.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	 Then begin the healing of the bone, and the removal of it.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	 And this is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	 The first method is to cut the bone with a knife having a narrow blade: and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	 And administer another knife wider than the previous one a little: and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	 Then also administer another knife even wider than the second one.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	 And the second method is that there should be a number of knives of different sizes among you; some of which are wider than others and some shorter than others: and they should be at the end of sharpness extremities, and made of Indian iron or copper, and use them with ease in striking the knife so as not to strike the head and hurt it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	 If the bone is hard and tough: then it is necessary that you perforate around its circumference before you administer Incisoria, with Terebris which are called Terebra not penetrating deeply; and they are not so named except because they do not pass through the bone's flesh to what is beyond it; therefore, because the Terebra has a rounded end above that which is beneath its head, and a small circle prevents submerging, and passing through the bone's thickness.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	 And it is necessary for you to take a great number of these Terebris, one of which suits the thickness of the bone, until there is for you all the Terebra that fits the skull; whose sharp end's size in length and width should be according to the thickness of the skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	 And this is the form of three kinds of Terebris or Trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	 The quality of perforating the bone's circumference after it is broken, is that you place the Terebra on the bone and rotate it with your fingers until you know that the bone has already been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	 Then change the position of the Terebra to another place, and put in its place what is equal to the size of a finger or approximately that.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	 Then cut with Incisoria what is between every hole in the bone; and do it more delicately than you can on the top of it, as we have said, until you excavate the bone, either with your hand or with some other tools which you have prepared for that purpose: such as tenaliae and delicate forpices.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	 And you must be careful with all caution, lest the Terebra or any Incisoria touch something from the skull.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	 When you perforate the bone and it has been separated from the skull, if it is continuous with it and you extract it, then it is necessary to scrape and make equal the end that remains in the bone with another tool similar to an Incisoria.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	 It is necessary that it be thin and delicate more than other incisors.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	 If something remains of the small bones and cartilage, then take it with ease, along with what is at hand from your instruments.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	 Then care for the wound after that with linen cloths and unguents as we said before.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	 Another method of operation is easy, completely distant from fear; which Galen said and praised greatly; and this is his saying.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	 First, you must begin to expose the bone piece from the place where the fracture is more violent and clear; until when you have exposed that part and placed under it the end of this concave incisor, which has this form.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	 The concave part does not cut anything; and the sharp part of it facing in both directions along its length, as you see; so that the concave part is attached to the bone, with the sharp part incident on the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	 Then strike on the incisor from one side with a small hammer, until you cut the whole bone with ease, as it is turned; and be careful that no cloth (panniculo) from you happens to fall into what is happening, which you fear completely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	 And if the physician were not more foolish than men and ignorant of this, nor was he sleeping, then if something remained attached to the bone from the cloths in some places, he would cut it off with the end of the concave incisor itself and release it easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	 It is released from it without harm and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	 If the bone fracture does not penetrate to the cloth, and what is cut off from the bone is its face, and roughness and delicate cartilage remain in it; then it is necessary that you grind down the roughness, and dig out the delicate cartilages with fine rasps, which you have prepared of various sizes, so that it is possible for you to apply them more suitable and correct ones in every place according to what leads you the operation, and the fractured bone itself, and its shape.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	 It is necessary that you administer [the operation] according to your own judgment, firstly cutting the bone, more widely than those who scrape it off.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	 Then use a finer tool after that.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	 And do not stop doing it continuously until you reach the point of administering it more thinly and finer than all of them.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	 In every one of the remaining small fissures and a fine fracture, it is necessary to administer care, according to that which leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	 And there is a matter that does not hide over all, to whomever has any interest in this art, and it stands on what we have written and shown in large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	 If a membrane is found to be retained when you remove the bone: then it is necessary that you take linen cloth, according to the size of the wound, and immerse it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	 Then take another doubled or tripled cloth, immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it over the first cloth: and do that as easily as possible on top of it, so that it is not burdened by moisture.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	 Then administer a broad ligament over it: and do not tighten it, unless for the amount that holds the wound only: and release it with this care for one day or two days, until you are certain about the hot inflammation.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	 Then dissolve it, and administer afterwards medicines with which excess dryness is needed: such as the roots of garlic, and wheat flour, and frankincense powder, and aristolochia, and similar things: and there is, that you make from these medicines a powder, which is dusted over the wound like dry ones.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	 And universally administer all medicine in it of the nature that cleans and does not bite.
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	 "And be careful according to your virtue, so that the wound may be clean during your treatment: there should not be dirt from ointment, nor dirtiness.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	 "Do not allow pus to accumulate at all: since when pus accumulates on the brain tissue, it corrodes and rots it, causing great harm to the sick person afterwards; and this has already happened with the skull, when the bone is being cleaned by him, especially when care for it is neglected. A blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	 "Therefore, if the conditions that I mentioned occur in the sick person, know that it is surely fatal.
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	 "And if blackness does not occur, except from the medicine applied to him and it is effective in its action so that it makes this blackness: then one should take a portion of honey, three portions of rose oil, and anoint with them a cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	 "Then place it on the skull; afterwards take care of him with the means of healing that are appropriate, until he is healed.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	 "On the restoration of a broken nose.
Caput IIII.	 "Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	 "Know that the nose is not broken except when both of its upper parts are broken at once or only one of them: because it consists of two bones; since below it is cartilaginous and does not break, but only becomes bruised, distorted, and crooked.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	 "If one of the two parts is broken, then one should insert a small finger into the nose and push the fracture back with the index and thumb to its normal shape; this should be done skillfully.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	 "And be careful that pain does not occur in the sick person during your operation.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	 If the fracture is in the upper part of the nose and does not reach it with the finger: then, it is necessary to align the extremity of the radius, where there should be a small swelling.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	 If the fracture is in two parts, then make it similar to that one: and bring together with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	 And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day, at rest with the cauterization of warm lard.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	 Then insert a piece of flax from linen cloth into the end of the nose if the fracture is in one part: or insert two pieces of flax if the fracture is in two parts: and let there be a swelling on the flax of such size that it fills the nostril opening.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	 And some of the old restorers said, that the flax should be soaked in butter and changed every day.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	 But this does not seem to me, rather it is necessary that the flax should be soaked in egg white, made with flour mill powder.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	 Then release the flax when the bone hardens and the cartilage hardens.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	 And sometimes a feather of the goose is inserted into the nose in place of flax after it has been covered with soft cloth: and this makes it so that the feather holds the fracture of the nose more firmly, and so as not to prevent the weak from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	 And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	 If you want, do it: if you want, do it with flax.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	 If the nose again forms an abscess while treating it with warm cautery, apply a nasal plaster with pitch, or with pitch soaked in rose oil, or a little with balsam of Mecca.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	 But if no abscess forms with the warm cautery, then it is necessary to apply plasters made of sesame flour and incense powder mixed with egg white.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	 Then place a soft cloth upon it (the wound), and do not tie the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	 If however the nasal bones are broken or crushed, then it is necessary that you make an incision over them and extract them with instruments suitable for the purpose.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	 Then apply a suture and take care of it with that which causes it to heal, using ointments or plasters suitable for the purpose.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	 If a wound occurs between the nose, then it is necessary that you treat it with linen and administer a lead cannula until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	 Chapter on the restoration of the lower jaw when it is fractured.
Caput V.	 Chapter 5.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	 When the lower jaw is fractured and the fracture is not accompanied by a wound: then observe whether the fracture is only on the outside and is not broken into two pieces, and bends inward: then its diagnosis is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	 Therefore, if the fracture is on the right side, insert your left index finger into the weak jaw: similarly, if the fracture is in the left lower jaw, then insert your right index finger: and press with it the protrusion of the fracture from inside to outside with ease using your other hand from the inner part of the bone correctly, and equalize it.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	 If the fracture of the lower jaw has already separated into two pieces, then administer traction from both sides according to straightness: until it is possible to equalize it.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	 If however a loosening or displacement of the teeth has already occurred, then tie them with a thread of gold, silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	 Then place a soft cushion on the fractured lower jaw.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	 Then place a double cloth on the fractured lower jaw, and place over it a large star-shaped cushion made properly: or an equal piece of skin from a sandal in length to the jaw bone.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	 Then bind it up from above, according to how you prepare its ligature, and let it rest until it is healed: and instruct the patient to be at peace and rest: and put for his food softened meals.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	 If however you think that something is changing in the figure by any means: then be quick, and dissolve it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	 Then correct whatever has been changed from it, and apply plaster made of milled flour with egg white, or with sifted wheat flour, after you have removed the scabs: and place soft wool on top of the plaster.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	 While that plaster remains attached to it and the bone arrangement does not change, let it be, without removing it, until it is healed: or bind the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	 This fracture is bound many times in three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	 If however a warm abscess occurs in the meantime: then administer what I said many times for its reduction, until the abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	 And if the fracture is with a wound, consider it.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	 For if a piece of bone is separated, or from a sawing: then be subtle in this, to remove those pieces of sawing with what suits you for the removal of them from the instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 If however the wound opening is narrow: then enlarge it with a leech according to your needs.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	 Then when you remove the sawing, and nothing remains of them: or if the wound opening is wide: and if not, place on it from plasters that suit for this, and let it heal until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	 Chapter on the restoration of a Fork, when it breaks.
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	 The fork is broken most often from the front part from the shoulder, and its fracture is made according to one of three modes.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	 For it is broken and separated into two, except that there occur in it suppurations: and it is more easily restored to its state.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	 For such as occur in the bone, suppurations: and it is more difficult to restore.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	 For such as is a fracture with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	 And the operation in it when there is a fracture without a wound, is that you make two assistants present, one of whom holds the splintered furcula, and the other stretches the neck towards the opposite side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	 Then equalize the fracture with your fingers until its form is made, according to what is required: and let there be neither prominence nor hollowing in it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	 If you need more extension, then it is necessary that you place under the neck of the weak one a sphere made from cloth or wool: and let its size be according to your need: and stretch, lift, and squeeze the sphere with your hand until you equalize the fracture, according to what is required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	 If you cannot pull the end of the furcula outwards because it has reached deep: then it is necessary that the weak one lies down on his neck: and place under his shoulder a beam in size, and press the minister under his arm towards the lower part, until the bone of the furcula which is deep is lifted upwards: and then correct the fracture, and equalize it with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	 If, however, you feel a suppuration from the furcula and it moves: then it is necessary that you make an incision over it, and extract the suppuration easily.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	 If it remains in the bone, then make a handle on the incision of it with one of the Incisorium which you have prepared for that purpose, after you place under the furcula an instrument which saves the saw: and it is an instrument made from wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	 This is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	 It resembles a snail shell without a concavity.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	 And let its width be according to the need of that bone's size and proportions.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	 The length of it as much as possible for your operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	 And have two extremities, as you see; and one extremity be wide, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	 If the wound rupture which you split when extracting satheiatum bone is wide, and your cauterizing iron is hot, then gather two lips of the wound with suture.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	 And if the rupture is small, or fear hot cauterizing iron; then fill the wound with cloths and wool, according to the amount of the wound's cut.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	 If it happens that hot cauterizing iron occurs, then pour oil of roses on the cloth, vinegar, and wine, and place it on top of it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	 But the fixation of bone without a wound and without cutting is, to place plaster on the bone made from flour milled with egg white.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	 And put soft wool on top of it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	 Then place a sphere under the wound if it is needed.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	 Then take a leech, that is, the roll which the Saracens hold, which is very long; and its width should be as wide as one palm, or approximately that.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	 Then place a double piece of wool on top of the soft wool and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	 Then take a needle from fine wood, whose width is three fingers, and similarly in length.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	 Then thread the needle with cloth.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	 Then thread the cloth with the needle in the place of the leech which falls on the fracture and the wound.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	 Then place the leech on the fracture as it is rolled, and thread it over its neck, and under the healthy wound, and under the sick wound; and return it over all parts, and so that the fixation holds the fracture properly; and this is what must not be hidden from you, and completely, so that the needle does not move over the broken bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	 It is necessary to observe the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	 Whenever the ligament becomes soft and you see the knot being removed, then correct it and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	 Then place the sick man's sleep on his back and place a small pill under his pillow at night so that when he wakes up, his aid may be raised from his side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	 Therefore, raise the fracture of the collarbone by elevating the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	 Either bind his arm to his neck and do not loosen the bandage unless it happens in a place that is swollen due to itching or from an abscess, for twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	 Then renew the plaster if you see his face turning towards it.
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	 And add to the constriction and release it until it is restored and healed.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	 The fracture of the collarbone is bound and supported for up to twenty days; it may be less in some people.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	 Chapter on the restoration of the Fractured Spatula (Scapula).
Caput VII.	 Chapter 7.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	 The scapula rarely breaks in a wide place; it does not break except at its edges.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	 When it breaks from there, and breaks in the middle of it, and it is not known unless by touch, then make the preparation according to the shape of the fracture.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	 And reduce it to its natural shape in every way possible for you.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	 Then place flour of milling with egg white and soft wool over it and put a pillow made of double cloth on top.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	 Then place the wide knot under it from a thin board according to the size of the scapula or larger but not too much.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	 If there is a concavity under the knot at some place on the scapula, then fill it with soft wool until the knot descends to the same level.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	 Then apply a tourniquet above with sufficient tightness and firmness, until it is no longer moved from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	 And consider the bandage daily.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 Whenever therefore the bandage becomes soft, tighten it, and equalize the pressure if it is moved from its place: let the weak side lie upon the healthy one.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	 The spatula is restored in twenty or thirty days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	 When this number is completed, then loosen the bandage: and be safe.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	 For it is from bones whose fracture is not feared nor their separation.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	 If however it protrudes from the bone and punctures under the skin: then cut above it, and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	 And do as I have said in the treatment of a fracture of the neck of the femur by hot poultice, if anything occurs from it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	 Chapter on the restoration of a breastbone fracture.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter VIII.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	 The chest is sometimes broken in the middle, and this happens rarely.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	 However, its extremities are broken and crushed more frequently due to accidents of it.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	 When the middle of it is broken, which inclines towards the lower part, and a violent pain occurs in it, and difficulty in breathing, and coughing; and perhaps blood vomiting occurs, and the hollow in the fractured bone is evident to the sense, and not covered: the restoration of this is that the weak side lies upon its back: and place between its spatulas a cushion.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	 Then press the shoulders and join the ribs from both sides or flanks with hands: and grind it evenly, according to every way in which this can be done and fits together, until the figure of the bone returns, as required.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	Then place on top of it an ointment and a powder, and place on top of that a thin star-shaped piece made from willow or boxwood, or similar materials, after you have rolled it up in a cloth.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	 Then wrap it around the broken bone, so that it is not removed: and go with the bandage following the roundness to the back several times, and bind it tightly enough.
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	 Then consider the bandage at every hour and whenever it becomes soft, tighten it; and if its necessity causes it to dissolve due to itching or corrosion that occurs in the place, or pain, or abscess: then hurry, and loosen it, remove the ointment, and correct what happened with the treatment method.
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	 Then reduce the ointment if you see it going to that face; and join a tight bandage until healed.
