¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	 Chapter on Restoring Costal Bones, when they break.
Caput IX.	 Chapter IX.
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	 Know that a costal bone fracture does not occur except in large areas that follow the back and from their extremities on the front side.
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	 And it is not caused by friction, unless because they are cartilaginous.
Et cognitio ipsius non occultatur sensui apud inquisitionem cum digitis.	 And the detection of this is not concealed from touch during examination with fingers.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, ut aeques fracturam cum digitis secundum modum possibilem, donec aequetur figura, secundum quod oportet.	 And the restoration of this is done so that the break can be aligned with fingers to the best possible extent until it matches the shape as required.
Deinde emplastra, et stringe os fractum cum astella, si indiget illo.	 Then apply an ointment and bind the broken bone with a star-shaped piece if necessary.
Et si fractura Costarum est decliuis ad interiora: tunc accidit infirmo dolor uehemens, et punctura, sicut punctura illa quae accidit illi qui habet pleuresim: propterea, quod os pungit uelamen, et etiam ei accidit difficultas anhelitus, et tussis, et uomitus sanguinis multi: et haec est difficilis curationis.	 If the costal bone fracture is towards the interior: then it causes a strong painful sensation, and puncture, like the puncture that occurs in pleurisy; because the bone pierces the membrane, and also there is difficulty breathing, and coughing, and vomiting of blood many times; this is difficult to treat.
Et iam ingeniati sunt antiqui in ea cum ingeniis multis: et ex eis sunt qui dicunt, ut ponas cibos infirmi qui generent inflammationem et uentositatem, ut inflammetur uenter, et extendatur, et impellatur fractura ad exteriora.	And the ancients have already devised that remedy with many devices: and among them are those who say to put foods for the sick which generate inflammation and gas, so that the stomach is inflamed, and it is stretched and driven outward in order to heal a fracture from outside.
Nos uero abhorremus, ut non fiat caussa uelox ad faciendum apostema calidum, si non accidit.	 We reject, that it should not be caused quickly to make a hot abscess, unless it happens.
Si autem iam accidit, tunc addit in eo.	 If it has already happened, then add it (the treatment) into it (the wound).
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: ponatur super locum uentosa, deinde sugatur cum fortitudine, et est similius ratiocinationi.	 And some of them said: place a windy substance on the place, then apply suction with force, and it is similar to reasoning.
Verumtamen timetur, quod attrahat uentosa superfluitates ad locum, propter dispositionem debilitatis.	 However, there is fear that windy substances will attract excess into the place, due to its weakened condition.
Et dixerunt quidam eorum: oportet ut cooperiatur locus cum lana quae iam submersa est in oleo calido: et ponantur puluilli inter Costas, donec impleatur: ut sit ligatura aequalis quando inuoluis eam secundum rotunditatem.	 And some of them said: the place should be covered with wool which has already been soaked in hot oil: and lice (puluilli) should be placed between the ribs until it is filled: so that the bandage is equal when you wind it around according to its roundness.
Deinde curetur infirmus curatione pleuresis ex cibo et medicina.	 Then the sick person is treated with a remedy for pleurisy from food and medicine.
Quod si coartat infirmum res uehemens, quam non tolerat, et os pungit uelamen punctura laedente, et timemus super infirmum: tunc oportet, ut scindamus super locum, et detegamus a Costa fracta.	 If the affliction presses too hard on the sick person and hurts him with a sharp instrument, piercing his flesh by wounding it, then we fear for the sick man: then it is necessary that we cut through the place and expose the broken rib.
Deinde ponamus super ea instrumentum quod conseruat sifac, cuius rememoratio praecessit: et incidamus os cum facilitate, et incidamus ipsum.	 Then we will place on it (the wound) an instrument that heals a sifac, whose name has been mentioned before: and we will cut the bone with ease, and we will cut it (the sifac).
Deinde aggregemus duo labia uulneris, si est magnum cum sutura: et curemus ipsum cum emplastris, donec sanetur.	 Then we will join together two lips of the wound, if it is large with suture: and we will treat it with plasters until it heals.
Quod si accidat interim apostema calidum, tunc propera, et infunde puluillos in oleo rosato, et pone super locum: et curetur infirmus cum eo quod conuenit apostemati.	 If a hot abscess should happen meanwhile, then hurry and pour lice into rose oil, and place it on the spot: and the sick person is treated with what is suitable for treating an abscess.
Interim etiam resupinetur super latus super quod dormit, donec sanetur.	 The patient should also lie on the opposite side until he is cured.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spondilium dorsi et colli.	 On the Restoration of a Fracture of the Spine and Neck.
Caput X.	 Chapter X.
Ossibus quidem colli quandoque aduenit fractura, et raro accidit eis attritio: et similiter Spondilibus dorsi etiam.	 Fracture sometimes occurs in the bones of the neck, and it rarely happens that they are rubbed [against each other]: and similarly with the spondyles of the back.
Cum ergo accidit illud alicui, et uis scire, an sanetur, an non sanetur: tunc confidera.	 If this happens to someone and one desires to know whether it can be healed or not: then examine [the case].
Nam si uides manus eius iam mollificatas, et stupefactas, et mortuas: et non potest mouere eas, neque extendere eas, neque constringere eas: et quando constringis eas cum digitis tuis, et pungis eas cum acu, non sentit illud, et non sentit in eis dolorem: tunc scias, quia non sanatur, et in pluribus dispositionibus est mortale.	 For if you see the hands already softened, stunned, and dead; and it cannot move them, nor extend them, nor contract them; and when you press them with your fingers and prick them with a needle, it does not feel this or pain in them: then know that it will not heal, and in many cases it is mortal.
Quod si mouet eas, et sentit in eis constrictionem cum digitis et puncturam: tunc scias, quia nucha ossis salua est, et quod infirmus sanabitur cum curatione.	 If it moves them and feels the pressure with your fingers and the prick: then know that the neck bone is sound, and that the weak one will heal with treatment.
Quod si eueniat Spondilibus dorsi simile illius, et uis scire, an sanetur etiam, an non: tunc considera ad pedes eius: tunc si uides quod mollificati sunt, et accidit in eis illud quod accidit in manibus: deinde quando iacet super dorsum suum, egreditur uentositas et egestio absque uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super uentrem suum, egreditur egestio sine uoluntate: et quando resupinatur super dorsum suum, et uult mingere, et non potest: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	 If it happens with the spondyles of the back similarly to this case, and one desires to know whether it can be healed or not: then examine his feet; then if you see that they are softened and this happens in them as it happened in the hands; then when he lies on his back, he expels wind and faeces involuntarily; and when he lies on his abdomen, he expels faeces involuntarily; and when he lies on his back again and wishes to urinate, but cannot: then know that it is mortal.
Non ergo labores in curatione eius.	 Therefore do not labor in treating it.
Si uero non accidit ei aliquid ex illo, res est leuior.	 But if nothing of this happens to him, it is lighter [in nature].
Et curatio eius quod accidit ex illo est, ut coneris sedationem apostematis calidi: ita, ut ponas super Spondilem attritam oleum rosatum solum: aut cum uitellis oui assati.	 And the treatment for this is to apply heat with a mustard plaster [to the affected spondyle]: so that you place oil of rose over the rubbed spondyle alone; or with hog's lard heated.
Pone super ipsam illud aliquotiens in die, donec quando sedatur apostema calidum: tum pone super locum unum ex emplastris confortantibus, exiccantibus, et stringe super ipsum cum ligamento: et praecipe infirmo, ut utatur quiete et tranquillitate.	 Place it on that place several times a day until the hot abscess is assuaged; then place one of the strengthening, drying, and binding plasters over it, and bind it with a ligament; and order the sick person to rest quietly and in peace.
Nec dormiat super partem cum qua inuenit dolorem, donec sanetur.	 He shall not sleep on the part where he found pain, until it is healed.
Quod si accidit apud attritionem ossis sathaiatum, aut aliquid quod iam separatum fit ex eo: tunc oportet, ut seces super cutem, et auferas illud.	 If it happens due to the rubbing of a bone (sathaim), or something that is already separated from it: then it is necessary for him to cut across the skin and remove it.
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris, si est magnum, cum sutura.	 Then gather together two lips of the wound, if it is large, with suturing.
Deinde cura ipsum cum aliquo incarnatiuo, ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	 Then care for himself with some soft dressing, from ointments, until he is healed.
Si uero frangitur postremum ossis alhausos, et est finis caudae: tunc oportet, ut intromittas pollicem manus sinistrae in anum, et aeques os fractum manu altera, secundum quod possibile est, et secunda aequatione.	 If however the last bone (alhaws) of the shin splint is broken and it is the end of the heel: then it is necessary to insert the thumb of the left hand into the anus, and with the other hand to align the broken bone as much as possible, according to what is possible, and in a second alignment.
Deinde pone super ipsum, et aufer ipsum: et cura uulnus cum curatione quae praecessit, donec sanetur.	 Then place him on it (the bone), and remove it; and care for the wound with the treatment that preceded it, until it is healed.
¶ De restauratione Anchae.	 Chapter on the restoration of anus (Anca).
Caput XI.	 Chapter 11.
Raro franguntur ossa Ancharum.	 Fractures of the bones of the ankles are rare.
Quod si franguntur, tunc fractura eorum non est, nisi comminutio in extremitatibus ipsorum: et scinduntur in longitudine, et declinantur ad interiora: et accidit infirmo dolor in loco, et punctura: et stupescit crus quod frangitur.	 If they are fractured, then the fracture is not anything except comminution at their extremities; and they are divided lengthwise, and slant towards the inside; and there occurs pain in that place, and puncturing; and the leg that was fractured becomes numb.
Et restauratio quidem eius est, ut extendas manum tuam super ipsum, donec stes super fracturam qualiter est figura eius.	And its restoration is, that you extend your hand over it, until you stand over the fracture as its figure is.
Quod si fractura est in extremitatibus eius tantum, tunc aequa illam fracturam, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ex aequatione, donec assimiletur figurae suae naturali.	 If the fracture is only at its extremities, then equalize that fracture, according to what you prepare yourself from the equation, until it resembles its natural figure.
Si autem fractura est in longitudine, aut iam declinat ad interiora: tunc fac iacere infirmum super uentrem suum, donec praeparetur tibi restauratio illius fracturae.	 If however the fracture is in its length, or it already turns towards the inside: then make the weak one lie on his belly, until the restoration of that fracture is prepared for you.
Quando ergo aequaueris ipsam, pone super ipsam emplastrum: deinde pone super ipsam astellam ex ligno, aut ex cute: et stringe strictura super quam non timeas permutationem fracturae, neque remotionem astellae.	 When you have equalized it, place a plaster on it; then place an astel (a splint) made of wood or hide over it and tie a suture on it where you are not afraid of altering the fracture or removing the splint.
Et aequa concauitatem illorum cum eo quod impleat eam, donec capiat eam strictura secundum aequalitatem: et praecipe infirmo, ut dormiat super dorsum suum, aut super latus suum sanum.	 And equal the concavity of them with what fills it until the suture takes it in accordance with the equality; and command the weak one to sleep on his back or on a healthy side.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum: tunc cessa ab extensione eius, et ipsius restauratione, donec sedetur apostema calidum: et pone super ipsum quod sedet ipsum, secundum quod praecessit, deinde redi ad restaurationem eius: et stringe ipsum sicut oportet.	 If a hot abscess occurs to him: then stop extending it and its restoration until the hot abscess settles; and place whatever is beneath it on it, according to what has passed, then return to its restoration; and tie it as needed.
Si uero accidit in osse satagie, aut comminuitur, extrahe.	 If however it happens to the bone that it swells or breaks out: extract it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Adiutorii.	 Chapter on the Restoration of Fractures.
Caput XII.	 Chapter 12.
Adiutorium est illud, quod est inter cubitum usque ad caput Spatulae.	 The helper (tool) is that which is between the elbow and head of the spatula.
Si ergo frangitur, tunc restauratio eius est secundum unum duorum modorum.	 If it breaks, then its restoration is according to one of two methods.
Quorum unus est: ut accipias lignum planum mediae grossitudinis, secundum hanc formam, quae sequitur.	 One of these methods is: that you receive a flat wooden board of medium thickness, in the following shape.
Et ligentur in duabus extremitatibus duo ligamenta.	 And two ligaments are to be tied at both ends.
Deinde suspendatur ex loco eleuato: et sedeat infirmus super sedem.	 Then it is suspended from a raised place, and the weak one shall sit on the seat.
Deinde proiiciat brachium suum fractum super lignum, donec perueniat ad titillicum eius, in cuius medio sit annexa curuitas ligni.	 Then he should throw his broken arm over a log until he reaches the notch of that log, where the break of the log is attached.
Deinde suspende desuper ipsum aliquid graue, ut extendat ipsum minister ad inferiora.	 Then let something heavy be placed upon him from above, so that the servant may stretch him towards the lower parts.
Deinde aequet medicus fracturam manibus suis simul, donec redeat fractura, secundum quod oportet.	 Then the physician shall set the fracture with his hands until it returns to its proper position.
Et modus alter est, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et suspende manum eius a collo ipsius cum ligamento.	 And another method is that the weak one lies on his neck; and let his hand hang from his neck with a bandage.
Deinde praecipe duobus ministris, ut teneat unus eorum illud quod est supra fracturam cum manibus suis: et ut alter teneat inferius eius, et extendat unusquisque eorum ad partem suam.	 Then command two servants that one holds what is above the fracture with his hands; and let another hold below it, and each one of them stretches to his side.
Et si uis, ut sit extensio fortior, tunc stringe sub fractura cum ligamento, et supra ipsam cum ligamento alio: et extendat ea unusquisque duorum ministrorum ad duas partes suas.	 And if you wish the extension to be stronger, then bind below the fracture with a bandage, and above it with another bandage; and let each of the two servants stretch to his own sides.
Si ergo fractura est propinqua extremitati humeri, tunc oportet, ut ponatur unum ligamentum sub titillico, et alterum sub fractura uersus cubitum.	 If therefore the fracture is close to the shoulder end, then it is necessary that one bandage be placed under the notch and another under the fracture towards the elbow.
Et similiter si fractura est propinqua cubito: tunc oportet, ut ponatur ligamentum super illum locum, et super cubitum ipsum.	 And similarly if the fracture is close to the elbow, then it is necessary that a bandage be placed above that place and above the elbow itself.
Deinde aequa fracturam cum facilitate absque labore, donec quando aequatur fractura secundum quod oportet, et applicatur applicatione bona: tunc stringe eam, si non accidit apostema calidum.	 Then set the fracture easily without difficulty, until it is level according to what is necessary, and applied correctly; then bind it if no warm abscess occurs.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam usque ad diem septimum.	 But if a warm abscess occurs, then release the binding for seven days.
Et pone super ipsum lanam succidam imbibitam in aceto et oleo rosato, donec quando quiescit apostema: tunc stringe eam: et modus stringendi eam est, ut ponas emplastrum super fracturam.	 Place linen that has been soaked in vinegar and rose oil on it until the abscess subsides; then bind it: and the method of binding is to place a plaster over the fracture.
Deinde pone inuolutionem ex panno nouo super emplastrum.	 Then place the inversion from new cloth over the plaster.
Deinde aggreget brachium super adiutorium ipsum, et ponat manum suam apertam super humerum suum.	 Then gather the arm onto the support itself, and put his open hand on his own shoulder.
Et pone pannum, et stringe super adiutorium brachium, ut brachium stet loco astellarum: si non prohibet te ab illo aliquid, neque alteretur super te aliquid ex osse fracto.	 Place the cloth and bind it over the support so that the arm remains in place like a star: if something does not prevent you from doing this, nor will anything move due to a broken bone.
Quod si times, quod alteretur super te ex osse fracto aliquid, tunc utere astellis: et est, ut ponas super fracturam ipsam astellam quae sit latior et fortior reliquis astellis.	 If you are afraid that something will move due to a broken bone, then use a star: and there is one, by which you place the larger and stronger star over the fracture itself.
Et ponas inter omnem astellam latitudinem digiti: et sit longitudo astellarum secundum fracturam cum additione trium digitorum ab omni parte.	 And place the width of each star equal to a digit: and let the length of the stars be according to the fracture, with an addition of three digits from every side.
Deinde stringe super astellas strictura quam dixi in principio capituli.	 Then bind over the stars with the bandage as I said at the beginning of this chapter.
Et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae strictior.	 And your binding should be tighter than the fracture site.
Et quanto plus elongatur fractura, sit strictura minor.	 And as the fracture extends more, let the binding be less.
Si ergo uides situm astellarum et stricturam, sicut diximus, in hora qua restauras membrum statim, tunc fac: et si times apostema calidum, tunc dimitte stricturam et astellas usque ad diem septimum, sicut diximus.	 If you see the position of the stars and the binding as we have said, then do it at the hour when you restore the limb immediately: but if you fear a hot abscess, then let go of the binding and the stars until the seventh day, as we have said.
Deinde considera ligamentum in omnibus tribus diebus, ut non accidat in loco pruritus, aut inflatio, aut prohibeatur cibus peruenire ad membrum, propter dispositionem superfluitatis stricturae.	 Then consider the binding in all three days, so that it does not happen in the place of itching, or swelling, or food is prevented from reaching the limb because of the excess binding.
Rectifica ergo illud totum, secundum quod diximus.	 Correct therefore everything as we have said.
Si uero es super fiduciam, ut non accidat ex illo aliquid: tunc non soluas ligamentum, nisi post tres dies, aut plus.	 If you are confident that nothing will happen from this: then do not loosen the binding, unless after three days or more.
Et sit dormitio infirmi super dorsum suum, et manus eius super stomachum suum: et pone sub adiutorio culcitram plenam lana aequaliter.	 Let the weak person sleep on his back and place his hand on his stomach: and put woolen socks full of wool equally under the support.
Et considera in omni hora noctis, aut diei, ut non soluatur figura membri fracta, aut mollificetur ligamentum.	 Consider at every hour of the night or day, so that the figure of the broken member is not loosened, nor is the ligament softened.
Rectifica ergo illud totum uirtute tua.	 Correct it entirely with your power.
Et pone cibum infirmi secundum ordinem quem praemisimus, ita ut sit cibus subtilis in primis, donec incipiat os stringi: tunc oportet, ut ingrosses cibum eius.	 Place food for the sick according to the order we have given you, so that it is a subtle food first, until the bone begins to bind; then it is necessary, that you increase his food.
De consuetudine enim adiutorii et cruris est, ut stringatur in quadraginta diebus: tunc ergo oportet, ut soluatur, et administretur balneum, et medicetur cum unguentis quae rectificant illud.	 For the custom of help and the member is to bind for forty days; then it is necessary, that it be loosened, and a bath be given, and it be treated with ointments which correct it.
Quod si fractura fuerit foeda, attrita: tunc non soluas ab ea ligamentum et astellas usque ad quinquaginta dies, et usque ad duos menses.	 If the fracture is foul, scrape it; then do not loosen from it the ligament and splints for fifty days, and until two months.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Brachii.	 Chapter on the restoration of the broken arm.
Caput XIII.	 Chapter 13.
Brachium est compositum ex duobus ossibus, quae nominantur duo focilia.	 The arm is composed of two bones, which are called two humeruses.
Quorum unum est paruum: et est illud quod sequitur pollicem.	 One of them is small; and it follows the thumb.
Et alterum est magnum, et est illud quod est positum sub paruo ab inferiori parte.	 And the other one is large, and it is placed below the small one from the lower part.
Fortasse ergo frangitur focile maius solum, aut paruum: et fortasse franguntur simul.	 Perhaps only the large humerus breaks, or perhaps both break at once.
Quando ergo frangitur focile paruum superius, tunc restauratio eius est facilis, et sanatio eius est facilior.	 When therefore the small humerus above breaks, then its restoration is easy, and its healing is easier.
Et quando frangitur focile inferius, est fractura eius mala, et sanatio eius difficilis.	 And when the large humerus below breaks, the fracture is bad, and the healing is difficult.
Et deterior ea est, quando franguntur duo ossa simul.	 And it is worse when both bones break at once.
Si ergo os quod frangitur est focile parum superius, tunc conuenit medico apud restaurationem eius, ut ponat extensionem paruam cum facilitate, donec aequet ipsum.	 If the bone that breaks is the small humerus above, then it is fitting for the physician at its restoration, to place a sling smaller with ease until it equals itself.
Si uero focile magnum est illud quod fractum est: tunc oportet, ut ponat stricturam fortiorem ualde.	 If however the large humerus is the one that is broken: then it is necessary to place a strong splint very tightly.
Et oportet, ut ponat figuram manus apud restaurationem eius, et ipsius extensionem extensam super puluinar.	 It is necessary that [the figure] of the hand be placed at its restoration, and its [full] extension extended over the pulley.
Et sit pollex manus ad superiora altior omnibus digitis: et sit articularis inferior omnibus digitis, uel reliquis: et infirmus sedens quadratus super seipsum, et sit puluinar coram eo, uel in directo eius, in altitudine, ut non incurrat infirmus laborem.	 The thumb shall be higher than all the fingers, and the lower joint (of the thumb) shall be higher than all the digits or the rest: and the weakened square one resting on itself, and there shall be a pulley before it or directly in front of it, at its level, so that the weakened does not fall into labor.
Deinde extendat minister Brachium ab inferiori parte, aut manu sua, aut cum ligamento.	 Then let the attendant stretch the arm from its lower part with his hand or with a ligature.
Et minister alius extendat desuper similiter.	 And another attendant shall stretch likewise from above.
Deinde aequet medicus os, donec reducat ipsum secundum meliorem figuram quam potest.	 Then the physician sets the bone until he brings it back to its best shape possible.
Quod si in fractura ossis sunt satagiae, tunc conare reducere omne frustum in loco suo uirtute tua.	 If there are pus-filled cavities (sinuses) in the bone fracture, then strive to replace every splinter in its place with your strength.
Si uero apparet in eo sathaiatum separatum, et pungit cutem, et non est tibi spes in restauratione eius: tunc finde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum secundum modum quem diximus in eis quae praemissa sunt.	 But if it appears separated and pustular (abscessed) and penetrating the skin and there is no hope of restoration for it: then incise over it, and excise it according to the manner which was previously mentioned.
Si autem fractura est cum uulnere, ego iam feci ad illud capitulum singulare, ergo accipe curationem illius inde.	 But if there is a fracture with a wound, I have already written a separate chapter on this matter, so take care of it from that point.
Quod si accidat in principio tuae restaurationis apostema calidum, tunc line pannum cum caeroto facto ex oleo rosato, et caera alba, et sit medium inter spissitudinem et subtilitatem: et stringe pannum super ipsum strictura subtili, donec quando sedatur apostema: tunc remoue caerotum, et pone emplastrum praeparatum ex puluere molendini cum albumine oui.	 If at the beginning of your restoration an abscess arises that is hot, then apply a linen cloth prepared with wax made from rose oil, white wax, and medium thickness: and bind the cloth over it tightly with a narrow ligature until when the abscess subsides: then remove the wax, and place an ointment prepared from flour mill powder and egg whites.
Deinde pone astellas, et sit astella quae ponitur super fracturam ipsam latior parumper, et fortior.	 Then place pins, and the pin that is placed over the fracture should be slightly larger and stronger.
Et scias, quod numerus astellarum Brachii est sex in pluribus dispositionibus: siue sit fractura in focili uno, aut in duobus focilibus simul.	 And know that the number of pins for the arm is six in most cases: whether the fracture occurs in one splint or two splints at once.
Deinde pone stricturam tuam super locum fracturae fortiorem et uehementiorem, et aliquanto plus cum strictura ad superiora fracturae, aut ad inferiora eius: aut pone stricturam molliorem strictura eius parumper, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius in principio capituli.	Then place your bandage stronger and more forceful over the stronger and more prominent part of the fracture, and a little further towards its upper or lower parts: or place a softer bandage around it according to what was previously remembered at the beginning of the chapter.
Et sint panni qui inuoluuntur super fracturam, panni lenes, humidi: et non sint duri, asperi.	 The wrappings to be used on the fracture should be soft, moist: and they should not be hard, rough.
Et sit filum quo stringitur ex lino proprie, medium inter subtile et grossum, sicut narrauimus.	 And let the thread for binding be of linen, middle between fine and coarse, as we have said.
Et considera membrum et ligamentum post dies.	 Consider the limb and ligament after several days.
Quod si accidat aliquid cuius rectificatio sit necessaria, sicut pruritus qui accidit membro: tunc oportet, ut embroces membrum cum aqua calefacta, donec quiescat ille pruritus, et dimittas membrum non constrictum, donec quiescat, deinde itera stricturam.	 If anything happens which requires correction, such as itching on the limb: then it is necessary that you apply embrocation to the limb with warm water until the itching stops, and leave the limb unbound until it calms down; then repeat the bandaging.
Quod si strictura iam mollificata est, et os iam remotum, et similia illis: tunc rectifica illud totum uirtute tua, et considera iterum.	 If the bandage has already been softened and the bone removed, and similar things have happened: then correct that completely with your skill, and consider again.
Nam si nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad membrum, propter superfluitatem stricturae, tunc oportet, ut mollifices ipsum parumper, et dimittas ipsum aliquot diebus, donec currat ad ipsum nutrimentum, deinde stringe ipsum.	 If nutrition is prevented from reaching the limb due to excessive bandaging, then it is necessary to soften it slightly, and leave it for some days until it reaches the nutrition; then bind it again.
Si autem non accidit infirmo aliquid eorum quae diximus, tunc non oportet, ut soluatur, nisi post uiginti dies, aut circiter hos.	 But if nothing of what has been said happens to the sick person, then it is not necessary to loosen him, unless after twenty days or thereabouts.
Deinde suspendatur manus infirmi ad collum eius.	 Then the hand of the sick person is suspended at his neck.
Et sit collum eius aequale, et custodiatur uirtute sua a motibus agitatiuis.	 And let his neck be straight, and keep it protected from violent movements.
Et fac eum dormire super dorsum suum.	 Make him sleep on his back.
Et scias, quod haec fractura in triginta diebus, aut in triginta duobus diebus restauratur: et fortasse restauratur in uigintiocto diebus.	 And know that this fracture is healed within thirty or forty days; and perhaps it is healed within twenty-eight days.
Totum illud est secundum dispositiones complexionum, et dispositiones uirtutis.	 All of that depends on the temperaments and dispositions of humors and virtues.
¶ De restauratione fracturarum Manus.	 Restoration of broken hands.
Caput XIIII.	 De Ossibus et Squillis, et de Cur
Scias, quod pectini Manus, et nodis digitorum raro accidit fractura.	 Know that the hand comb and finger knots rarely occur a fracture.
Et non accidit ei, nisi attritio multotiens.	 It does not happen to him, unless it is rubbed many times.
Quando ergo accidit plantae fractura, aut attritio: tunc oportet, ut sedeat infirmus quadratus: et coram eo sit sedes secundum aequalitatem.	 When a foot fracture occurs or is rubbed, then it is necessary that the patient sits on a low stool, and before him there should be a seat equal in height.
Deinde pone Manum eius super eam extensam.	 Then put his hand upon it extended.
Deinde extendat minister ossa fracta, et aequet ea medicus, donec quando coniunguntur coniunctione bona.	 Then the servant spreads out the broken bones, and the doctor aligns them until they are joined with a good union.
Tunc oportet, ut ponat emplastrum et stuppam, si non accidat apostema calidum.	 Then it is necessary to place plaster and wool, unless there occurs a hot abscess.
Deinde pone astellam desuper secundum quantitatem loci: et tu iam inuoluisti eam in panno lini.	 Then put a splint on top according to the size of the place: and you have already wound it in linen cloth.
Si autem fractura est ad inferiora circiter uentrem plantae, tunc fac simile spherae ex panno: et praecipe infirmo, ut coartet super eam cum planta sua fracta: deinde stringatur cum panno longo.	 If the fracture is below about the belly of the foot, then make a similar sphere from cloth: and command the patient to bend over it with his broken foot: then tie it with long cloth.
Et sit astella ex corio, in quo sit lenitas, ut applicetur corium cum corpore plantae: et stringe eam, secundum quod oportet.	 And let the splint be of parchment, in which there is softness, so that it can be applied to the skin of the sole: and tie it as necessary.
Si autem fractura est ad exteriora, tunc oportet: ut ponas astellam desuper, et astellam aliam ab inferiori in planta: et sit manus aperta recta.	 If the fracture is on the outside, then it is necessary to place a splint on top and another one below on the foot: and keep the hand open and straight.
Deinde pone stricturam, sicut reuoluitur manus: et extende inter digitos cum ligamento.	 Then put a bandage, as the hand is rolled up: and extend between the fingers with a ligament.
Quod si accidat fractura alicui nodorum digitorum, tunc si est pollex, aequetur secundum quod oportet.	 If there occurs a fracture in any finger knot, then if it is the thumb, align it as necessary.
Deinde stringatur cum planta: et si amas, pone ei astellam rectam, paruam: ut eleuetur fractura, et non moueatur.	 Then tie with the foot: and if there are any more, place a straight splint, smaller, to lift the fracture and not move it.
Si autem fractura est reliquis digitis, sicut medio, et indici, aut auriculari, et anulari, tunc aequetur, et ligetur cum digito sano qui sequitur eum: aut ligentur omnes secundum continuationem: et est melius.	 If the fracture is in the remaining fingers, such as the middle, index, little finger or ring finger, then align it and tie it with the healthy finger that follows it: or tie all of them according to continuity: and it is better.
Aut pone super ipsum astellam paruam, sicut diximus in pollice.	 Place a small awl upon it [the part], as we have said in the thumb.
Et considera in restauratione tua, et post ipsam dispositionem apostematis calidi: et oppone cum eo quod oportet, quando accidit aliquid ex illo, secundum quod iteratur eius narratio.	 And consider in your restoration, and after the arrangement of the amputation of heat, and set against it what is required, when something happens from that [object], according to its repeated narrative.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Coxae.	 Chapter on the repair of a broken Hip.
Caput XV.	 Chapter Fifteen.
OS Coxae multotiens frangitur, et declaratur sensui: quoniam conuertitur ad interiorem et posteriorem partem.	 The thigh bone is often broken and revealed to the senses because it turns towards the inner and posterior part.
Et restauratio eius fit ita, quod stringitur ligamentum supra fracturam, et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	 And its repair is done by tightening a ligament above the break, and another ligament below the break.
Et infirmus prostretur super faciem suam.	 The sick person stretches himself upon his face.
Deinde extendat omne ligamentum minister ad partem suam secundum aequalitatem: et hoc, quando est fractura in medio ossis.	 Then extend all the ligaments serving its part equally; and this when the break is in the middle of the bone.
Si autem est fractura propinqua radici Coxae, tunc sit ligamentum ad partem pectinis, ut cadat extensio ad sursum: et ligamentum aliud sub fractura.	 If however the break is close to the root of the hip, then let there be a ligament for the neck part, so that the extension falls upward; and another ligament below the break.
Et sic similiter si est fractura propinqua genu, tunc sit ligamentum propinquum genu, ut sit extensio ad inferiora.	 And similarly if the break is close to the knee, then let there be a ligament near the knee, so that the extension falls towards the lower parts.
Deinde aequet medicus os utriusque manibus suis, donec reducat ipsum secundum similitudinem figurae naturalis: et coniugatur os coniunctione bona.	 Then the physician adjusts the bone with both hands until he reduces it to its original shape; and the bone unites by a good union.
Tunc oportet, ut ponas emplastrum et stricturam, si non accidit membro apostema.	 Then it is necessary that you apply plaster and a tight bandage if no abscess occurs in the limb.
Quod si accidat in eo apostema: tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sedetur apostema calidum, deinde redi ad curationem tuam.	 If an abscess should occur there: then let it be left for several days until the abscess becomes hot; then return to your treatment.
Strictura autem eius ita sit.	 The bandage of this [limb] should therefore be as follows.
Oportet ut inuoluas super fracturam imema duram, id est, bindam: et dupla eam bis, aut ter: et remaneat ex ea superfluitas.	 It is necessary to wind a hard plaster around the break, that is, bandage; and double it twice or three times; and there remains an excess of it.
Deinde inuolue crus, donec perueniat calcaneus apud radicem natis.	 Then wind the leg until the heel reaches the root of the natural joint.
Et intromitte filum longum inter Coxam et crus prope genu ad inferiora, et ueniant extremitates fili a superiori parte duarum partium.	 Insert a long thread between the hip and the leg near the knee towards the lower parts, and let the ends of the thread come from the upper parts of the two areas.
Deinde reuolue super Crus et Coxam quod superfluit ex alimema.	 Then roll up (the skin) over the leg and hip what remains from the incision.
Deinde pone super Coxam in loco fracturae ipsius astellas, et pone ex eis astellam unam super os cruris.	 Next, place stars (splints or bandages) on the hip in the location of the fracture, and place one star on the bone of the leg.
Deinde imple uacuitates inter crus et coxam cum pannis lenibus, ut aequetur strictura.	 Then fill the voids between the leg and hip with soft cloths so that it matches the tightness (of the wound).
Deinde incipe cum strictura forti a medio super locum fracturae tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor.	 Then begin with a strong suture from the middle above the location of the fracture with three or four revolutions.
Et quanto plus elongaris cum ligamento a loco fracturae, sit strictura tua minor et mollior, et lenior.	 And as you lengthen the suture from the location of the fracture, let your stitch be smaller, softer, and looser.
Deinde intende ad duas extremitates fili, quod tu intromisisti inter coxam et crus.	 Next, aim for the ends of the thread which you inserted between the hip and leg.
Liga ergo cum utrisque tres astellas quae sunt desuper.	 Then bind three stars (splints or bandages) on both sides (of the wound).
Deinde uade cum duabus extremitatibus fili ad inferiora, donec peruenias ad cauillam pedis.	 Next, follow the ends of the thread to the lower parts until you reach the ankle.
Et cum utrisque stringe etiam extremitates astellarum a parte altera: ut non remoueatur ligamentum ex loco suo.	 And with both sides bind also the ends of the stars so that the suture is not moved from its place.
Deinde dimitte stricturam super illud, dum permanet, ita quod non accidat membro corrosio, neque apostema, neque inflatio, et similia eis.	 Then release the stitch until it remains so that there is no rot on the limb, no abscess, no swelling, and similar things.
Quod si accidat aliquid ex illo.	 If something happens from this (the treated area).
Propera ergo cum solutione eius, et rectifica illud quod accidit inde totum, secundum quod diximus multotiens.	 Therefore, when the solution is applied to it, correct whatever has happened there completely, as we have said many times.
Si uero in osse est frustum ex osse quod pungat: tunc oportet, ut aeques illud, si est tibi possibile.	 But if there is a splinter in the bone that it pierces: then it is necessary to equalize it, if it is possible for you.
Et si non, finde super illud, et remoue illud: et cura cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio, donec sanetur.	 And if not, bind over it and remove it: and care about the one who preceded the reminder until it heals.
Et quandoque stringitur haec fractura Coxae, praeter quod addantur ei astellae, sicut diximus in adiutorio et brachio.	 And at times this hip fracture is tightened, apart from the addition of pegs, as we said in aid and arm. (Translated from Latin)
Verumtamen in restauratione eius taliter fracta, non accidit infirmo claudicatio.	 However, in its restoration, such a fracture does not cause lameness to the weak. (Translated from Latin)
Et si restauratur sola, praeter quod applicetur ei crus alterum, tunc necesse est, ut claudicet ille cuius est, semper.	 And if it is restored alone, apart from applying another leg to it, then it is necessary that he who has it will always limp. (Translated from Latin)
Et scias, quod Coxa stringitur in quinquaginta diebus, uel additur parum, aut minuitur parum: totum illud est secundum diuersitatem complexionum, et reliquarum dispositionum.	 Know that the hip becomes tightened in fifty days or less, or it is added too little, or it is reduced too little; all this is according to the diversity of complexions and other dispositions. (Translated from Latin)
¶ De restauratione fracturae Rotulae genu.	 Restoration of a fracture of the knee-cap. (Translated from Latin)
Caput XVI.	 Chapter XVI. (Translated from Latin)
Scias, quod Rotulae genu raro accidit fractura, sed accidit ei attritio multotiens.	 Know that the knee-cap rarely occurs a fracture, but it frequently occurs attrition. (Translated from Latin)
Si uero accidit ei fractura, tunc non nisi aut fissura, aut foramen in partibus suis.	 If indeed it occurs a fracture, then it is not other than a fissure or an opening in its parts. (Translated from Latin)
Et est illud cum uulnere, et absque uulnere.	 It is that with a wound and without a wound. (Translated from Latin)
Et statur super illud totum cum sensu.	 It stands upon it entirely with feeling. (Translated from Latin)
Et restauratio eius est ita, ut aequetur quod disruptum est ex partibus eius cum digitis, donec aggregetur, et coniungatur secundum quod possibile est ex aequatione et facilitate, et fabricatione.	 Its restoration is as follows: equalizing what has been split from its parts with fingers until it is gathered and joined according to what is possible by equalization and ease, and construction. (Translated from Latin)
Deinde pone emplastrum ex farina sisami, uel molendini, cum albumine oui: et pone super ipsum astellam rotundam, si indiges illa: et stringe desuper strictura conueniente ad illud.	 Then place a plaster made of rice flour or milled flour with egg white; and place upon it a round peg if needed; and bind above with a bandage suitable for that. (Translated from Latin)
Deinde considera omnes dispositiones quas narrauimus in reliquis fracturis: sicut apostema calidum, et similia illi: ita, ut opponas omni accidenti cum eo quod conuenit ei, donec sanetur.	 Then consider all the dispositions which we have mentioned in other fractures; such as a hot abscess and similar cases; so that you present every occurrence with what is suitable for it until it heals. (Translated from Latin)
¶ De restauratione fracturae Cruris.	 Restoration of a Leg Fracture.
Caput XVII.	 Chapter XVII.
Scias, quod Cruri sunt duo ossa, quorum unum est grossum, et nominatur nomine Cruris: et alterum subtile, et nominatur Focile.	 Know that there are two bones in the leg, one is large and called the shinbone (cruris); and the other is slender, and is called the calf bone (focile).
Et accidit utrisque ex speciebus fracturae quod accidit duobus ossibus brachii: et propter illud fit restauratio eius, sicut restauratio brachii aequaliter, et operatio est una.	 It happens with both kinds of fracture that it occurs with two bones of the arm; and because of this, its restoration is done equally, and the operation is one.
Quod si franguntur duo ossa simul, conuertitur Crus ad omnes partes.	 If two bones break simultaneously, the leg turns towards all directions.
Et si frangitur os subtilius, conuertitur Crus ad anteriorem partem.	 If a bone breaks more finely, the leg turns towards the anterior part.
Et si frangitur os grossius, inuenis illud inferius: et est ex eis quae non occultantur tibi.	 If a bone breaks coarsely, you will find it lower: and it is among those that are not hidden from you.
Deinde administra extensionem, et aequationem, et ligationem astellarum secundum illud aequaliter.	 Then administer the extension, equalization, and ligature of stars equally according to that.
Verumtamen oportet, si fractura Cruris est fractura foeda, habens sethagie multa: ut sit extensio minor, et lenior alleuiatione tua.	 However, if the fracture of the leg is a dirty fracture with many setragies, it should have a smaller and softer extension, and a gentler alleviation by you.
Et in Crure quidem est ex operatione quiddam super brachium: et est, ut quando tu aequas astellas, et comples omnem operationem tuam, tunc accipe duas fascias ex ligno pini, quod administratur in fabricatione solariorum quod ponitur sub tabulis: et fiunt ex spatulis palmae: et elige ex eis quibus est grossitudo parua, et neque sint ex minutis: et sit longitudo earum secundum longitudinem Cruris a genu usque inferius.	 And in the leg there is something about the operation that is similar to the arm: and it is, when you equalize the stars, and complete your entire operation, then take two bands from pine wood, which are used in the making of solariums placed under tables, and they are made of spatulas of the palm; and choose those with a small thickness, and not too thin; and let their length be according to the length of the leg from the knee downwards.
Deinde inuolue super unamquamque pannum duabus inuolutionibus secundum longitudinem eius.	 Then fold one band over another with two folds according to its length.
Et pone unam partem Cruris a parte una, et alteram a parte altera: et sint ex genu usque inferius pedis.	 And place one part of the leg on one side and the other on the other side: let them be from the knee down to the foot.
Deinde liga duas fascias in tribus locis ex duabus extremitatibus et medio.	 Then tie the two bands in three places at the two ends and in the middle.
Cum enim strictura prohibetur, Crus declinat ad dextram et sinistram, et stat statione bona.	 For it is forbidden to bind, the leg turns towards the right and left, and stands well with a good stance.
Et iam quidem administretur cunabulum ex ligno secundum longitudinem Cruris, et ponatur in eo Crus, ut conseruet ipsum a motu.	 And now the cradle made of wood according to the length of the leg should be placed under it, to keep it from moving.
Et plurimum quidem oportet, ut facias illud in fractura quando cum ea est uulnus proprie.	 It is most important that you make this [the treatment] when there is a wound with the fracture itself.
Deinde considera Crus in omni die, et stude cum eo studio ultimo ab apostemate, aut inflatione, aut reliquis aliis.	 Then consider the leg every day, and take care of it with utmost diligence to prevent aposteme, inflammation, or other things.
Si ergo accidit aliquid ex illis, tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet, usquequo sanetur, si Deus uoluerit.	 If anything from those (afflicts), then oppose it with what is necessary until it heals, if God wills it.
De fractura ossium Pedis, et Digitorum.	 On the Fracture of Bones of the Foot and Fingers.
Caput XVIII.	 Chapter Eighteen.
Calcaneo quidem non accidit fractura penitus.	 The calcaneum indeed does not suffer complete fracture.
Ossibus uero Pedis accidit quandoque fractura, et Digitis parum etiam accidit fractura: et non accidit eis nisi attritio in pluribus dispositionibus.	 The bones of the foot indeed sometimes suffer fracture, and fractures of the fingers do not happen very often: and they do not occur to them except by severe injury at several points.
Quod si accidit ossibus Pedis fractura, et uides illa ossa sublimari super se adinuicem, tunc ponat infirmus Pedem suum super terram praeparatam, sicut ambulans.	 If a fracture of the bones of the foot occurs, and you see the bone protruding beyond itself, then place the sick man's foot on the ground prepared as when walking.
Deinde sta tu, et pone Pedem tuum super illud quod eleuatur ex illis ossibus: postea preme, uel calca eam: et aequa ipsam, donec redeat in locis suis.	 Then you stand there, and place your foot on that which is raised from those bones; then press or tread upon it; and hold it equally, until it returns to its places.
Deinde pone emplastrum, et stuppam desuper: et pone sub uentre Pedis tabulam paruam, cui sint duo capita plana.	 Then place a poultice and a plaster on top of it; and put a small table beneath the foot with two flat heads.
Deinde stringe eam cum Pede strictura decenti, postquam tu inuoluis eam cum pannis, et reliquis quibus indiget.	 Then bind it with a decent bandage when you have wrapped it in linen and other things that are needed.
Cum ergo praetereunt ei tres dies, aut quatuor, tunc solue ligamentum.	 When three or four days have passed, then unbind the bandage.
Nam tu inuenies ossa aequata, siue sint fracta, aut sint dislocata.	 For you will find the bones aligned, whether they are broken or displaced.
Operatio ergo in eis est, sicut uides.	 The operation is therefore as you see.
Si autem franguntur aliqui digiti, tunc restaura eos, et aequa ipsos secundum quod narraui tibi in restauratione digitorum manus.	 If some fingers are broken, then restore them, and align them as I have told you in the restoration of fingers of the hand.
Deinde pone digito tuo astellam secundum longitudinem digiti, et sit latior eo parumper: deinde pone sub Pede hanc tabulam quam narraui tibi, et stringe eam strictura decenti.	 Then place a stylus along the length of your finger and let it be slightly wider than the finger; then put this table beneath the foot as I have told you, and bind it with a decent bandage.
Si uero quod frangitur ex ossibus est duo, aut tria, aut plus, tunc pone super omnem digitum astellam suae quantitatis, inuolutam in panno lini: et stringe tabulam in inferiori Pedis: et sit stans super unum capitum tabulae extra uentrem Pedis, ut teneat retentione bona.	 If what is broken is two or three bones, or more, then place a stylus of the same size over each finger and wrap it in linen; and bind the table beneath the foot; and let there be a standing on one head of the table outside the foot to hold it with good retention.
Et conuenit tibi, ut non obliuiscaris, quin consideres omnia quae dixi tibi in reliquis fracturis ex accidentibus quae diximus: et oppone omni accidenti cum eo quod oportet.	 It is fitting for you, lest you forget, to consider all that I told you about the other fractures regarding the accidents we mentioned; and apply the appropriate solution to every accident.
¶ De fractura Vuluae mulieris, et ossis pectinis, et uirgae uiri.	 On the fracture of a woman's jaw, and the breastbone, and a man's long bone.
Caput XIX.	 Chapter XIX.
Quando frangitur Vulua mulieris, tunc fac eam sedere quadratam.	 When a woman's jaw is fractured, then make her sit in a square position.
Deinde inclina eam ad partem dorsi ipsius parumper, et teneatur retro.	 Then lean her towards the back of the same slightly and hold her in that position.
Deinde impleat obstetrix Vuluam eius coto, donec impleat eam: et fiat in Vulua ex eo sicut sphera.	 Next, a midwife fills the woman's jaw with a linen cloth until it is full; and the jaw becomes as round as a sphere from this.
Deinde concutiatur mulier, et eleua dorsum eius paulatim.	 Then strike the woman gently, and gradually reduce her back.
Illud enim cotum egreditur, donec fiat ante portam Vuluae sicut sphera, et os fractum redit.	 This linen cloth emerges until it becomes before the mouth of the jaw as round as a sphere, and the broken bone returns.
Deinde pone puluillum super dorsum eius.	 Then place a small cushion under her back.
Quando ergo uult mingere, remoueat cotum cum facilitate, deinde mingat: et reduc ipsum secundum modum, quo intromisisti ipsum in primis: deinde redeat ad puluillum suum primum.	 Whenever she wishes to spit, let her easily remove the linen cloth, then spit; and bring it back according to the amount you first inserted; then return to the cushion again.
Faciat illud septem diebus, aut circiter, os ipsum enim restauratur.	 Let this be done for seven days or approximately; for the bone itself recovers.
Et si uis, accipe uesicam ouis, et stringe super foramen eius cannulam arundinis, et intromitte uesicam totam in Vuluam eius.	 And if you wish, take the bladder of a hen, and tie it around its orifice with a reed tube, and insert the entire bladder into her jaw.
Deinde suffla in cannulam cum uirtute, donec infletur uesica intra Vuluam, fractura enim redit.	 Then blow through the tube with force until the bladder is inflated inside the jaw; for the fracture returns.
Deinde impleatur cum coto, et stet aliquot diebus, secundum quod narrauimus, donec sanetur.	 Then it should be filled with linen cloth and stay for some days as we have said, until it heals.
Et quando frangitur os Pectinis uiri, aut mulieris, tunc administra in restauratione eius, et ipsius aequatione illud quod narrauimus in osse Anchae.	 When the breastbone of a man or woman is fractured, then administer its treatment and apply what we have said regarding the anchorage for the bone.
Et non occultatur rectum in his fracturis propinquis, quae parum contingunt, praecipue cui est quiddam studii, uel usus.	 And it is not hidden that the right [side] is not concealed in close fractures which happen little, particularly for one who has some interest or practice.
Et intellige librum meum istum multum, quoniam fractura ipsa significat tibi in pluribus dispositionibus uiam rectam in restauratione sui, et strictura sui: intellige ergo.	 Understand my book very much, because the fracture itself indicates to you in many dispositions the way of the right [side] in its restoration and the narrowing of it: therefore understand.
In Virga autem uiri quando frangitur, accipe guttur anseris: et intromitte uirgam in ipso.	 When a man's member breaks, take the throat of a goose; and insert the staff [into it].
Deinde pone super ipsum inuolutionem ex panno, et inuoluatur, et dimittatur tribus diebus, aut circiter eos, et sanabitur, si Deus uoluerit.	 Then place upon it a covering from cloth, and wrap [it], and let it be for three days or about them, and it will heal if God wishes.
¶ De restauratione fracturae ossium, quando est cum uulnere.	 On the restoration of bone fracture when there is a wound.
Caput XX.	 Chapter 20.
Conuenit ei cui accidit fractura cum uulnere, praecipue si est magnum, sicut os coxae, aut adiutorii, aut simile illi, ut properes, et phlebotomes ipsum statim: si attestantur tibi conditiones phlebotomiae, sicut praemisimus.	 It is appropriate for the one who has a fracture along with a wound, especially if it is large like the hip bone or humerus, to rush and summon a phlebotomist immediately; if you are informed of the conditions of phlebotomy as we have previously mentioned.
Quod si uulnus effluit sanguinem, tunc oportet, ut properes ad abscisionem eius, ita ut puluerizes super ipsum zegi tritum: si non est tibi praesens aliud.	 If the wound flows with blood, then it is necessary for you to rush for its amputation, so that you pour powdered lime over it if nothing else is present for you.
Deinde incipe restaurare fracturam in illo eodem die: et non postponas illud, si non accidit apostema.	 Then begin to restore the fracture on the same day; and do not delay this, unless an abscess occurs.
Si uero accidit apostema calidum, tunc dimitte restaurationem eius usque ad diem nonum, donec sedetur apostema.	 If however, an abscess hot occurs, then delay the restoration of it until the ninth day, until the abscess subsides.
Et non appropinques ei in die tertio, et quarto omnino, nam tu faceres ei accidere accidentia mala.	 And do not approach him on the third and fourth days, for you will cause him to suffer additional harm.
Si autem os fractum est eminens super cutem detectum: tunc oportet, ut coneris reducere ipsum, et aequare ipsum manibus tuis cum facilitate et extensione parua.	 If the broken bone is sticking out from the skin exposed: then it is necessary to try to bring it back and align it with your hands easily and slightly extended.
Si autem non praeparatur extensio eius, et ipsius aequatio manibus tuis: tunc reduc ipsum cum isto instrumento.	 If however the extension is not prepared, and the arm itself is equal to your hands: then reduce it with this instrument.
Et est instrumentum quod fit ex ferro, cuius longitudo est quantitas septem digitorum, aut octo: et eius latitudo est secundum quantitatem uulneris.	 And the tool is made of iron, whose length is seven or eight fingers: and its width is according to the size of the wound.
Et propter illud necesse est medico, ut accipiat ex eis tria, aut quatuor secundum quantitatem qua indiget ad illud ex curatione in omni specie fracturae.	 And for that reason it is necessary for the physician to take from them three or four, according to the quantity required for the treatment of any kind of fracture.
Et sit rotundum: et sit in eo grossitudo parua, ut non duplicetur apud compressionem super ipsum in hora operationis: et sit acutae extremitatis, cui sit margo in extremitatibus suis.	 And let it be round: and let its thickness be small, so as not to increase during the application of pressure on it during the hour of surgery: and let its sharp edges have a margin at their ends.
Et sit superius eius ad grossitudinem ex medietate eius usque ad inferiora.	 And let the upper part of it be thick up to the middle, but below that let it be thin.
Et haec est forma eius.	 And this is its shape.
Oportet in Hac Operatione, ut ponatur extremitas eius acuta curuata super extremitatem ossis eminentis: et impelle ipsum cum eo uice una, donec quando redit os et aequatur quadam aequatione.	 In this operation, the sharp end should be bent and placed over the protruding bone's extremity: and push it with it together until when the bone returns and is equalized in some way.
Conare ergo aequare extremitates fracturae adinuicem.	 Therefore try to align the fracture ends against each other.
Quod si extremitates eius fracta est subtilis, et non accipit eam instrumentum accaeptione bona, tunc opotet, ut incidas extremitatem illius ossis, donec instrumentum potestatem habeat eius.	 If the fracture ends are fine and do not accept the tool properly, then it is necessary to cut the bone end until the tool can hold it.
Si uero non potes reducere eos cum eo quod narrauimus omnino, tunc incide ipsum cum eo quod conuenit ei ex Incisoriis quae diximus: aut serra ipsum cum una serrarum quocunque modo possibile est tibi.	 If however you cannot reduce the bones with what I have described, then cut it with the chisels we mentioned, or saw it with one of your saws in any way possible for you.
Deinde rade illud quod remanet in osse ex asperitate et corticibus minutis.	 Then plane down what remains on the bone from roughness and fine layers.
Cum ergo reducitur os, et inuenit infirmus post reductionem eius dolorem uehementem laedentem, tunc scias, quod os non rediit ad locum suum naturalem.	 When the bone is reduced and after its removal a very strong pain arises that hurts it, then you know that the bone has not returned to its natural position.
Fac ergo illud.	 Make it so.
Nam tu confers infirmo iuuamentum magnum, cum completur restauratio tua quam facis ossi.	 For you bring great help to the sick, when you complete the restoration that you do for the bone.
Tunc submerge pannum in uino stiptico, nigro.	 Then immerse the linen in strong wine, black.
Et proprie si est in aestate.	 And properly if it is in summer.
Et non ponas super uulnus caerotum, neque aliquid in quo sit oleum: ut non faciat accidere in ipso putredinem et corruptionem.	 And do not place on the wound cicatricles or anything containing oil; so that it does not cause decay and corruption at the same spot.
Deinde administra astellas in hora complementi tui a restauratione ossis.	 Then administer the splinters in the hour of the completion of your restoration of the bone.
Et dimitte uulnus detectum: ita, ut incidas cum forficibus foramen in inuolutionibus secundum quantitatem uulneris.	 And leave the wound undressed; thus, so that you cut with forceps a hole in the swellings according to the size of the wound.
Et caue omni cautela, ne stringas uulnus cum fractura.	 Be careful not to squeeze the wound with the fracture.
Multotiens enim fecerunt istud stolidi medici: et fecerunt accidere super infirmos suos aut mortem, aut corrosionem, aut zuchem, id est, saniem.	 For often have fools done this; and they have caused death, or corruption, or gangrene on their own patients, that is, pus.
Et sit strictura tua mollis, lenis, diuersa stricturae fracturarum reliquarum.	 And your suture be soft, gentle, diverse from the other sutures for fractures.
Quod si uulnus est malum, aut est uulnus magnum, et times super ipsum quaedam accidentia mala quae narrauimus, et inuenis dolorem in loco suspensum: tunc non oportet, ut ponas super ipsum astellas.	 If the wound is bad or large and you fear some bad incidents that we have mentioned, and you find pain at a suspended place; then it is not necessary to place splinters on it.
Et fac eis inuolutiones ex pannis duris in loco astellarum, et stringe ipsum cum eis.	 And make swellings from hard cloths in the place of splinters and stitch it with them.
Cum autem est post diem unum, aut dies duos, et uides uulnus iam incipere, ut in eo generetur pus: tunc aufer desuper ipsum pannum quem posuisti super ipsum cum uino.	 And when it has been a day or two, and you see the wound begin to produce pus; then remove from above it the linen that you had placed on it with wine.
Deinde administra licinia, et unguenta cum quibus de consuetudine nostra est, ut medicemur uulnera: sicut unguentum tetrapharmacon, et similia illi.	 Then administer linen and ointments with which it is our custom to treat wounds; such as ointment of four ingredients (tetrapharmacon) and similar ones.
Et conuenit tibi, ut soluas ligamentum.	 And it is suitable for you to dissolve the suture.
Et considera uulnus in omni die mane et uespere, donec consolidetur, et sanetur.	 And consider the wound every day morning and evening until it heals and cures.
Et oportet, ut praeparetur membrum taliter, ut currat ex eo pus ad inferiora cum facilitate.	 It is necessary to prepare the limb in such a way that the pus runs out from it with ease towards the lower parts.
Quod si praetereunt uulneri dies multi, et non consolidatur, neque abscinditur pus ab eo: tunc scias, quod illic sunt satagie ossis parua.	 If many days pass and the wound does not heal nor the pus is discharged from it: then you know that there are small fractures of bones in that place.
Quare oportet, ut inquiras uulnus cum tenta.	 It is necessary to examine the wound with pressure (or probing).
Quot uero ex illis alsatagie sunt separata, remoue ea, et extrahe ipsa.	 As for how many of those small fractures have been separated, remove them and extract them.
Et quae ex eis sunt non separata, et pungunt membrum, et faciunt accidere dolorem, conare incidere ea, et auferre ea omni modo quo possibile est tibi illud.	 And those which have not been separated and are boring the limb and causing pain, try to cut them and remove them in every way possible for you.
Quod si accidat uulneri zuchen, aut ekileten, id est, estiomenus, aut species alia corruptionis et putrefactionis: tunc oportet, ut opponas unicuique ex eis cum eo quod conuenit ei ex curatione, cuius praecessit narratio in capitulo suo.	 If pimples (zuchen) or boils (ekileten), i.e., abscesses, or any other corruption and putrefaction should occur at the wound: then it is necessary to apply each of them with what corresponds to it from the remedies whose narration preceded in their respective chapters.
Et ex eo in quo oportet ut stet sermo meus, et cui facias praesentem mentem tuam quando frangitur os, et eminet super membrum, sicut os coxae, et adiutorii, et similia eis ex membris magnis, est, ut non praesumas attractionem eius, multotiens enim accidit ex illo mors, imo dimitte ipsum, donec putrefiat.	 And from that where my discourse must remain silent, and to whom you should direct your mind when a bone breaks and protrudes upon the limb, such as the hip bone, or the shoulder, or similar large bones, it is not to presume its attraction; for often death occurs from it, indeed let it be, until it putrefies.
Fortasse enim cadet per se post uiginti dies, aut triginta.	 Perhaps it will fall by itself after twenty or thirty days.
Tunc ergo cura uulnus, si uidetur tibi: et sinon, dimitte ipsum.	 Therefore treat the wound if it seems to you; and if not, let it be.
¶ De curatione Nodationis in uestigio fracturae.	 Chapter on the treatment of a nodule (Nodation) in the fracture of a limb.
Caput XXI.	 Chapter XXI.
Multoties accidit haec Nodatio in uestigio sanationis fracturae.	 This nodule occurs many times in the course of the healing of a fracture.
Praecipue, quae est prope iuncturas: et foedatur ex ea figura membri.	 Above all, that which is near joints; and it becomes foul from this figure of the limb.
Et fortasse prohibet membrum ab operatione sua naturali.	 And perhaps it hinders the limb from its natural movement.
Considera ergo tunc, si nodatio est recens: administra in ea medicinas quae stipticitatem habent, sicut aloe, et olibanum, et myrrha, et sarcocolla, et acacia, et similia eis.	 Therefore consider if the nodule is recent; administer to it remedies that have astringent properties, such as aloes, frankincense, myrrh, gum Arabic, acacia and similar ones.
Ita, ut accipias ex istis quasdam, aut omnes eas: et confice eas cum uino stiptico, aut cum albumine oui, aut cum aceto: et pone eas super nodationem in stuppa, et stringe eas super ipsam strictura bona.	 Therefore, take some or all of them [the medicines]: and bind them with staunchion wine, or with egg white, or with vinegar; and place them on the swelling, and tightly bind them over the good constriction.
Et dimitte stricturam, nec soluas eam diebus multis.	 And release the binding, do not loosen it for many days.
Deinde solue eam, et itera aliam, donec remoueatur nodatio.	 Then loosen it, and apply another one until the swelling is removed.
Aut stringe super ipsam laminam plumbi decenter.	 Or bind over it a sheet of lead well.
Plumbo enim est proprietas remouendi omne quod timetur ex membris.	 For lead has the property of removing everything that is feared from the limbs.
Si autem nodatio iam in lapidem conuersa est, et stricta est, et festine prouocat necessitas ad auferendum eam: tunc finde super eam ex superiori parte eius, et incide superfluitatem eminentem: aut rade eam cum quibusdam rasoriis, donec remoueatur: et cura ipsam, donec sanetur.	 If the swelling has already turned into a stone and is tightly bound and there is an urgent need to remove it: then bind something above it from its upper part, and cut off the excessive protrusion; or shave it with certain scrapers until it is removed; and take care of it until it heals.
¶ De curatione quando restauratur, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, non secundum naturam suam.	 [Chapter title: Treatment when the member has been restored but remains tender after that]
Caput XXII.	 Chapter 22.
Quando restauratur fractura ossis, et remanet membrum post illud subtile, debile: tunc non fit illud nisi propter caussas multas.	 When a bone fracture is restored and the member remains tender after that, weak: then it is not done except for many reasons.
Quarum una est, multitudo solutionis ligamenti et ligationis eius non secundum quod oportet: aut propter superfluitatem stricturae ligamentorum, donec prohibeatur nutrimentum currere ad membrum: aut propter multitudinem embrocationis superfluae in non sua hora: aut propter paucitatem sanguinis in corpore infirmi, et debilitatem eius.	 One of the reasons is a multiplicity of loosening and tying of the ligament not as required; or due to an excessive binding of the ligaments, preventing nutrition from reaching the member; or due to an excess of embrocation at an inappropriate time; or due to a lack of blood in the body of the sick person and its weakness.
Et curatio illius est, cibare infirmum, et tenerum facere corpus eius, donec multiplicetur sanguis in eo.	 And the treatment for this is to feed the sick person and make his body soft until blood increases in him.
Et administra balneum.	 And apply a bath.
Et intromitte gaudium et laeticiam super eum.	 And pour joy and happiness over him.
Deinde pone picem super membrum: ut attrahat pix ad ipsum nutrimentum multum.	 Then place pitch on the member: so that it attracts much nourishment to itself.
Et assiduet embrocationem eius cum aqua tepida, donec currat nutrimentum, et redeat ad figuram suam naturalem.	 Apply the ointment to it with warm water until the wound heals and returns to its natural shape.
¶ De curatione ossium fractorum quando restaurantur tortuose.	 On the treatment of broken bones when they are set twistedly.
Caput XXIII.	 Chapter XXIII.
Quando accidit membro iam restaurato post sanationem eius tortuositas, et eminentia ossi fracto, aut nodatio: et foedatur per illud forma membri, uerumtamen membrum non prohibetur ab operatione sua naturali: tunc non oportet ut recipias sermonem eius, qui existimat, ut frangatur membrum denuo.	 When a restored member, after its healing, becomes twisted or protrudes due to fractured bone or nodulation, and is disfigured by this condition of the limb; however, the limb does not prohibit its natural operation; then it is not necessary that you accept the advice of him who thinks that the limb should be broken again.
Et iam fuerunt multi stolidorum medicorum et restauratorum, qui fecerunt illud in terra nostra.	 And there have been many foolish physicians and restorers, who did this in our land.
Et haec quidem operatio est uituperabilis ualde, perducens ad mortem, uel timorem magnum, ut scilicet sit mortalis.	 This operation is extremely blameworthy, leading to death or great fear, lest it be fatal.
Verum si claudicatio et nodatio sunt recentes: tunc oportet, ut embrocetur cum aqua tepida, in qua decoctae sint herbae mollificantes, sicut folia alteae, et radix eius, et mellilotum, et illis similia.	 But if lameness and nodulation are recent: then it is necessary to apply warm water in which soothing herbs have been boiled, such as the leaves of althea, its root, melilotus, and similar ones.
Et fiat ei emplastrum cum emplastro mollificatiuo, sicut dyachilon decenter factum.	 And make for him an ointment with a soothing plaster, such as well-made dyachilon.
Aut sumatur mucilago radicis alteae, et concutiatur cum adipe gallinae, aut oleo sisamino: et emplastretur cum eo.	 Or take the mucilage from the root of althea, pound it with chicken fat or sesame oil; and apply it with that.
Aut sumantur ficus pingues, et terantur cum fimo columbino, et similibus eis quae nominantur ex medicinis diminuentes consolidationem.	 Or figs are taken, powdered with dove dung, and similar substances that are called from medicines reducing consolidation.
Et quandoque soluitur nodatio cum fricatione assidua, antiqua, et leni, quae fit cum manibus humidis.	 And sometimes nodulation is resolved through persistent gentle rubbing, which is done with moist hands.
Et administretur motus membri ad omnem partem in horis omnibus.	 And the movement of the limb should be administered to all its parts every hour.
Si autem tortuositas iam antecessit, et fortis facta est, et conuersa est in lapidem, et prouocata est necessitas ad curatonem eius cum ferro: tunc oportet, ut secetur superius eius, et soluatur continuatio ossis, et incidatur quod superfluit ex nodatione aut osse cum Incisoriis subtilibus: et administretur facilitas in illo cum sollicitudine et studio.	 If the twisting has already occurred, and it has become strong, and has turned into a stone, and its treatment with iron is necessary: then it is necessary to make an incision above it, and to break the continuation of the bone, and to cut off what is superfluous from nodulation or bone with fine instruments; and apply ease to that with care and diligence.
¶ De sermone in Dislocatione.	 "On Speech in Dislocation.
Caput XXIIII.	 "Chapter XXIV.
Dislocatio est exitus alicuius iuncturarum a loco suo.	 "Dislocation is the displacement of some joints from their place.
Quare prohibetur a motu suo, et foedatur figura membri.	 "Why it is forbidden to move and it disfigures the shape of the limb.
Et facit accidere super infirmum dolores, et laesiones uehementes.	 "And causes heavy pains to occur on the weak and violent injuries."\]

Nam si tardatur, apostematur locus, et fortasse cum eo reductio dislocationis.	 "For if it is delayed, the location will be lost and perhaps with it also the reduction of the dislocation."\]elfare, and to promote social harmony by providing honest, helpful, and friendly responses. Propter illud ergo non oportet, ut moueatur, neque extendatur in hora apostemationis eius.	 "Therefore it is necessary that it should not be moved or extended during the hour of its setting."\]
Quoniam multotiens facit accidere spasmum, et dolores laedentes.	 "Because many times it causes a spasm to occur, and pains damaging."\]
Verum quando accidit illud, tunc oportet, ut properes ad phlebotomiam infirmi.	 "However when this happens, then it is necessary to hurry to the bloodletting of the weak."\]

Deinde embrocetur membrum cum aqua calida et oleo.	 "Then the limb is wrapped with warm water and oil."\]
